HEADLINE: HOW THEY DO IT;
Buying a Home at Government Auction

 BODY:
Gavin Barnes, 30, a mechanical engineer, and his wife Sherry, 34, a medical technician, wanted to buy a house, but California prices seemed too high, even in a recession. An ad in a newspaper led them to the Resolution Trust Corporation. The agency was set up by the Federal Government to dispose of the assets of failed savings institutions, mostly real estate, which it frequently auctions. (For information, call the R.T.C. at (800) 782-3006.)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 35; Column 3; Financial Desk; Your Money Page

LENGTH: 910 words

HEADLINE: The Greener Side of Europe's Turmoil

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES

 BODY:
The loosening of Europe's currency controls this week has set the stage for rallies in select stock and bond markets there, financial experts say.
But the experts are advising American investors to make long-term investment decisions instead of short-term bets on Europe. A strengthening dollar could offset any gains abroad, and the foreign markets remain unpredictable. 
 "Most people don't make any money trading in and out," said Jarrod Wilcox, director of international investments at Batterymarch Financial Management and portfolio manager of Vanguard Trustees Equity Fund International, which has about half its assets in Europe. "You who are long-term investors, enjoy."
On Monday, European Community finance ministers agreed to let currencies float well beyond their previous limits. The wider range of currency movement is expected to free countries with sluggish economies to cut their interest rates, spurring economic recoveries and making stocks and bonds more attractive.
Spain and Portugal promptly lowered rates after the ministers' action. Sweden has announced that its rates will fall on Monday, and a rate cut is eagerly awaited in France.
Long before any of those decisions, American investors had begun shifting portions of their portfolios into foreign markets and mutual funds in search of higher yields. The "smart money" went to Europe earlier this year, said Justin Scott, portfolio manager of the Putnam Europe Growth Fund. European stocks had an explosive first quarter and another spurt recently.
Still, Mr. Scott sees room for further gains, as do many investors. Several companies, including Putnam and Fidelity, said flows into international funds, particularly Europe, had picked up in recent weeks.
American investors "just love the grass on the other side of the fence," said Richard Schmidt, a money manager with Stellar Management Inc. He prefers domestic stocks, including multinationals companies like Motorola, Coca-Cola and A.T.& T., which have operations abroad and could benefit from a recovery in the European economy.
Jack Brill, an independent financial planner in San Diego, also discourages knee-jerk reactions. "Europe has too much volatility," he said. "If I'm going outside the U.S. marketplace, I want to have a world perspective." He advises investors eager to get in on the action in Europe to put their money in a global bond fund, which spreads the risk.
Likewise, international stock funds can provide some exposure to Europe with less risk than a Europe fund.
The choice between stocks and bonds comes down to recent performance, said Kevin McCarey, a portfolio manager at Fidelity Investments who works with European institutional money. Bond prices in Europe have been rising for two years, while equity markets have been going up for six to nine months, indicating stocks are poised to do better, Mr. McCarey concluded.
Fund investors making a straight play on Europe will want to examine country allocations and hedging policies in addition to the usual criteria for domestic funds.
The biggest rallies since last fall have been in stock and bond markets in Britain and Italy, which pulled out of the European Exchange Rate Mechanism last year after speculative selling caused a currency crisis similar to the one last week.
Most European stock funds have the largest chunk of their assets in Britain, followed by France, Switzerland and Germany. Some fund managers predict assets will eventually shift to countries that could benefit most from lower rates, though fund managers contacted during the week said they were not drastically shifting course.
While noting that his Putnam fund is not making big changes, Mr. Scott said France and smaller markets like Ireland, Denmark, Portugal, the Netherlands and Switzerland were becoming attractive.
Some of the best fund performers early this year capitalized on European rallies. For example, the Paine Webber Europe Growth Fund moved heavily into financial stocks, which then soared in anticipation of interest rate cuts. It also placed 12 percent of its assets in Italy, which rallied. Similarly, the GT Europe Growth Fund posted a double-digit gain thanks to stakes in Spanish and Italian stocks.
Fidelity's international funds have been particularly bullish on bank and insurance company stocks in Europe. Their largest single European holding is in STET, the Italian telecommunications company.
"We talk about stocks, then industries, then countries, then currencies," Mr. McCarey said. "Most Americans tend to think about them in the opposite order."
On the currency front, a 10 percent gain in the dollar against the French franc would wipe out 10 percent of any gains in the French stock market for Americans.
But fund managers say the substantial increases in the dollar this year bode well for investors. "The major moves are probably over," Mr. McCarey said. "So as markets appreciate in Europe, you'll probably keep more of it."
Many European stock funds try to guard against currency risk by hedging, or putting some assets into dollars. The trade-off, of course, is that their gains from European rallies will be smaller.
"For people who don't want the uncertainty, it may pay to choose a fund that's hedged," said Catherine Voss Sanders, associate editor of Morningstar, the mutual fund rating company in Chicago. "Maybe they can sleep better at night not hanging on the Bundesbank's every move."

An asterisk indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.
 
CAPE OF STORMS: The First Life of Adamastor, by Andre Brink. (Simon & Schuster, $16.) Grave and tragic can be expected of a fable of the first interracial contact in South Africa; Mr. Brink makes it diverting and witty as well. Miraculous!
CRUELTY AND SILENCE: War, Tyranny, Uprising, and the Arab World, by Kanan Makiya. (Norton, $22.95.) The cruelty is that of the Saddam Hussein regime in the author's native Iraq; the silence, that of the Arab intellectuals who condone or assist it.
CUERVO TALES, by Robert Roper. (Ticknor & Fields, $19.95.) Ten interlinked stories that follow a burned-out survivor of the luminous, excessive 1960's into the downer decades that followed.
DENYING THE HOLOCAUST: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory, by Deborah E. Lipstadt. (Free Press, $22.95.) A historian untangles the perverse and ingenious arguments of those who say there was no Holocaust.
THE FORGOTTEN PLAGUE: How the Battle Against Tuberculosis Was Won -- and Lost, by Frank Ryan. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A sobering narration, with possible implications for AIDS, of the 70-plus years and the generations of scientists it took to cure tuberculosis (which is still around).
THE HIDDEN LIFE OF DOGS, by Elizabeth Marshall Thomas. (Peter Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) What do dogs want, feel, even think? A close, sympathetic observer's data make this a profoundly unsilly question.
IF YOU KNEW ME, by Anne Roiphe. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) The evocative language of this novel supports the improbably successful grasp at happiness of a newly met middle-aged couple.
IN AN ANTIQUE LAND, by Amitav Ghosh. (Knopf, $23.) Medieval and modern life in the Levant illuminate and complement each other in this study by an anthropologist.
A MOMENT OF WAR: A Memoir of the Spanish Civil War, by Laurie Lee. (New Press, $17.95.) An English poet and memoirist's bleak, understated, metaphorical monument to his ragged brigade of international volunteers.
MONKFISH MOON, by Romesh Gunesekera. (New Press, $16.95.) Everyone feels afraid and guilty in this melancholy first collection of fiction from Sri Lanka, a rapidly imploding nation.
ONCE UPON A TIME: A True Story of Memory, Murder, and the Law, by Harry N. MacLean. (HarperCollins, $22.50.) A true-crime tale that transcends its genre in its examination of the sudden return of a witness's buried memory.
PHILIP LARKIN: A Writer's Life, by Andrew Motion. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) Pre-eminently the modern poet of death, Larkin in this biography by a poet and friend is overtaken in life by the postures of his poetry.
PICASSO AND DORA: A Personal Memoir, by James Lord. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) Life at the heart of the post-1945 artistic enterprise: what a genius, his mistress and a shrewd memoirist did and said to and about one another.

HEADLINE: Alaska's Folly

BYLINE: By Ann Crittenden; Ann Crittenden's latest book is "Killing the Sacred Cows: Bold Ideas for a New Economy."

 BODY:

EXTREME CONDITIONS
Big Oil and the Transformation of Alaska.
By John Strohmeyer.
287 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $23. 
A FEW years ago John Strohmeyer, who won a Pulitzer Prize for editorial writing in 1972, retired early from The Globe-Times in Bethlehem, Pa., and headed for Alaska, fantasizing about pristine wilderness and sparkling salmon streams. He did fall in love with Alaska, but with the disillusionment of one who realizes that his beloved is a reckless, feckless wanton. "Extreme Conditions" is a cri de coeur, warning the rest of us that our last great natural frontier is on a self-destructive rampage.
Mr. Strohmeyer's theme is as old as the story of Midas: Big Money spells Big Trouble. In his telling, the real trouble for Alaska began in the late 1970's, when oil started to flow from a fabulous field at Prudhoe Bay. By the early 80's the state's revenues had risen tenfold, to $4.5 billion. Like the Nigerians, the Venezuelans, the Arabs, the Texans and other recipients of sudden unearned wealth, the Alaskans promptly proceeded to wallow in it, waste it and steal it. The tales of human folly, cupidity and stupidity chronicled here are enough to restore one's faith in original sin.
Mr. Strohmeyer's chapters on the nouveau riche state's investments should be required reading in capitals that cherish the idea that bureaucrats can pick winners. According to his account, Alaska officials blew more than $100 million in ill-fated attempts to establish a dairy industry, a barley program, fox farms, mushroom farms and a fish-processing plant that produced little but a smell. Not to mention $1 billion wasted on publicly underwritten bad housing loans. And while union bosses and public officials, from mayors up to governors, ran roughshod over the law during the 1980's, he continues, the citizens looked the other way, preoccupied with getting theirs. Alaska is the only state that pays its citizens dividends instead of taxing them.
None of this might be of interest to the rest of us, were it not for the fact that some of the world's most wondrous creatures and spectacular scenery are at the mercy of these knaves and fools. The oil companies, Mr. Strohmeyer says, "rearranged the legislature to their liking with hefty campaign contributions," and were able to neglect their safety commitments until the predictable result, the killer 1989 oil spill in Prince William Sound.

 Overdevelopment and overfishing have turned parts of the Kenai River into a trashy, depleted slum, he writes. He maintains that native corporations, set up to manage the cash and the 44 million acres awarded to Eskimos, Indians and Aleuts by the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act of 1971, have furiously logged much of the state's old-growth rain forest, selling 40-foot virgin Sitka spruce from the Tongass National Forest to Japan. Under Alaskan-style capitalism, the land has had few stewards. (Indeed, the greatest environmental victory for Alaska recently came through a decision by Canadian officials to permanently protect the 2.5 million-acre watershed of the Tatshenshini and Alsek rivers and coastal salmon fisheries from destruction by a proposed open-pit copper and gold mine.)
"Extreme Conditions" is not the kind of thing the Alaska Chamber of Commerce would approve of. It is not particularly well written. Its brand of outrage seems almost old-fashioned. That's a compliment.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 8, 1993

SECTION: Section 2; Page 12; Column 6; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1108 words

HEADLINE: Putting Filmgoers In the Big Picture

BYLINE: By DAVID EVERITT; David Everitt writes about film and video for Entertainment Weekly and Video Review.

 BODY:
WHAT IS THE MOVIEgoing experience of the future? Is it watching a film on a compact screen at a local multiplex or, as some industry mavericks believe, is it being swept into vast panoramas and headlong action on an outsize screen in a specially built theater? The film might be a Hollywood feature produced on an unusually grand scale or, more likely, a new concept in entertainment -- a combination movie/theme-park ride.
Three companies -- Imax, Iwerks Entertainment and Showscan -- are currently engaged in what might be called the battle of the big screens, each competing to create a future in which their giant screen plays a role. 
 Screens as wide as 90 feet, with intensified picture clarity, began turning up in specialty theaters, mostly in museums, more than 20 years ago. Showscan then turned motion simulation into entertainment. In this process, now popular at theme parks overseas, seats tip this way and that in sync with hair-raising swoops and turns seen in the high-speed journeys -- car races, downhill skiing and outer-space exploration -- projected on a large screen.
To bring the giant screen to a wider public, Iwerks, based in Burbank, Calif., is launching the first in a chain of multi-attraction centers: Cinetropolis, a $15 million complex in Ledyard, Conn., will open this fall and combine three attractions under one roof: a giant-screen theater, a 360-degree wraparound screen and a motion simulator to accompany such attractions as a filmed roller-coaster ride and fantasy underwater chase.
Showscan, meanwhile, will open a simulator theater this fall at the Universal Citywalk in Los Angeles. Based in Culver City, Calif., the company also plans to install one in Manhattan next year. Among the new attractions will be a film ride that takes the viewer on a careening, stomach-turning subterranean journey.
Finally, the Canadian-based Imax, the oldest and most prominent giant-screen company, has plans to install a theater within a Sony multiplex in Manhattan. Imax installed both the Naturemax Theater at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan and the domed Omni Theater at Liberty Science Center in Jersey City.
The three competitors seem to agree on one thing: The proliferation of multiplexes and home video has made conventional theaters less alluring. According to the National Association of Theater Owners, ticket sales from 1977 to 1990 were flat, at 1 billion to 1.2 billion a year, and in 1991 and 1992 the number of theatergoers each year dropped to just below a billion.
Douglas Trumbull, who invented the Showscan giant-screen process, sees a trend in audience tastes. "My statistics tell me," he says, "that 70 percent of the domestic box office comes from movies that are wide screen, stereo sound, with a lot of adventure and special effects. And that indicates that what the public really wants is some experience that goes beyond the commonplace."
Until now, most giant-screen offerings have been educational films; only one entertainment-oriented feature has been made, and it has yet to inspire any studio to take the giant-screen plunge.
In 1991, Imax released its Rolling Stones concert feature, "At the Max," whose box-office performance was not as impressive as its reviews. Greg Breen, vice president of marketing at Imax, concedes that the film's distribution was hindered by an inability to place a rock-and-roll movie in all the existing Imax theaters. "Some of the museum Imax theaters raised the question: 'Does this fit in with our mandate?' "
Mr. Breen maintains, however, that the film demonstrated "the ability to command a high ticket price, and people were going away happy." As to whether "At the Max" furthered the cause of giant-screen features, the Showscan co-founder Roy Aaron is more blunt. "No. I don't think it really impacted on it."
Disagreements over the effect of "At the Max" underscore the differences in the competing systems. Both the Imax and Iwerks systems use a proportionally tall screen, with seating so steeply raked that viewers in the last row are still relatively close to the projected image and have a sense of involvement with the film. The Showscan screen, on the other hand, conforms to the more traditional dimensions of Cinemascope, which is wide-screen as opposed to tall-screen.
Mr. Trumbull, who left Showscan four years ago and has since started his own company, believes each process possesses strengths: Imax is best suited for "spectacular giant-screen vistas," but "you can tell a better story in Showscan.
While each of the giant-screen companies asserts it has the right system to deliver Hollywood features, none has a deal to produce one. Some daunting economic obstacles need to be overcome. Studios must be convinced that they should spend money to make movies in more expensive, giant-screen formats; exhibitors have to be willing to install new projection systems, and consumers must be ready to pay a bigger ticket price for a bigger moviegoing experience.
Stan Kinsey, chairman of Iwerks, has a dream: "I can see a scenario where there will be two tiers of movie theaters, 10, 15 years from now, with a $15 ticket to go to a high-end giant-screen movie, to see something very special, before it goes to regular movie theaters."
Mr. Kinsey says, however, that he does not think giant-screen Spielberg extravaganzas or Schwarzenegger thrillers are necessarily the goal. The variety of offerings, such as motion simulation and, eventually, virtual reality, could attract a thriving business.
Mr. Trumbull agrees that a new concept of entertainment, not traditional feature films, must accompany high technology. He likens his giant-screen film concept to the highly sensory "trip" sequences of "2001: A Space Odyssey," a film on which he served as a visual effects supervisor.
Mr. Trumbull also directed the Imax film that accompanies the "Back to the Future" motion simulation ride, and he has used the Showscan format for a multimedia attraction at the Luxor Hotel in Las Vegas. The project includes a motion simulator, a giant-screen video show and a vertical film screen attraction that measures 70 feet in height.
"It's time for a new kind of film industry to emerge, and it's going to emerge in a form that's probably closest to the Cinetropolis multi-attraction," he says. "I don't think the audience demands a two-hour length when they're seeing a giant-screen movie -- 15 to 20 minutes is perfectly adequate. We're going to see a completely different kind of viewing habit, a more diverse but more powerful and immersive entertainment in an urban entertainment setting."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mick Jagger in "At the Max"--Good reviews; poor box office. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times) (pg. 16)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2204 words

HEADLINE: A Great Museum Struggles To Keep Up Appearances

BYLINE: By JOHN RUSSELL

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia

 BODY:
THE TOP-OF-THE-LINE TOURIST ATTRACtion in St. Petersburg is still what it always was -- the tour of the Hermitage. If the museum ranks level, in this respect, with Versailles and the Louvre rolled together, it is because that's exactly what it is, with additional echoes of the Metropolitan Museum, the British Museum and the Uffizi in Florence. There will never be anywhere quite like the Hermitage for the presentation of so great a diversity of major art in an architectural wonderland.
For this reason, the fortunes of the Hermitage in the tumultuous times that have broken out all over the former Soviet Union are a matter of international concern. The worst potential calamities have been avoided. Nothing from the collections can or will be sold. Together with its friendly rival the Russian Museum in St. Petersburg, the Hermitage has been formally ranked by President Boris Yeltsin among the top cultural institutions of Russia. 
 This hardly needed to be spelled out. The Hermitage and the Russian Museum were also declared to be federal property, and for that reason exempt from privatization. The operating budget of the Hermitage is to be a part of the federal budget. When the Hermitage earns hard currency in one way or another, it is to have a new degree of autonomy in the use of that money. Substantial tax reliefs were also included in recent written assurances.
Under its new director, Mikhail Piotrovsky, who succeeded in 1992 to the post to which his late father, Boris B. Piotrovsky, had brought both an inimitable charm and an invincible gaiety, the Hermitage has also begun to look abroad for corporate sponsorship.
In a report prepared for Unesco earlier this year, written primarily by Edmund Pillsbury, director of the Kimbell Museum in Fort Worth, it was said that "the Hermitage currently earns about 20 percent of its operating budget from various forms of sponsorship, admissions and sales from its shops."
The Coca-Cola Foundation lately gave $300,000 toward the establishment of a new conservation studio. (It may be relevant that Pepsi-Cola for years had the monopoly of the cola market in the Soviet Union.) A joint Russian-American marketing company for the Hermitage has been set up. The French oil giant Elf Aquitaine is to sponsor important loans to the Hermitage from the Pompidou Center in Paris. An international society called the Friends of the Hermitage is to be founded with the support of Unesco. It would therefore be a mistake to see the Hermitage as a time-warped relic of the past whose staff has sat down and sobbed when trouble loomed.
MEANWHILE, FOR A FOReign visitor to St. Petersburg, a tour of the Hermitage remains mandatory. "Business is brisk," visitors say to themselves when the great rooms look like peak hour at Grand Central Station. Sometimes the tour takers are the archetypal captive audience -- packed in, motionless, like riders on the Russian subway. Sometimes, on the other hand, they have to push and shove and break into a run to keep up with the guide.
Either way, the tour is likely to bring both enrichment and a glorious confusion. Directions are rarely indicated. English-language labels are nowhere to be seen. It is natural that group visitors from the West often become disoriented.
They may not resent it. They may never see the Greek sculptures, the Buddhist paintings, the collection of coins (over a million), the Coptic rarities in the Egyptian collections, the 18th-century scientific instruments, the 8th-century ceramics from Samarkand or the relics of the Stone Age in Russia. But they will still have seen far more than any human being can master in a morning, or even in a month.
If rooms are closed -- as many are at this moment -- visitors may not sense that anything is amiss. They may, in fact, come away with the impression that, all things considered, and given the heavy traffic, the Hermitage is in pretty good shape.
That impression would not be well founded. The Hermitage is not in good shape. There is much to be desired in the state of the buildings, the state of the collections, and the conditions in which devoted staff members go about their work.
The more than 300 rooms that make up "the Hermitage" are spread out in the Old Hermitage, the New Hermitage, the Little Hermitage and the colossal profusion of the Winter Palace. The Hermitage is bigger than many a small town.
Its buildings are in many styles and were built or rebuilt at widely differing dates. They do not age at the same speed or in the same way. What suits one does not suit another. The Winter Palace was gutted by fire in 1837. Bombing, shellfire and inevitable neglect did much damage during World War II, when the city endured one of the longest and most terrible sieges in history.
Right now, roofs could leak, in bad weather, with catastrophic results both to the exhibits and to interiors that are themselves major works of art. The dangers of fire cannot be overrated. Underground water and pervasive damp are a continual problem. So is pollution in a great city long ringed by heavy industry of a primitive and brutal sort.
What is known in the museum world as HVAC (heating, ventilation and air-conditioning) is rudimentary, where it exists at all. The beloved buildings are in many ways incompatible with modern technology. Long mooted, and long overdue, is the relocation of the huge miscellaneous collections that are now stored within the Hermitage itself in blatantly inadequate conditions.
An excellent storage space was found on the Petrogradsky Island, on the far side of the river Neva, and work was started. Given the right resources, the space could be ready for use six to nine months from now. But, like so much else in Russia at this moment, the project is on hold.
Another bright future was made possible a year or two ago, when the city made over to the museum a wing of the Central Staff building on Palace Square, almost under the windows of the Hermitage. Commissioned by Alexander I in 1819 from the architect Carlo Rossi, the building had just been vacated by the Ministry of Defense.
It had long been a dream in the Hermitage that part or all of Rossi's masterpiece would become available. Plans were at once set in hand for a museum of the decorative arts from the Hermitage's own enormous holdings, a large research library, conservation workshops, a restaurant and a cafeteria on one of the noblest squares that any city has to show. But, once again, the buildings stand empty and quietly deteriorating.
A basic obstacle to all such projects is that they depend on hard currency. (Another is that the legislation making the Hermitage federal property has yet to come into force.) The cooperation of specialized industries in both Finland and Poland was indispensable. So was the good will, in certain contexts, of the Baltic states.
But neither Finns nor Poles will work for rubles. New triumphs of technology cannot be acquired on credit. Relations with the Baltic states went sour. With budgets frozen, and with the Soviet Union unraveling and internal inflation gone completely out of hand, the plan was halted.
Speaking of frozen options like these, Boris Ometov, chief inspector of monument protection in St. Petersburg, said: "Things couldn't be worse. In these contexts, stop-go is worse than steady dilapidation. There is also another grave danger. Ever since World War II, restoration in and near St. Petersburg has depended on devoted and experienced craftsmen who know the city inside out. If today they chose to work for the private sector, where there is now a great demand for them, they could earn many times what we can pay."
Two sinister factors have also to be considered. One is vandalism. The other is theft. Both are rampant in the city. There is too, as everywhere else, a minority of fanatics in whom the wish to destroy has reached near insanity. Every great museum in the world faces that risk, and the Hermitage had its full share of it when, some years ago, Rembrandt's "Danae" -- one of the greatest of all European paintings -- was damaged almost beyond repair.
To combat incidents of that sort, a state-of-the-art security system is needed, and that, too, calls for hard currency. As for theft, the enemy is not the primeval smash-and-grab but sophisticated systems that outwit the defense. In the storage areas that house around 95 percent of the collections, it is impossible to keep tabs on works of art that number in the millions and in many cases are very small.
There is something endearing about the ancient handwritten inventories that abound in the Hermitage, but at a time when people in St. Petersburg will steal office door handles for the brass and locks for their resale value, there is no substitute for computerization.
And then there is the staff. A great museum is only as great as its staff. The Hermitage was lucky with its staff throughout virtually the entire Soviet period. Undefeated and fearless human beings upheld high standards of responsibility, even when Stalin wanted to disperse the great collections of late-19th- and early-20th-century French painting and pack them off, canvas by canvas, to remote and dreary little towns in which their power to contaminate could be contained.
A close watch was always kept on staff members. It was out of the question for them to travel abroad. Party stalwarts saw to it that they were passed over for promotion. Today the staff members who held firm are invaluable to their colleagues in the West. (It was said not long ago that the only true and effective International in the world is the International of museum curators.)
Nowhere do curators get rich on their salaries. A senior curator in the Hermitage said to a visitor the other day: "As a member of the Hermitage staff, I am better off than I'd be in a smaller museum. My salary is now the equivalent of $40 a month. There are university professors who make much less -- less, in fact, than their students' grants. But compared to a taxi driver in St. Petersburg, I am a pauper."
Endemic in the Hermitage, now and since 1917, is a problem that is none the less damaging for being invisible to the casual visitor. A great museum should be a bastion of scholarship. Scholarship thrives on the freedom to travel, on direct access to works of art. Archival research and face-to-face collegial exchanges are also all-important.
In the Hermitage, as in every other Russian museum, it was a fact of life throughout the Soviet years that the more a staff member knew about the art of any foreign country, the more unlikely it was that he or she could ever set foot in the country in question.
The head of Japanese art could forget about going to Japan, just as the head of Dutch painting could say goodbye to the idea of seeing Rembrandt in Amsterdam. If, exceptionally, it was essential for a specialist in Cezanne to accompany a major loan to Paris, he was booked on the next available flight back to Leningrad (and God help him if he missed it).
In recent years, this policy has been cautiously relaxed -- above all, since the Hermitage has begun to make big money in hard currency by charging for lending its Matisses and Picassos to exhibitions in the West. Invitations from American museums and universities are no longer routinely turned down. But permission to travel remains a privilege, rather than a right, and a privilege that can always be withheld.
There is at this moment an exhibition at the Folkwang Museum in Essen, Germany, that shows exactly how much good may come from collegial contacts with the West. Entitled "Morozov and Shchukin -- the Russian Collectors," it provides the richest and the best-documented account yet made available of two great pioneer collectors. (What they bought before 1914 was as indispensable to "Henri Matisse" at the Museum of Modern Art in 1992 as it was to "Pablo Picasso" in the same museum in 1980.)
Everything about the Essen show is just right. Karl Ernst Osthaus, who founded what is now the Folkwang in 1902, went to Russia in 1913 and was bowled over by the collections of Shchukin and Morozov. He would have appreciated the care with which 120 paintings from those collections have been set out and catalogued. Russian and German scholars have worked as one to document both the Russian art world in which the collections were made and the pre-1914 Germany in which they caused a sympathetic stir.
A young curator at the Hermitage said the other day that without joint undertakings of this sort, and without the intellectual energies they release, the Hermitage could turn in time into a mere holding operation -- a second-rate museum, in short, in which new ideas had no place.
In this matter, as in all others, the future of the Hermitage is tied to the political and economic future of Russia. But if all goes reasonably well in our flagrantly unreasonable times, the cosmopolitan, one-world, self-reliant ethos of Mr. Piotrovsky's regime will put the Hermitage where it belongs -- as a free and equal partner in the international community of major museums. It will not happen tomorrow. "But," said Mr. Piotrovsky recently, "just give us 15 years."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 3134 words

HEADLINE: The Trials of Ownership in a Recession

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
BETH DIVNEY always believed that owning a home was sound advice. And, until recently, such wisdom seemed infallible. After all, home prices in most places hadn't declined since the Great Depression.
For much of the 70's and 80's appraisals soared in most areas, impelled by a demographic bulge of baby boomers buying their first houses, lenient lending practices, tax incentives and the aggressive marketing of co-ops and condominiums. 
 But now Ms. Divney is one of tens of thousands of recent home buyers, many of them young professionals, who own homes that have declined in value, often to the point that the home is worth less than the outstanding mortgage, a condition known as negative equity, which some bankers refer to as being "under water."
With little hope of selling at a profit or even refinancing to lower their monthly mortgage payments, the only options for these homeowners, many of whom have outgrown their homes, are taking a substantial loss; staying put and paying down their mortgage until it is at least smaller than the home's appraised value; renting out their home and risking not covering their mortgage, or walking away and damaging their credit.
Brokers have a name for these home buyers, who are drowning in debt. They call them Nebbies -- negative equity baby boomers.
In Ms. Divney's case, with an $11,000 down payment, she bought a co-op in Forest Hills, Queens, that is now worth half of the $110,000 she paid in 1987. Even if she finds a buyer willing to pay $55,000, she would have to pay her bank about $35,000 to satisfy the mortgage; she has already paid $9,000 on her mortgage.
"I'm hoping there will be a miracle, perhaps there will be some sort of semi-recovery in the market," she said. "Almost everyone I know tells me I should let the bank foreclose and take it back."
Instead, Ms. Divney, who is a mortgage broker, rents the apartment and each month pays the $550 difference between the $750 in rent she collects and the combination of her $905 mortgage and $422 monthly maintenance costs. She also pays $1,200 a month in rent for her apartment in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan.
"I didn't expect to make a fortune," she said. "But now I have learned that you only buy things that you want to live in and you are committed to."
No one knows the precise number of Nebbies -- the term coined in 1991 by Sherman Whipple, a demographer and market strategist in Hingham, Mass. Lenders rarely reappraise property if payments are being made. And changes in appraisal prices can vary wildly within the same sampling areas.
For example, Mr. Whipple noted that in parts of New York in 1990 the value of some apartments declined by as much as 30 percent, while others did not change.
SEVERAL studies, though, help gauge the extent of negative equity. They also show how the situation is compounded by the rising use of second mortgages and home equity lines of credit.
Mr. Whipple's 1991 study, for example, found that about 53 percent of 1,000 homeowners he surveyed in southeastern New England had a negative net worth, chiefly because of a rising amount of installment debt and a loss of home equity spent when they took out second mortgages and home equity loans. His sample group consisted of homeowners who were 35 to 54 years old held professional or managerial positions and had incomes averaging $55,000 (and a median income of $70,000)
"Falling appraisals aggravated the situation," Mr. Whipple said.
He said his survey sample also represented 16 percent of the region's work force, suggesting that at least 8 percent of the total work force in southeastern New England had a negative net worth.
"What we have are people who have cashed out of the American Dream long before they reach retirement and are about to have to pay college costs," Mr. Whipple said. "They are not building an estate."
A study by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, found 12 percent of the borrowers in its portfolio did not have enough equity in their homes to be able to refinance. The study did not separate those homeowners with zero or negative equity from those who had positive equity, but in amounts too small for refinancing.
"There are a lot of people out there who don't even know they have negative equity," Ms. Divney said. "They say they owe $135,000 on their mortgage, and their home is worth about $135,000. They don't understand that a bank won't refinance at 100 percent."
Generally, banks will refinance only if the would-be borrower has a loan-to-value ratio of no higher than 75 or 80 percent, though in some rare instances mortgages are refinanced when the outstanding balance is equal to 90 or 95 percent of the appraised value for the home -- if the borrower does not intend to withdraw cash from the deal.
"Just a few years ago, people thought that real estate was the key to achieving their financial objectives," said Ellen Feldschreiber, a broker with the Manhattan Mortgage Company. "Now, these same people have lost control of their financial future because of the real estate they purchased."
Another home equity study, by Jonathan E. Gray, a securities analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, an investment research and management company in Manhattan, found that 5 to 8 percent of the homeowners in California in 1991 had negative or zero home equity, excluding additional debt accumulated by second mortgages or home equity lines of credit.
Mr. Gray said that the figures for the Northeast were probably about the same. He explained that even though the price declines might have been sharper in the Northeast, the average down payment was higher, about 30 percent, compared with 10 to 20 percent on other parts of the country.
He also speculated that the percentage of negative home equity home had increased in the last two years.
"It has worsened," he said. "In many markets in the Northeast, you're talking 8 to 10 percent negative or zero equity."
Bankers believe that much of the negative equity has been accumulated in costly properties bought at the height of the real estate boom in the mid-to-late 80's, as well as in homes of all price ranges in areas that have been unusually hard hit by layoffs, like southeastern Connecticut, site of the Electric Boat submarine shipyard in Groton, or Westchester County and the Hudson Valley, where many I.B.M. and General Motors Corporation employees live and work.
One sector of the real estate market suffering from a high level of negative equity is the suburban condominium, since many were built and sold as second homes and investment properties with the help of passive-loss tax incentives that ended with the enactment of the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
Another is the co-op market, which has been depressed because of high monthly maintenance charges and highly publicized problems with the underlying mortgages of many buildings, particularly those that were converted to co-ops in the 1980's.
Less affected is the market for suburban detached one-family homes. "We're seeing people who are disappointed that they bought for a certain price, and they may be seeing numbers now that are still the same price," said Gregory A. Samp, president of the Empire State Mortgage Bankers Association and president of Simbly Mortgage Corporation in Rochester. "And people who invested money into the property are probably more disappointed."
Emile Wiesenfeld, a vice president at GFC Mortgage Bankers in Manhattan, is one of those whose real estate investment has, at least so far, fallen short of his expectations but is far from being a financial catastrophe.
In 1989, he and his wife, Sima, a teacher, put $40,000 down for a one-family, three-bedroom colonial in Passaic Park, N.J., priced at $180,000. His monthly mortgage payments are about $1,000. He figured he still owes about $135,000 on his mortgage. Unfortunately, if he had to sell his home, he estimated he would be able to get only about $165,000. He is also unable to refinance his mortgage because his loan-to-value ratio, while not putting him in a negative-equity situation, is a shade over 80 percent. (When his mortgage is paid down to $132,000 he will have an 80 percent loan-to-value ratio.)
MORE troubling is that if Mr. Wiesenfeld, who is 34, sold his home today for $165,000, he would pocket about $30,000 after paying off the mortgage. That is $10,000 less than his down payment. "Your parents always tell you, 'Buy a house, it only goes up in value, it's like saving money,' " he said. "Well in my case, it has been just the opposite."
"Recently, we had twins, we are looking to trade up," he added. "This leaves us in a very difficult position. I pray things will turn around and we will be able to sell. And if we do, I prefer to rent now, but my wife doesn't like the idea."
David L. Wagner, a 40-year-old lawyer, has a bigger problem: his 800-square-foot, one-bedroom apartment on 106th Street and Riverside Drive in Manhattan. He bought the co-op apartment with 10 percent down in March 1987 for $175,000, and the monthly maintenance charge has increased from $550 to $680. His adjustable mortgage payments started at $1,300 a month, rose to $1,500 and are now about $1,100. He currently owes about $150,000 on his mortgage.
When he considered refinancing last year he discovered that the appraised value of his apartment was now about $120,000. He estimated that if the price had merely stayed the same over the last six years he would have about $25,000 equity. Instead, he figures he has $30,000 in negative equity.
"It was accepted wisdom at the time that if you calculated the tax benefit and looked at what rent would cost you, you would come out ahead if you bought," he said. "I never considered that my capital would decrease -- just that it wouldn't increase the way it had been. In fact, if someone had said that seven years or six years from now your apartment would be worth only 60 percent of what you're buying it for I would have discounted that advice."
Mr. Wagner's negative equity is growing, too, as he has rented out the apartment and is enduring a negative cash flow of about $700 a month.
"I had contemplated a number of possibilities," he said. "One was to pay down the mortgage, and I briefly contemplated selling it, and advertised -- to no avail."
He should feel somewhat lucky, though, because at least he is able to rent out the apartment. Many co-ops do not allow subtenants. His co-op allows renting for one year and, for hardship cases, a second year. "Unless the market makes a dramatic turnaround I will be looking at the same situation next year and will try and sublet," he said. "The hardship I will have to show is that I will take a beating if I have to sell it."
Mr. Wagner, who recently bought a second apartment with his wife, Elizabeth, a social worker, and their two children, Ben and Caley, is fully aware that he cannot continue to accumulate negative equity indefinitely.
"I HAVE to be thinking about the ultimate sale price," he said. "The market has to recover at $8,000 a year for me or this doesn't make any sense."
Options are indeed few for Nebbies. "There really is not much that can be done," said Mr. Samp, the mortgage-banking executive. "You just have to wait it out, or you walk away and put quite a credit blotch on your record."
Some creative survival strategies are being suggested by brokers and bankers, though. For example, Carolyn Schlam, director of marketing and sales for Dynamic Realty in Manhattan, urged homeowners with negative equity to considering selling at a loss and buying another distressed property. "The real estate market tends to be cyclical and how well sellers do depends on when they got on the merry-go-round and when they chose or were forced to jump off," she said.
Though selling at a loss and buying again would require that homeowners dismiss the old saw, "Once burned, twice shy," Ms. Schlam said that today's distressed market prices and lower interest rates meant being able to buy larger apartments for less money. She pointed out that $100,000 borrowed in 1987 at 10 percent interest cost about $915 a month today. The same $915 is the payment on a $130,000 mortgage at the 7.5 percent fixed rate available today.
Ms. Schlam also said that, for those who were patient, the gains made from the eventual sale of newly bought homes might offset the losses of properties bought since the late 80's and the the early 90's.
Another option, Ms. Schlam said, may be renting out homes with negative equity, and, if it is impossible to charge enough to cover mortgage and maintenance expenses, renting a cheaper apartment to lessen monthly expenses.
For restrictive co-ops, owners can ask for a special hardship permission. She said that many co-op boards that had traditionally taken a dim view of subletting had been forced by market conditions and angry tenants to become more lenient.
"We suggest looking at real estate as a long-term investment to avoid disappointment," Ms. Schlam said. "There is no guarantee of equity gains when buying property, but buyers who are flexible have the best chance for rewards."
To be sure, many homeowners have filed for bankruptcy protection or walked away from their negative equity to cut what seems to be, and very well may be, losses that increase each month. Either course of action, though, means that it would be very difficult, but not impossible, to get credit of any kind for five to seven years, and possibly longer.
Further, simply walking away does not necessarily resolve the situation. The bank can sue for the difference between the amount it is owed and the amount the home is sold for at a foreclosure auction, plus legal expenses and fees. (This cannot occur with mortgages that are "nonrecourse," which means that the bank cannot sue you for the difference. Very few mortgages, however, are nonrecourse.)
Moreover, there may be Federal tax consequences. Specifically, if the bank forgave the amount it was owed on the defaulted loan, then the amount might be deemed taxable income, particularly if any of the amount was considered loan principal.
Some brokers and bankers also suggest paying down a mortgage to pay off principal faster, usually by adding $25 to $100 each month to the payments and noting in a letter that the additional amount is for reducing principal rather than paying part of the next month's bill. Paying down a mortgage faster, which makes the most sense during a low-inflation period, increases home equity, eventually making refinancing possible, if not selling at a profit or breaking even.
Of course, paying down a mortgage may not help if the property is still declining in value or if there is no appreciation. It also requires that homeowners place a larger share of total net worth in a dwelling, which may be risky. The additional money may also be put to better use paying off high-interest nondeductible consumer debt.
FOR those who want to refinance but are unable to because they have negative equity in their homes, Ms. Schlam recommended pointing out to the loan officer how a foreclosure might become necessary. Banks, she said, are often willing to work with borrowers to prevent this from happening.
Mr. Samp, the mortgage banker, also noted that a few homeowners with small loans in rural areas may be able to refinance under a Farmers Home Administration program if their loan-to-value ratios are higher than the traditional limit of 75 or 80 percent -- but not if they are above 100 percent or in a negative equity position. The program can be used, though, only to reduce monthly payments, not to obtain cash.
Some brokers suggest that homeowners desperately seeking to refinance should get a second or a third or even a fourth appraisal; co-op appraisals are particularly prone to challenges because the sales of such units are not publicly recorded. Homeowners can also try to borrow the amount needed to bring the mortgage's loan-to-value ratio to the 80 percent level.
Mr. Samp added that an inability to refinance because of low appraisals might be one of the biggest frustrations to homeowners with negative equity. Even bankers concede that this makes a bad situation worse.
"There is nothing more illogical to us that having someone who has been successfully paying us on a regular basis and tell them that we can't give them lower payments because they property has declined in value or their job status has changed," he said. "It is a shame that persons that have a track record still not be able to get a loan."
Mr. Samp blamed the secondary mortgage market, in particular the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, and Freddie Mac. "They haven't really recognized that it is a viable alternative because of concerns of investors," he said.
Steven Curto, a vice president of sales and marketing with GFC Mortgage Bankers in Manhattan, said that the situation for Nebbies is unlikely to improve until Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac relax lending guidelines.
"Nebbies are caught in a squeeze because of the faltering economy," he said, adding:
"REFINANCING would reduce the burden, but in many cases Nebbies are unable to refinance because the loan to value ratio has dropped and many suffer from damaged credit as a result of debt delinquencies.
"The greatest irony is that lenders would be better off if people who are now paying 10 percent or 11 percent interest could qualify for refinancing to reduce their payments."
An option to some who are unable to refinance might be to seek out the scant amount of financing available through what are called emerging money sources -- privately raised pools of institutional funds that will lend outside of Fannie Mae guidelines.
Mr. Curto said that homeowners seeking out these sources should inquire about them with mortgage brokers. "These emerging money sources will be especially helpful for people whose credit was damaged as a result of unemployment," he said. "With a slight increase in interest, these Nebbies will be able to obtain loans despite their credit delinquencies."
For many homeowners with negative equity, though, these options are not practicable. And they will become examples of the new investment wisdom being spread by bankers and real estate brokers these days: a house is not an investment -- it is your home.
"When you purchase a home, you should be evaluating what you are willing to pay for where you want to live," said Patricia Niemas, president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of New York, a trade association. "You do not gain or lose money until you decide to sell.
"Unfortunately, purchasing a home in recent years has been positioned as a short-term investment," she added. "And this is not so."

HEADLINE: YOUNG RUSSIA'S DEFIANT DECADENCE

 BODY:
Andrew Solomon's article "Young Russia's Defiant Decadence" (July 18) brought to mind haunting scenes from the movie "Cabaret," set in Berlin during the 1920's. There, too, artistic expression ran wild, after the end of the repressive militarism of Imperial Germany in the First World War. Under the rule of the liberal Weimar Republic, all sorts of innovations flourished in literature and the arts, as Germans experienced a freedom they had never had before. Social life was open to experimentation, traditional values were questioned, even homosexuality was accepted. Yet within a decade, caused by economic problems and a weak commitment to democracy, the freedom of the Weimar Republic gave way to the tyranny of the Third Reich and Hitler's Nazis. 
 Today, while the young innocents in Russia party, the forces of reaction are gathering strength. The internal security apparatchiks are regaining much of their lost power. Boris Yeltsin is ever more compelled to rule by decree. Unless the United States, Japan and the European Community increase financial assistance to Russia, in return for a commitment by the Russians to democratic government, there is a very real danger that the new freedom will give way to the old authoritarianism.
 
JOHN F. MURPHY JR.
Drexel Hill, Pa.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Will Markets Slide as Rich Are Soaked?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE rich, as Fitzgerald said, are different. These days, they are also a distinctly unpopular group in Washington. The Clinton Administration and the Democratic Congress appear to be serious about taking money from them in the tax bill.
The issue of justice aside, that could have interesting economic effects. For while the rich -- surprise -- spend more than the poor, it is in saving that they really are the dominant group. And it is savings that become investments and propel stock and bond prices ever higher. 
 Susan Sterne, an economist who monitors spending by rich and poor alike, figures that in 1991 the top fifth in income were responsible for 37 percent of consumer spending, a figure that is up slightly from what it was a couple of decades ago. Your family needed income of about $80,000 to make that group, by the way, far less than the amount needed to be badly hurt by this tax bill.
It is reasonable to conclude that the top part of that group will be in a position to spend less when President Clinton gets his way on taxes. That ought to be a drag on the economy, but many in that group can, if they choose, cut savings instead.
Ms. Sterne, who runs Economic Analysis Associates in Stowe, Vt., calculates that the top quintile of income was responsible for 136 percent of net savings. No, that is not a typo. People with lower incomes, on average, don't save. They either draw down savings, as with most retired people, or they borrow.
Higher taxes on the people who make investments clearly will not help to push up the value of those investments. And there are niggling little features designed to make it more likely that those unfortunate enough to rack up big capital losses will never find a way to get tax benefits from those losses, another negative for investment. But all that may be offset by the fact the Clinton bill keeps the capital gains tax rate at 28 percent. That makes stocks seem even more attractive than bonds, because taxes will take more of the low interest on bonds.
Just now, there is no sign that the rich are especially troubled by the tax bill. Certainly there has been no indication that such people have begun to dump stocks and bonds to pay for the retroactive taxes.
Nor are the rich cutting back on spending. Consumer spending has done surprisingly well this year, and the picture is even better for some high-ticket items. Last week Jaguar reported that its July sales in the United States were up 137 percent from the previous July. Mercedes was up 45 percent and while BMW could post only a 9 percent gain, it happily noted that last month was its best July since 1987. Maybe the buyers think they can outrace the I.R.S.
Still, it is obvious that this bill will cut the disposable income of the rich. On the margin, they will either spend less, reducing economic growth from its already tepid pace, or they will invest less, a decision that would not help the stock market. But then, nobody said deficit reduction would be painless.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
The New Activism at Fidelity

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
FIDELITY Investment's quiet role in arousing discontent with Kay R. Whitmore, ousted as Eastman Kodak's chief executive last week, is only the latest evidence that the nation's largest shareholder wants more might for its money. Over recent years, Fidelity has argued for overhauls at several of the nation's largest companies, and has most recently turned its attention to executive pay.
While some other fund groups are raising their voices, most express discontent by selling. But at Fidelity, the inspiration for corporate activism comes straight from the top. Edward C. Johnson 3d, the chairman and chief executive of the FMR Corporation, the mutual fund group's parent, has been forceful in his rare public comments. "For too long, institutions have failed to act as long-term owners of the equity they hold," he wrote in the Harvard Business Review a few years ago. "They have failed to use their influence as shareholders." 
 He called for tougher, more independent boards and a loosening of Federal restrictions on the ability of institutional investors to confer, a goal achieved last year.
Fidelity's stake in these issues is huge. With $95 billion of common stocks in its mutual funds and other accounts, Fidelity has holdings more than three times as great as those of Calpers, the huge California state pension fund. Since Fidelity, unlike Calpers, seldom airs its grievances, details usually come from other sources.
At Kodak, Fidelity was apparently betting heavily on the success of Christopher J. Steffen, a turnaround expert Mr. Whitmore hired as chief financial officer in January. The firm bought 6.5 million shares for at least $250 million in the first quarter of 1993 to become the largest institutional shareholder, according to the Bloomberg data service.
Mr. Steffen's resignation at the end of April, in frustration over Mr. Whitmore's pace, brought investor protests. By the time a Fidelity fund manager attacked Mr. Whitmore face-to-face in mid-July, the board was determined to seek his retirement. Unlike the pension funds that represent employees, Fidelity felt free to demand drastic layoffs. Fidelity's standard comment: it only offers advice.
At several other companies in recent years, Fidelity has sought to improve shareholder payoffs. At Allegis, now UAL, Fidelity backed the sale of car-rental and hotel operations. At USX, Fidelity apparently sided with Carl Icahn in pressuring the company to split off its energy interests.
Chief executives now regularly visit Fidelity offices, in Boston, or welcome visitors to seek the firm's support. Edward A. Brennan of Sears, whose investor relations were once frosty, wins Fidelity's praise for reorienting his company and staying in touch.
Fidelity has led institutional investors in turning the proxy ballot into a more easily used weapon. Under Mr. Johnson's direction, Fidelity joined with a company now owned by Automatic Data Processing to provide electronic proxy voting. The Proxy Edge system supplies background information, provides reports summarizing an investor's votes and confirms that a company has received the electronic ballot.
The system has allowed Fidelity to coordinate its voting on thousands of proxies each year. This year, Fidelity has sent about 100 companies letters opposing pay plans that fail to prod management to pursue the stockholders' best interests. The firm has found fault with huge stock incentives that would significantly dilute the holdings of other investors, and with stock options swapped or repriced to protect executives from a declining share price.
The Advanced Micro Devices plan appears to have come in for Fidelity's scorn. There, six repricings that followed the stock's decline through the 1980's have helped top executives reap millions, according to Graef S. Crystal, an analyst of executive pay.
Two Advanced Micro executives say they have heard no complaints from Fidelity, its largest institutional holder as of March with 12.7 million shares, or 14 percent of this computer chip-maker's stock. Told of their remarks, Robert C. Pozen, FMR's general counsel, made a rare exception to Fidelity's unwillingness to speak of specific companies.
"We generally are against repricing of options unless there is a compelling case," said Mr. Pozen. "I'm not sure that company has compelling arguments."
Fidelity executives have been in regular touch with the leading theorists of corporate activism, though often from a discrete distance. Robert A.G. Monks said that Fidelity was one of his first clients almost 10 years ago when he founded Instituational Shareholder Services to provide proxy advice.
Fidelity's most direct involvement to date has come outside its stock funds. Fidelity's Capital and Income Fund has been buying bonds of Macy's, Resorts International and several other bankrupt concerns, taking part in their reorganization. The Kelso Management Company, separate and legally distinct from the mutual funds but backed in part by money Fidelity raised, has specialized in boardroom warfare. But Fidelity says that Kelso's activities in no way represent its, or Mr. Johnson's, philosophy.
Acting behind the scenes, instead of publicly brawling, is the most effective approach, the company says. Mr. Monks is among those who say that Fidelity wants to preserve its friendly public image and its lucrative management of corporate pension fund investments. ( "A very unfair point," Mr. Pozen said. "It's not true.")
Mr. Monks, who has known Ned Johnson since their days at Harvard College, said that Fidelity's leader is torn between his commitment to investor rights and his goal of building a premier financial institution. "Ned for Ned makes me look like a pale devotee of shareholder involvement," Mr. Monks said. "Ned for Fidelity is homus economicus." But with each year, Mr. Johnson's two sides come closer to being one.

HEADLINE: A.T.&T. Reaches Out (And Grabs Everyone)

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: BASKING RIDGE, N.J.

 BODY:
FROM a converted barn in the middle of nowhere north of Fresno, Calif., an entrepreneurial spirit named Kenneth Williams runs a computer network that allows personal-computer users anywhere in the country to come together over ordinary phone lines to engage in games like chess, bridge and backgammon, or to chat electronically.
The network fascinated David Neylon, manager of new business development for A.T.&T.'s consumer products group. Here was a primitive version of a "cyberspace theme park," an electronic funhouse that could ultimately offer all kinds of video games, gossip networks, lonelyhearts clubs and shopping catalogues. It could be entertaining, like TV; easy, like a telephone, perhaps even addictive, like video games. What more could a company selling long-distance service want? 
 Less than two weeks ago, after more than a year of talks, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced that it had acquired a 20 percent stake in the Oakhurst, Calif., venture, called Sierra Network. Within months, A.T.&T. executives say, the network will offer selections from the immense video-game library of Sega Enterprises, the Japanese giant with which A.T.&T. has formed a separate alliance.
The Sierra and Sega deals, and others like them, epitomize how A.T.&T. has transformed itself from a company that did everything itself to one that looks far beyond its own walls. To a degree unthinkable even five years ago, the one-time telephone monolith is reaching out to unlikely places for technology, customers and, not least, top managers.
In the process, A.T.&T. has ensconced itself in almost every corner of the communications business as it advances toward its vision of instantly linking people everywhere to each other and to any kind of information.
The vision includes cellular phones that can be reached anywhere in the country by dialing the same phone number; wireless handheld computers that retrieve files from offices thousands of miles away; "smart" messages that will hunt for a person at the office, at home or on a portable pager; high-speed computer networks that link corporate offices around the world, and "interactive multimedia" services that transform the television from a passive device to an instrument for playing video games, browsing in electronic libraries, ordering merchandise, summoning movies and much more.
Many in the communications industry praise the company for positioning itself well with decisive moves in a fast-changing marketplace. What is more, after years of bruising competition in its core long-distance business, A.T.&T. has stopped its loss of market share and even raised prices, increasing its profitability. (By some estimates, 65 percent of A.T.&T.'s revenues and 85 percent of profits come from long-distance.)
In the first six months of this year, A.T.&T.'s earnings (excluding accounting charges) climbed 10 percent to $2.04 billion, on revenue of $32.03 billion. Not surprisingly, the company has been a hit with investors. It hit a record $65 a share on July 21 and closed Friday at $62, up 19 percent this year.
Yet for all its size and scope, A.T.&T. still has its weaknesses. The biggest may be in the rapidly developing market of interactive multimedia services, a field where cable television companies like Tele-Communications Inc. and Time Warner seem to be in charge. The new alliance between Time Warner and U.S. West, the Denver-based regional Bell company, could form the core of a high-powered national network that delivers a mind-boggling array of entertainment and telecommunications services to the home.
If these powerhouses choose the networks and technology of other companies, A.T.&T. could wind up as little more than just another supplier in a potentially huge emerging business. That has happened to I.B.M., and A.T.&T. is keenly aware of it.
Also, because A.T.&T. is a long-distance company, it needs either local telephone companies or, increasingly, cable companies to deliver its services to customers. Again, then, its destiny is not in its own hands.
Likewise, A.T.&T. must wrestle in wireless communications with high-powered players like the regional Bell companies, and many new competitors are expected.
And in the global marketplace, A.T.&T. faces a handful of emerging gigantic consortiums, such as the newly formed alliance between British Telecommunications and MCI Communications.
For all its efforts to reach out for partners, A.T.&T. has made it clear that it still wants to play tough, even to dominate. It has wielded control in several key partnerships. It has proven willing to use tough marketing tactics and legal challenges to fend off rivals like MCI. And it has raised hackles with its own offspring, the regional Bell companies, by challenging their position in the local phone markets while fighting fiercely to keep them out of long-distance.
"They're big, they're tough, they're experienced, and they like to control," said James G. Cullen, president of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, who worries that A.T.&T. will cut deeply into his own local-service territory and who wants access to the long-distance business. "We could lose body parts over this. Given their size, this is a long-term threat not only to us but to customers in the markets we see evolving."
 
The Golden Days
 In the old monopolistic Bell System, A.T.&T. controlled the national telecommunications network from the inside out, dictating details down to the shape and color of a telephone. These days, when no company can corner the market on innovation, A.T.&T. must seek to shape the network by working from the outside in. So it is forging alliances, even while seeking control.
A.T.&T. has now digested the NCR Corporation, the computer company it swallowed two years ago for $7.5 billion. A.T.&T. is expected to sign within a few weeks a final agreement to pay $3.8 billion for one-third of McCaw Cellular Communications, a deal that will go a long way toward merging the world's biggest long-distance carrier with the largest and arguably most visionary provider of wireless phone service.
It has also bought its way into hot new markets by investing in companies like Sierra. Its portfolio now includes a 50 percent stake in EO Inc., which has invented a hybrid handheld device that acts like a computer and a telephone; General Magic Inc., which has developed software for advanced messaging systems, and the 3DO Company, which is introducing acompact-disk player that mixes video, text and voice.
By all accounts, A.T.&T. is still on the prowl. It wants to team up with foreign telephone companies, to build its international business. It wants to hook up with big cable television companies, which are upgrading their networks to provide hundreds of television channels and two-way communications services. A.T.&T. would like to provide the nationwide network that links the local cable systems and would also like to use the cable systems as a lower-cost alternative to the local phone companies in reaching its customers.
Underlying everything A.T.&T. does is a conviction that its network is its crown jewel, more important than equipment-manufacturing or any of its other businesses. "Everything we are doing is designed to put more traffic on our network, to enhance the value of our network," said Robert E. Allen, chairman and chief executive, at A.T.&T.'s main campus in this central New Jersey community.
In its five years under Mr. Allen, A.T.&T. has arrived at something of a turning point. For the first time since the Bell System was broken up almost 10 years ago, A.T.&T. is not fighting a rearguard battle to prevent losses in market share to rivals like MCI and Sprint. The long-distance market has matured into what some would call an oligopoly, and price slashing has given way to fatter profit margins for everybody. There is more money and more management time to spend on the future.
A.T.&T. has also finally adjusted to losing its captive market -- the local Bell companies -- for central-office switches, transmission equipment and the like. After losing market share and profits to the likes of Northern Telecom and Ericsson, the equipment business has cut its costs, raised sales overseas and become more adept at meeting the needs of big customers. The business is once again profitable and growing.
Under Mr. Allen, A.T.&T. began its first hostile takeover battle, for NCR. Inside A.T.&T., he has cut many of the 140,000 jobs the company has shed since the breakup in 1984, written off billions of dollars in assets to clear the way for modernizing the network, and reorganized the business units by making them more independent and more accountable for their individual financial performance. And where the old Bell System rewarded "lifers" who slowly climbed the corporate ladder, Mr. Allen, who himself rose through the ranks at several local Bell companies that at the time were owned by A.T.&T., has recruited big thinkers from outside the company and given them room to make things happen.
Those executives have shown an appetite for dealmaking but also a determination not to lose control in areas close to the core business. The deal with McCaw demonstrates this.
Under the plan, McCaw can market its services under the A.T.&T. brand name, and the two companies are expected to roll out a family of fancy wireless-phone offerings, also under the A.T.&T. name.
Yet the negotiations leading up to a preliminary agreement last November stretched out for months. Craig McCaw, who controls McCaw through a block of 10-votes-per-share stock, wanted to stay independent while also benefitting from A.T.&T.'s financial strength and marketing power. But A.T.&T. officials didn't want to let McCaw use their brand name unless they had the control to insure standards of service.
In the end, after two years of talks, A.T.&T. got what it wanted -- for a price. In addition to the $3.8 billion for one-third of McCaw's stock, it will pay $100 million for the option to buy Mr. McCaw's right to vote the shares. If A.T.&T. exercises that option -- a move that would raise regulatory questions about whether the company was in effect re-entering the local telephone business -- it will have to pay an additional $600 million.
The McCaw deal has alarmed competitors. MCI executives winced when the agreement was announced, and have since been trying to organize a broad alliance of their own to obtain a nationwide license for new pocket-phone radio frequencies.
But it is the regional Bell companies, fearful that their former parent will try to break into the local market, that are most upset. The Bell companies worry that A.T.&T. will use McCaw to avoid paying access charges to local phone companies. The Bells argue that they should be allowed to enter the long-distance market if A.T.&T. is to muscle its way into their business.
Over time, the baby Bells represent A.T.&T.'s biggest potential competitor, bigger than MCI or Sprint, if they are allowed into the long-distance market. As a result, Mr. Allen and other top A.T.&T. executives are hotly opposed to lifting the prohibition that bars the Bell companies from entering the long-distance market.
Mr. Allen has also been quick to throw up legal barriers to competitors. For example, A.T.&T. fought at the Federal Communications Commission an attempt by British Telecommunications to offer corporate networking services between the United States and Britain. (British Telecom retaliated by buying a stake in MCI and forming a broad-based alliance.)
A.T.&T. also played marketing hardball this year in the battle over toll-free 800-number services, a $7.5 billion market. Not only did the company match MCI blow for blow in a bitter advertising campaign, it also informed corporate customers that agreements with MCI or Sprint might be illegal because those companies had failed to disclose all their rates.
Looking to the future, A.T.&T. has placed heavy bets in six areas that touch just about every hot button in telecommunications:
* Expansion overseas, from manufacturing switching gear in China to providing seamless private networks for multinational companies.
* Wireless services, the exploding field of pocket phones, handheld computers and "mutant" devices that combine the attributes of phones, computers and fax machines.
* Messaging -- electronic mail and sophisticated paging systems.
* Data communications, linking far-flung computer networks.
* Voice-processing technology -- systems that recognize and respond to voice commands.
* Multimedia communications services that allow A.T.&T.'s network to carry text, voice and images -- for interactive television and the like.
 
Goliath and David
 A.T.&T. has proven agile at teaming with pivotal start-ups in many of these fields. Under Robert M. Kavner, now executive vice president and head of the mutimedia group, A.T.&T. has invested (along with companies like Sony and Matsushita) in 3DO, which plans to sell in time for Christmas a compact-disk player for playing interactive video programson home TV sets.
It was also an early investor in EO, which this summer started selling a "personal communicator" that combines a handheld computer that recognizes handwriting, with a telephone. The unit uses a powerful computer chip from A.T.&T. called the Hobbit, as well as an operating system from the GO Corporation, in which A.T.&T. also owns a minority stake.
But the telephone giant's most interesting relationship may well be with General Magic, which was started by former employees of Apple Computer. General Magic, which is also supported by Sony, Matsushita and Motorola, is developing what it hopes will become a communication standard for messages that travel over a patchwork of networks.
The revolutionary idea underlying General Magic is the creation of "smart" messages that navigate through many different networks to find their target at home, at the office or on a pager. A.T.&T. has not disclosed its stake in General Magic, but A.T.&T. officials hope to offer "smart messages" and "smart mailboxes" (which reroute incoming messages) over the Easylink electronic mail network by early next year.
On another front, rumors have been rife in recent months that A.T.&T. was in talks with Apple Computer. People familiar with the talks say Apple's chairman, John Sculley, who has been preaching about the convergence between computing and communications, proposed that A.T.&T. buy Apple. While executives like Mr. Kavner were said to favor the idea, other A.T.&T. officials saw no real value and the talks ended.
Perhaps the hottest speculation centers on a possible deal between A.T.&T. and a major cable television operator like Denver-based Tele-Communications Inc. Such a deal would give A.T.&T. a powerful partner in the multimedia entertainment world, but the most immediate draw is that a cable network could offer A.T.&T. lower access charges than do local telephone companies for linking it to customers.
Top A.T.&T. executives -- and their counterparts at MCI -- readily admit that they are talking to cable companies. But many experts say it remains unclear that a cable giant like Tele-Communications has much to gain from a partnership with A.T.&T. Mr. Allen discounted the rumors of such a deal.
Underlying the frenzy for alliances is a clear sense of uncertainty about the future. No one pretends to know, for example, whether people will flock to Sierra's network video games or will want to read the newspaper on a handheld computer.
"In the final analysis, customers will have a lot of choices, not only in telephones but in access to information services and entertainment," Mr. Allen said. "The great unanswered question is what do people want? What will people use? That's the fuzziest part of it for me."
 
LOOKING OUTSIDE FOR SMARTS
 Robert E. Allen, chairman and chief executive of A.T.&T., has surrounded himself with a cadre of strong-willed and independent executives who came from outside the company, and given them room to run. Among them:
* Alex J. Mandl, executive vice president and head of the core long-distance business, had been chief executive of Sea-Land Service Inc., the shipping company with $3 billion in sales. Mr. Mandl, a gregarious, Austrian-born executive who brims with the confidence of a chief executive, is best known for having negotiated the deal with McCaw, and he has gained enormous influence within the company.
* Robert M. Kavner, once a consultant at Coopers & Lybrand who advised A.T.&T. throughout its breakup, came aboard in 1984 as head of the communications-products group. It was Mr. Kavner, now executive vice president and head of the mutimedia group, who masterminded the takeover of NCR and who has been quarterback for investments into multimedia products. A man who with close ties to Silicon Valley and its venture capitalists, Mr. Kavner has made it possible for A.T.&T. to invest in and guide some of the most closely watched start-up companies at the nexus of computers and communications.
* Jerre L. Stead, formerly chief executive of the Square D Company, the big manufacturer of electrical components. Mr. Stead, who arrived in 1991, was put in charge of A.T.&T.'s loss-plagued office-equipment business and returned it to profitability last year. Mr. Allen named Mr. Stead chief executive of NCR in March and more recently named him an executive vice president of A.T.&T..
