HEADLINE: Profile: Robert A. Iger;
A Strong Signal to a Man Who May Be King at ABC

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
FEW executives get higher marks for good management than Thomas S. Murphy, chairman, and Daniel B. Burke, chief executive, of Capital Cities/ABC Inc. After building Capital Cities into one of the most profitable television-station companies, they acquired ABC in 1986, integrating the two companies well during a rough period for broadcasting.
If their record has had a flaw, it has been the failure to prepare for succession. Capital Cities/ABC has never had an obvious team of young executives groomed to take over when Mr. Murphy, who is 68, and Mr. Burke, 64, eventually retire. Mr. Burke is already scheduled to retire next February. 
 The company's announcement 10 days ago that Robert A. Iger, a senior vice president, would become executive vice president was a clear signal that Messrs. Murphy and Burke are trying to remedy that problem. The promotion was the third in seven months for Mr. Iger, who is only 42.
Mr. Iger is a logical choice for a company committed to promoting insiders. In the 18 years since he began at ABC, he has shown a keen ability to manage people. And as head of ABC Entertainment, working in Los Angeles between 1989 and 1992, he ran the crucial prime-time programming operations, if not brilliantly, at least well. He closed the ratings gap between second-place ABC and the front-runner, though ABC never took the lead, increased the profitability of prime time despite a difficult economic environment, and enjoyed no major turnover in management.
Mr. Iger had final say on which programs went on the prime-time schedule. In that role, he bet successfully on the comedy "Home Improvement," which has been a hit from the start and finished third in the ratings last season. Also, the low-cost, immensely profitable comedy "America's Funniest Home Videos" made its debut under him.
In a contrarian move at a network chasing younger audiences, Mr. Iger signed the detective series "Matlock" after Fred Silverman, whose company produces the show, learned that NBC had decided to drop the show. Mr. Silverman asked Mr. Iger whether ABC wanted it, and "Bob made the decision within five minutes," Mr. Silverman recalled. "In Hollywood that is very unusual."
Indeed, industry associates say Mr. Iger can make tough decisions quickly, in addition to being affable and approachable.
Mr. Iger also oversaw some big flops. He signed the movie producer George Lucas to do TV sequels to the "Indiana Jones" films. The 22 episodes, almost all of which aired, cost the company $1 million each. Their poor ratings meant they were aired only once and could not recoup that cost in reruns.
ABC also lost money on "Cop Rock," the ill-fated police musical conceived by the producer Steven Bochco.
And it gambled on "Twin Peaks," which garnered publicity more than ratings. But "Twin Peaks" and other programs did signal to two of Mr. Iger's constituencies -- Capital Cities management and Hollywood -- that he was willing to take unorthodox risks.
During his tenure in Hollywood, Mr. Iger also kept the low profile that both Mr. Murphy and Mr. Burke espouse. He rarely grants interviews (he declined to give one for this article). Nor was he seen a great deal around Hollywood high spots, though he had the Los Angeles quota of luxury automobiles -- a BMW and a Porsche. He sold the Porsche after Mr. Burke complained about how uncomfortable it was when Mr. Iger used it to chauffeur him during his trips to the West Coast.
Last January, Mr. Iger was named president of the ABC Television Network Group, which encompasses not only prime time but the entire programming schedule. In March, he was named a senior vice president of the corporation. Now, even with his latest appointment, Mr. Iger is only the frontrunner for the top job. As one longtime Capital Cities/ABC executive put it, "The job is his to lose." The executive noted that Capital Cities/ABC's management views programming as the core of its business, so Mr. Iger's position at ABC Entertainment is a valuable credential.
Insiders expect that Mr. Murphy will continue as chairman for some time. Whereas Mr. Burke has told associates he looks forward to leaving and spending time with the minor-league baseball team he bought, Mr. Murphy thrives on dealing with company issues.
THAT would allow him to work directly with Mr. Iger. Some think the chairman may play an even greater role than he has recently. One question for those watching for signs of a power shift is whether Mr. Iger will be given either of Mr. Burke's titles -- president and chief executive -- after Mr. Burke's departure.
One Wall Street analyst noted that Mr. Iger has had relatively little exposure to some of the corporation's crucial constituencies, including Wall Street.
Another crucial question is whether Mr. Iger, whose experience has been in sports and entertainment operations for the network, will exhibit the vision necessary to run a company that encompasses not only broadcast television but also cable television, publishing and forays into new businesses, including pay-per-view and high-definition television. Capital Cities/ABC owns the ESPN cable sports network and a host of newspapers and magazines, including Women's Wear Daily and Institutional Investor.
But the new businesses are growing in importance as the way entertainment and information is packaged and delivered evolves with dizzying advances in communications and computer technology.
The $5.3 billion company has $1.2 billion in cash, which gives it a lot of flexibility in making strategic investments. "What you don't have now is a dealmaker," said Dennis Leibowitz, who follows the company for Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette. "That is why Murphy is important."
Executives like Ted Turner and Rupert Murdoch have benefited handsomely by positioning their companies to take advantage of emerging trends. In recent months, Mr. Iger has met with executives at telephone companies and in Silicon Valley to educate himself.
Mr. Murphy and Mr. Burke may well value careful management more than vision, however. They built their businesses slowly and carefully, sticking to what they knew best -- managing television stations. Not until Mr. Murphy was in his early 60's did he significantly expand Capital Cities.
Since his childhood in Oceanside, L.I., Mr. Iger has always liked television. After he was graduated magna cum laude from Ithaca College with a major in television and radio, he worked a short stint as a television weatherman. It convinced him he would never be more than mediocre, so in 1974 he joined ABC, taking an entry-level job preparing studios for the filming of soap operas and game shows.
Despite his reputation as a "people person," one of his bosses was not happy with him. Mr. Iger moved to ABC Sports as a supervisor for production of sports programs.
A year later, he was manager of program planning for "Wide World of Sports," suggesting events to cover, negotiating for the rights to events like cliff diving and wrist wrestling, and then scheduling the events.
Those events led to jobs in which he made decisions about licensing the right to broadcast sports events, which involved dealing with affiliates and the sales division, among others. Those events ranged from boxing matches to the Olympic Games.
At the 1988 Winter Games in Calgary, the weather proved unusually warm and events had to be rescheduled; that task fell to Mr. Iger. One Capital Cities/ABC executive said Mr. Iger's handling of the problems impressed his superiors.
Later that year, he was tapped to become executive vice president for the television network group. That job put Mr. Iger in charge of business affairs, which included negotiating for prime-time programming. In some cases he also became involved with scheduling. For example, if the news department wanted to do a special on whether the budget would pass, Mr. Iger became the traffic cop, working with news and entertainment to find time for the program.
When management brought in Mr. Iger to replace Brandon Stoddard as president of ABC Entertainment, the move was considered unorthodox. Mr. Iger has said that even he was somewhat surprised by the appointment.
Although Mr. Iger dedicated himself to the endless business of reading scripts, friends say he does not have the obsession with programming that is characteristic of some network heads. "The trick is not to take it too seriously," he has said. Indeed, associates say, since his return to New York he has read relatively few scripts and prefers nonfiction reading, like "We Were Soldiers Once . . . And Young," a book about Vietnam. His hobbies include sailing and cooking. He likes cooking because it allows him to turn out a product himself, something that executives do not really do.
That Mr. Iger was not a zealous programmer may have benefited him in moving up the ladder, because his interest was as much in managing as in raising ratings.
Mr. Iger has told associates, and even mentioned in discussions with Mr. Burke, that he never had as his goal either running the network or its parent company. Mr. Iger is more prone to describe himself as a man of modest goals who wanted to do each job well. In a recent speech at his alma mater, Mr. Iger said he viewed patience as the most important quality in getting ahead. "It keeps you from making mistakes," he has said. "I have seen impatience ruin more careers than anything else."
But beneath that seeming lack of focus on the long term may lie an ardent determination. Today he is clearly aware that he is being considered as the heir to Capital Cities/ ABC. Indeed, after he and his wife separated, he acknowledged to an associate that he had considered the career implications of the split at a company where the chairman and the president boast decades-long marriages and where some have said, only half-jokingly, that divorce can be a liability. (He and his wife have two daughters.)
Times have changed, of course, and both of Mr. Iger's most obvious rivals to run the company -- Stephen A. Weiswasser and David Westin -- are divorced.
Like Mr. Iger, both men were promoted 10 days ago. Mr. Weiswasser was named president of the Capital Cities/ABC Multimedia Group and senior vice president of the corporation. Mr. Westin became a senior vice president and president of production for the network group.
But Mr. Weiswasser, 52, who was executive vice president at ABC News from 1991 to 1993, has had less programming experience, which at least one longtime Capital Cities executive thinks makes him a less likely candidate for the top job.
Television executives think Mr. Westin, who joined the company only two years ago and comes from the legal side, is on the fast track. However, he has had no programming experience.
That means Mr. Iger has at least a strong opportunity. In a succinct analysis, he recently said: "There was a message sent to me that I had the potential. For the record, there is nothing promised or guaranteed."

The New York Times

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1707 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/July 25-30

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Climax for the Federal Budget Debate 

The Federal budget bill headed toward resolution late last week. By a 218-216 vote, the House squeaked its approval Thursday night; a sure-to-be-close Senate vote was scheduled for early Saturday morning, after press time for this section. Without major change, the bill would slash $496 billion from the deficit over five years. Military and Medicare spending would be cut, and various taxes would be increased. Selected tax highlights: The gas tax would rise from 14.1 cents a gallon to 18.4 cents. For single persons and couples earning taxable income of, respectively, $115,000 to $250,000 and $140,000 to $250,000, the top income tax rate would rise to 36 percent from 31 percent. Businesses could deduct only 50 percent of meal expenses, instead of the current 80 percent, and the top business tax rate would go from 34 percent to 35 percent for companies earning $10 million or more.
 
More Phone Competition
 
Dial C for competition. Last week, the F.C.C. opened up another part of the $86 billion local telephone market to challengers to the Baby Bells. The agency is allowing the so-called upstarts to compete for some of the $4.2 billion in connection fees that long-distance carriers, like Sprint and MCI, must pay so that their customers can use local lines. Last September, the F.C.C. allowed the upstarts in on another piece of the local action, the $2.5 billion market for "special access" phone lines used by large companies. The two pro-competitive steps are tiny ones in the $86 billion local market, though. Still far away is the day Cliff Robertson and Candice Bergen represent vying local phone companies, much as they now do long-distance ones.

Paper Piles Up in Hospitals
 
It's sure to spike the cost-cutters' blood pressure: Nearly one of every 10 health care dollars pays for nothing more than hospital paperwork. According to a study published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine, $666.2 billion was spent on American health care in 1990. Of that total, $256 billion was spent on hospital care, of which a whopping $63 billion financed hospital administration alone. In contrast to earlier eras, hospitals now have lots of clerks to push these growing stacks of paper. In 1990 hospitals had 1,221,600 administrators, while the average daily patient roster was only 853,000. Why is $1 of every $10 of all health care revenue, or $1 of every $4 of hospital revenue, spent on paper shuffling? Growing record-keeping and billing requirements, say the study's authors.

Fewer Businesses Are Failing
 
There is good economic news these days, but often it's only modestly good. (For instance, construction was up 1.2 percent in June -- but the residential sector was still relatively unresponsive.) And so it's refreshing to get some unqualified good news, such as Dun & Bradstreet's report last week that business failures were down a solid 9.9 percent in the first half of this year from the first half of 1992. The decline, from 50,793 to 45,749, was a broad one involving all industrial sectors. And the drop in the liabilities of failed businesses was sharper still, from $54 billion to $25 billion during the same periods. The final bit of undiluted good news: Big businesses are under-represented in this group of faltering enterprises.

Happy Dilemma for Detroit
 
The smiles faded slightly in Detroit last week, as the big auto makers realized that their collective $2.34 billion profit last quarter has put them in a happy dilemma. On the one hand, to get higher values for their stocks and lower rates on their loans, they want to amplify the success of their second quarter to bankers and investors. On the other hand, they want to downplay that success as they resume their seats at the bargaining table with the U.A.W. in contract negotiations. Appearances can be deceiving, of course, and that's what the Big Three will argue to the union. Despite the recent profits, the companies will say, they can't afford to pay more or reduce the work force less in an age when building autos is increasingly global and nonunion. Of course, the union will have a rejoinder: that the Big Three can't afford a strike just as they start to cash in on growing demand and to retake market share from the Japanese.

Motown Sold, But Not for a Song
 
Motown Records, the legendary black-owned record company whose stars have included Stevie Wonder, Marvin Gaye and Diana Ross and the Supremes, was sold for $301 million to Polygram Records last week. Polygram, based in London and owned mostly by Philips Electronics, the Dutch company, is the world's third-biggest record seller. The deal -- part of a trend in which independent labels are bought by conglomerates -- will not bring Polygram a large stable of current stars. But it does bring Polygram a catalogue of 30,000 classic master recordings, plus all the R-E-S-P-E-C-T the Motown name musters, as Aretha would put it.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Get Yer Ice Cold Ice Beer!
 
It gives new meaning to the term "cold one." Molson, the Canadian brewer, will start selling "ice beer" in the United States this week. So named because it is brewed and filtered at freezing temperatures, ice beer has grabbed an impressive 10 percent of the Canadian beer market since it was introduced there last April by Molson and Labatt. Will it do equally well in its American debut? One factor that might affect sales is the beer's 4.4 percent alcohol content by weight -- the average for beer is 3.6 percent. But Molson plans to ignore that fact in its ads, highlighting instead the brew's "smoothness and distinctive, full-flavored taste," said a spokesman.

Orioles Take First (Sales Div.)
 
If dollars were homers, the Baltimore Orioles would lead their division. The baseball team was auctioned off last week for $173 million, $103 million more than the previous owner paid in 1989 and the most ever paid in this country for a professional sports team. (Second place goes to football's Dallas Cowboys, bought for $140 million in 1989 by an Arkansas businessman.) The auction was forced when the now-former Orioles owner Eli Jacobs went bankrupt from unrelated business reversals. The winning investor group, which includes Tom Clancy, the novelist, and Pam Shriver, the tennis player, deny they paid too much. Indeed, the team is enjoying sellout crowds in its new stadium, Camden Yards, and the Orioles themselves seem to like it: They won three games in a row in the days following the auction.
 
Questions Remain at Guess?
 
Appropriately shrouded in mystery, the top executive at Guess? jeans decided in mid-week to leave the $500 million company and sever all ties to it. Georges Marciano will resign as chief executive, relinquish his seat on the board and sell his $220 million share to his three less-famous brothers, all of whom remain as top Guess? executives. A possible clue to the departure came in succeeding days, though; it turns out Georges wanted to distribute his fashionable pants to mass marketers like Wal-Mart and Sears, while brothers Maurice, Paul and Armand wanted to stick with department stores and their own outlets. There's another mystery, however. The remaining Marcianos will borrow money to buy Georges' stake. But who will lend hundreds of millions to a company whose primary inspiration has just departed?

Nike: Just (Re)Do It
 
Help the environment and help yourself. That may be the motto of the new recycling program at Nike Inc. In stores in Florida and Washington State, the company will collect worn-out sneakers and have them remade into something guaranteed to wear out more sneakers: running tracks and tennis courts. Customers will get $5 to $10 rebates for their old footwear. The program was born two years ago when Nike employees saw old shoes being shoveled into a landfill. Will Nike accept other brands? "We can't accept responsibility for everyone's garbage," said Keith G. Peters, a Nike spokesman, his tongue perhaps in his cheek. "But if you really twist our arm, we will take the Reeboks."
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Week 2: The Franc-Mark Fiasco
 
The week began in disaster and ended in hope. Early on, Europe was panicked by speculators' attacks on the French franc. But as the markets calmed, some saw the solution to the crisis -- allowing most European currencies to float within a wider range than previously allowed under the European Exchange Rate Mechanism -- as a blessing in disguise. Three of the optimistic theories: First, the freer play in currency will produce lower interest rates in Europe, thus helping revive the recession-bound economies of France, Italy and elsewhere. Second, a revived Europe means more demand there for imported goods -- a boon for the United States. And third, reduced European interest rates mean a stronger dollar, which helps American consumers of wine and other European exports.

Extra Innings for Steel Tariffs
 
It ain't over 'til it's over. So reason America's steelmakers, who began a broad campaign last week to reverse recent tariff rulings. Citing a slump in their stocks following the decisions, a dozen steel companies petitioned the International Trade Commission to rehear the tariff cases; the request is the first ever in the commission's 77-year history. Also, 60 members of the House have petitioned President Clinton at the steelmakers' urging, asking him to monitor steel imports for the industry. Big Steel is also asking Congress itself to review the cases and, in New York, industry lawyers are appealing the rulings to the Court of International Trade. Yogi would approve.

Lloyd's Director Resigns
 
The finance director of Lloyd's of London has resigned. David Bruce, in office for only four months, quit to pursue other interests, but the pressing problems of the 300-year-old British insurer remain. Facing $9 billion in losses for the four years from 1988 to 1991 -- the most recent figures available -- Lloyd's has been seeking funds from corporate investors. Standard & Poor's recently hurt that effort, though, by declining to give Lloyd's a specific financial rating.

HEADLINE: Making Health Plans Prove Their Worth

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
KATHLEEN ANGEL oversees $200 million a year in medical spending for employees of the Digital Equipment Corporation. But like most benefits executives, she is largely flying blind when it comes to comparing the performances of the slew of health plans used by big companies.
Even the simplest request for information to compare the quality of care, patient satisfaction and cost efficiency, among other things, can produce a harvest of statistical apples and oranges. 
 Last year, for instance, Digital, the second-biggest computer maker in the United States, asked 45 of its 90 health maintenance organizations how many days their respective groups of covered employees had been hospitalized. The answers were of little value, Ms. Angel said, because some were based on claims for payment, some on individuals' medical charts and some on the number of days approved before admission.
"Nothing was comparable, even at a very gross level," Ms. Angel said.
Now, in a ground-breaking attempt to get numbers that could help shape the national debate over medical costs and choices, a group of large employers, including Digital, and big H.M.O.'s is set to introduce a standardized report card system that it has developed for all health plans.
The report cards would allow employers -- and in some cases, employees -- to compare how plans perform in more than 60 categories, or benchmarks, with the data compiled in carefully defined ways. Among other things, participating H.M.O.'s would report the percentage of infants receiving immunization shots and the number of diabetes patients who had an annual eye exam, a recommended procedure. Data on hospital admissions and lengths of stay would be included, as would numbers measuring a plan's financial stability and cost efficiency.
A one-year trial of the report cards is to begin next month. Perhaps a dozen plans will take part, including at least three that have helped develop the standards -- Kaiser Permanente, the Harvard Community Health Plan and Prudential -- along with Blue Cross plans in several states. All four companies that worked on the standards will also be part of the trial. Besides Digital, they are GTE, Xerox and Bull HN Information Systems, a unit of Groupe Bull, the Paris-based computer maker.
 
A National Model?
 If all goes well, the benchmark system could become the model for a national report card, said Ms. Angel and others involved in the project. The project has already been endorsed by 30 managed health care plans with 55 million members, including the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association. And as the White House moves closer to unveiling its health care reform package, Administration health advisers and Medicare officials say they are looking with approval at the benchmark program and others like it that have been tried in several states.
A precursor of the pilot program was a collaboration between Xerox and Kaiser, one of the company's main H.M.O.'s. For Xerox, which demands steady improvement in quality from employees and suppliers, the primitive medical statistics traditionally provided by health plans were unacceptable.
"Xerox has long been aggressively committed to basing everything we do on measurement and documentation," said Helen Darling, the health care strategy and programs manager at Xerox. Last summer, she said, Xerox and Kaiser began to develop "meaningful, credible, pertinent, relevant information that everyone can be reasonably proud of and that everyone can use."
For employers, the system will provide a means to insure they are getting their money's worth. They can use the numbers to prod H.M.O.'s to do better and, in extreme cases, to drop the ones that are clearly inferior.
The H.M.O.'s can also use the system to improve care. In addition, the better ones can use the benchmarks as calling cards in the looming era of health reform, where they will have to compete harder for business from giant purchasing alliances. What's more, the system will help the health plans make the right choices as they invest heavily in computer software to deal with a multitude of customer demands for reports on care and costs.
And consumers should benefit, proponents say, by having a tool to make more informed decisions when choosing among plans.
"Women 20 years old, for example, may choose differently if they find a plan had an excellent record in providing early prenatal care, and if the waiting time to see an obstetrician was very small," said Dr. Arnold Epstein, a White House health care adviser who is an internist at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston.
But there could be a bigger payoff, proponents say. Researchers could use the system to help determine which treatments and preventive approaches lead to longer, healthier lives -- and which have little or no effect. The study of so-called medical outcomes is still in its infancy, but offers great potential for emphasizing the things that work and dropping those that do not.
For instance, is the number of visits to a doctor for prenatal care linked to the rate of low birth weights? "Some say 'yes' and some say 'no,' " said Janet M. Corrigan, a vice president of the National Committee for Quality Assurance, a nonprofit H.M.O.-accrediting group based in Washington. "We expect to see those linkages become more well established."
The companies and H.M.O.'s that developed the performance standards were operating under the auspices of the accrediting body. The project also has the support of prominent members of the Washington Business Group on Health, including Bank of America, Chrysler, Ford, General Electric and Hewlett-Packard.
While the benchmark system has drawn support from many large employers and health plans, some physicians and health care experts have reservations.
The benchmarks are "a positive step," said Robert McAfee, a Portland, Me., surgeon who is president-elect of the American Medical Association. But, he added, "there is no simple way to measure quality."
 
Understanding the Numbers
 Critics note the controversies surrounding Medicare reports on hospital mortality rates and the statistics on individual doctors published in recent years in a few states.
Some of the data were subject to misinterpretation, the critics said. A high mortality rate could mean a doctor was incompetent or a hospital had an inept staff. But it could also mean that a doctor or hospital was so good it had attracted the most difficult cases.
For that reason, they say, a report card system could backfire. They argue that some health plans, doctors and hospitals would concentrate on getting a good rating instead of improving care.
There are stories of hospitals that transfer dying patients to long-term-care units to keep their mortality numbers low, and surgeons who refer dangerously ill heart patients to other hospitals for the same reason.
In particular, some experts question the wisdom of giving report cards to consumers, who may have little knowledge of the medical subject matter. "I wonder if we have done enough research on whether patients can handle this kind of information," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health policy economist at Princeton University.
Added Sheila T. Leatherman, head of policy and evaluation for United Healthcare, an H.M.O. based in Minnetonka, Minn., "The notion of informed consumerism is becoming a central precept in health care reform, but it is largely untested." There is no agreement, she added, about "who should receive the data, in what format and with what kinds of interpretive materials." United Healthcare was one of the six H.M.O.'s in the group that developed the benchmarks. It also included Aetna Health Plans and U.S. Healthcare.
On the other side, Dr. William L. Roper, the former head of the Federal Centers for Disease Control, said that "producing information for beneficiaries is a powerful idea that can't be rolled back."
Dr. Roper, who now heads the Prudential Insurance Company's new health care research center in Atlanta, said consumers should get report cards to help them choose a health plan. As for reports on individual doctors and hospitals, he said, "the plans themselves will need information to make judgments." But he said more study was needed before making those reports public.
Dr. Mark Chassin, the New York state health commissioner, said everyone in health care, from individual physicians to hospitals to H.M.O.'s, would eventually have to "produce data that is useful for quality measurement. It's just a matter of time." The information should be fed back to "people responsible for delivering care," he said, "in a quality improvement context, but not in a punitive way."
White House advisers working on the Clinton health care proposals said they were still debating how far the President should go. Philip R. Lee, Assistant Secretary for Health in the Department of Health and Human Services, said Administration aides want "health plans and systems to have built-in continuous quality improvement."
A number of large H.M.O.'s already have quality improvement systems, he noted. "There is a lot of experimentation that is very helpful in guiding us in the right direction," Dr. Lee said.
But are the benchmarks the right ones? The current measures do not "go far enough in measuring the impact of health care on the function and well being of consumers," said Dr. Paul Ellwood, who heads the Jackson Hole Group, an influential coalition of researchers and industry representatives.
Indeed, the 60 or so benchmarks used in the one-year trial will be refined and expanded as more becomes known about medical outcomes, said Ms. Corrigan of the quality assurance committee. Some measures may be dropped or replaced, she said. "We need an evolutionary process, with revisions every couple of years," she added.
Some benchmarks, including those for the treatment of mental illness and substance abuse, will probably not be released to employers by the health plans because of lingering disagreements over what they mean.
In any event, the companies and H.M.O.'s that helped draft the performance measures plan to install an "external auditing" system to insure the honesty of the reports, Ms. Corrigan said. "If we are going to rely on this information," she added, "we have to be comfortable that the underlying data are reasonably complete and reliable."
The group said it had high hopes that the new measurements would gain national acceptance. "They would fit nicely into a national report card," said Ms. Angel of Digital.
"If we do it right," added Ms. Darling of Xerox, "that data, or perhaps some modified version, would become the set that every health plan in the nation would be reporting to purchasing alliances, which would then report it to the Federal Government."
But Professor Reinhardt urged a gingerly approach. "I salute these people for trying to do this," he said. "But they should apply it the way alligators make love -- very cautiously."

HEADLINE: The World Bank Responds

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "World Bank Needs a Wake-Up Call" (Aug. 1), Gary Kleiman argued that the World Bank is assisting nations that no longer need help and neglecting nations that desperately do. Both claims are false. 
 Mr. Kleiman seems to be particularly concerned with our assistance to Latin America. It is true that in most countries in the region, the debt crisis has been resolved -- happily, in a democratic framework. The scars of past mismanagement, however, remain. Latin America continues to be a region of highly unequal distribution of income and economic opportunities. The poorest 20 percent receive only 4 percent of the regional income.
The Latin American countries never forthrightly addressed the issues of human development and poverty. Matters worsened during the 1980's. Government programs in education, health and nutrition were cut back. The serious issues of environmental degradation were barely touched. Infrastructure was not maintained and investments were deferred.
The World Bank has contributed heavily to the reform of the Latin American economies and the resolution of the debt crisis. Since the onset of the debt crisis in 1982, World Bank financing in the region has been $18 billion.
Recognizing that governments in crisis could not meaningfully address longer-term developmental issues such as education, health, the environment and infrastructure, it provided financing to backstop the restructuring of policies and institutions and the reduction of the commercial debt. Now the emphasis has to be on longer-term questions.
The Latin Americans and their financial partners face a serious challenge: how to establish the relevance of the state for the people. It has to be done through the reform and expansion of education, health, urban services, environmental programs, infrastructure, agriculture and capital markets. This is where the World Bank comes in, allotting $13 billion of its resources in the next three years.
In Mexico, the World Bank expects to put up half a billion dollars a year in environmental projects, particularly in the border regions. In Chile, it is supporting a fundamental restructuring, decentralization and expansion of basic education. In Brazil, there are projects to conserve tropical forests, arrest soil erosion and improve the urban environment. In Argentina, there is support for capital market reform and a bond market, essential for the private sector.
Private flows are important and should finance industry and much of the privatized infrastructure. But private funds, often speculative and volatile, are not available on terms suitable for long-term investments in public services. Nor do they bring with them the necessary technical expertise. The World Bank's work complements such funding.
The needs of Eastern Europe are also large and diverse, and money is not the only issue. The World Bank has the financial, technical and managerial capacity to do its part in Eastern Europe without compromising on its role in Latin America and other parts of the developing world.
 
S. SHAHID HUSAIN
Washington, Aug. 4
 
The writer is vice president for Latin America and the Caribbean region at the World Bank.

HEADLINE: At Work;
The New Equality in Hard Times

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
LAST hired, first fired, goes the wisdom about women. By that logic, women should be hit hardest by recessions, and that indeed is what three Bureau of Labor Statistics economists thought they kept reading in news accounts of women's status.
William Goodman, Stephen Antczak and Laura Freeman went back to their files -- comparative male-female data on the five recessions since 1969 -- and confirmed reality as they knew it: men typically fare far worse than women in recessions. As the three economists point out in research published last month in the Labor Department's Monthly Labor Review, men lost nine times as many jobs as women did in each of the last five recessions. 
 But they also found something that does not bode well for women: in the last two recessions, the employment experience of men and women began to converge. For the first time, women experienced a net loss of jobs. "It is a pattern that the men get most of the layoffs," Mr. Goodman said. "That's known. But's it's getting worse for women."
The trend, if it is one, may mean the end of a devil's tradeoff imposed on women by occupational segregation, wage inequality and discrimination, some economists say. "This is bad news for women," said Heidi Hartmann, head of the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington. "It reflects considerable turmoil in the white-collar sector."
What happens to men and women in recessions is largely a function of the industries they work in. Men suffer more layoffs because they tend to work in the goods-producing sector of the economy, which has been more volatile during downturns. Men are also concentrated in specific industries, like steel, that have undergone dramatic and probably permanent shrinkage. "In the four most recent recessions," Mr. Goodman and the other authors write, "the number of unemployed men expanded by one and a half to three times the increase in the number of unemployed women."
Women predominate in the services-producing sector, which has been relatively sheltered from the upheavals of the economy. In fact, the number of "women's jobs" has actually grown through several recessions. Health services, for example, where employment is about four-fifths female, has grown in good times and bad. Social services and education are still predominantly female and growing. And the authors theorize that even in contractions of state and local governments, as occurred in the last two recessions, women are somewhat protected by affirmative action policies.
Even women employed in the industry groups seriously disrupted by recessions, like construction, tend to be insulated. Most women in construction have been office workers, who are still needed when there is a dropoff in demand for laborers, skilled or otherwise.
A cynic might argue that women suffer fewer layoffs in recessions because, given their lower wages, the net savings to employers is so puny.
 MR. GOODMAN agrees to an extent: "Lost jobs tend to be higher paid," he said. "So jobs saved are likely to be lower paid." But the molasses-like rebound of the economy is taking a toll. As Mr. Goodman and his colleagues point out, services are no longer a port in the storm. Though the sector gained some 160,000 jobs in the last recession, in each of the 70's and 80's recessions, it gained a quarter of a million jobs.
It has been a given that women's wages are generally lower than men's. "Men's work" has been more unstable, more susceptible to cyclical production, but rewarded with a higher hourly wage.
Many women have low-paid, near-minimum wage jobs, but relative employment stability. If the service sector is becoming more volatile, "now they can't even count on that," said Ms. Hartmann of the policy research institute.
The increase in employment volatility is also bad news for women because the unemployment insurance system is geared toward workers in male-dominated industries like construction and mining.
Higher-wage workers are likely to have saved enough to ride out a recession, if not necessarily in style, on a weekly unemployment check. Lower-wage workers, without financial reserves, are less likely to be able to get by on that check. "Low earning makes you less able to withstand the onslaught of no earning," Ms. Hartmann said.
And since women predominate in industries like retail, where many jobs are part-time or seasonal, they are less likely to qualify for unemployment insurance. Half the states require workers to work at least 20 hours a week at the minimum wage for a year to qualify for unemployment. "These are problems we didn't have to think of in these sectors," Ms. Hartmann said. "They should be addressed by public policy."
 
 
SOME STATS FROM THE BOTTOM LINE
 A roundup of factoids on women in the workplace from statistics released by the Women's Bureau of the Labor Department earlier this summer:
* Women's labor force participation in the United States hit an all-time high -- at 57.8 percent -- in 1992. Of the 100 million women 16 or older, about 58 million were working.
* In 1983, women held 40 percent (9.7 million) of managerial and professional specialty jobs. That total rose to 47 percent, or 14.7 million, in 1992.
* Women are still over-represented in lower-paying jobs. Forty-four percent -- 23.5 million -- work in technical, sales and administrative support jobs.
The earnings gap is closing, but women still take in only about 75 cents for every dollar men earn, according to 1992 median weekly earnings figures. The figure for women was $381, $505 for men.
* Women earned at least half the bachelor's and master's degrees in the last 12 years.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Some Options for Startup Investors

SERIES: First of three articles on investing by generation. Next: the 40's and 50's.

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
INVESTING takes many twists and turns through a lifetime, and what makes sense for beginners in their 20's and 30's is far different from what's best for their elders.
The 20's and 30's are realistically a time of spending, not saving: college loans are paid off, a home is bought and furnished, a family started. Still, some money should be set aside, financial planners say. "Start with the idea that investing is not a choice, it's a necessity," said Carol C. Pankros, a planner in Palatine, Ill., a Chicago suburb. 
 Before investing, create an emergency reserve of up to three months' living expenses, said Harold Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla. Keep it in liquid form -- money market funds or, for slightly higher yields, short-term bond funds. Mr. Evensky likes Federated Short-Intermediate Government Bond Fund, currently yielding 3.53 percent, and Vanguard Short-Term Corporate Bond Fund, 4.91 percent.
Next comes risk management. First, medical coverage and disability insurance. Then, property and casualty insurance. Life insurance probably isn't necessary, unless you have dependents or pre-existing conditions that might prevent future coverage, Ms. Pankros said.
After that, she counsels saving at least 10 percent of gross income. Some mutual funds will automatically deduct money from paychecks or bank accounts and use it to buy shares -- a good option, she said, because if you don't see the money, you don't miss it.
Where that money goes depends on what it's needed for.
If you plan to use it in three years or less to buy, say, a house or a car, "you should be saving, not investing at all," because most investments are too volatile, said Ross Levin, a financial planner in Minneapolis and president-elect of the International Association for Financial Planning, a trade group based in Atlanta. He would combine savings bonds with Vanguard Prime, a money market fund.
People who have three to five years before they intend to use the money, however, should consider stock funds, planners say, choosing the amount of risk they feel comfortable with. Ms. Pankros recommends the Janus Fund, a blue chip fund that often moves into cash, and Financial Industrial Income, which invests one-third of its portfolio in utilities, real estate investment trusts and other high-yielding securities.
Money available for longer than five years should go in part into qualified retirement plans because of tax deductions and deferrals. "Participate at least up to the point that your employer matches your contribution," said Katharine A. McGee, a planner in St. Louis, or set up a Keogh plan if you're self-employed.
The biggest risk for investments at this time of life is inflation, planners agree, not market volatility. Time smoothes out interim fluctuations in the stock market, so "the key to investing is growth, growth and more growth," Mr. Evensky said. Thus nearly all the advisers suggested all-stock portfolios for those with long-term savings.
Index funds might be good bets because new investors generally lack the money to diversify, Mr. Evensky said. Index funds buy all or a representative sample of securities in a market index, so "you don't have to worry about being in the right place at the right time," he said. Mr. Evensky likes the Vanguard Index Trust Portfolio 500, which tracks Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and the Schwab 1000, which tracks the 1,000 largest domestic stocks.
Index funds do, however, garner only market returns. For an actively managed fund that might return more, Mr. Evensky likes SoGen International, which invests in stocks and bonds worldwide, sold no-load through Charles Schwab & Company. (Sold by others, it carries a 3.75 percent upfront load.)
One possibility for start-up investors, said Eileen M. Sharkey, a planner in Denver, is to split a portfolio between Vanguard Wellington, which mixes bonds and stocks, and Financial Industrial Income. These are "all-weather core holdings that won't make a million dollars but will do well in good markets and bad," she said.
Systematic investing, a strategy often called "dollar cost averaging" that involves investing fixed amounts regularly, lessens risk because, on average, you buy more shares when prices are lower. Mr. Levin recommends the Kaufmann Fund, a very aggressive stock fund, the volatility of which can be offset by systematic investing.
As you begin to accumulate more money to invest, begin diversifying -- that is, splitting investments among various assets or investing styles, with the idea that if one style is out of favor, the others may earn gains to offset the losses. Today most advisers recommend splitting stock portfolios among domestic small-company funds, and funds that buy stocks based on future earnings growth ("growth funds") or cheap current prices ("value funds"). Add a sprinkling, 10 to 20 percent, of funds that invest abroad.
Among growth stock funds, Mr. Evensky likes Gabelli Growth and SEI Capital Appreciation; among value funds, Windsor II and SEI Value. He recommends three small-company funds: Meridian, SEI Small Cap Growth Portfolio and DFA U.S. Small Cap Value; and three international: T. Rowe Price International Stock, Harbor International and SEI International.

GRAPHIC: Table lists performance of three international stock funds (Harbor International, T. Rowe Price and SEI International) recommended by some investment advisors for diversifying a portfolio. (Source: Morningstar Inc.)

HEADLINE: From Russia, With Red Tape: A Technology Boom

BYLINE: By SABRA CHARTRAND

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
LABORING behind the Iron Curtain, Soviet scientists often worked in crude laboratories, struggling to create new medical, chemical or engineering technologies with fewer resources than their Western counterparts.
These disadvantages frequently compelled the scientists to make do, pushing the limits of creativity in ways that led to unorthodox, uniquely economical or especially efficient inventions. But since nearly every scientific or engineering institute was dedicated to military research, many of the Soviet Union's most innovative scientific discoveries were stamped "top secret" and never seen in the West. 
 Until now. Even as much of the potential wealth of the former Soviet Union is trapped by the breakup of its republics, more American business executives are jetting to and from Moscow, positioning themselves as brokers to market Russian technology to the West.
Some American companies, like the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, have gone directly to former Soviet institutes to hire their staffs. But the sheer number of institutes -- there are hundreds -- is giving American brokers an opportunity to carve out their own niche.
For the Russians, the brokers represent a chance to redirect a scientific industry on the verge of collapse now that military research money has all but dried up. For the brokers, the Russians represent a chance to hit it big.
"The changes in Russia are an enormous opportunity for U.S. industry," said Mark S. Taylor, a vice president of one of the biggest new technology transfer companies, East/ West Technology Partners Ltd., which is based in Washington. "Access to Russian technology is a great resource. But obviously we're also in this because there's money to be made."
DESPITE the formidable amounts of red tape and complicated questions about ownership, American brokers are negotiating licensing rights to market hundreds of Russian inventions in the United States. They include drug treatments for tumors, lithium batteries, a method for diagnosing pre-cancerous cells, steelmaking processes, magnetic welding, ultraviolet sterilizers for medical tools -- even an industrial-strength deodorizer.
It is impossible to put a dollar value on the new industry because none of the brokers has sold any of the technologies to American manufacturers. But some of the brokers, like East/West Technology and Scientific Dimensions U.S.A. Inc., say deals are close and they will be earning licensing fees and manufacturing or sales royalties by the end of the year. The potential payoff, they say, is huge.
East/West, which was formed in May, says it is about to license a Russian all-aluminum circuit board to the Unisys Corporation. Unisys says it is still evaluating the worth of the invention, but East/West executives say they believe the deal might ultimately earn them half a billion dollars a year in royalties alone. (The standard arrangement is a 50-50 split with the Russian inventors, with the Americans paying up-front legal and research costs for patents and marketing.)
No one knows how many brokers are scrambling for a piece of the pie, but they have been popping up in all sizes and shapes with increasing frequency.
Large American consulting firms, like B.D.M. International Inc. and Kaiser Research, which have hundreds of scientists and engineers, are entering into joint ventures with companies formed in Moscow that represent former Soviet research institutes. Patent law firms are forming scientific branches to search for technology in Moscow. And independent entrepreneurs are trying to cash in on one or two Russian inventions.
Scientific Dimensions, for example, was started in February 1992 by the New York patent law firm of Kenyon & Kenyon, now one of its shareholders. The company, which has an office in Moscow and eight Russian patent agents, already has 280 patent applications pending in the United States for Russian technology, according to its president, Charles A. Gamer Jr., who travels to Russia about every six weeks.
"There are some great inventions here," said Mr. Gamer, looking over the prototypes in his office in Lexington, Mass. "I've got radiation reflective cloth, I've got titanium alloys, cold cathodes for producing ions. I've got crazy stuff like hair gels and a lock so big and heavy that even though it's burglar-proof you'd never want to use it."
He added: "So many things Russian scientists did were just submerged because they didn't want the West to get a hold of it. Or it was deemed a military secret. Anybody working in space fell into that."
As an example, Mr. Gamer offered up an invention for an artificial soil -- a fabric, imbedded with nutrients, that can be wrapped around seedlings to help them grow in space.
"But how can trans-genic fish be a military secret?" he asked, referring to Russian work in genetic engineering. "Because they were making whales five times the size so they could ram submarines?"
So the hunt for a gold mine in hidden technologies is on.
East/West Technologies says it may have found one when it bought the rights to a chemical compound that it says will dye cancerous and pre-cancerous cells, allowing surgeons to remove cancerous tissue with precision.
"One big problem in cancer surgery is where is the margin between tumors and healthy tissue?," said the company president, Arnold Lipman. "The general tendency is the radical approach, to take too much tissue just to be safe."
He says he believes the compound, developed by Dr. Viktor Lazarev at Moscow State University, could also radically alter cancer diagnoses by pinpointing pre-cancerous cells. The compound, after being injected or taken orally in the form of a dye, is absorbed by the cancerous and pre-cancerous tissues. During surgery, a special light generated by optical equipment developed by Dr. Lazarev causes the dye to become fluorescent, distinguishing the diseased cells from healthy tissue.
This is the sort of potential that is prompting brokers to bring together Russian and American companies that might otherwise never find each other. But first, the brokers must be expert in the legal systems and business cultures of both countries.
That means understanding patent law, marketing, sales negotiations and corporate contracts. It also means finding Russian friends and other contacts as guides through the tangled bureaucracies left behind by 70 years of Communism. In many instances, that means taking on a Russian partner.
That was the case with East/West, which was formed when Mr. Lipman started a joint venture with a Russian company set up by Evgeniy Velikohov, vice president of the Russian Academy of Sciences and a scientific adviser to President Boris Yeltsin.
But East/West decided it also needed a third partner, someone prominent enough to get corporate leaders to return his calls. So Mr. Lipman and Mr. Velikohov turned to B.D.M. International and its chairman Frank Carlucci, a former Secretary of Defense.
Still, the business side of this new industry -- isolating the technology, evaluating its market worth and pitching it to big American manufacturers -- may be its easiest part.
"The single largest problem is not finding or selling, but proving the chain of title," to show who really owns the Russian technology, Mr. Lipman said. One of the first things the American brokers want to know is whether the invention can be patented.
"You are starting with a system where the Government owned everything," Mr. Lipman said, echoing other Americans working in Russia. "They might have given the scientist an inventor's certificate. But the invention belonged to the institute where he worked, which was controlled by a particular ministry, so it was the property of the state."
The Soviet Union long allowed writers and musicians to patent or copyright their work. But the first technology patent laws were put on the books only last January and they were not retroactive.
"You have to get a release from the institute the scientist worked for," Mr. Lipman said. "Then you have to go to the Government ministry and do the same thing."
If that does not work, the Russian Government has the power to "provide the title by decree," he said.
IN some cases, though, Russian inventions cannot be patented because the inventors were ignorant of international patent law. When Russian scientists came to the West in the past, they sometimes presented papers on their inventions or published brochures about them and went home. But they often did not follow up with a patent application, allowing their inventions to fall into the public domain.
Apart from the questions about the chain of title, the technology must have commercial potential. "We discard more Russian technology than we take," Mr. Lipman said. "It may be great science, but there's not enough commercial potential. Or it's already being done here and the Russians don't realize it."
But if the Americans are interested, they will do a market analysis of the sales potential of the invention. Since the Russians have no hard currency, the American brokers pay for the patents and marketing. That can be risky because the licenses might not pay off. But if they do, the royalties could roll in for years with few continuing costs.
"There's never been an opportunity like this before, and probably won't be again," said Mr. Gamer, of Scientific Dimensions. "It's like discovering Atlantis." 
 
 
SO WHOSE IDEA IS IT, ANYWAY?
 AMERICANS are not the only ones fixating on dreams of lucrative royalties from Russian technologies -- European and Japanese companies are also rushing to cash in.
But the Americans say the race is not just against time and a crowded field. The bigger hurdle is trying to overcome the legacy of Soviet red tape and a Russian system that has not yet settled on new business laws and practices.
"It's frustrating, definitely a challenge," said Herman J. Hohauser, president of the American Group for Innovation and Technology Inc., a technology brokerage company based in Washington. "There are so many people there who say they have technology they want to transfer. We've got a bunch waiting, but we want to be sure we're dealing with reputable people."
Mr. Hohauser speaks from painful experience.
"I signed a contract with a company in Russia called Altair Holdings, which assured me it had the rights to about 30 Russian military technologies," he said with a sigh. "But in the first technology we're working on, the ownership issue has become a quagmire."
Altair Holdings had offered rights to a formula for ultra-dispersive powders, sometimes called nanophase powders because they are composed of particles measuring a billionth of an inch. Mr. Hohauser said the formula could be used in paints to enhance color and density.
"When we asked for samples of the material, another man from outside Altair appeared and intimated he was the real inventor," Mr. Hohauser said. "Now we're in the middle of trying to find out who owns this technology." He could not guess how long that might take.
Others say they believe wild-goose chases over a title can sometimes be tests to determine if Western executives have staying power.
"If they smell you and like you, to use a Russian term, then they'll give you something horrible to follow up on to see if you can cut the mustard," said Charles A. Gamer Jr., president of Scientific Dimensions U.S.A. Inc., another American brokerage concern.
Sometimes, "there could be 15 guys pursuing the same worthless technology," Mr. Gamer said.

HEADLINE: CUTTINGS;
How Thirsty Plants Struggle to Survive

BYLINE: By Anne Raver

 BODY:
THE cows in New Jersey are so hot they don't feel like making milk. The drought in Georgia has deep-sixed the corn. And it almost looks like fall in Central Park.
What the ground needs is a slow, steady rain that lasts about a week. A sudden heavy downpour will run right off hard-packed soil that in some cases is dry four feet down. 
 "Some trees have lost most of their leaves," said Tobi Bergman, the park's tree-care coordinator. "The London planes are particularly hard hit. The lawns are all brown, and we're trying our best to save the shrubs."
Though New York City's Department of Environmental Protection has not declared a drought emergency -- or imposed the water restrictions that ensue -- the city's eight reservoirs and three lakes are low. The normal reservoir level for this time of year is 88.7 percent, but it is down to 73.5 percent.
"We're definitely concerned, but we're not that close to declaring a drought," said Ian Michaels, a spokesman for the department. "The last time we declared a drought -- the spring of 1992 -- we were 25 percentage points below normal."
He added: "If we did declare a drought, it's at least three weeks away -- and that's if we went without any rain at all."
Meanwhile, it sure looks like a drought out there.
"The ground is so baked, our turf specialist said his teeth almost rattled out of his head when he had to mow," said Edmond Moulin, the director of horticulture at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. "The colloids of clay in the soil have pulled together so tight, the ground is just like adobe. It's cracked in some places."
And when soil is that dry, there's not a drop of water left for plants, especially when hot weather is increasing their transpiration. Under normal conditions, plants draw water up from the soil as they photosynthesize, taking carbon dioxide from the air, and release oxygen and water vapor through openings in the leaves called stomates.
"Plants have an incredibly strong ability to pull water in from the soil even when it appears to be quite dry," said Dr. Wayt Thomas, a botanist at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. "But when the amount of moisture gets so low, plants can't draw up any more, they will start to shut down and the leaves will wilt."
Leaves wilt partly because there simply isn't enough water in their cells to keep them turgid, and partly out of self-defense.
"The plant will cut its losses, shed its leaves and preserve what energy it has left for twigs and stems," Dr. Thomas said. "Not much water can get out through the bark."
So what's a gardener to do? Water, of course, but choose your rescue efforts well. If you need to conserve water, forget the lawn.
"Worry about the grass last; the grass will come back if it's well established," said Mr. Moulin at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. "I've never seen a whole lawn die out anywhere, though you may have bare spots and weeds, which always seem to find enough moisture to grow."
You can help out your lawn by mowing a lot less. "If it gets real high, maybe take off just half an inch," Mr. Moulin said. "But unless it gets too weedy -- kind of seedy-looking -- keep it about three and a half inches high."
Brittle grass does not need a good shave to add to its stress. Nor does it need the wheels of a lawn mower rolling over it. Don't even walk on it, if you can help it. (Ever notice how you can leave footprints in a dry lawn? That's because it doesn't have the turgor, or pressure from fluids in its cells, to spring back.) And please, don't fertilize a dry lawn. You don't want to push the poor thing into growing more when it's dying of thirst.
"Never apply fertilizer to anything when the soil is dry," Mr. Moulin said. "And that includes soluble fertilizer. If the soil is too dry, the soluble salts could end up taking water out of the plant."
Sarah Price, curator of the Conservatory Garden in Central Park, said the priorities during dry spells are trees, shrubs and lawns, in that order.
"It's an economic issue, but it's also a structural one," she said. "If you lose your annuals, that's sad, but you can replant next year."
Ms. Price has 50-year-old lilacs and 30-year-old azaleas with wilting leaves in her garden. "Usually, you don't have to water such established plants," she said.
Mr. Moulin said the Brooklyn Botanic Garden has been watering new trees and plants put in this year on a weekly basis. "But even the old ones are showing stress," he said. "Our Oriental summersweet is really flagging. So are the azaleas and rhododendrons." When veterans like these get crispy leaves, it's a sign that even their deep roots are coming up with zero.
So lay a hose at the base of a flagging tree and just let it drip slowly for a few hours. This method avoids the evaporation that occurs with a sprinkler, and puts precious water just where you want it. If you have a sprinkler, leave it on long enough to give your plants an inch of water a week. Put some coffee cans around the area to see how much accumulates over a period of time.
"If things are really dried out to the point of wilted, I put the water on for a couple hours," Ms. Price said.
Dr. Thomas advised: "Water deep. Let it soak in a long time." One of the worst things you can do for plants is to water frequently for short periods of time, because superficial watering encourages shallow roots. Water deeply and roots will follow that moisture deep into the ground.
Everything should be mulched, of course, with an inch or two of some organic material like wood chips, cocoa hulls, pine needles, shredded leaves or salt hay, to keep whatever moisture there is in the ground.
"Touch up the bare spots, especially around the base of the plant, where the mulch has washed away, or maybe you planted it too high anyway," said James Cross, a nurseryman on the North Fork of Long Island. Mr. Cross can't say enough about the importance of good topsoil and compost. "I can show you gardens out here that haven't gotten a drop of water and they're in great shape," he said.
So if you're planning a new garden or lawn for next spring, invest in good topsoil this fall: eight inches to a foot and a half. Add another four inches of compost. It may seem expensive now, but good soil, which holds moisture and nutrients, is life insurance in a drought.

HEADLINE: ENGAGEMENTS;
Miss Handwerger And Mr. Large

 BODY:
Gretchen M. Handwerger of Paris and Joseph Handwerger of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Chapman Handwerger to Curtis Eugene Large, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Wayne T. Large of Ann Arbor, Mich. An October wedding is planned.
Miss Handwerger, 25, and her fiance, 23, are associate consultants at Bain & Company, the management consulting firm in Boston. They graduated from Yale University, she cum laude. 
 Her father is the principal of Joseph Handwerger Architects, in Washington. Her mother, a former deputy director of the Peace Corps, is with the World Bank as the special representative to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris.
Mr. Large's mother teaches history at the Central Middle School in Plymouth, Mich. His father is the director of the Wesley Foundation, the church ministry at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Lexus Weighs In With a 'Gran' Sedan

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
IT occurs to me that it has been a good long while since I have heard Detroit automakers whine about "perceived quality."
What that phrase meant to the executives who were wringing their hands through much of the last decade was a misguided public's notion that Japanese cars were simply better, no matter the actual quality of domestic cars. 
 Charitably, one could say Detroit was wrong. Or, more likely, disingenuous.
The executives did have to sell cars, after all. And the reason we don't hear the same old cry is that the Big Three have finally done something about quality. American automobiles are closing in on the imports, in the way they are built and in the way they are sold.
Ford was the first to make a serious effort with its popular Taurus. The rejuvenated Chrysler Corporation then came nipping at its heels and now has terrific products in the form of the LH sedans. And General Motors formed a new subsidiary, Saturn, to retake lost territory.
Still, it took Toyota, Nissan and Honda to light the way. After Honda created its Acura luxury division, Nissan countered with Infiniti, and Toyota weighed in with Lexus, perhaps the most polished series of new cars in history.
Lexus continues to dominate the surveys for quality and satisfaction, and the latest of those, the 1993 J. D. Power and Associates customer satisfaction index, shows Lexus in the top spot for the third year in a row. The California market research firm based its results on responses from 31,000 owners of 1992 and early '93 cars and trucks, and Toyota-produced vehicles accounted for 6 of the top 12 models.
Lexus appeared on the scene in 1989 with the LS 400 sedan, and the line has evolved into SC 400 and SC 300 coupes and an ES 300 sedan. This year, too, there is a new GS 300 sedan.
And if all those alphanumerics are as confusing to you as they are to me, remember that Toyota has adopted the Mercedes way of doing things, and the letters stand for the body style, and the numbers reflect the size of the engine.
What that means is that an LS is a luxury sedan; SC stands for sport coupe; ES is an executive sedan (whatever that is), and the GS is a gran sedan. The 400 series carries a 4-liter V8, and the 300 stands for a 3-liter six. All clear? Good.
For 1993, the four-door GS 300 fills the gap in the line that occurred over the last several years when the LS 400 moved farther upscale and gained a sticker that currently reads $47,000. With a base price of $37,500 ($42,263 as tested), the GS 300 puts Lexus back where it started.
It also puts the car into competition with some heavy-hitter imports, among them BMW's 5-series models, Saab's 9000 Aero, and, to some extent, the Mercedes 300E. But the Lexus is considerably longer and wider than any of those and has more interior stretch in most of its measurements.
The maroon tester (Prussian red pearl, excuse me) with its body-colored bumpers, blackout trim, molded wheels and front air dam, was a very rounded car with a wedge-shaped profile that reflected its origins in the Italian design studio of Giorgio Giugiaro.
A high rear end emphasizes the pleasing and aerodynamic wedge, but the tall rump has its price, too. Liftover for the medium-sized trunk is at bumper height -- but the bumper is so high that back strain is a possibility.
Dual exhausts emit a nice tone under that bumper, and the engine they serve is a twin-cam 24-valve in-line six. Its 3 liters produce 220 horsepower and 210 foot-pounds of torque, which is sufficient but not overly muscular in a car that taxes the scales at 3,652 pounds. Antilock brakes are standard.
Considering the car's heft, too, fuel economy is reasonable if not great, and the 21-gallon tank doles out its premium contents at a rate of one gallon for each 18 miles, city, and 23, highway.
Like all Lexi, the GS 300 is a rear-wheel-drive model, and the engine's power feeds through a four-speed automatic transmission. Zero-to-60 acceleration takes slightly more than nine seconds, but the car feels quicker than that when you are tromping the accelerator at the highway's on-ramp. Out there in traffic, the Lexus hush takes hold. This is an extremely quiet car, and it ladles on the comfort, particularly if you like isolation with your jam.
If you care to make noise, though, the entire hub of the four-spoked wheel serves as a horn, a real safety feature in these days of tiny and hard-to-find buttons. The hub houses an air bag, and another bag protects the front passenger, occupying a space in the top of the dash over a medium-size glovebox.
When you turn the ignition off, the steering column automatically tilts up and out of the way to make exit easier, returning to its preset position the next time the key is turned. The usual power-everything is standard in the GS 300, and the ergonomics put some of the competition to shame.
The window buttons are in the driver's armrest, where they should be, and a padded armrest in the center console is replete with dual cupholders. The standard sound system is an impressive 225-watt unit, but if that's not good enough for you, the test car's 280-watt Nakamichi setup with a compact-disk changer in the trunk can be had for a mere $1,900 more.
The upholstery is leather, of course -- cream colored in the maroon test car -- and real walnut trim offers the counterpoint.
The GS 300 can seat five, but that is a nominal figure, and four is more realistic, given the car's high driveshaft hump, which would put the middle-rear passenger's knees in the vicinity of his or her chin. Otherwise, though, there is good room in the back, and the seat has a fold-down center armrest. The rear windows provide one of the few nits to pick in the car, however, because they go down only halfway.
Up front, it's another story, and there is nothing not to like. The reclining buckets are thoroughly comfortable, the driving position is excellent, and the vista inside and out is just plain satisfying.
If Detroit hadn't said differently for all those years, I'd know I was perceiving quality.

HEADLINE: Study Doesn't Prove Beer Harms Students

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Alcohol's Effect on Learning," a "Blackboard" item in your Aug. 1 Education Life supplement, reports on a study by two Duke University professors, but fails to probe shortcomings of the research.
This study is one more overreaching, simplistic attempt to justify massive beer tax increases as the panacea for a problem that has much deeper roots. The study creates an illusory cause-and-effect link between academic success, the level of state beer taxes and the availability of beer to young people. It trivializes a problem of educational decline that is rooted in the changing -- some might say weakening -- social, political, environmental and economic fabrics of our society. 
 Student test scores and achievement are suffering for reasons far more complicated than those espoused by the Duke study.
Beer taxes are already highly regressive, meaning that their impact is greatest on middle- and lower-income families. Beer is taxed three times higher than most other consumer goods. No reliable studies have ever established a link between higher taxes and lower rates of alcohol abuse. The Duke study's recommendation to raise taxes is not an effective or appropriate response to declining academic achievement.
Problems of alcohol abuse by young people require real solutions, like intensive, objective alcohol education.
 
WILLIAM L. SCHREIBER
President, Beer Drinkers
of America and Party Smart
Costa Mesa, Calif., Aug. 2, 1993

LENGTH: 312 words

HEADLINE: Joining Technology And the Work Force

 BODY:
The article "For Law Graduates, a Scarcity of Jobs" (New Jersey Q & A, July 11), is more evidence of the growing need in this country for an integrated employment agency.
With the combination of new technologies, along with downsizing and re-engineering of jobs, the greatest threat to the American work force has become its own increased productivity. An example of this could be seen when Martin Allen attributed the scarcity of jobs for lawyers in New Jersey to their own efficiency. 
 In this age of total quality management, we are beginning to see more and more tasks that in the past took 30 employees 25 days to complete now take one employee one hour. Technology is such that General Motors could construct a mile-long plant that is run by three people. If we are to remain a competitive nation, our work force must be prepared and adapted to these changes.
The problem has become one of a lack of harmonization. The work force is filled with potential workers who have been prepared and oriented toward positions that either do not exist or will not exist any longer. The job market, on the other hand, is filled with positions that require skills and abilities that are at the moment scarce.
The result is a high need for employees coupled with high unemployment and no vehicle for reconciling these two situations. An integrated employment agency, which could harmonize the work force with the needs of business not only today but also 5 and 10 years into the future, could be this vehicle.
An integrated employment agency that could link the business community and schools through an intelligence network would help to tailor tomorrow's work force to business's future needs. By giving employers more input into the preparation of their future employees, schools could be preparing students for tomorrow's jobs.
 
MARC ESPOSITO
Staten Island
