HEADLINE: Clinton Is Pulled From the Brink. He'll Be Back.

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE margin could not have been thinner or the stakes higher. One switched vote in the Senate or the House of Representatives, and Bill Clinton would have lost his economic package and perhaps his Presidency. So all the bargaining in the great souk on Capitol Hill over the last three months, all the searching for backbone by legislators terrified of the electoral guillotine, clearly was worth it.
Thursday's and Friday's gut-wrenching roll-call victories represented a down payment on Mr. Clinton's campaign and inaugural promises to get the country moving again. Failure would have made the President look impotent on the economic issues that stand quite clearly at the center of national politics. He has avoided that, although the urgency of taming the deficit has allowed him little room for the innovative programs and redirection of Government that he and his party are committed to seek. 
 Whether his victories really represent a turning point for the Republic, a departure down a new road of fiscal sanity, as so many Democratic orators argued last week, is another question.
Although most of the new taxes will be borne by the rich, as Mr. Clinton's Technicolor pie charts showed, the package comes nowhere near undoing Ronald Reagan's tax breaks for the wealthy. It leaves the tax burden in the United States far less onerous than those in most other Western nations. If the electorate is as serious as it tells itself it is about eliminating the deficit and cutting the national debt, it will eventually have to accept far more than this modest effort to increase revenues.
It will also have to support far deeper spending cuts and there are only a few categories where such savings can be found -- mainly in military outlays, where significant cuts are under way, and in so-called entitlement spending, on Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid and the like, where they aren't.
But the great lesson of the passage of Bill Clinton's proposals through what is laughably referred to here as the legislative process is that neither broad new taxes nor painful spending cuts can be achieved in the political environment that now exists in the United States. Mr. Clinton's energy tax and his fallback proposal for a significant increase in the gasoline tax both had to be jettisoned to keep Senator Herb Kohl of Wisconsin on board. Other legislators demanded and got breaks for favored constituencies.
"It's a start," the Democrats say. Projected spending would be reduced by more than $250 billion over the next five years (though most of the cuts would come later than that, and the President and Congress may be tempted to cut the cuts as their effective dates draw near). The other half of the package will come, in large part, from raising the top income tax rate to 36 from 31 percent (with a surcharge on those with taxable incomes above $250,000), as well as small increases in the gasoline tax and in corporate tax rates.
Struggles With Soloists
Still, the plan does not envision eliminating the deficit; indeed, the Administration's own figures show the deficit rising again after five years. If Mr. Clinton is still in office then, the chances that he will attack again are minimal. Second-term Presidents are seldom innovators, partly because Congress, knowing that they can't run again to gain a fresh mandate, won't let them be.
It may be that Mr. Clinton was rolled by Congress, that he caved in too soon on some issues, thereby convincing Senators and Representatives that they could get what they wanted if they held out long enough. Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who provided the decisive vote in the Senate, said the President had been dangerously "green" when he came to Washington, but surely he assigned an insufficient portion of the blame to his own colleagues when he urged Mr. Clinton to "say no to us; get us back onto the high ground where we actually prefer to be."
Mr. Clinton had as hard a time as he did partly because members of Congress in the modern era, even members of the President's party, tend to see themselves as soloists. Like primadonnas everywhere, they demand pampering. A senior White House official commented with disgust on Friday that many freshman House members demanded to talk to the President personally.
If the Democrats threw tantrums, the Republicans sulked in a corner. Historians at the Library of Congress and elsewhere could remember no major piece of legislation at least since World War II that was passed without a single vote from the opposition party. Meanwhile, the public continued on its fickle way. People demand that the deficit be cut, the polls said. They are willing to bear their fair share, the polls said. But to judge by the uproar that rose every time the lawmakers suggested a tuck here or a trim there, they defined "fair" as "infinitesimal." It was entirely appropriate that one poll on the eve of the final vote showed that 43 percent of the electorate wanted the economic package passed and 44 percent did not. The country was right where the legislators were: split down the middle. It must not be as simple to fix this automobile as Ross Perot says it is.
Armageddon Can Wait
With most of his agenda still awaiting action, Mr. Clinton bravely insisted, "The margin was close, but the mandate is clear." In fact, the path ahead is less visible this weekend than it seemed to be when the President took office. Health-care reform is absolutely vital to Mr. Clinton's plans and to the Democrats' future. If the deficit is not to skyrocket once again, Medicaid and Medicare and the cost of private health insurance must be brought under control.
The search for funding has led the Administration toward some sort of fee system. Last week's debates suggest that anything like that will be seen as an indirect tax and, as such, political poison. A member of the Senate leadership commented "if this was Guadalcanal, passing health care is likely to be Armageddon if we're not careful."
Bob Dole, who likes to posture as the ax murderer of American politics, knows that his party eventually has to stand for some things and not just against everything the President wants. Already, the Republicans have been forced to give way on Mr. Clinton's national service program, and on Friday night, Mr. Dole made a point of suggesting that on some of the big tests to come -- he mentioned the North American Free Trade Agreement, and he might have mentioned welfare reform -- some of the President's best friends will be Republicans.
Perhaps Mr. Clinton has broken through a psychological if not a political barrier by passing an economic package with at least a family resemblance to the one he wanted. Perhaps things will be different in Washington now. But much of the country doesn't like this budget, thinks it will hurt the middle class, whatever Mr. Clinton says, thinks the President is doing a lackluster job and mistrusts most things the Government does.
It is that pervasive lack of confidence that Mr. Clinton must now assail, hoping all the while that his economic medicine works. The stakes are not small. A man who would like to unseat him in 1996, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, gleefully stated the alternative on Friday night: "I believe thousands of people are going to lose their jobs. I believe Bill Clinton will be one of those people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vice President Al Gore patting President Clinton on the back after the House of Representatives narrowly approved Mr. Clinton's five-year economic plan. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Forget About Lotus Land. Thank You for Not Smoking.

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
AS a boy, Roger Diamond sometimes snatched the cigarette from his mother's mouth and demanded that she quit her "disgusting habit." As he grew older, he took to carrying a water pistol with him to squirt at smokers. Naturally he became a lawyer, and he made it his business to agitate, in vain, to make jury rooms smoke-free.
Today Mr. Diamond is a successful criminal lawyer, but his heart is still in his anti-smoking campaign. And now he is tasting one of his greatest victories as a ban on smoking took effect in all restaurants throughout Los Angeles last week. He is not the leader, but he is one of the most dedicated soldiers in what is just the latest, but perhaps the most authoritarian, in this state's long history of health crusades. 
 After years of struggle, the Los Angeles City Council passed the restaurant-smoking ban last month. It has survived, for now, a petition challenge by opponents, and amid much confusion at restaurants big and small, it took effect.
Mr. Diamond was expansive the other evening, relaxing at home in sweat clothes after his yoga lesson, with a giant bowl of no-salt, no-butter popcorn on his lap and the Pacific Ocean lying calm beneath his picture window.
" 'Stop poisoning me,' I say to these people, 'Stop,' " he said.
He is aware of the clash of California cultures his passions embody: health fanaticism meets do your own thing. In recent years, pushed by people like Mr. Diamond, anti-pollution measures have threatened to encroach on power mowers and outdoor barbecues. Automobile emissions have been strictly regulated. But smoking is pollution at its most personal, and people here don't like being told what to do.
"It's totally wrong, totally wrong," said Martine Varlet, manager of Modo Mio restaurant in the affluent Pacific Palisades area. "When I heard of it, I said, 'No way.' I don't have to argue with customers any more; this law did the job for me. But I still don't think it's right."
As California has become more congested, with traffic jams sometimes stretching the entire 100 miles from Los Angeles to San Diego, the nation's westward migration has shown signs of reversing itself, with people heading east to Arizona, Utah or Wyoming for open spaces and jobs. Those who stay behind remain in a region increasingly defined by its problems -- pollution, congestion, crime, economic decline and an influx of immigrants -- and many are ready to embrace limits.
 
Lobbying Against Limits
 "In California we do our own thing; I believe in that very strongly," said Mr. Diamond. "But you have to have regulation. You have to tell people what to do, because we don't have a perfect society."
Not surprisingly, California is a leader in the nation's anti-smoking movement. Of the 70 jurisdictions to ban smoking in restaurants nationwide, 60 are in California. Los Angeles is the biggest city yet to institute the ban, over the strenuous lobbying of the tobacco industry. Ten other California cities are set to consider similar measures in the next month.
The battle is being fought simultaneously at the statewide level as two competing regulatory bills make their way through the legislature, one of them supported by smokers and one by non-smokers.
Yet of all the state's problems, of all the issues that call for regulation, it is immigration, both legal and illegal, that has most seized people's attention today. And it is these demographic shifts that will do the most to redefine California, especially Southern California, in the years to come.
"We've been the leader in California," Mr. Diamond said with enthusiasm. "Frozen yogurt came from California. Tofu did. Jogging came from California."
But these are not the foods or the pastimes of a large portion of the swelling immigrant population that has turned whole neighborhoods of the city into dislocated fragments of El Salvador, Mexico, Guatemala, Armenia or Korea. Smoking is not their issue.
Its prominence is one more reminder that the political agenda here is changing more slowly than the population and that in a city like Los Angeles, where minorities make up nearly half the residents, a white Mayor can be elected with a base of support among white voters in outlying areas.
"In a way, it's a class thing," Mr. Diamond said of the anti-smoking campaign. The immigrant population has other concerns. But as immigrants assimilate, they embrace as well as change the culture of their new home, taking on a society shaped by the California enthusiasms of personal fulfillment and a readiness to look beyond jogging and tofu to embrace any other new fads and philosophies.
Ms. Varlet of the Modo Mio restaurant is herself an immigrant, from France, and she revels in individualism. As she takes the corners of Sunset Boulevard or breezes up the highway, she refuses to wear her seat belt as the law requires, challenging the police to ticket her.
When they do, she lectures them on personal freedom, and in return, they give her a lesson in the kinds of controls that are strapping in the residents of California for their own good, like seat belts and smoking laws.
"They just say, 'Madam, it's the law,' " Ms. Varlet said in disappointment. "They are not sensitive to feminine charm. This is supposed to be the land of freedom, but it's all an illusion."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Puerto Rico's Identity, Up for a Vote

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico

 BODY:
IN little more than three months, Puerto Ricans will be asked whether they prefer to become the 51st state, remain a commonwealth or seek independence. The campaign leading up to the vote is barely under way, but it is clear that partisans of all three options are also grappling with an underlying question: What does it mean to be a Puerto Rican?
Ever since the United States seized this lush Caribbean island in 1898 as booty of the Spanish-American War, the relationship between the mainland and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico has been marked by ambivalence on both sides. Puerto Ricans have often seemed unsure whether to regard themselves as Americans, Latin Americans or both. 
 Many on the mainland evidently find it difficult to regard a mixed-race, Spanish-speaking society with a per capita annual income of just over $6,000 as truly being part of America.
If it were a state, Puerto Rico would have more members in Congress than 25 states. Since its 3.7 million people do not live in a state, they do not pay Federal taxes and they have their own Olympic team. But they still can be drafted.
The plebiscite comes at a moment when Puerto Ricans are being sharply reminded of their second-class colonial status. With only symbolic representation in Congress and unable to vote in Federal elections unless they live on the mainland, they watched impotently as the Clinton Administration and Congress, intent on reducing the budget deficit, hacked away at the corporate tax exemptions that have been the backbone of the local economy for the last 40 years.
As a result, Puerto Rican subsidiaries of mainland companies saw the reduction of the 100 percent income credit that encouraged many to locate here. The companies will now be expected to pay $3.75 billion in Federal taxes during the next five years, which, leaders here fear, could encourage them to shift their operatons to Mexico to benefit from the North American Free Trade Agreement. Washington has offered little in compensation from the expected losses. Furthermore, the Nov. 14 vote is not binding, so that even if the statehood option wins narrowly, as many here predict, Congress could reject the island's petition to join the union.
 
A Plebiscite or an Opinion Poll?
 From 1989 through 1991 both the Senate and the House, urged on by the Bush Administration, debated legislation that would have established a binding plebiscite. In the end they failed to take action, fueling the suspicion here that Congress is simply unwilling to add a 51st star to the flag. "Statehood is contrary to the national interest of the United States," said Ruben Berrios, head of the Puerto Rican Independence Party. "That is why there was no plebiscite."
Largely because of that experience, Puerto Ricans cannot even agree what to call the upcoming vote. Gov. Pedro Rossello of the pro-statehood New Progressive Party has called it both a "plebiscite" and a "referendum." On the other hand, the Popular Democratic Party, which favors commonwealth, refers to it as an "opinion poll" or "consultation," implicitly downgrading its importance. Carlos Noriega Rodriguez, head of the Puerto Rico Bar Association, dismisses it as "a sterile exercise," while some independence supporters recently complained to the United Nations that the vote is "a colonial mechanism" and "an attempt at deception."
Every President since Truman has supported the notion of self-determination for Puerto Rico, but then again, the White House would only have to make a decision on Puerto Rico's status should Congress approve statehood. "Whatever they decide, I will support," Mr. Clinton said last month on "Larry King Live." "I think they, the people of Puerto Rico, should decide."
But exactly what constitutes "the people of Puerto Rico" is the subject of some debate. Mr. Rossello wants to limit participation to Puerto Ricans who live on the island. Both the commonwealth and independence parties argue, however, that the 2.6 million Puerto Ricans who live on the mainland, more than half of them in New York and vicinity, must also be granted voting rights if the result is to have any meaning.
 
San Juan or Timbuktu
 "We believe that Puerto Ricans are a nationality apart and distinct from the rest of the world," said Sen. Eudaldo Baez Galib, a commonwealth supporter. "It doesn't matter whether they live in San Juan, New York or Timbuktu."
Not surprisingly, many mainland Puerto Ricans also take that position.. "This is not an election for state assemblyman or to raise taxes," said Representative Jose Serrano of the Bronx, one of three Puerto Ricans in Congress. "This is a vote that may determine for all time the future of an entire people."
Puerto Ricans on the mainland "are as much Puerto Ricans as people on the island," he said. "Some of us were born on the mainland. Some of us came with our families. But all of us who live on the mainland do so as a result of the relationship between the United States and Puerto Rico, and we deserve to have our voices heard."
Opposition parties have a vested interest in that position because they believe that support for commonwealth and independence is even stronger among mainland Puerto Ricans than here on the island. Differences of class and race further cloud the issue: A slogan proclaims that "statehood is for the poor."
Mr. Rossello says the issue is a matter of residence, not nationality. Explaining why he intends to exclude Puerto Ricans on the mainland from the vote, he said, "You would not expect people born in California who now live in New York to get on a plane and go to California and vote in whatever referendums are decided there. That is not acceptable."
But Mr. Rossello and his party risk alienating mainland Puerto Ricans, who they expect to lead the charge for statehood in Congress after November. "Some of us are kind of ticked off by all of this," said Angelo Falcon, president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy in New York. "How can the Government of Puerto Rico ask us to support them on the tax benefits program and then go back to Puerto Rico and draft a bill that does not allow us to vote? It makes us feel like the black sheep in the family."

HEADLINE: Call It Baseball or Call It Business, It's Still Booming

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
AS the bids soared in the auction of the Baltimore Orioles baseball team last week in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, one of the many lawyers in the standing-room-only courtroom smiled gleefully and said in a stage whisper, "Keep going, guys. I like it, I like it."
The lawyer happened to represent one of the Orioles' minority owners, Sargent Shriver, who profited handsomely from the winning $173 million bid. But in another sense, baseball profited, too. 
 The price tag, a record for an American sports team, caught the attention of fans and non-fans alike. The message they got was that baseball is not in danger of imminent demise, despite what they had been hearing from doom-sayers within the game itself.
Baseball has this internal problem: Some officials want to celebrate the positives -- the record number of people flocking to games, the excitement of the division races, the attractive young players. Others only seem to emphasize the negatives -- the high player salaries, the disparities in economic status among the 28 teams, the impending drop in television revenue.
Perhaps the real problem is that the major leagues don't have a commissioner to set the tone. They have played without one for 11 months since they forced Fay Vincent to resign. No replacement appears to be in sight yet.
But the game goes on. Entering the weekend, 47.5 million fans had attended major league games this season. That's a 22.5 percent increase from last season, and not all of it is attributable to the two new teams, the Colorado Rockies and the Florida Marlins. Even if their attendance were deducted and the old National League method of counting fans were used, attendance would still be up by 4.4 percent.
The Rockies have quickly developed into a phenomenon as awesome as the mountains they took their name from. They already have drawn 3.2 million fans and could entertain an additional 1.5 million, shattering the major league record of slightly more than 4 million the Toronto Blue Jays set last year.
The Blue Jays should surpass 4 million again, and five other teams are on a pace to reach the 3 million plateau. Never have more than three teams made it to 3 million. Furthermore, for only the fourth time ever, every team has reached 1 million.
Those fans have been treated to the performances of players like Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants, Ken Griffey Jr. of the Seattle Mariners, Juan Gonzalez of the Texas Rangers, Frank Thomas of the Chicago White Sox and Albert Belle of the Cleveland Indians. They have seen Bonds and a new owner, Peter Magowan, resuscitate the Giants into an exciting first-place team, the Philadelphia Phillies go from worst in their division to first in it, John Olerud of the Blue Jays and Andres Galarraga of the Rockies threaten to become the first since Ted Williams in 1941 to hit .400, Griffey hit home runs in eight consecutive games and tie a record.
They have even seen a revival of the Yankees in the Bronx, which George Steinbrenner is threatening to abandon. Last week's four-game series with the Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium attracted a total of 192,000 fans, showing that when a team plays games that count, fans will come, even to a stadium in the Bronx.
"There's no question baseball's picture is rosier than what some people are trying to paint," said Donald Fehr, head of the players' union and chief skeptic of the gloom-and-doom view of the game. "That doesn't mean it's free from troubles, but you don't see an industry in imminent danger of financial collapse -- which is what some of them like to picture. We always say: watch their actions, not their words."
Richard Ravitch, chief labor executive for the club owners, has painted the bleakest picture, using it to support his effort to increase revenue sharing among the owners and get players' salaries capped.
"We are losing a competitive position for the entertainment dollar," Ravitch said. "Television revenues are coming down. There is great disparity between the clubs." As for the $173 million purchase of the Orioles, he said: "That's what the market says the Orioles are worth. It doesn't say anything about the value of the other 27 clubs."
No team, however, has sold for less than its previous sale price. No team has languished without a buyer.
If baseball officials want to look for a potential problem, they could glance at their labor relations. Management is insisting that it won't happen, but players are discussing with increasing seriousness the possibility of striking next month.
The owners meet at a resort in Wisconsin this week to try to agree on a plan for more revenue sharing. It would be contingent on the players' accepting a salary cap. The players, who want no part of that, feel they may have to stage a pre-emptive strike, threatening the owners' hefty post-season television payoff and preventing them from changing the work rules during the winter or locking them out of training camps next spring.
The fans, though, aren't thinking about the season ending prematurely; like the players in a pennant race, they're taking it one game at a time.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Even Castro Sees the Possibilities of Enterprise in Cuba

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
WHILE debate heats up in the United States over the wisdom of continuing to turn a cold shoulder toward President Fidel Castro, a consensus is growing among American business executives and academics that major changes are inevitable in Cuba, ones likely to transform the island into a lucrative new business frontier.
Many of the executives and scholars say Cuba's badly wasting economy will soon be cast open one way or another, be it through the continued crumbling and eventual collapse of Mr. Castro's Communist system or through some kind of constructive engagement initiated by the United States to encourage faster reforms. The latter course is being urged on the Clinton Administration with increasing forcefulness by advocates of a new approach toward the island after 33 years of economic embargo and political ostracism. 
 Forced to introduce limited reforms by near-disastrous economic conditions brought on in large part by the collapse of his Soviet bloc benefactors, Mr. Castro has already begun welcoming mixed ventures with Western companies. More boldly, though, the Cuban leader has recently allowed citizens to spend dollars and other foreign currencies legally for the first time -- both a recognition of the power of the black market and an attempt to dry it up. Meanwhile, he has invited Cuban-Americans to visit the island in much greater numbers in the hope that their free-spending ways will provide a boost. Many expect the next step to be greater freedom for individual Cubans to engage in private enterprise legally.
American policy-makers are debating whether encouraging such reforms would promote an orderly transition from the Communist order, as opposed to its catastrophic collapse, which might place an economic rebirth through capitalism out of reach for a long time. The voices arguing for a diplomatic opening are gaining force, but the Clinton Administration seems in no rush to pronounce itself on such a controversial topic, having only recently assembled its Latin American foreign policy staff after a long interregnum tended by Bush Administration holdovers. In the meantime, conservatives in the Cuban exile community and their allies in Congress stand as committed to a hard-line approach as ever.
Still, prospective investors have quietly begun sizing up the opportunities for American capital.
In the short term, the fast-expanding Cuban tourism industry, exploiting the island's readily accessible natural beauty, would appear to offer the safest bet for new American investments, along with basic industries like public transportation and food. Beyond those, the Cuban economy presents a long list of needs waiting to be filled by longer-term investments in areas from housing to manufacturing.
Many of the best deals, however, are already being locked up by competitors in Europe, Canada, Mexico and Jamaica.
 
Plums Already Plucked
 "Almost all of the hotels in Havana are already gone," said Arlene Alligood, a Washington-based consultant who publishes the newsletter Cuba Business. She noted a Spanish company's recent takeover of the former Havana Hilton. "Once the major investments are taken, they are taken for a generation or more. American companies are going to wake up and find themselves at a disastrous disadvantage."
If many plums have already been plucked by European and Canadian interests, the scope of Cuba's needs and its proximity to the United States would present both countries with an unusually rich blend of opportunities. A recent study by Johns Hopkins University estimated that the United States could expect to do $2 billion in business with Cuba in the first year of an economic opening, a figure that could rapidly rise to $7 billion annually or more.
"You are talking about a semi-industrialized country of 11 million people that is 90 miles away from Florida and that desperately needs to be brought into the 21st century," said Joseph Strain, chief of the Jacksonville Port Authority, who has visited Cuba twice to scout opportunities there. "That means rebuilding railroads, phone systems, electrical systems, you name it. We are talking about hundreds of millions of dollars of merchandise."
Mr. Strain said that an opening of the Cuban market to American commerce would mean that the rate of growth of Florida's ports in terms of the value of goods handled would easily double.
Experts say there would be other important opportunities beyond commerce -- for example, insuring the safety of Cuba's nuclear energy program. The United States has expressed concerns about a half-built Soviet-designed nuclear power plant at Cienfuegos, which the Cuban Government says it is committed to completing to alleviate severe energy shortages. Strapped for capital and hard-pressed to proceed alone, however, it has also said it would welcome American participation in the plant's management; that would help to guarantee that international safety standards are stringently observed.
Similarly, American companies could help market Cuban-designed pharmaceutical goods currently unavailable in the United States, from meningitis and hepatitis vaccines to livestock drugs. Although Cuba invested large sums to develop selected pharmaceuticals, it now lacks the wherewithal to distribute them abroad effectively.
Experts on Cuba caution that a simple ending of sanctions would not alone produce miracles, and in any case the United States is unlikely to lift the embargo imposed in 1960 by President Eisenhower without conditions.
For Cuba to take full advantage of any such easing of American policy, they say, it would have to introduce far more sweeping changes, all involving much larger political gambles than the Cuban Government has so far shown itself willing to take. Herein, for those urging a more supple approach, lies the logic of engaging Cuba now on trade.
Analysts of Cuban affairs point out that the country is prevented from buying most of the goods it needs not by American sanctions but by the island's own collapsing production and lack of cash.
"The Cubans would quickly be forced to admit that most of their problems do not stem from the embargo at all," said Jorge Dominguez, a Harvard University scholar who specializes in Cuban affairs. "Then it quickly becomes a blunt question for the Cuban Government of all of the changes they would need to undertake to begin attracting the kind of capital the country needs.
"Doing something like this would be a bold political risk in the American context, but it would produce a Cuba very different from anything we have ever seen: something that looks and feels like a market economy."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
How Success Spoiled the European Currency System

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
FRANCE and Germany haven't quite called off their planned economic marriage, but the relationship is on the rocks. Last week, Europe's finance ministers announced that they had all but abandoned their 14-year-old plan to limit the fluctuations among the Continent's major currencies.
The arrangement had limited currency variations to 2.5 percent above or below levels set in 1987. The idea was to stabilize the value of everyone's money so there can ultimately be a single European currency. But in recent weeks currency markets kept pushing the French franc down and the German mark up too hard for central banks to resist. So the governments retreated and allowed fluctuation of as much as 15 percent. 
 Next, they blamed the neighbors. A former French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, said "Anglo-Saxon" speculators -- a reference to British and American currency traders -- had undermined Europe's aspirations. "You have to look at who profits from the crime," he said.
It is certainly true that many British and American traders profited handsomely betting that Europe would fail to keep exchange rates within a narrow range. But so did many traders on the Continent and in Asia.
Nor are non-Anglo-Saxons particularly picked on. Last September, as the British Government was said to be pouring half its $30 billion foreign currency reserve into defending the pound, George Soros, a Hungarian-American speculator, reportedly made $1 billion selling the pound short.
But the billions risked by Mr. Soros and other short-term traders are only the froth atop far greater global waves of capital. Thanks to technology and deregulation, $1 trillion in currency is exchanged every day, more than triple the level of 1986. The pension funds of American workers now have $150 billion invested overseas, 20 times the level of a decade ago. Everyone from Japanese insurance companies to American mutual funds is scouring the world for investments. And before one of these funds can buy a French stock or a German bond, it must first buy francs or marks.
"Everyone talks about the global village, but the currency market is the real global village," said Ronald Layard-Leishing, head of research for Parato Partners, a London currency manager.
 
But That Was the Plan
 The central irony of this crisis is that a principal goal in establishing the system of semi-fixed rates was to encourage just this free flow of money. The flow gives businesses access to the widest range of investors and thus should lower their cost of capital, spurring growth. But it also means that investment can leave as easily as it came.
"The European central banks are the victims of their own success," said Adam M. Greshin, who manages $4 billion in international bonds for mutual funds and pension funds at Scudder Stevens & Clark. "They convinced investors that Europe was a place worthy of their investment. But when the system slowly caved in, global investors took their money elsewhere." Since March, he said, Scudder has been selling both the mark and the franc to buy dollars.
The crux of the problem can be traced to German reunification. By issuing West German marks for East German marks, Germany increased its money supply, fueling inflation. Because of Germany's hyper-inflation between the world wars, the Bundesbank has long had a strict charter to fight inflation. To do so, it has kept interest rates high.
Meanwhile, Europe went into a deep recession. That would normally prod governments to lower interest rates in order to encourage businesses and consumers to borrow and spend more. But the system of semi-fixed rates prevented them from doing this. If France lowered rates, investors would sell French investments to earn the higher interest in Germany, pushing up the price of marks. This is routine for currencies like the dollar and the yen, which float freely, but the European governments had committed themselves not to let their currencies fluctuate more than 2.5 percent.
To nearly every investor watching this situation, it was clear that domestic political pressure would force France to lower rates. Thus either Germany would lower its rates too, or the system would collapse.
This would hurt any investor in European bonds, many of which offered 1.5 to 3 percentage points more interest than American bonds. So investors protected themselves with two-part trades. They would, for example, buy French bonds and simultaneously "short" francs (in effect, selling the francs they hadn't yet collected in interest and principal on their bonds). You short (selling even though you're "short" the item) by agreeing today to sell francs some weeks from now for an agreed amount of another currency.
These two positions combined would benefit from falling interest rates (if you bought yesterday's bond paying 5 percent and today's bonds are paying 4 percent, you're smart) but would not be hurt by falling exchange rates (you already sold the francs you're collecting, perhaps for yen, so you're smarter).
This is a conservative strategy meant to reduce the risks for pensioners and mutual fund investors. Yet it involves the same trade used by the big-time speculators -- selling the franc short.
"George Soros can make a lot of money in a short period of time with a lot of risk," said Judy M. Pagliuca, a manager of portfolios for Fidelity Investments, the giant mutual fund company. "We use the same idea to make smaller amounts of money in a longer period."
Indeed, it was only because there was a consensus among long-term investors that the short-term traders could feel confident enough to take large positions. They saw huge pools of money betting exchange rates would go lower pitted against central banks committed to defending the set rates. They moved. The central banks lost, expensively.
Now, with a 15 percent margin of fluctuation, the battle between the central banks and the speculators is more evenly matched. Government traders have more leeway over when to intervene, and central banks like the Federal Reserve find that intervention works better when it's unexpected.
"Speculation has been made markedly riskier," said Helmut Schlesinger, the Bundesbank's president.
Now the governments of France, Germany and the rest of Europe have to decide if they are ready for a real marriage -- one checkbook, one savings account, one set of Continent-wide inflation and unemployment measures, a little sacrifice of economic autonomy for the sake of the relationship. If not, it wouldn't be the first engagement to be broken off because of money.
 
Why Currencies Float -- And Policies May Wash Away

Gold Standards, Floating Rates
And Fixed Ones
 Currencies were once linked to gold; that is, the U.S. Government would pay a dollar's worth of gold to any government that turned in a paper dollar.
After World War II, most countries agreed to fixed exchange rates: the British, for example, might guarantee that they would pay five U.S. dollars or 25 French francs to anyone redeeming a pound note.
In the 1970's, currencies were allowed to "float," like the price of oil or wheat. If many people suddenly want German marks, for example, the price of a mark -- in dollars, yen or francs -- will rise. However, Europe is now working toward a single money, so its currencies are semi-fixed. Central banks intervene to try to keep them within a narrow range. When everyone is dumping francs, for example, they buy. This can be expensive.
 
 
Why Trade Currencies?
To Pay for Imports When an American buys cameras from Japan, the Japanese camera maker must eventually be paid in yen (the currency he pays his employees in). When Japanese cameras are popular, more people must buy yen, so the price of yen relative to dollars goes up.
 
To Take Profits Home A McDonald's in Britain or a Disneyland in France takes in pounds or francs. Eventually, they must buy dollars, and will try to make money doing so.
 
Because Interest Rates Look Good If Germany's interest rates are high, American investors earning less than 3 percent on their money market accounts will buy German bonds or stocks, meaning they own marks. Mutual funds, pension funds and other huge pools of cash make such investments.
 
Out of Fear If investors think a country is politically threatened, they may move their money someplace like Switzerland, pushing up the Swiss franc. If they think a country will suffer from inflation (like Italy), they will protect their purchasing power by buying the currencies of more stable economies (like Japan or Germany).
 
 
How a Currency Can Plummet
 Generally, currencies rise or fall with a country's inflation rates, trade balances and other long-term factors.
Expectations spice this stew. When a change appears imminent, speculators may move in. For example, if it appears that the Bundesbank will not lower its interest rates to keep money from flowing into Germany, they may buy marks on the assumption that more investment money will indeed go to Germany. (The Bundesbank may WANT more money in Germany, but the British, French and American Governments may be pressuring Germany to be a good neighbor.)
If the franc drops too much against the mark, the Bank of France and Bundesbank can sell other currencies and buy francs, trying to push the price up. They can also change interest rates, but at a political cost.
But as a practical matter, governments can only slow things down. Speculators may trigger a rush out of a currency, but corporations, mutual funds, pension funds and banks seeking to avoid losses will sell, too, overwhelming the stabilization effort. For obvious political reasons, central bankers cannot forever commit billions of taxpayers' money to pay 20 cents for francs that soon might be worth 19 cents.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: The Overview;
REJOICING IS MUTED FOR THE PRESIDENT IN BUDGET VICTORY

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
While flush with triumph after Congressional passage of his five-year economic plan, President Clinton was careful today to claim the narrow, bruising victory as no more than a first step toward setting the economy on a more prudent course.
Having won over skeptical Democrats only by promising to put together another package of spending cuts by fall, Mr. Clinton and his aides faced a morning-after prospect of having to return once more to the politically hazardous occupation of singling out victims of the budget knife. 
 White House aides have refused to say how broad those cuts might be, although they say privately that they have identified $5 billion to $10 billion that could be stripped from current appropriations bills. But promises made to Senator Bob Kerrey, the Nebraska Democrat who provided the crucial vote Friday night, and others have increased the burden on a review by Vice President Al Gore due next month that was to have focused on "re-inventing Government."
 
Big Battle Ahead
 Mr. Clinton must also find a way to muster support for his still-unannounced plan to overhaul the health care system. While Mr. Clinton regards that initiative as central to the task of restraining Government spending and cutting the deficit, the package is certain to include an unspecified number of new tax increases, forcing a return to the unpopular subject that nearly sank his budget proposal.
"Our work is far from finished," the President said today in his weekly radio address, issuing both a pledge and an apologia. He said his Administration would "continue to look for ways to further cut unnecessary spending and trim waste." And he vowed, "On that front we will remain tireless, responsible and accountable to you."
 
Uncertainty About Cuts
 The cautious appraisal reflected a White House recognition of how many hurdles lie ahead. Even after a tie-breaking Senate vote gave the final go-ahead to the $496 billion deficit-reduction package, White House aides were heading back to work in a special "war room" in a renewed bid to overcome public antipathy to the tax increases and spending cuts.
After striking a deal with House leaders this week, Mr. Clinton promised that the report by Mr. Gore would include "a myriad of exciting possibilities" for reducing Government spending.
But it is not at all clear what kinds of additional programs the White House might be willing to cut. Of the more than $250 billion in spending reductions it won over the next five years, the bulk came from cutting military spending and putting limits on how much Medicare spending can rise. Neither Congress nor the White House has shown much willingness to venture further along those lines.
And while the promises of more cuts may have been intended to give Democrats political cover, the public scolding of Mr. Clinton by Mr. Kerrey and others from the Senate floor on Friday night suggested that they may well hold him to account for not having done more to "cut spending first," as Republicans had urged.
Mr. Kerrey announced his reluctant support for the package only in an exceedingly blunt speech in which he demanded that the President "get back on the high road" and move off "the low road of the too-easy compromise or the too-early collapse." Mr. Clinton was watching the speech from his residence in the White House, and some aides suggested today that he had been stung by the Senator's words.
 
An Unstable Consensus
 But Mr. Clinton's communications director, Mark D. Gearan, carefully described Mr. Kerrey's remarks as "a thoughtful statement" that the President was taking seriously. "Many people are frustrated with the process," he said in acknowledgement of the shallowness of Democratic support for Mr. Clinton's package.
That frustration is reflected in polls showing a broad, general preference for spending cuts over tax increases, which comprise the other half of Mr. Clinton's deficit reduction package. But that consensus breaks down when voters are asked what services they could do without, and the dilemma the White House faces is to find a better way of satisfying the broad sentiment without igniting narrower hostilities.
Even as the White House began to plot the weeks ahead, however, Mr. Clinton and his advisers were clearly in a mood today to savor the moment.
After a nighttime celebration where aides wore T-shirts emblazoned in red with the word victory, Mr. Clinton began his radio address this morning by seeing in Washington's sunny summer skies a metaphor for his triumph.
"The political fog that has surrounded this town for so long is at long last lifting," Mr. Clinton declared. He praised the courage of the House and Senate and said their approval of his plan "plants us firmly on the path to getting so many good things done for our people."
 
Mockery From Republican
 While Mr. Clinton spent much of the rest of the day on the golf course, aides sought to make the festivity contagious. They said the President would travel to Charleston, W.Va., on Monday for a celebratory rally, and would begin an extended trip later in the week with stops in the Midwest, Colorado and California.
Mr. Clinton filled his foursome with three Democratic legislators who voted for his package, Senator Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin and Representatives Pat Williams of Montana and John Tanner of Tennessee. The White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, described her boss as "very happy, kind of giddy."
But the White House faced a reminder of its plight in remarks today from Representative Jim Ross Lightfoot of Iowa, who delivered the Republican response to Mr. Clinton's address. Calling attention to House and Senate approval of the package by the narrowest of votes, Mr. Lightfoot mocked the President for claiming a mandate in the passage of a package "by a margin of three-tenths of one percent."
For a time, it had appeared that the margin might even be negative. Mr. Kerrey today told The Washington Post that he had told the President in an angry telephone conversation on Thursday that he would vote against the package.
Mr. Kerrey said that Mr. Clinton had responded angrily that his Presidency was at stake. "He shouted at me," Mr. Kerrey told The Post. "I shouted at him." The two men then hung up on each other, he said.
Mr. Kerrey said that he had changed his mind after long meetings with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, an old friend and supporter.
Mr. Kerrey's vote was vital because all 44 Republicans in the Senate voted against the bill along with six Democrats, Senators David L. Boren of Oklahoma, Richard H. Bryan of Nevada, J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, Sam Nunn of Georgia and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama.
A senior White House official insisted, however, that the White House had never truly doubted that Mr. Kerrey would come around.
Even before the vote, Roger Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said the White House operation to rally support for the plan would remain open to defend the plan against damaging Republican criticism.
In particular, the White House is hoping to create a backlash among middle-class voters who may have been led by Republican criticism to believe that Mr. Clinton's proposal would raise their income tax rates. In fact, income taxes will increase only for the very wealthy and some affluent retirees.
But Clinton aides also acknowledged that their battle to transform the plan from political liability to benefit was likely in the end to depend on the performance of the economy.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE;
Wealthy or Not, Taxpayers Will Find Plenty of Surprises

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
The Democrats have said, correctly, that the new law raises taxes mainly on the wealthy. But many people who are not wealthy will be affected by the tax increases, some in ways that have been widely heralded, but others in ways that may come as a surprise.
Gasoline taxes are going up; so are taxes on many people's Social Security benefits. Anyone who moves for a new job might lose certain deductions of expenses, whether he is Croesus or Cratchit. 
 Others who may be affected by the changes in the new law include employees who take classes paid for by their employers, people who make contributions to their colleges or to other charities and grandparents and others who set up trusts for children.
 
Refiling May Be an Option
 Tax specialists advise that even people who think they will not be touched by the new tax law because they are not wealthy should study the provisions carefully. In fact, some people may want to refile their tax returns for 1992 because the new law deals retroactively with certain areas, like the treatment of tuition assistance and low-income housing credits.
"Everybody should review their personal financial planning, their investment asset mix, and their estate planning," said Andre Fogarasi, the managing director of the Federal tax service at Arthur Andersen, the big accounting firm, in Washington.
The consequence of these tectonic shifts in personal taxation -- call it fairness, or call it folly -- is an inevitable upheaval in the complexity of the tax landscape.
"This is a massive step backward from simplicity," said David Berenson, the managing partner of Berenson & Company, as the Senate writhed along its parliamentary path toward enacting President Clinton's tax program on Friday night. "What is simple will never be perceived as fair. And what they perceive as fair will never be simple."
For a few years in the late 1980's, when taxes were lower and simpler, virtually every couple in the country making more than $30,000 in taxable income paid taxes at the same marginal rate: 28 percent.
It did not last long. A new 31 percent tax bracket arrived in 1991. And now comes the new tax bill, with added marginal rates of 36 percent, 39.6 percent and even a bit higher for people earning hundreds of thousands of dollars a year.
The changes in the income tax rates are retroactive to Jan. 1, 1993. The changes in the taxation of Social Security benefits and in the application of the Medicare payroll tax take effect next Jan. 1.
The big increases in income tax rates that raise most of the money in this bill affect only the well-off. Under current law, the top statutory rate of 31 percent applies to single people earning more than $53,500, and couples earning more than $89,150 in taxable income. The new law creates a 36 percent tax rate on taxable income above $115,000 (single) and $140,000 (married). When income exceeds $250,000, for either singles or couples, it will be taxed at 39.6 percent.
And changes in the Medicare taxes, along with the continuing effects of the way deductions and exemptions are treated at upper incomes, mean tax rates at the top can go as high as 44 percent in some cases.
That does not mean that someone earning $300,000 must fork over 40 percent of it to the Internal Revenue Service. The percentage figures are marginal tax rates. The term "marginal" means, for example, that someone in the 36 percent bracket must pay $360 on every additional $1,000 earned over the figure at which that tax bracket begins; Someone in the 39.6 percent bracket would have to pay $396 on every additional $1,000 earned. But people do not pay their marginal tax rate on their entire income; for most people, the bulk of the income is taxed at lower rates.
Even so, it is at the margins that tax laws exert their most powerful leverage on financial behavior. This is true whether one is a millionaire deciding to give tens of thousands of dollars to a charity, or a Social Security recipient deciding whether to rearrange a nest egg.
 
More Complications For Social Security
 Some of the most complicated parts of the new tax bill are those applying to Social Security recipients. The bill will make subject to income tax up to 85 percent of the Social Security benefits of relatively affluent taxpayers. Calculating the tax is complicated enough; figuring out strategies to avoid it can be even trickier.
Social Security beneficiaries must include in taxable income a portion of their benefits if their "provisional income" exceeds certain thresholds. Provisional income is defined as the sum of an individual's adjusted gross income, tax-exempt interest, certain foreign-source income and half of the taxpayer's Social Security benefit.
Under the present law, 50 percent of the benefits are taxed at the person's ordinary rate if the provisional income is more than $25,000 for a single person, or $32,000 per couple. Under the new law, up to 85 percent can be taxed if the provisional income exceeds $34,000 for a single person, or $44,000 for a couple.
How much of the benefit would be taxed? No more than 85 percent, and possibly less. The formula is so complicated that the I.R.S. will have to publish a new worksheet to help taxpayers figure it out. Arthur Andersen figured that a single taxpayer with a provisional income of $36,000 and Social Security benefits of $8,000 would have to pay taxes on $5,700 of the benefits. Under the old law, $4,000 would have been taxable. Such a person is likely to be in the 28 percent tax bracket, so the tax increase amounts to 28 percent of $1,700, or $476.
 
Low-Wage Earners Get a Bigger Credit
 One of the major changes in the bill is the big expansion of the earned income tax credit, which bolsters the income of eligible low-income workers. Its inclusion in the budget, along with an expansion of the food stamp program, keeps the President's campaign promise that, at least for a family with two children, nobody who works full time should live in poverty.
The tax credit, which reduces the taxes of those who owe them and is refunded as a direct payment to those who make too little to owe taxes, can be claimed at the end of the year or can be included in every paycheck by employers.
The credit is bigger for people with two or more children than for people with only one child. But for the first time, some people with no children will qualify for modest credits under the new law.
This year, under the present law, taxpayers with more than one child can claim a credit of up to 18.5 percent of the first $7,750 they earn. The credit dwindles as income rises beyond that point. The maximum credit is $1,511.
Next year, for taxpayers with two or more children, the credit is 30 percent of the first $8,425 earned. The maximum credit will be $2,527, and it is phased out when income rises above $11,000 a year.
The credit will rise even higher, hitting 36 percent in 1995 and 40 percent in 1996. At that point, the working poor will be rewarded by the tax code for earning income at just about the marginal rate at which the wealthiest workers are taxed on their income.
 
Capital Gains Taxes Remain Unchanged
 Elsewhere in the tax bill, things are changing more subtly. Capital gains taxes, for example, are not being changed. Property and stocks sold at a profit will be taxed at no more than the current 28 percent.
What has changed is the attractiveness of such investments, because this tax rate is so much lower than the top rate on income.
And that has meant that the law had to be tightened to prevent people from structuring investments to make ordinary income, like interest, look like capital gains. Financial maneuvers such as straddles, involving the purchase and sale of futures contracts, have been ruled out, and the Treasury has been given the authority to write future regulations to rule out yet undiscovered gimmicks.
Another change limits the deduction for interest expenses for people who borrow money to make investments. Interest can still be deducted from investment income, but not from net capital gains. The change is intended to prevent people from deducting interest expenses at up to a 39.6 marginal tax rate against capital gains that are taxed at a lower rate.
 
Alternative Rates Will Be Increased
 And there are changes in the alternative minimum tax, known as the A.M.T., the method of calculating tax bills that is meant to prevent people from taking so many deductions that they pay little or no tax.
The new alternative minimum tax rates for individuals is 26 percent on income up to $175,000, and 28 percent thereafter. It sounds attractive, but it is not: Income is defined differently for the A.M.T., and taxpayers generally try to avoid it.
The combination of higher A.M.T. rates for all, combined with higher regular tax rates on higher incomes, will in effect mean that the A.M.T. can now trap some upper-middle class people who never had to worry about it before. Tax and investment decisions, such as exercising incentive stock options, will have to be considered carefully as a result.
Indeed, the one thing to remember about the new law, said Mr. Fogarasi of Arthur Andersen, is the need for careful planning, not just year by year but over a lifetime.
 
Estate and Trust Rates Are Revamped
 For example, the law has changed for estates and certain trusts.
Lower inheritance tax rates that had taken effect just this year for large estates have been revoked retroactively, a rude surprise for some heirs of people who died in the last seven months. The top rates are not 50 percent, but 53 percent on estates of more than $2.5 million, and 55 percent on estates of more than $3 million.
And there are new tax brackets for income-retaining trusts, a widely used mechanism under which some parents and grandparents set aside money for the future use of younger generations. Experts say the changes have all but wiped out the utility of these trusts, and that the trustees for those that have already been set up must look carefully to see how best to manage them under the new regime, which applies higher taxes to much lower earnings within the trusts.
 
Several Revisions For Small Businesses
 There are important changes in the law for people who own small businesses. For one, sole proprietors and others who pay taxes on business income at personal tax rates can now be taxed at considerably higher rates than corporations. Some of them might consider changing the structures of their businesses, although that can subject them to double taxation: once as a corporation and again as a shareholder or employee.
Those who pay for their own medical insurance through a business will be relieved by the retroactive restoration of the deduction for a portion of insurance premiums, which had lapsed in 1992. Of course, this, like several other provisions of the law, makes it necessary for some people to file amended returns for last year.
Small-business owners will also feel the change in the deductibility of business meals and entertainment. It used to be that 80 percent of such expenses were deductible; now it is only 50 percent.
And taking a spouse on a business trip is harder to justify under the new law. Expenses for this used to be deductible if there was a good business reason for taking the spouse. Now a spouse must also be a bona fide employee of the person or business paying the expenses.
 
Wider Tax Break For Real Estate
 For people in the real estate business, there is a considerable expansion of one of the tax breaks eliminated in 1986 -- the passive loss rules.
Starting next year, eligible taxpayers who actively participate in the business of renting out properties will be able to deduct rental losses from other sources of income, such as wages or unrelated businesses. To be eligible, the taxpayer must work mainly in real estate, at least 750 hours a year, and if that work is performed as an employee, the taxpayer must own at least a 5 percent share in the employer's business.
But for a lawyer involved heavily in real estate work, for example, who owns, rents out and actively manages an investment property, if the rent on the property does not cover its mortgage, the difference can be deducted from the lawyer's other income.
There is also a new incentive for people to buy into certain small businesses. For those who buy newly issued stock and hold it for five years, half of any capital gain will be untaxed. But the gain cannot exceed 10 times the original price, or $10 million, and the gain cannot be reduced by any capital losses. Furthermore, the exclusion of the capital gains taxes might trigger the alternative minimum tax, and most experts consider this tax break to have limited appeal.
 
Big Earners to Face More Restrictions
 Highly paid business executives face other complications under the new law. For example, there are restrictions on the ability of publicly held corporations to deduct from income the salaries of executives paid more than $1 million, unless the pay is linked to performance.
And highly paid executives with employer retirement plans, as well as self employed people with tax-deferred Keogh retirement plans, might lose some tax benefits of contributions.
This year, a person making $300,000 who participates in a pension plan that allows contributions of up to 10 percent of salary can make a contribution of only $23,584, because current law allows contributions only on the basis of income up to $235,840.
The new law, however, will allow contributions to such a plan only on the basis of income up to $150,000. That means the 1994 set-aside can be only $15,000. Many companies will find other ways of making up contributions to pension plans, but the tax advantages for the employee might not be so great.
On a lesser scale, a crackdown on dues at private clubs will affect some taxpayers, who will not be allowed to deduct the dues even if the club is used principally for business related activities. On the other hand, an employer may deduct the cost of dues to the extent that they are treated as compensation. And activities at the club, such as the cost of meals, remain deductible to the same extent as any other meal and entertainment expenses.
 
Rules Are Broadened On Charity and Gifts
 The tax bill introduces, restores and expands several kinds of tax breaks, and among the greatest of these is charity.
Philanthropic gifts have been tax deductible all along. But it is even more advantageous for the wealthy to give now that the after-tax cost of gifts is just 60 cents on the dollar for those in the highest marginal tax bracket.
There has been another important change in the law, however, that makes it easier than in recent years to make gifts of property that has increased in value over the years. These gifts can be deducted at present market value even though the taxpayer never paid that much for them, and the gifts do not incur any capital gains tax.
Under the new law, this kind of transaction can no longer trigger the punishing alternative minimum tax. And the provisions have been expanded to include not only property like paintings, but so-called intangibles, such as stocks or even royalty rights.
For gifts of tangible property such as paintings, the law is retroactive, so no alternate minimum tax will result from gifts made since June 1992.
All it takes is a little paperwork, under the new rules that tighten the substantiation and disclosure of charitable contributions. The Internal Revenue Service has also been ordered to develop a method for taxpayers to agree in advance of making a charitable donation with the I.R.S. on the value of a painting or other property, so there will be no disputes.
 
Luxury Tax Struck; Moving Breaks Cut
 Another change in the law, the repeal of the luxury tax on jewelry, boats, airplanes, and furs, is good news, and not just for the people who make and sell these items or those who plan to buy them. The repeal was made retroactive, so someone who bought, for example, a $20,000 fur coat in February can ask the retailer for a rebate of the $1,000 excise tax that should have been collected at the time. The retailer, in turn, can get a refund from the Government.
Another benefit that has been restored could prompt thousands of taxpayers to file amended tax returns. Among several tax breaks that expired in the middle of last year was the one making employer-provided education assistance, such as tuition payments under qualified plans, tax free. Since then, employees have been required to report tuition payments as income, and pay tax on them.
The new law restores the tax break back to June 1992. Companies that give aid to employees this year can stop withholding taxes on it. But to make it appear less costly in the five-year budget, Congress extended the benefit only through the end of 1994, when presumably it will be renewed again.
But for anybody who is moving to a new job, there is a shrinking tax break. In general, expenses related to a work-related move are deductible. But under the new law, you have to move at least 50 miles; it used to be just 35. And the costs of meals, temporary lodging near the new job and house-hunting trips will no longer be allowed as deductions. Nor will you be able to deduct the costs, such as fees paid to lenders or real estate commissions, associated with buying or selling a house.
The new rules for moving expense deductions do not take hold until next year.
And the movers, like everyone else, will be paying the new 4.3 cent-a-gallon gasoline tax which takes effect on Oct. 1, 1993.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 32; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Union Leaders Fight for a Place in the President's Workplace of the Future

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration seeks to define the high-performance workplace of the future, union leaders are fighting for a place in that definition. More specifically, they say any Clinton campaign to upgrade the workplace will not succeed without unions.
But the Administration, backed strongly by unions in last fall's election, is not ready to go that far. "The jury is still out on whether the traditional union is necessary for the new workplace," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview. 
 The conflict surfaced recently at a conference on the workplace in Chicago, sponsored by the Administration, as well as in interviews with Administration officials and union leaders.
The resolution is not likely to come until May, when a Presidential commission studying labor issues makes its first report. But union leaders say the Administration itself has already demonstrated the value of organized labor.
At the conference in late July, the Administration began using 20 companies as examples for corporate America to mimic in moving toward its vision of the workplace of the future. At the majority of these companies, unions played a vital role in making them better. And now union leaders say these selections make it clear that unions have an important role in the workplace of the future.
 
Prospects for Change
 "We have to persuade all the principal players by one means or another that the new workplace is not going to achieve anything like what we need in America without unions," said Lynn Williams, president of the United Steelworkers of America. "The record shows a high failure rate in the development of high-performance workplaces in nonunion settings."
Unions have long been blamed by some people for being part of the problem with American industry. They are portrayed as intransigent institutions responsible for impeding change and pushing wages and other compensation to the point where their companies cannot compete with businesses around the world.
But some union leaders say that if this was their tactic once, it no longer is. And they point to the showcase companies as evidence that the unions have become a vital part of the process, not an obstacle. Xerox, U S West, A.T.& T., two General Motors auto-making ventures, Chrysler, Levi Strauss and Corning Glass are all on the showcase list. And all have unions deeply involved in the workplace. Of eight nonunion companies, only Motorola is a major corporation.
Illustrating the change in tactics, Mr. Williams, who is trying to halt the decline in his own union's membership, has signed agreements with steel companies recently that he and the Administration hold up as examples. Rather than confront management, he said, the Steelworkers have agreed to concessions in pursuit of common goals like efficiency, lower costs and, ultimately, survival in global competition.
 
Winning Strategy
 The Williams strategy has made companies represented by the Steelworkers prominent on the Administration's showcase list, among them Inland Steel, L-S Electro-Galvanizing Company, Republic Engineered Steel and Magma Copper.
But while the unions argue that only a union presence guarantees that managers will not take advantage of cooperative workers, Administration officials say the self-interest of workers and of managers is now so intertwined that unions might no longer be needed as guardians.
"Unions are O.K. where they are," said Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown. "And where they are not, it is not clear yet what sort of organization should represent workers."
The commission, headed by John Dunlop, an economist at Harvard University who was Labor Secretary in the Ford Administration, sees one of its main tasks as deciding who should represent workers in their dealings with management. The answer is likely to determine whether unions can regain some of the membership and influence lost during the Reagan and Bush Administrations. But even now these showcase companies are focusing public attention on this problem.
One issue involves the penchant at the showcase companies for work councils, with labor and management represented. These councils are intended to make corporate decisions, like setting production schedules, judging quality, determining wages, hiring new people and making job assignments.
 
Union Involvement
 "We have the union involved at all levels of our operation," said Robert J. Darnall, Inland's chairman.
The unions agree, but offer a different thought. They argue that while the goal of labor-management councils is laudable -- a worker voice in running the company -- the councils can become management controlled, in violation of Federal labor law.
The commission must decide on how to avoid such an imbalance, or whether the law itself should be changed. The commission's report could make it easier for unions to represent workers on these councils, or deal them a setback.
A second issue centers on the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s demand that the Administration propose changes in the Labor Relations Act to remove what the unions call an obstacle to the organizing of nonunion workers. Currently, a union must win the right to represent a company's workers in a special election. But the unions say companies have increasingly found ways to prevent or delay these elections.
 
Easier Union Elections
 So they want the right to represent a company's workers if a majority sign petition cards requesting such representation -- a request that corporate spokesmen say would result in a setback for the Administration's campaign to create high-performance workplaces.
"Although there are some great cases of labor union participation in high-performance workplaces, the bulk of the success stories are clearly in the nonunion camp," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "That is just the facts."
The Administration's list of showcase companies seems to carry a different message, and that came out at the Chicago conference, where executives and union officials from these companies gave testimonials about their experiences together.
The testimonials produced some common themes, all related to the issue of whether workers need unions to represent them in the new cooperative effort to improve a company's performance.
 
Back From the Brink
 Many of the showcase companies were losing money or facing bankruptcy when they sought help from their workers to improve efficiency and lower costs.
That was the case at the Magma Copper Company, which mines and processes copper into bars in Arizona. After years of conflict with the Steelworkers, Magma was on the verge of shutting down. Now, under a 15-year labor contract -- longer contracts have become a trend at the showcase companies -- Magma is investing nearly $500 million in a new mine, having first lowered its costs enough to make Magma competitive on world markets.
There have been no layoffs in several years, but as part of the effort to be more efficient, the union agreed to alter job rules so that workers could pitch in where they were needed. "A welder who works in the mine will now come and work in the smelter on a busy day there," said John Champagne, a Magma executive.
The profits from such efficiencies will help to make the new workplace high-wage, the Clinton Administration argues. But wage increases at Magma and other showcase companies have taken a back seat to bonuses tied to profits or greater efficiency.
 
Working Faster
 Magma's average wage for 4,400 workers is $15 an hour, but $2.25 of this, or 15 percent, is in a "gain-sharing" bonus paid for greater efficiency. To get it, each miner must now dig roughly 570 pounds of ore a day, on average, rather than the 350 pounds that was typical in 1988. "The 350 was a lazy day," Mr. Champagne said. "If miners have an incentive to work rather than sleep in the mine, that is a huge increase in productivity."
Mr. Williams, the Steelworkers president, makes a different point. Without a union, the job flexibility can turn into exploitation, he says, and without union access to Magma's books, the workers cannot know whether they are being shortchanged on their bonuses. "You need the union's collective bargaining power to split up the pie fairly for workers," Mr. Williams said.
The showcase companies, in most cases, have also gotten the unions to agree to shed jobs, but through attrition, rather than layoffs, or by retraining and transferring workers to new jobs from disappearing ones. Some displaced phone operators at U S West, for example, have become sales representatives at stores the company is opening in shopping malls.
Job preservation has taken a different form at other showcase companies, including L-S Electro-Galvanizing, a Cleveland auto parts company staffed with laid-off Steelworkers. The company's 70 workers are often not enough to keep up with the production pace. So with the union's permission, outsiders -- mainly former Steelworkers who had lost their jobs -- are brought in as contractors, and then let go when production falls. The tasks that had been done by the outsiders are reassigned to regular employees, to avoid layoffs.
