HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE -- Economic Memo;
In Short Run, Economy Could Suffer

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Now that the President's $496 billion budget bill has passed, the question on many Americans' minds is whether the plan will help or hurt the economy.
During the debate, the Administration promised that higher taxes, spending curbs and a shrinking deficit would produce millions of new jobs in the next three years. Congressional opponents, on the other hand, predicted that the deficit-cutting plan would produce nothing but another recession. 
 Both are way off base, many economists say.
 
Outlook on Jobs
 Forget about the promise of millions of new jobs, they say. "Those jobs would have been created by a recovering economy whether or not there was a plan and no matter who was in the White House," said Joel Prakken, an economist at Laurence Meyer & Associates, the economic forecasting firm whose projections the Administration cited in making its claim.
Indeed, according to just about every economist not on the Administration's payroll, the plan is apt to cost some economic growth and jobs in the next two or three years as the new taxes and spending cuts take their bite. The reason is simple: higher taxes and less Government spending means less money in consumer pockets.
"In the short run, our view is that the package will slow the economy," said Davis Wyss at DRI/McGraw Hill in Lexington, Mass. Rob Wescott, chief economist of the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., said, "Half a trillion dollars of deficit reduction is going to have a somewhat depressing effect on the economy,"
And Allen Sinai, managing director of Lehman Brothers, said, "The hit is real in the short run."
To be sure, most analysts give the budget plan at least some of the credit for the sharp drop in long-term interest rates -- to about 6.5 percent today from 7.65 percent on Election Day. Lower long-term rates will blunt a good deal of the impact from taxes and spending changes, economists say, by stimulating businesses to invest and consumers to buy houses and cars.
 
Slowed Economy
 They also agree with much of what Mr. Clinton has said about the long-term benefits of freeing up for investment some of the money that would otherwise go to feed the deficit.
But, they part company with the Administration -- which has been denying stoutly that cutting the deficit is going to hurt in the short term -- by insisting that lower rates alone are unlikely to offset the drag on growth entirely.
Estimates by Merrill Lynch, DRI McGraw Hill, the WEFA Group and The Boston Company Economic Advisers of how much would be knocked off the growth rate range from 0.2 percent to 0.5 percent of the gross domestic product -- the nation's output of goods and services -- a year.
That means that if the economy were to grow at a 3 percent rate over the next three years without the plan, it would instead grow at 2.8 percent or 2.5 percent annually.
A lower growth rate would also mean fewer new jobs -- 150,000 to 250,000 a year fewer for one to three years, according to the estimates. The unemployment rate, which has been hovering around 7 percent most of this year, would take a bit longer to come down than otherwise.
"We don't think of it as a short run job creation program," Mr. Prakken said.
This is just common sense. Higher taxes will leave consumers and some small businesses with less money to spend and, though less tangible, with less enthusiasm for new money-making ventures.
 
$30 Billion in Taxes
 According to the Joint Committee on Taxation, taxes are apt to go up by $30 billion next year or 0.5 percent of G.D.P. The top 1 percent of taxpayers, who earn more than $200,000 -- and command more than 13 percent of all taxpayers' income -- will have to ante up $23 billion of that amount. Other taxpayers will bear the remaining $7 billion, which consists of the gas tax, the corporate tax and and higher levies on retirees.
The number of jobs will be hit directly by curbs on spending, especially Medicare and Medicaid caps, deep cuts in military outlays and reductions in the Federal work force.
Under the budget plan, the cuts, which are supposed to average about $30 billion a year but in fact are concentrated in the last couple of years of the plan, will really start to bite in a couple of years. At that point, consumers will wind up with less pre-tax income to spend.
But it is very easy to exaggerate the effect of these changes, which loom very large for individuals and companies, on the economy as a whole. In particular, fears that the budget bill will knock the economy into a new recession are overblown.
"This is a $6 trillion economy on its way to becoming an $8 trillion economy in 5 years," said Mr. Westcott of WEFA. "In that context, these are really small changes."
Besides, the way the plan affects the economy depends ultimately on the way millions and millions of people, from bond investors to businesses owners to consumers react.
If bond investors believe that the budget plan will actually reduce the deficit and also keep growth modest, long-term interest rates are more likely to stay low even as the recovery continues. Beyond giving a boost to public and private construction and the like, that would also tend to let foreign interest rates edge down.
The Federal Reserve is also an important actor because tighter monetary policy would intensify the cooling effects of the budget. To the extent to which slightly slower growth would help stave off inflationary pressures, the Federal Reserve would be less inclined to tighten as the economic recovery continued.
Ultimately, whether short-term pain is worth it depends on whether there is any long-term gain. The economists do see some.
 
Chief Benefits Seen
 They see three long-term benefits. One is stability. Like the benefits of lower inflation, keeping deficits from exploding does not translate easily into jobs created. But a debt that grows faster than gross domestic product, as the Federal debt has been doing in recent years, ultimately risks feeding on itself
"Once deficits get to be 8 to 10 percent of G.D.P., countries experience serious problems with interest rates and inflation," said Art Rolnick, research director at the Minneapolis Federal Reserve. "It looks as if this policy really will help rein in the deficit and keep the deficit from growing faster than the economy. That's very important."
The second benefit is higher investment. Cutting the deficit increases national saving directly and makes more resources available for investment in productivity-boosting capital. The principal benefit of this for workers in labor force will be higher pay, reflecting the higher productivity.
Finally, taxing the current generation strikes some as fairer than pushing the tax burden onto their children or grandchildren, which is what happens when government takes on more and more in obligations, whether social security or education spending, that current taxpayers pay an ever smaller fraction of.
"If you keep running large deficits today, you leave less capital for future generations," Mr. Rolnick said. "That's a question of fairness."

HEADLINE: In the Path of the Flood, Hard Times Just Got Harder

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. CHARLES, Mo., Aug. 7

 BODY:
The flood water that swamped Deerfield Village Mobile Home Park here last month has receded nearly a foot in recent days, but it has left the twin plagues of foul-smelling mud and larger-than-life mosquitoes.
The muck, the bugs and the stench reminded the 265 families who live here that ferocious rivers, frantic sandbagging and failed levees are only the first chapter in the great flood of 1993 and will be followed by less drama but more misery. 
 The trailer park is home to mechanics, cashiers and janitors, to folks who talk with a twang and drive old Chevies, to men and women who are already struggling and now must struggle some more. Many of them have spent their lives in low-lying trailer parks, the only housing they can afford, and are not strangers to rising water.
These days, forced from their single- and double-wide trailers, they gather on the shoulder of Elm Point Road, outside the park's entrance, to complain and commiserate, watch and wait.
In canoes and johnboats, or by foot in chest-high waders, they visit their homes daily to discourage looters, check out how much water has seeped into the insulation or grab a few more videotapes to entertain bored children now living in motels.
 
Catfish and Frogs
 Most of the residents fled on July 9, when the Mississippi River jumped an agricultural levee about a a half-mile away. But some stuck around a few more days, until the murky water filled the streets of the 40-acre park, or until their air-conditioning units went under, or until they found catfish or frogs in their beds.
Now, a few at a time, they began returning this weekend to help with the cleanup, which is being led by the park manager, Peggy Hooker; the owner's son, Craig Ingram, and a handful of residents who have been offered a break on their rent if they pitch in. No one will be expected to pay rent for August.
With shovels and backhoes, the cleanup crew is removing the sludgy mixture of mud, dead plants and railroad ties from ruined gardens and the empty soda cans that have been left in the wake of the flood. They are bleaching their parking pads and patios, hoping to kill the stench and rout the germs.
Eventually, said Ken Ingram, the park's owner, all the trailers will be washed down with a power sprayer, and the grassy areas now turned to swamp will be worked with a farm implement that aerates the soil. Grass will be replanted, and the whole park will be sprayed for mosquitoes.
"It looks bad now," the elder Mr. Ingram said, "but it doesn't take that long to clean it up. Come back in a month. You'll be amazed."
 
Some Resentment
 The owner is not a popular man among many of the Elm Point Road residents, who say they were misled when they rented lots at Deerfield, which is at the northern edge of St. Charles, a bedroom suburb of St. Louis close to the confluence of the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers.
A pleasant place in better times, with manicured gardens, swing sets and basketball hoops, Deerfield boasts that it was not overrun by water in either the 1973 or 1986 floods.
Hanging in the manager's office are aerial photos of the park when it was untouched by water during earlier floods. And the owner proudly notes that he built up the land, making it 3 to 5 feet higher than the adjacent soybean field, and then insisted that residents lift their trailers on platforms to 444 feet above sea level, which put them a foot above the designated 100-year flood line.
Some residents took that as a promise that they would always be on dry ground. "They say, 'It didn't happen in '86, so you're safe,' " said Roy Spencer, a retired meat packer whose wife cleans the St. Charles County Courthouse here. "To me, when you're in a flood plain, you shouldn't make a statement like that. You should say there's always that possibility."
Others residents figure that the people who run Deerfield Village should not be expected to predict or prevent a flood of epic proportions. "I don't hold anybody responsible," said Bob Bodley, a county building inspector. "This one was beyond the control of anybody."
Another thing that galls the residents here is what they described as gouging by the haulers who showed up last month to offer to pull trailers to dry ground. As the flood water approached, residents said, scores of haulers tried to drum up business in the streets of Deerfield, with prices ranging from $250 to $3,000.
 
Some Trailers Escaped
 About 60 residents, alone or with professional help, hauled their trailers to parking lots on higher land at local schools.
"I thought about it," said Guy Civey, who rebuilds transmissions for a living and whose wife, a shipping clerk, wanted him to haul their mobile home away. But Mr. Civey said he had told her that moving a double-wide trailer, which costs about $50,000, would be risky.
"You pull this unit apart and you'll never get it back right," he said.
Another of the residents' gripes is the rush to solicit business by insurance companies, who also came calling at Deerfield just as the water began to rise. Craig Ingram, who has three inches of sludge in his trailer despite jacking it up an extra foot, said he had seen agents sell two dozen policies at the last minute, including one to Dale Covington, who fears that he did not pay enough attention to the "small print."
Mr. Covington signed first and worried later, but he has now been told by his neighbors that flood insurance includes a rule to the effect that a homeowner cannot collect unless the policy was bought five days before water reached the property.
Mr. Covington does not understand if that means the yard, which was already wet by the time he bought his policy, or the mobile home itself, which he said was still dry. "I'm hoping I can collect, but I don't know," he said.
 
Tales of Woe
 Most of the people in the mobile home village -- residents guessed about 80 percent -- have insurance. In many instances, they had bought insurance because they had been victims of earlier floods while living in other lowland trailer parks throughout the Mississippi Valley and had learned their lesson.
That is the case with Tom Lupo, who this week told a tale of woe that made him sound like a latter-day Job. Mr. Lupo was flooded out of a trailer park in Bedford, Mo., in 1986, lost his father shortly thereafter and was then dismissed as a manager for a local trash-hauling concern.
He has exhausted his unemployment benefits, Mr. Lupo said, his ex-wife is suing him for additional alimony, and he is barely paying his bills by driving a delivery truck for Domino's pizza. Now he is trapped in a single room at the Red Roof Inn here with his second wife and two cranky stepchildren.
"Let me tell you where my stress level's at," Mr. Lupo said as he hung around on Elm Point Road, hoping to hitch a boat ride to his swamped trailer. "I'm at the point now where I just want to scream."
Also suffering cabin fever from a month in a motel room with two toddlers is Steve Lopez. Mr. Lopez took his johnboat into the flooded streets the other day to fetch Superman and Bugs Bunny videos for 5-year-old Timothy and 2-year-old Brandon, who are having trouble sleeping in unfamiliar beds.
Mr. Lopez is a house painter with nothing to paint these days, although he hopes the later stages of flood recovery will mean lots of work. For now, he hangs out at the muddy trailer park, gazing with envy at the $200,000 houses on the bluff above. These sturdy homes, safe and dry, are in a subdivision known as Edgemont, which is also owned by Ken Ingram.
"We should have got us a house up there," Mr. Lopez said.

The water has receded somewhat but has left foul-smelling mud and large mosquitoes. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE -- Political Memo;
For Clinton, Plenty of Work Is Left

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
President Clinton scraped through and got the budget victory on which he staked his Presidency. Now comes the scary part.
How scary? One Democratic Senator who reluctantly voted for the package, Herb Kohl of Wisconsin, bought television commercials this weekend defending his decision. 
 Senator Dennis DeConcini, an Arizona Democrat who also sided with the President, has been overwhelmed by voters back home asking him why. Acknowledging the political risks, Mr. DeConcini joked that Mr. Clinton promised him the next opening on the Supreme Court.
By contrast, Senator Richard C. Shelby, an Alabama Democrat who has emerged as his party's most relentless critic of the President, proudly declared: "I was the first Democrat to oppose this measure."
 
Risks for Democrats
 To calm his fellow Democrats, Mr. Clinton must prove that he was not uttering empty words when he proclaimed that gridlock had broken, enabling him to fulfill his more ambitious promises to overhaul the health care and welfare systems.
But even as they rejoice this week at the White House, Mr. Kohl and Mr. DeConcini and the other jittery Democrats facing re-election next year are well aware that their political futures, and Mr. Clinton's, may well rise or fall on a series of gambles that are largely beyond their control.
Will there be short-term growth in the economy? Or, as many economists predict, will the tax increases only discourage any upturn? Will the victory this week help Democrats persuade Republicans to end their united opposition and build the bipartisanship needed to pass Mr. Clinton's legislative agenda? Or will the stalemate only linger?
"Clinton lives or dies on this bill," said Charles Rund, a Republican pollster. "He's got to show that something actually happened that was positive. But if the economy just muddles along and he proposes that we spend more money on health care, his agenda will be in serious trouble."
 
'We Have No Illusions'
 While they acknowledge the challenge, Democrats frame it in more reassuring terms. "Sure, ultimately, peoples' pocketbooks will tell the tale," said David Wilhelm, chairman of the Democratic Party. "We have no illusions about the task ahead, but the vote was a key moment because we have shown that we as a party have the will and the capacity to govern."
Mr. Clinton emerged from the budget battle victorious, but not unscathed. That Vice President Al Gore had to break the tie in a Senate dominated by Democrats demonstrates that his mandate was hardly overwhelming. While Mr. Clinton deserves great credit for holding the Democrats together in the face of opposition from every Republican in the House and Senate, it was not without cost: he is viewed as a President who let lawmaker after lawmaker in his own party extract concessions from him to gain their support.
"If I were Clinton and his staff, I wouldn't do much bragging about this," said Tom Cronin, an authority on the Presidency who is president of Whitman College in Walla Walla, Wash. "He's got to keep hammering at the theme that we as a country have enormous deficits. He should say that this is just a beginning."
If his radio address today is any evidence, Mr. Clinton understands the struggle before him. "This plan is an urgent step," he said. "But I want to emphasize, it is only the first step."
 
Difficult Tasks
 In the starkest terms, Mr. Clinton's long-term chances rest with the 19 percent who voted for Ross Perot last year, voters who Mr. Clinton needs to draw from if he is to be re-elected. Mr. Perot is already complaining that the package will do little to significantly affect the deficit. And polls show that the American people have little faith that the package will turn the economy around, and they have even less patience for the prospect of new taxes.
"Quite honestly," said Joan N. Baggett, the White House political director, "I don't think this President is ever going to have extremely high approval or popularity because everything he does is difficult."
But Mr. Clinton did buy himself some time, and a degree of momentum, as he heads into what everyone expects to be the more bruising battle over health care in September.
Unlike Mr. Clinton, the Democrats who face re-election next year do not have three more years to hope that the economy recovers, and they are nervous. Two of the six Democrat Senators who opposed the bill are running next year, and several others who face re-election sided with the President only after great trepidation.
Senator Bob Kerrey, the Nebraska Democrat who handed Mr. Clinton the victory at the last minute, was not as confident that as the President that "the days of endless gridlock, rising deficits and trickle-down economics are over."
"There is no consensus yet either in the Congress or the country about what we should do to achieve economic growth," Mr. Kerrey said in an interview today. "Somebody has to accept less income. And somebody has to pay the bills."
 
Attacks Back Home
 In a taste of what Mr. Kerrey and other Democrats can expect in the 15 months leading up to their re-election contests, the Nebraska Republican Party issued a press release today attacking the state's two Democratic Senators: "Instead of standing up for Nebraska, Bob Kerrey and Jim Exon were the key votes to pass the Clinton budget plan. This tax plan is a fraud masquerading as deficit reduction."
Indeed, there is little evidence that the budget victory will usher in a new era of bipartisan cooperation in the capital.
Though he prefaced his remarks by saying "I don't wish bad things for this country," Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the ranking Republican on the Budget Committee, hardly seemed convinced that the Clinton plan would put people back to work and boost the economy.
"The proof will be in the pudding," he said. "If it doesn't work, it's not going to be much of a victory."
As the Democrats continue to rebut such skepticism, and convince a somewhat disbelieving public that the budget plan is a good step, officials say they plan to keep the White House "war room," originally created for the Congressional fight, open.
Roger C. Altman, the deputy treasury secretary who runs the operation -- and is no doubt weary after months of insisting that the budget would not place an unfair burden on the middle class -- said: "We still have work to do in terms of dispelling some of these myths and explaining again and again and again why this is good for the country. So we're going to continue in business for a while."
Ms. Baggett, the White House political director, said the Administration hoped that after Mr. Clinton traveled around the country promoting the plan beginning next week, "people will start to feel better," adding, "Even in our own polls there's still a disappointing number who think they're going to be the ones taxed."
Many Democrats in Congress do not sound as hopeful as Mr. Altman or Ms. Baggett. Senator Kohl, for one, seemed to hedge his bets in his 60-second television commercial.
"While you and I may not agree on all aspects of this bill," he told viewers, "I believe it is essential for our future and the future of our children that we begin to get this deficit under control."

HEADLINE: Votes in Congress

 BODY:
Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
Senate
1. Nomination: Vote to confirm Sheldon Hackney, president of the University of Pennsylvania, to be chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities. Approved 76 to 23, Aug. 3.
2. National Service: Vote on passage of a national service bill that would give students education aid in return for community service. Approved 58 to 41, Aug. 3.
3. Abortions: Vote on an amendment to a spending bill for the Treasury and other related agencies that would allow a ban on insurance coverage for abortions in Federal workers' health plans. Rejected 51 to 48, Aug.3.
4. Budget : Vote on passage of President Clinton's five-year economic plan. Approved 51 to 50, Aug. 6. The tie-breaking vote was cast by Vice-President Al Gore.

HEADLINE: A Slow Boil In the Melting Pot

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

 BODY:
On wooden benches at Seth Low Park in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, Russian emigres gather daily to play chess and dominoes and to discuss the latest political developments in their homeland. Not long ago, Italian-Americans would have been sitting on those benches playing cards.
But in the last few years, the Russian emigres, most of whom are Jewish, have slowly replaced the Italian-Americans, who have moved their card games inside the park's clubhouse. "It's too bad that they don't come anymore," 66-year-old Mikhail Kopyt said through an interpreter. "There was never any problem with them. I don't know why they stopped coming." 
 Faced with a shortage of affordable and decent housing in the traditional Russian enclave of Brighton Beach, a new wave of emigres, who left soon after the 1991 failed coup against Mikhail S. Gorbachev, have opted to settle in Bensonhurst.
 
Clash of Cultures
 While Bensonhurst has been viewed in recent years as not welcoming outsiders with open arms, it was not seen as antagonistic toward other white ethnic groups. Yet, with the arrival of about 17,000 Russian Jewish emigres since 1991, many of the community's longtime residents have been less than cordial to their new neighbors.
Interviews with more than two dozen people revealed deep resentment toward the Russians, with Bensonhurst's longtime residents complaining that the emigres are too pushy, do not understand American culture, are taking scarce jobs and, when unable to find jobs, are living on welfare.
At the same time, the Russians often keep to themselves because many of them do not speak English.
"If you told me years ago that a blond-haired, blue-eyed person would be discriminated against in Bensonhurst, I would have thought you were crazy," said Dennis Torreggiani, chief of staff for Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro, a Democrat whose district includes Bensonhurst. "I don't go anywhere without hearing some remarks about the Russians."
 
Tension and Animosity
 "No one indoctrinated the Russians before they got here," said Carmine Santa Maria, president of the Bensonhurst West End Community Council, a community organization.
But Mr. Santa Maria said the Italian-Americans sometimes have to reach out to the newcomers to help close the cultural gaps. "They don't understand the American ways," he said, "and consequently they are rubbing people the wrong way."
In some ways, the tension and animosity in Bensonhurst simply reflect the problems that can arise when a neighborhood experiences an influx of a different ethnic or racial group. Several neighborhoods in New York City have recently experienced the arrival of black, Hispanic or Asian people in mostly white communities.
And when such a shift occurs in a neighborhood like Bensonhurst, where some residents may still feel the sting of racial tension that flared after the shooting death of a black youth, Yusuf K. Hawkins, in 1989, there can be a volatile strain.
But in other ways the tension seems to reflect deeper problems, including economics and some of the animosities that many Americans feel toward immigrants.
 
Deep Resentment
 Rose Mattino, who has lived in Bensonhurst all of her 39 years, expressed some of those views when she complained that too many of the emigres receive public assistance. "They come here and get it like that," she said, snapping her fingers. "They all have food stamps. That's my money and I resent it."
Sal Liotti, 41, who was standing next to Mrs. Mattino, added: "When my parents came over from the old country, they had to work. Today everything is given to them. We have the greatest deficit. We have homeless people who were born here. Why don't we take care of them."
In the last three years, about 40,000 Jews have left the former Soviet Union, with half settling in New York City, said Joel B. Karpp, executive director of the Jewish Community House of Bensonhurst. That influx has helped to make Russians the seventh-largest ethnic group in the city, according to the Department of City Planning, and their numbers may grow as the former Soviet Union relaxes restrictions on travel.
As more Russian Jews move to New York City, many look outside their usual settlement areas, like Brighton Beach, in the hope of finding a nicer neighborhood.
 
'The Word Is Out'
 Mr. Karpp, whose agency is one of the largest community-based organizations working in the resettlement of Russians in the United States, said the new immigrants know of Bensonhurst, with its broad streets and single-family houses, even before they come here.
"They come with a piece of paper with our address scribbled on it," he said sitting inside his spacious office in Bensonhurst with folders stacked on a large desk. "The word about Bensonhurst is out back there. They're not going to Brighton Beach as much anymore."
Many of the recent immigrants settling in Bensonhurst are largely professionals and members of the former Soviet Union's intelligentsia. To them, Brighton Beach is a stronghold of the proletariat.
"We're very educated people," said Gabriel Shalmiy, a 36-year-old dentistry student at New York University who settled in Bensonhurst about a year ago. "We try to find a very quiet place to live. We like a place where there is no fighting."
 
Paying a Price
 While they have found such a place, it has not come without a high price.
Mikhail Penkich, a 68-year-old former factory manager in the old Soviet Union, said that recently while playing dominoes in Seth Low Park a passer-by shouted to them: "You should all be shot. You're sitting here playing while we're out working."
Most of the emigres are simply impervious to the animosities, in part because they do not speak English and tend to keep to themselves.
Others, like Mr. Penkich, are willing to dismiss such outbursts as the acts of a few zealots. "It's possible that the man was insane," Mr. Penkich said. "We just ignored it."
Of course, not all of Bensonhurst has shown animosity or resentment toward the emigres.
Assemblyman Barbaro, for example, hired a Russian affairs liaison to translate documents and to help the Russians file for political asylum, said his aide, Mr. Torreggiani.
Local banks display "We speak Russian" signs on their windows and Russian language is available at many automated teller machines.
 
Opening Stores and Delis
 At the same time, Russian emigres have opened dozens of stores and delis selling Russian sausage and pelmeni, a ravioli stuffed with meat, on 86th Street, a busy commercial center. Others have posted Russian language fliers advertising their skills. "Manicure, pedicure, wax, very low prices," reads one.
"They've added a certain amount of flair to the community," said Howard Feuer, district manager of Community Board 11 in Bensonhurst. "They pour money back into the community and have kept it thriving."
Many of the new emigres are not thriving. Despite public and private assistance, they are struggling to eke out a living.
Yelena Kolbasko, 24, who worked as a food manager in Minsk, is now unemployed. Her husband, Sergei, 25, a mechanic, is also out of work. They have a 4-year-old daughter, Yekaterina. The family receives $600 a month in public assistance. Their one-bedroom apartment costs $500, leaving little for luxuries. To get by, they juggle their budget, and they are always late paying one bill or another.
"We feel very badly about it," Mrs. Kolbasko said about receiving public assistance. "We feel like we're at the bottom rung of society. But without it we could not survive."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With the arrival of about 17,000 Russian Jewish emigres in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, since 1991, many Italian-American residents have begun to express deep resentment toward this other white ethnic group. For the last few years, tables in Seth Low Park in Bensonhurst, above, have been occupied by Russians rather than Italian-Americans, who have moved their games and discussions elsewhere. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Just a Moment on Those Layoff 'Experts'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Regarding "Learning the Lessons of a Layoff" and "Job Hunting Beyond the Want Ads" (Your Own Account, July 11 and 18): Just where did you dig up the "experts" on the unemployed? They seemed to agree on just one thing -- if people are laid off, it's got to be their own damn fault. My guess is that they all make a good living soothing the feelings of the managers booting people out on the street. As one who was laid off late last year, I suggest that the management expert you might consider for your next article on this subject is W. Edwards Deming, who says 85 percent of the problems a company has are caused by its management.
 
JAMES V. CHAVERN
Boulder, Colo., July 18

HEADLINE: The Budget Fight Has Just Begun

 BODY:
When Vice President Al Gore cast the tie-breaking vote in the Senate on Friday, Congress ended a long battle over the Administration's five-year economic program. But an even more fundamental struggle over the budget has just begun.
What Congress did last week was primarily to set taxes and spending formulas for entitlement programs, like Medicare and food stamps. But it still must decide, after returning from summer vacation, how much to spend next year on programs that don't work by formula -- discretionary programs that include everything from the F.B.I. to the census. At stake is whether the core of Mr. Clinton's program survives, or whether he is forced to retreat to a program little different from George Bush's. 
 At the center of Mr. Clinton's economic plan was the promise to tilt spending toward investment, the key to growth. He proposed new discretionary programs to finance worker training, scientific research and infrastructure improvements. But for Congress to pass the new and stay within self-imposed spending limits, it must give up the old -- spitting in the face of powerful constituents who are quite happy with their Federal handouts.
And to make matters worse for Mr. Clinton, members of his own party, like Representative Timothy Penny of Minnesota, want Congress to make an additional round of spending cuts this fall. If these cut-at-all-cost advocates get their way, they will force Congress to abandon almost everything that's new in the Clinton program. That would turn Clintonomics into little more than Reaganomics: Cut Federal spending for its own sake.
Contrary to the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole, and friends, the five-year budget agreement has teeth. Discretionary spending, other than for defense, will be held virtually constant for five years, accounting for inflation. President Clinton has proposed about $50 billion in new investment spending over five years. If he's to get his way, Congress must take an equal amount out of old programs. But for a legislature that can't summon the courage to take on the mohair and honey bee producers, the task appears herculean.
The House has proposed eliminating almost half of Mr. Clinton's investment initiatives for next year. Mr. Clinton asked for $135 million for his youth apprenticeship program, a key to training non-college-bound workers. The House gave him only $34 million. He asked for $1.5 billion to help workers thrown out of work because their plants closed; the House gave only $550 million. He sought more than $200 million for aid to schools serving underprivileged children; the House gave nothing. He sought about $200 million for scientific initiatives; the House gave less than half.
The list goes on and on. Of course, some of Mr. Clinton's proposals weren't worth funding. And the Administration is responsible for part of the problem by proposing too few cuts to pay for its initiatives. Nevertheless, the pattern of cutting huge chunks out of the President's investment plans is unsettling.
Matters will turn darkly worse if Congress engages in a new round of deficit cuts. Mr. Clinton plans to ask Congress next year to substitute more of his programs for existing programs. But if Congress cuts spending first and devotes the savings to deficit reduction, it would put the White House in a no-win bind. The President would be forced to pay for new programs with tax hikes, leaving him prey to bashing by Republicans as a tax-and-spend Democrat. Or he would have to abandon his investment program, rendering him indistinguishable from George Bush. Congress should spare him that predicament.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In America;
The 6.8% Illusion

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
Following a marathon struggle, President Clinton has his budget deal. Now would be a good time for the Administration to stop giving the public a false impression about job creation.
Mr. Clinton's top economic adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, says a million jobs have been created so far this year. To the average ear, that sounds impressive. It's not. The Administration sometimes uses employment statistics the way a carnival barker uses his pitch -- to mislead the unsuspecting. 
 According to figures released by the Federal Government on Friday, 1,230,000 jobs have been created since January. But 728,000 -- nearly 60 percent -- were part-time jobs. Most of the remainder were service-sector jobs, many of them temporary, that paid low wages and offered few or no benefits.
These are not the kind of jobs that can adequately support families or sustain an economic recovery.
Real wages, meaning wages adjusted for inflation, continue to fall, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
And good jobs continue to vanish at an alarming rate. Layoffs in the U.S. this year have reached 353,614, according to a report by Challenger, Gray and Christmas, a private firm that counsels employees who are discharged. Layoffs are averaging more than 50,000 per month, which is 4,000 per month higher than the recession year of 1991.
"The jobs being created are not good jobs," said Dean Baker, a research economist with the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. "Overwhelmingly they're poorly paid, less secure, and less likely to have benefits. A lot of them are in retail trade, so we're having people going to work in 7-11's, McDonald's, . . . a lot of restaurant work."
The jobs situation has a direct and formidable impact on families. "You have a lot more families that are in distress," said Mr. Baker. "Now the typical family is the two-wage-earner family. The odds are that at least one of the wage earners has either lost their job, or is worried about losing their job."
Few economists are forecasting substantial improvements. "My contention is that the statistics look better than reality would suggest," said Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist for DKB Securities, the domestic arm of the Dai-Ichi Bank of Tokyo, the world's largest private banking organization.
Mr. Braverman believes that some of the job-creation estimates by the Federal Government are too high. Last year, for example, as more data came in, the Bureau of Labor Statistics found it had overestimated manufacturing jobs by about 129,000.
Mr. Braverman also noted that among individuals who are counted as self-employed, there are many who have chosen self-employment because they could not find other work. "Many people who are self-employed have no income," he said. Yet they are still counted as employed.
There are many reasons for the widespread gloom over jobs: Major firms are downsizing, government and business are overburdened by debt, Federal taxes are increasing, Federal spending is decreasing, and there is an enormous employment drag caused by the post-cold war contraction of defense spending.
"The Defense Department estimates that through 1997 an additional 1.9 million individuals will lose their jobs," said Mr. Braverman. He added that the estimated "indirect effect of those layoffs" will be five million more people "thrown out of work."
"This will be an unusual, extraordinary burden that is not being adequately recognized by economists," he said.
The official unemployment rate dropped from 7 percent to 6.8 percent in July. But William Barron, Deputy Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, told a Congressional committee that because of the statistical rounding of numbers the new, lower rate "was not materially different from the levels that have prevailed since early in the year."
That was underscored by the latest figures on the long-term unemployed -- individuals who have been out of work at least 15 weeks. The number of people in that category rose by 188,000.
The Clinton Administration has been desperate for good economic news, but there is not much of it in employment.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Coming Oil Shortage Will Worsen Food Crisis;
New Crops Needed

 BODY:
To the Editor:
An all-out effort is needed to slow population growth, as Lester R. Brown states in "Natural Limits" (Op-Ed, July 24), but such an effort will not significantly reduce the population explosion of the next 10 to 20 years. In addition, some 700 million people today do not have access to enough food. 
 To meet the needs of these and future populations, developing countries must be helped to grow more food. Eating fewer or smaller steaks in the United States will not help starving people in Ethiopia. Consuming less of what developing countries export, such as coffee, will make matters worse, particularly for the poor who depend on exports for income.
The international aid community, together with the governments of developing countries, can expand food production and reduce poverty.
Science and technology, along with the building of rural roads and other infrastructure and government policies, still offer the only means to meet food production needs in Africa and South Asia, which are the areas of greatest concern.
The focus of agricultural scientists in national and international research centers around the world, particularly those that are members and affiliates of the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research, is development of new crop varieties that not only increase yields but also protect the environment.
Research and technology require money. Investment in agricultural research and development has been declining among the world's aid agencies -- including the United States Agency for International Development and the World Bank -- and agriculture has received less attention from many governments of developing countries in recent years. We need to start focusing on the problem by setting realistic goals.
These include population planning and increased investment in agricultural research and technology to increase production and reduce poverty in those countries with the most need.
 
PER PINSTRUP-ANDERSEN
Director General, International
Food Policy Research Institute
Washington, July 30, 1993

HEADLINE: A Cartel Is Forever

BYLINE: By Adam Hochschild; Adam Hochschild is the author of "Half the Way Home: A Memoir of Father and Son" and "The Mirror at Midnight: A South African Journey."

 BODY:

THE LAST EMPIRE
De Beers, Diamonds, and the World.
By Stefan Kanfer.
Illustrated. 409 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux.
$25. 
SOME years ago I interviewed the gold and diamond magnate Harry Oppenheimer in Johannesburg. A man of great, unassuming charm, he had mastered the South African art of sounding enlightened: one jolly well can't deny all these black chaps the vote forever, can one? It was hard to remember that his industrial empire made munitions for the South African police, and that it once equipped the barracks of restive black miners with tear-gas dispensers operated by remote control. All too many reporters never do remember such things, and those who write about Mr. Oppenheimer's multibillion-dollar business kingdom tend to be awe-struck. Happily, Stefan Kanfer is not.
His story is of the oldest part of the kingdom's wealth, the diamonds. It begins in 1867, when a 15-year-old Boer farm boy discovered a glittering stone. Ten years later, Mr. Kanfer tells us, the "Big Hole" at Kimberly was "the largest man-made excavation in the world," a 12-acre bowl 230 feet deep, where 3,500 sweating black laborers filled buckets with diamond-bearing earth, which were then hoisted on cables to the surface, where white claim holders reaped the profits.
Several decades later the Oppenheimer family, German-Jewish immigrants to South Africa, gained control of De Beers Consolidated Mines, the dominant power in the South African diamond fields and therefore in the world diamond market. Before the Oppenheimers there had been a colorful procession of other magnates, from Cecil Rhodes to the eccentric Barney Barnato, who went mad, clawed for diamonds at cracks in the wall and leapt to his death over a ship's railing screaming, "They're after me!" The stories of these men have been told often, but in "The Last Empire" Mr. Kanfer retells them well. He has a fine eye for the striking quote. For example, when Rhodes feared that Rhodesia might lose its name, he cried: "They can't take it away from me, can they? You never heard of a country's name being changed?"

 Despite the fluent, vivid writing, the book sometimes has an armchair feeling about it. This may be unavoidable in covering the 19th century, but when Mr. Kanfer, the author of books on the Holocaust and the blacklisting era in the United States, brings his account up to the present, there is little indication of any talks he may have had with key figures in De Beers or, more important, that he visited a diamond mine and spoke to the people who worked there.
Nonetheless, he tells an important tale. The diamond empire of the Oppenheimers is the world's most enduring cartel. Beside it, OPEC is an unsteady toddler. Diamond prices only go up. The main reason is that whenever someone finds a new source of diamonds, whether in Arkansas or Australia, the helpful investors who immediately appear on the scene are almost always from one of the 1,300 companies around the world affiliated with De Beers. So is the buyer of the patent when an inventor finds a new way of making synthetic industrial diamonds. During World War II, President Franklin D. Roosevelt placed a huge, urgent order for industrial diamonds with De Beers. Fearing that a quick end to the war might leave the United States with a big surplus, which could send diamond prices plunging, De Beers said no. It claimed that its London storage vaults "had been bombed shut." After much angry pressure, De Beers finally supplied a small fraction of what Roosevelt had asked for.
What does the wielding of such great power mean? Although Mr. Kanfer never says so explicitly, the moral of his story seems to be this: International business no longer inhabits a world where companies try to influence governments. Instead, to the multinational mega-corporations, it makes little difference what kind of government a country has.
Dozens of African nations became independent during the 1960's. If they had diamonds, it did not matter whether they were capitalist (Botswana), socialist (Tanzania) or dictatorial (Zaire), or even if they were at war with South Africa (Angola). De Beers was always there with an offer they couldn't refuse -- in part because they, too, wanted diamond prices high. And for those who did not wish to deal with a company from apartheid South Africa, it was always possible to set up a joint venture with a firm from Luxembourg or Switzerland or the Bahamas.
The most extraordinary such partnership of all was between De Beers and the Soviet Union. South Africa banned the Communist Party and imprisoned every member it could find (until 1990); the Russians gave military training to African National Congress guerrillas. Yet De Beers executives quietly slipped in and out of Moscow, and, for decades, tens of billions of dollars worth of Soviet diamonds passed across the long mahogany table of the De Beers central sales office in London.
At the end of last year, things were looking ominous for the cartel; in his final pages Mr. Kanfer wonders whether it can endure. The world recession had depressed the demand for diamonds; the Soviet Union had dissolved, and Russia was threatening to as well -- with the vast Far Eastern territory of Yakutia, source of one-fourth of the world's diamonds, loudly declaring independence and secretly selling cut-rate diamonds to Japan. However, De Beers has plenty of experience in Africa with countries going independent. Its trouble-shooters have struck new deals with the Russians and the Yakuts. Since Mr. Kanfer finished his book, De Beers has raised the world diamond price once again. Governments fall, entire countries come and go, but diamonds -- and the cartel that controls them -- are forever.

LENGTH: 1515 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
When It Comes to the Hereafter, Romance and Sentiment Rule

BYLINE: By KENNETH M. CHANKO; Kenneth M. Chanko writes about movies and video for Entertainment Weekly and Parenting.

 BODY:
EVER SINCE THE 1937 "TOPPER" became a hit, spawning two sequels and a television series, Hollywood has been dabbling in ghost stories. For decades, movies set in haunted houses were a horror staple. In the past few years, however, it has been fanciful romantic comedies and dramas like "Ghost" (1990), which earned more than $200 million at the box office, and the sentimental "Field of Dreams" (1989), with its baseball-playing ghosts, that seem to beguile Hollywood.
The basic conceit of these ghost movies is that the dearly departed return to guide, reclaim or pester the folks who are left behind. On the heels of two recently released ghost comedies, "Hocus Pocus" and "My Boyfriend's Back," comes the spirits-in-limbo sweepstakes "Heart and Souls," which opens on Friday with Robert Downey Jr. as a mortal with four soul mates. 
 Ron Underwood, like most directors working the territory, has not blown the budget on pie-in-the-sky sets. Few heaven-related movies devote much time to heaven. That would be a bore. The appeal of ghost movies, not hard to understand, is to have dead people take matters in hand and reconnect with the living, which usually turns out to be character-building, or at least comforting, for all.
The draw of such movies is, of course, the primal fear of death and the happy possibility of an afterlife. But most also affirm that a moral code is still operational in the hereafter, and that ghosts will be able to obtain a measure of justice or, failing that, revenge.
The touchstone for many of the recent ghost movies ("Heart and Souls" included) is "It's a Wonderful Life," in which Clarence the guardian angel steers James Stewart back to his family and friends. It is this film's humanistic spirit that movies like "Heart and Souls" try to capture. In uncertain times, the conceit is that everyone has a guardian angel like Clarence. "It's much more comforting when the spirits turn out to be good ones," says Stuart Fischoff, a media psychologist in Los Angeles. "Those movies play very well -- as long as they are nondenominational."
In "Heart and Souls," four people who randomly board a bus in 1959 perish in a crash. Their spirits then witness the birth of baby Thomas (who will grow into Mr. Downey) in a car near the crash site. Perceived by the child's parents as "imaginary friends," these four spirits -- a two-bit thief (Tom Sizemore), a timid would-be singer (Charles Grodin), a young woman (Kyra Sedgwick) trying to reach her boyfriend and a single working mother (Alfre Woodard) -- can be seen and heard only by Thomas. Years later, Thomas (now a callow yuppie) is called on to help the four ghosts right old wrongs and wrap up their lives. Through those good deeds, Thomas learns to value what's really important.
Thus "Heart and Souls" pushes more than the usual number of buttons for a movie of this kind: childhood fears of abandonment are played upon (when Thomas is 7, his angels decide to leave him by making themselves invisible -- for his own good, of course) and the wishes of a single mother are satisfied when she learns how her children fared after her death. And throughout there is the notion that one can form one's own nourishing circle of friends, even if those friends happen to be dead.
Movies like "Heart and Souls" speak to our innermost anxieties, according to Arthur Kovacs, a Los Angeles-based psychologist. Mr. Kovacs believes such films are especially appealing these days. "The hard economic times, our aging population and the continuing erosion of traditional religions among the more educated middle and upper classes contribute to their popularity," he says.
PARTICULARLY SUSCEPTIBLE is the aging baby boomer, who faces a precarious economic future and may be prone to worries about dying (partly because he or she has doubts about an afterlife). By the time baby boomers have reached their late 40's, it's also possible that at least one parent has died. The loss of someone close -- especially in this age of AIDS -- only fuels the kinds of thoughts and yearnings these movies play to.
For Hollywood, the trick is to raise the subject of death without dwelling on it. Diane Keaton's 1987 documentary "Heaven" was a box-office disappointment, and Ms. Keaton has a good idea why. "I don't think most people really want to think too directly or too long about death," she says. For that reason, most of these movies resist overt religious overtones (the few that don't, like "Resurrection" and "The Rapture," pay a price at the box office).
Mr. Underwood, whose last film was "City Slickers," is comfortable working under the halo of secular humanism. "I'm not looking for people to debate the possibility of life after death," he says. "I'd prefer they come out of the theater valuing, here and now, their relationships with loved ones."
The more popular ghost movies have always reflected the times in which they are made. "We've been interested in what happens after death for at least 20,000 years," says Dr. James Lundy, a retired social psychologist and ordained minister in Greensboro, N.C. Dr. Lundy points out, "When religions don't fulfill society's needs or assuage people's fears -- which often involve fears about dying -- popular culture takes over." As much as reflecting our fears, stories about ghosts function as projections of our fantasies.
Take the blithe goings-on in the 30's escapist film "Topper." The Depression didn't burst the bubble of the Kirbys (Cary Grant and Constance Bennett), who traipsed off to places like the Rainbow Room at the drop of a hat. Once they died in a car accident, their good deed consisted of making the timorous Cosmo Topper (Roland Young) as happy-go-lucky as they were.
It isn't difficult to see why a movie like "The Ghost and Mrs. Muir" struck a chord in 1947, with many women trying to get on with their lives after losing husbands in the war. In the film, a young widow with a small child falls in love with the ghost of a handsome sea captain.
Other than the standard haunted-house B movie, the 1950's and early 60's offered few ghost films. Says Dr. Kovacs, "Those movies tend to pop up when society is in turmoil or traditional values are on the wane. We knew what we stood for in the 50's."
Tales involving the spirit world weren't terribly relevant in the late 60's and early 70's, either, since revolutionary cosmic entertainments like "2001: A Space Odyssey" were capturing the imagination. In the post-Vietnam era, Warren Beatty's 1978 film "Heaven Can Wait" (about a football player who is taken before his time and allowed to return to Earth) scored a modest success by positing that one's true love can be found and happiness attained -- even in the most muddled of circumstances. In general, when film makers want to appeal to a young-adult audience (not yet ruminating over its own mortality), romance is played up.
The 80's saw a proliferation of silly, special-effects-laden hits like "Ghostbusters" and "Beetlejuice." Since those were times when thoughts of self-improvement took a back seat to money-making schemes, it's worth noting that in "Ghostbusters" vanquishing the spirits provided gainful employment for the carefree main characters.
" 'Heart and Souls' wouldn't have worked very well in the mid-80's," says Mr. Underwood. "People like Thomas were being championed then for the very things we're now saying aren't what's really important."
Two years after the 1987 stock market crash, which essentially brought the high-flying 80's to an end, along came "Field of Dreams." In that box-office hit, the road to redemption and inner peace for the Kevin Costner character seemed to lead as well to almost-certain financial ruin.
"Ghost" was a notable hybrid in that it played on our doubts and fantasies yet was romantic to boot, which presumably accounts for its huge grosses. The film spent most of its time on the gratifying premise that even after death we remain connected to loved ones.
In the 1991 film "Defending Your Life," Albert Brooks set his entire movie about the afterlife in the Las Vegas-like Judgment City, where people must defend their spiritually hampered lives before progressing to the next level. But the limbo this idiosyncratic film envisions isn't as bad as it first seems. It's a place where you benefit from a not-too-painful analysis. And you can eat all you want and not get fat.
What many recent movies, especially "Heart and Souls," share is a humanistic, nonmaterialistic point of view. "As long as you don't get too preachy or self-righteous about it, people will go for this kind of thing," says Mr. Downey. "With the coming of the millennium, people are ready to look at things differently."
Since you can't take it with you, the rejection of material gain isn't a surprising theme in movies about the spirit world. But there's a certain irony when one considers the purveyor of the message. Sean Daniel, one of the producers of "Heart and Souls," recognizes that when he says, "Isn't it noble of Hollywood to deal with the materialism issue in this way?"

LENGTH: 1327 words

HEADLINE: Focus: Vancouver, B.C.;
Waterfront Projects Meeting Resistance

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, B.C.

 BODY:
WITH British Columbia's economy and real estate market improving, two local developers have been trying to redevelop the waterfront in two affluent communities across the harbor from downtown Vancouver and have run into opposition on several levels.
Land in the two communities -- North Vancouver and West Vancouver -- is scarce and expensive. The developers, the Larco Group of Companies and the Viam Group, are concentrating on an eight-mile stretch of Marine Drive, proposing new projects and speeding work on those already under way. 
 They have clashed with residents who fear that more traffic and people will change their neighborhoods and with marine-based industries that need the harbor to survive and feel threatened by commercial development.
The communities are linked to downtown by the Lions Gate Bridge. East of the bridge lies North Van, which from downtown looks like a mystical city built on Hollyburn Mountain's lower slopes. At sundown, the windows of its tall office spires, condominiums and hillside homes blaze with reflections.
West of the bridge, where Burrard Inlet empties into Howe Sound, is the resort-like West Van, one of Canada's wealthiest residential areas. And eight miles east is the working harbor for tugboat companies, drydocks, railroads and terminals for grain, potash and coal.
Until 55 years ago, the area -- directly across the bay from renowned Stanley Park -- was accessible only by private boat or ferry. But the Guinness family of England -- famous for stout -- acquired vast tracts there through a company called British Pacific Properties and built many homes. To entice people to move there, the company built the Lions Gate Bridge in 1938. As a further lure, it built Canada's first regional shopping center, Park Royal Shopping Center, on Marine Drive, in 1950.
In 1990, Larco bought the million-square-foot Park Royal mall and is now doing a $20 million revitalization, including 95,000 square feet of streetfront retail space and a golf range, which is expected to open soon.
"The shopping center needed a facelift," said Robert Heaslip, Larco's chief planner. "It looked tired. It was time to look at the retail mix and how we wanted to take the center into the year 2000." The center, which has had major additions through the years, is split by Marine Drive.
"The problem that needed solving was how to give a sense of unity," said John Cochran of the Callison Partnership, the Seattle architects who did the revitalization design. "We needed an upgrade consistent with the charm of the upscale neighborhood."
Mr. Heaslip said Larco was one of 10 investors who owned land on Clyde Avenue, parallel to and a block north of Marine Drive, adjacent to the quaint Park Royal Hotel. They plan to upgrade streets, utilities and landscaping and sell or lease sites for office, retail and residential development.
LARCO also owns a 4.5-acre site a few blocks away. It plans two high-rise residential towers there with 400,000 square feet. The plan would require razing the Capilano Athletic Health Club, now on the site, but the club's owner, whose lease runs to mid-1996 and who has refused Larco's offer of $400,000 for lost business, has vowed to go to court to halt construction.
Some residents say the development will destroy the character of their neighborhood. Larco counters by saying it will put something back into the community by including a community center and 40 units of housing for the elderly. Larco will have to get the city to rezone its site before it can proceed.
Controversy nearly killed a $50 million condominium project on 3.5 acres next to the Park Royal mall. West Vancouver owns the land, which had housed a municipal works yard and a car dealership. In the early 80's the municipality requested proposals from developers on a 99-year lease. The one selected fizzled when the economy soured.
In 1989 the municipality tried again. Viam Group and its proposal for a residential complex won out over four other bidders. Steven Nicholls, West Van's planning director, said that Viam, which had 20 years of construction experience, won partly because it offered to pay $10 million up front for the lease.
But residents grew concerned that the two towers, 18 and 24 stories high, would be out of scale for the neighborhood and that increased traffic would create gridlock on Marine Drive. In a 1989 referendum voters were asked whether they thought the project should be built. They split 50-50. Mr. Nicholls said the district's council, seeing opinion was divided, decided the project should proceed.
Construction recently ended and marketing is under way for the 182 condominum units, which start at $269,500 and average 1,300 square feet.
In West Van's business district, many older stores are being remodeled and on back streets new low-rise stores, offices and houses are being built. The same is true eastward along Marine Drive where a dozen years ago there were few fast-food restaurants; today cafes and pizza houses abound and there are strip malls as far as Lonsdale Avenue, eight miles away.
"Ten years ago we were quite lonely here along the water," says Claire Johnson, president of C.H. Cates & Sons Ltd,. a 108-year-old company at the foot of Londsale that operates 18 tugs on a five-mile stretch of Burrard Inlet between the Lions Gate and Second Narrows Bridges. "The lot next to us was vacant. We used to play horseshoe and volleyball and grow tomatoes there."
Today that lot is Lonsdale Quay and thousands of north shore residents stream onto Seabuses there to speed across the harbor to downtown. Adjacent to the Seabus terminal is a waterfront mall, built in time for Expo '86, with a farmers market, meat and seafood shops, ethnic fast-food restaurants, boutiques and the Lonsdale Quay hotel.
"Change has been dramatic," says Amin Karim, the hotel's general manager. "Upland from Marine Drive the rundown stores are gone, along with the feeling it was not safe to walk the streets at night. Now there are a lot of expensive condos. This is creating an environment for expensive shops."
Cates nearly became a victim of the pressure to sacrifice industry for tourism and commercial development. In the mid-70's while the province was planning the new Seabus terminal, a sheriff's deputy served notice on its owners that the province had expropriated their land. They were ordered to vacate within 30 days. The deputy tried to give them an envelope with a check as property compensation, but they refused it.
"We were in shock," said Mr. Johnson. "For us to pick up and move made no sense. Our business was between the Lions Gate and Second Narrows bridges and our 115 employees live close by."
The company refused to move and in 1981, after a hard-fought battle, it regained title.
SOME people and developers are looking at the potential of the abandoned Versatile Pacific Shipyards, just east of Cates, where the only operating business is the Vancouver Dry Dock. Many developers, municipal officials, businessmen and residents want the Lonsdale Quay retail shops and boutiques to be extended there.
This does not sit well with the Vancouver Port Corporation, an autonomous Federal Crown corporation that owns part of the land, which is valuable to industry because it is a deep-water seaport. The corporation is negotiating with the private owner of the remaining land to acquire the property.
"We want to safeguard this land for future industrial and marine business," says Dietmar Setzer, the corporation's director of property administration. He believes all land east of Lonsdale should be industrial. Community leaders say that if the powerful corporation wants the land it will get it.
James O'Hara, a corporation vice president, says: "Because of the scarcity of land, there is pressure from people who want to move back to the waterfront. But it just doesn't make sense to build a condo next to a grain terminal."

HEADLINE: An Island of Summer Fun in Bridgeport

BYLINE: By VALERIE CRUICE

 BODY:
"IT'S about a mile from 95," a visitor was told as part of the directions to the McGivney Community Center in Bridgeport. "And lock your doors."
For nearly that entire distance, from the exit ramp to the turn off East Main Street in the city's economically depressed East Side, the visitor had an escort of sorts: a battered late-model car with Massachusetts plates traveling slowly yet erratically, with its driver's head turning to one side and then the other, scanning the streets that throbbed with the rhythms of everyday life. 
 Suddenly, without warning, the driver jerked his car over to the curb; a group of young men on a sidewalk caught his attention. He had apparently found what he was looking for -- someone to buy drugs from.
Rising above the shoddy rows of buildings and within sight of such transactions was the tower of St. Charles Borromeo, a Roman Catholic church in whose complex is housed the year-and-a-half-old McGivney Community Center. It is part of a one-square-block fortress against readily available drugs, poverty and ignorance.
 
A Beacon of Sorts
 Outside its metal gates on a nearby street corner sat a lone, battered chair with debris scattered on the ground around it. A drug dealer's office, a visitor was told. And opposite the front door of the McGivney Center, across the street, a more violent beacon languished: a charred house whose former residents had been drug dealers -- mysteriously torched.
They had even tried to sell drugs to the workers renovating the center. But from those ashes will rise a new playground for the children being cared for at the center.
And like the climbing roses conquering a chain-link fence in a tiny yard across the street from St. Charles's own fenced-in complex, the children of the neighborhood are learning how to overcome their boundaries through the nurturing efforts of the McGivney Center.
Over the next few weeks, about 100 children 7 through 12 will be attending McGivney Summer Fun, a day camp that operates Monday through Friday. They are fed breakfast and lunch, learn about computers, arts and crafts and play sports, and several times a week are taken to nearby outdoor camps for swimming and other recreation. Many of the children learn -- for perhaps the first time -- how it feels to have rules, be safe and be cared for.
 
Instilling Values
 "In the midst of many of their lives, there's chaos," said the director of the camp, Anthony Tozzi, who is 38 years old. The camp addresses that by having tight security, being highly organized and focused and by instilling values, he explained.
"We have a tradition of God, country and self, which we've lost in America," he continued.
After a federally subsidized breakfast for the children, Mr. Tozzi holds an assembly in which three things are always done: "All the kids close their eyes and have a silent prayer. Even if an individual is not religious, it gives the kids the opportunity to reflect. Then we do the Pledge of Allegiance, and it's said with pride. Then we go into self. One of the counselors will lead the entire group in an exercise program," he said.
From there the counselors and their groups start scheduled activities. Over a vast expanse of highly polished gym floor, children were making an intricate spider web out of yarn, while on the stage at one end, games were being played at numerous tables. At the other end, boys patiently waited their turns to shoot a basketball, carefully studying an older boy's technique.
 
Learning About Computers
 Upstairs, in what was once the parish hall's balcony and are now air-conditioned classrooms and offices, girls were quietly engrossed in lacing change purses in the arts and crafts room, and down the hall, learning about computers.
"Press enter, two players," said Lillian Torres, who is 18 years old and the computer teacher, as she ambled among the dozen 11-to-13-year-olds. "Maria, type your name."
Different computer games were in progress, the girls staring intently at the screens. Tania Serrano and Yamayra Mendez were concentrating hard on the Wheel of Fortune. "Dutchess of blank blank NDSOR" was on the screen. Yamayra turned to a visitor and entreated, "Help me?"
"Buy a vowel," came the response.
"An I."
Tania figured it out.
 
Role Model
 Miss Torres, their teacher, said it was hard to get the children out and on to their next activity, so popular is the computer program. Valedictorian of the local high school, Miss Torres is a role model for the young girls; she is headed to Connecticut College on a full scholarship this fall, because of her gift for computers.
Like Miss Torres, the counselors and staff are from the neighborhood and are hand-picked and trained by Mr. Tozzi, who has been affiliated with St. Charles for nine years and is also a resident of Bridgeport. What he looks for is "some level of energy to emulate" for the 7-to-12-year-old campers. And they don't all have to be at the top of their class: "Success is being the best you can be," he said to his counselors. They've all been trained in C.P.R. and first aid, and keep daily diaries.
Several times a week the campers are taken on trips. They visit state parks, Y.M.C.A. camps in New Britain and Greenwich and other day camps.
"We're looking to get these kids out, to meet other kids. They have to get out of these boundaries; get out and see there's other places, kids, the outside. They need to break down these walls. And they have to learn how to function in society, how to be accepting and how to be accepted," Mr. Tozzi said.
 
'A Perfect Father'
 What about discipline? "It's talking and reinforcing. What's going on with the kids? Where's the problem coming from? The more organized you are, the less you have to discipline your kids. If we need to, we get the parents involved, and as a last resort, we take charge. You have to be a perfect father," said Mr. Tozzi, a parent himself.
Besides keeping the children occupied during the summer vacation time, the McGivney Community Center runs programs during the school year.
How does the center get the children through the door? Anthony Forni, a retired General Electric executive who came up with the idea for the community center and serves on its board, explained that the center's strategy was "to attract them through sports and recreation programs."
"Then we motivate them to stay in school; it's a cliche, but our belief is the only way out of poverty is through education."
 
Logo Sends a Message
 And nowhere is this philosophy more evident than on the gymnasium floor, where the huge McGivney Community Center logo is painted; a basketball, a baseball bat and a book.
After school, youngsters can get help with their homework as well as computer training, participate in team sports and work at arts and crafts.
A video program has been organized for teen-agers in addition to an enormously popular eight-team basketball league, and supervised Friday night dances for teen-agers. There is a parenting program run by Save the Children, and a social worker is available to parents and children.
In the works is a cultural-arts program, which is being supported by the Southport Showhouse. More than $110,000 was raised for programs in dance, theater, music and video communications.
Children pay $5 to $15 a year, depending on age, to use the McGivney Community Center. "The reason we charge is to be sure every child understands the McGivney Center has value. However, we never turn a child away who cannot pay. We have donors who pay for the fee," said Mr. Forni. For a child to attend the summer fun camp, the fee is $15 for the entire six-week period. There is a waiting list.
At the end of the busy day, the campers and counselors assemble in the gym for an orderly dismissal, group by group. Before the doors are unlocked, however, sometimes Mr. Tozzi will talk about walking home, what to look for, especially for those campers who are not picked up.
"You have to constantly reinforce their awareness, without instilling fear," he said.
And whether it's street smarts or booting up a computer, the youngsters leave the fortress wearing a little more armor than before -- knowledge.
