HEADLINE: A Promise or a Threat?;
Long-Sought Supermarket Now Draws Fire

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
For more than three years, a coalition of church congregations in southeastern Queens has clamored, cajoled, begged and lobbied to lure one of the amenities of suburbia: a huge, modern supermarket like those taken for granted almost everywhere in America except New York City.
Now, two decades after the major supermarket chains abandoned largely black neighborhoods, consigning their shoppers to smaller, more expensive groceries, the church coalition appears to have succeeded. 
 And yet, even as they envision fresh meat, vegetables and economic development, their hopes have run headlong into the swelling neighborhood opposition that has greeted the recent arrival in New York of some of the nation's largest discount retailers.
 
Plans for a Megastore
 Supermarkets General Corporation, which owns the Pathmark chain, has agreed to build one of the city's largest supermarkets -- a 62,000-square-foot megastore with a deli, florist, bakery, pharmacy and video rental -- where a warehouse now stands on the border of Springfield Gardens and Laurelton.
But even as the coalition that lured it, the Queens Citizens Organization, plans a ceremony for Tuesday to announce the project and its promise of better shopping and 250 jobs, some residents and merchants in Laurelton have already objected vehemently. Calling it a threat to a way of life, they have vowed to fight the zoning variances the Pathmark will need.
"We don't need a supermarket of that magnitude," said Herbert Murdock, a high school assistant principal and chairman of the Federation of Laurelton Block Associations, who lives a few blocks from the proposed site. "An urban blight, that's what it will be."
 
Growing Resistance
 While large new stores often meet local resistance, especially from small merchants, opposition to superstores appears to be mounting as more of them arrive in the city -- from the grumbling about a block-long Barnes & Noble bookstore on the Upper West Side of Manhattan to the court challenge to a Home Depot at Aqueduct Race Track in Queens.
And as the city's Department of City Planning rewrites its zoning policies to make it easier for more such stores to open, the impact of the discount retailers has become a campaign issue.
On the steps of City Hall last Tuesday, Herman Badillo, the Republican-Liberal candidate for Comptroller who is also seeking the Democratic nomination, joined a demonstration by a trade group opposing the Pathmark and denounced the zoning proposals, warning of an "invasion of mega stores" and attacking Mayor David N. Dinkins.
"This zoning proposal by the Dinkins administration is one more piece of evidence of the Mayor's unremitting attack on small businesses," said Mr. Badillo, who is running on the same ticket as Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor.
The city's planners and many elected officials dismiss the opposition as misinformed and shortsighted. They say that the newly arrived superstores have not destroyed the city's shopping neighborhoods and in fact attract new customers to stagnant districts. They also say that the city must do all it can to attract retailers that could create thousands of jobs and generate millions of dollars in tax revenues on purchases that New Yorkers now make in the suburbs.
"There certainly is some opposition from small merchants who are worried about competition, but I'm not sure what the eight million other New Yorkers think," said Barry Dinerstein, a senior planner at the City Planning Department. "It would be unfortunate if the small merchants would not allow them that choice."
For the coalition of 25 churches that worked to attract the Pathmark, the opposition has become the latest obstacle in a long, frustrating effort to bring a fixture of suburban life to their neighborhoods.
 
Paying More, Getting Less
 The effort grew out of a basic fact of urban life: people in the city's less-affluent, mostly minority neighborhoods have to pay more for food in small markets and corner delis than those in the middle-class neighborhoods and the suburbs, who have easy access to large supermarkets.
For the coalition's leaders, that disparity prompts a flurry of passionate anecdotes about inconveniences and indignities, higher prices, filthy aisles, wilting vegetables and long drives to the suburbs in search of a decent supermarket.
Nola Southerland, the co-chairwoman of the coalition, complained of not being able to buy laundry soap in bulk, of the iron bars that won't let shopping carts into parking lots, of angrily pointing out rotting meat to a store manager only to be told it was "the manager's special." Her only recourse has been to drive to Nassau County to do her shopping.
"After all these years of seeing these things, of taking our money and spending it outside our neighborhood, we asked, 'Why can't we have that here?' " said Mrs. Southerland, a retired telephone company executive from St. Albans.
After approaching Pathmark and then ruling out a series of locations, the church coalition settled on a 16.5-acre site at the corner of Merrick and Springfield Boulevards now occupied by a hulking, underused warehouse owned by the Nynex Corporation.
 
Special Permit Needed
 Under the agreement between Pathmark's parent company, Nynex and Norse Realty, a developer in Queens, the structure would be razed to make room for two buildings, one for Nynex, the other for the new Pathmark. Since the site is zoned for industrial use, the project would require a special zoning permit, a process that could take a year or more.
"We think there is a great opportunity and an unmet need for shoppers in that part of the city," said Harvey Gutman, senior vice president for retail development at Supermarkets General. He noted that the Queens store would be one of the largest of the company's 147 Pathmarks. "That's why we're very excited," he said.
Along Merrick Boulevard, which fading signs on telephone poles identify as the "Laurelton Renaissance Shopping District," the reaction has been less enthusiastic.
Like the other neighborhoods of southeastern Queens, such as Springfield Gardens, Cambria Heights and St. Albans, Laurelton is a mostly black, mostly working-class neighborhood of leafy streets and neat rows of single-family wood-frame or Tudor houses. And like the others, it is a place where residents are fiercely protective of their almost suburban way of life.
Some residents and merchants on Merrick Boulevard, which extends east from the site of the proposed Pathmark, have already complained that the giant supermarket would undo the work of civic leaders who have struggled to revive the neighborhood's commercial strip after years of decline.
 
'Don't Want Empty Stores'
 At Marder's Pharmacy, a neighborhood landmark for 30 years, a manager, Michael Rogoff, said merchants would be forced out of business by Pathmark's low prices and high volume, leaving behind vacant storefronts that would attract crime and litter.
"You don't want empty stores," said Mr. Rogoff, who like others in the neighborhood often refers to Laurelton as "town." "It's always been a small community. Something like this will be devastating."
More than 125 people turned out for a town hall meeting on Thursday night, organized by City Councilwoman Juanita E. Watkins, to discuss the proposed Pathmark. Though some said they welcomed the competition the supermarket would bring, many criticized the plan.
"The talk of profits and jobs is, to be honest, pie in the sky," said Astley Campbell, who warned that the Pathmark would shut down neighborhood businesses, leaving the shopping district and the homes around it to decline in value. "We must put our resources together and block this project morally, politically and legally."
The coalition supporting the Pathmark, which has the backing of the city's economic development officials, Borough President Claire Shulman and other elected officials, vowed to respond to the opposition by rallying those who have complained for years about the dearth of major supermarkets.
"They're trying to draw lines," the Rev. Leroy Burns of the Second Gateway Church of God in Christ in South Ozone Park said of the Pathmark's opponents. "They're trying to make it into something that it's not.
"We've been working on this for three and a half years. And I can tell you that we have more people on our side, who want it, than they have on theirs, that don't."

HEADLINE: More Attacks On Dinkins As Giuliani Speeds Pace

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Harshly criticizing the Mayor over asbestos problems in city schools, then reaching into the Bronx and Jackson Heights to shore up Hispanic support, Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday continued his aggressive effort to challenge Mayor David N. Dinkins and move his campaign to a higher pitch.
In the last several days Mr. Giuliani has opened offices around the city, begun a television campaign and heated up his charges against the Mayor as a "catchup" politician driven by reaction, not action. 
 Yesterday Mr. Giuliani used disclosures about failures in the asbestos testing program for schools to attack the Mayor for failing to name a replacement for Norman Steisel as one of three directors of the School Construction Authority. Mr. Steisel resigned from the board three and a half years ago to join the Dinkins administration as deputy mayor.
"How is it that after three and a half years he has yet to make that appointment?" he said. "I can't see how that can be if he really is interested in the schools."
 
Passive Government
 Although the asbestos testing failures occurred before Mr. Dinkins took office, Mr. Giuliani said the current crisis was reflective of what he called passive government by the Dinkins administration. He said that the Mayor was prone to react only during times of crisis and that the problem with the schools would have been addressed much earlier by a more active administration.
"I would have had regular meetings with school authorities and the board," Mr. Giuliani said. "There should be regularly scheduled cabinet meetings. The Mayor should know about these things."
Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary, acknowledged yesterday that the the construction authority post was still vacant, terming it "a hard position to fill." He added: "But that's not the real issue. The construction authority had nothing to do with the tests that occurred in 1987 through 1989. It's like saying that the U.S. Attorney for New York should have prevented the savings-and-loan scandal."
Since Friday, Mr. Giuliani has formally opened campaign headquarters in Woodside and Astoria in Queens and Brighton Beach in Brooklyn. Those offices, coupled with offices in Manhattan and Staten Island, give him a full-time campaign presence in all boroughs but the Bronx.
 
A 'Stealth' Campaign
 Those moves, while routine, may help Mr. Giuliani combat criticisms by supporters of Mr. Dinkins that the Republican-Liberal candidate has been waging a "stealth" campaign intended to take advantage of every misstep made by Mr. Dinkins while keeping a low enough profile to minimize any missteps of his own.
Another sign of a shift in the campaign is clear in Mr. Giuliani's schedule for the coming week. Though he has spent much of the summer on routine tasks like parades and raising funds, he is to give his first major policy speech tomorrow in Manhattan.
Due to be presented at a gathering of supporters and friends at a morning meeting at the Sheraton New York, the speech is to focus on his economic policies and is likely to concentrate on his intention to reduce taxes, shrink the size of city government through attrition and increase "privatization."
Other major speeches on such issues as crime, education and jobs are expected to follow within the month, said Christine Lategano, a campaign aide.
But yesterday it was politics as usual for both Mr. Giuliani and the Mayor as they courted Hispanic voters at the Bronx Puerto Rican Day Parade. Mr. Dinkins, who was among the first in the long line of marchers, was flanked on one side by Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, and on the other by Jose Torres, the former boxing champion and current deputy manager of the Dinkins campaign.
Mr. Torres has been criticized recently by the Giuliani campaign for suggesting that people with racist tendencies were more inclined to vote for Mr. Giuliani.
 
Waving Puerto Rican Flags
 As Mr. Dinkins and his entourage passed, women waving Puerto Rican flags screeched his name, and waved for him to come over and greet them. Young men also cheered, offering the Mayor the thumbs-up sign. Some of that response, of course, was the result of Mr. Dinkins walking beside Mr. Torres, who remains a popular figure. Occassionally, however, there was some booing for the Mayor, with one group of young men hollering: "Where's Rudy. He's our man."
Mr. Giuliani was joined by Herman Badillo, the Democrat who has also joined the candidate's "fusion" campaign to run as comptroller. Together they shook hands, kissed babies and hugged women who shouted and jumped at the sight of Mr. Badillo.

HEADLINE: Staten Island Secession More Than Fringe Threat

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
The distance between SoHo and Staten Island is a short hike and a 50-cent ferry ride, but for Daniel Singletary, a New York artist who has lived on Staten Island for more than 20 years, the mental gap is meaner than the flooded Mississippi.
"I don't know how long I've been going in to the Manhattan art world but I'm still considered the Staten Island redneck artist," he said. It rankles. So, like a growing number of his neighbors, Mr. Singletary wants to get out of town without ever leaving home: he wants Staten Island to secede. 
 "I'm here because New York City is supposed to be the gateway to the arts of the world," Mr. Singletary said. "But what's the point?" Others have sharper critiques: "We should get out," said a magazine store clerk who expressed the frustrations of many. "New York is shot."
 
Resentment and Distress
 The Staten Island secession movement, once dismissed as pointless grousing from a borough angered by its diminished role in city government, has grown in recent years into a powerful shout of resentment and distress that will go to a vote Nov. 2. A yes vote, which seems increasingly likely, would toss the matter to Albany, where the details of the divorce would be reviewed by the Legislature and then subject to the Governor's approval.
Even die-hard supporters of secession do not think that the proposal will make it through the gantlet in Albany. Yet successful or not, the movement has already sent a disturbing message to City Hall that the city's center may no longer hold. Once a virtual paradigm of the city's immigrant, working-class base, Staten Island's mostly white, politically conservative population has in the 1990's suddenly become -- psychologically at least -- a minority in a city now best known for its polyglot liberalism and new immigrants.
We haven't changed, Staten Islanders argue; the city has.
Coming while New York City is struggling with crime, homelessness, a perennially tight budget and a tarnished image as a megalopolis out of control, their anger is an anathema to city politicians who want to cling to the glory days of old. But worst, it sends a stab of fear that if Staten Island were to go, could Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx be far behind?
A breakup of the Big Apple would indicate rot at the core. New York would no longer really be New York. Even some song lyrics would have to change. "We'll have Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island too" just wouldn't make it any more. But then again, the title of that famous New York song is a rebuke itself: "Manhattan."
 
Bigger Than Buffalo
 While its population of 380,000 is dwarfed by borough giants like Brooklyn, with more than two million people, an independent city of Staten Island would surpass Buffalo as the second-largest city in the state and would be comparable in size to Miami, Minneapolis, Atlanta, Oakland, Calif., or St. Paul -- an appealing thought to island residents who feel perennially undervalued.
The cost of that independence would be high, however. Most early studies show that taxes on the island would almost surely rise -- with property taxes in some cases perhaps doubling or tripling. So strong is the sentiment, though, that a study conducted by the New York Charter Commission for Staten Island last year showed that 49 percent of those polled would accept a 25 percent increase in their taxes in exchange for their own city. A more recent, though less thorough, poll taken by the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce found 73 percent in favor, higher taxes and all. That body's directors also voted overwhelmingly to accept the Chamber's Secession Task Force recommendation to break free.
Those conclusions quantify a discontent that has been felt and expressed for years. In fact, Staten Island, the smallest of the city's boroughs, is different. Sixty-nine percent of its population is of Italian, Irish or German descent. Only about 5 percent of the island's residents are black. Less than 10 percent of families with a child under 18 fall below the poverty line, compared with a citywide average two and one-half times as large. And residents are more likely to have a telephone, a car and a mortgage -- the usual trappings of middle America -- than other New Yorkers.
 
Class, Race and Emotion
 The demographic differences disturb some critics who see the secession movement as spurred by issues of class and race. But David Goldfarb, the president of Staten Islanders for a Unified New York, says he believes, instead, that the movement is simply a matter of misplaced emotion. "There is a lot of dislike of the city of New York," he said. "And independence is a nice concept. But if we secede we will have no say at all and the city will still be the main economic engine."
Mr. Goldfarb says that much has already been lost in the debate. He has a son who just graduated from Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, which specializes in mathematics and science. If the island seceded, would other students have that same option? It is just one of many questions that would arise in a breakup, but it touches Mr. Goldfarb's fears that access to such city strengths would be squandered in exchange for higher taxes and the bureaucratic nightmare of setting up a city government virtually from scratch.
Mayor David N. Dinkins has far more to lose. If secession succeeded, he would forever be remembered as the Mayor who let his city fall apart. So he articulated his own opposition with the simplest of phrases: "We need them. And they need us."
For Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor, the immediate dilemma is more difficult. Mr. Giuliani, who won 77.4 percent of Staten Island's vote in his last run for mayor in 1989, hardly wants to lose that supportive district. But neither does he want to alienate one of his most solid voting blocs by directly criticizing their ambitions. Instead, he blames the Dinkins administration for the bad feelings.
 
Giuliani Blames Dinkins
 "I know what it is that is making them want to go," Mr. Giuliani said of impatient Staten Islanders. "The Mayor tries to put it in racial terms and that makes things worse."
In an interview on Saturday, Mr. Giuliani said he believed that sentiment in favor of secession had risen drastically during Mr. Dinkins's four years in office. He said that a better-managed city that paid more attention to borough needs in areas like schools and the management of the Fresh Kills landfill would improve the situation. "In the last few years we have seen the basic quality of the management of the city decline," he said.
For Mr. Giuliani, casting the matter as a complaint against the Mayor works several ways. He can stand as a strong supporter of the borough, criticize the Mayor and oppose secession all at once.
Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island borough president, has shifted his own stance from opposition to grudging, reserved acceptance as support for the referendum has gained momentum. "I am probably going to vote for it," he said hesitantly. "But I'll vote for it fully expecting the tax on my house to double or triple."
 
Whole New Bureaucracy
 Mr. Molinari's real hesitation, he says, is not just a tax increase but the difficulty of setting up an entirely new bureaucracy complete with police, fire, sewer and other services. Just one of many nuisances, he said, would be the requirement for the island, which still has large swaths of undeveloped land, to put in its own sewer lines. Such burdens could slow growth, raise taxes and lead to a tangle of other problems.
"People have asked me, 'Mr. Molinari, wouldn't you really like to be the first Mayor of Staten Island?' " he said. "And I answer very tersely: 'NO!' Let their names be on the first tax bills to go out."
In fact, the tax question is still vague and will need considerably more study. Some of the anticipated $170 million shortfall in revenue could be made up in real-estate taxes. Another possible income source would be a personal income tax. Yet Mr. Molinari and others who have qualms about secession warn that obtaining that particular tax could be a problem, since Albany has approved it only once before outside New York City, in the case of Yonkers, which faced bankrupcy at the time.
Mr. Molinari, having studied the existing reports, has commissioned yet more, perhaps casting about for darker findings. Borough politicians themselves are split on the matter. "It's what I call tribal warfare on Staten Island," said Joseph P. Viteritti, the executive director of the State Charter Commission for Staten Island, explaining the bad blood that has developed over time.
 
More and More Reports
 A result, he said, is dueling reports. In the months before the election two new studies are due to be completed. The borough has hired the consulting firm of Towers-Perrin Inc. of Virginia and Freelance Economics, another group from Albany, to review the proposal and deliver findings just as voters head off to the polls.
Dr. Viteritti says he thinks the plan could work. A study by his group revealed a Staten Island revenue base of $955.4 million, exceeding the $833 million average annual operating budgets of other cities of similar size that were studied by the commission. His study also reports that the island's long-term economic prospects are good. It is one of the fastest growing counties in the New York metropolitan area; it did not suffer a decline in employment since 1989 as the rest of the city did; the population is expected to grow by 20 percent by the year 2010 and employment should expand by 23 percent.
Perhaps just as important, he thinks New Yorkers themselves would not be bothered. "My own feeling is if you polled New Yorkers in the rest of the city they wouldn't care one way or another if Staten Island stayed or went," he said.
If it did go, the hardest work would come in defining the terms of a breakup. Since Staten Island has been intertwined with New York City for nearly 100 years, shoveling money into city coffers and getting services and status in exchange, just who would own a New York City-owned fire station, police building or other bit of infrastructure? And what, if any, stake would a Staten Islander retain in, say, Yankee Stadium?
 
Whither the Landfill?
 Harder, still, would be deciding whether a city of Staten Island would need high-cost items like bomb squads, SWAT teams and other special services demanded by a city like New York. And what to do with the Fresh Kills landfill, the nation's largest, which each year takes acre upon acre of New York City's garbage?
For all the importance of those practical matters, however, it is emotions, not arcana, that are still driving the debate. "It's reasonable to say, 'This city is too damn big; let's break it up,' " said Dr. Viteritti. "But when you get beyond that, you get to all the political questions. And that's the trouble. It's another nail in the coffin for New York City."
Mark F. Muscaro, president of the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce, argues that cost should be ignored. "Everyone would survive," he said. "This whole thing is like the breakup of A.T.& T. It's the same kind of situation as that faced by the Russian republics after the fall of the Soviet Union."
Mr. Singletary, the artist, just wants to keep his hometown feel. He says he feels far from the mean streets of New York and the issues that drive life across the harbor. His New York City is a place where tennis shoes dangle from telephone wires, shopkeepers stop to chat and crew cuts and big hair are not a retro-campy fashion statement. He wants to keep it that way. Even if it means goodbye.

HEADLINE: Review/Opera;
Seekers of the Unusual Find It Twice at Santa Fe

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 8

 BODY:
A visitor to the Santa Fe Opera has to admire the delicacy with which the company's season is balanced. Of its five productions, only "The Magic Flute" and "La Boheme" can be heard anywhere, anytime. The double bill of Kurt Weill rarities is guaranteed to lure specialists and the adventurous. But in some ways Handel's "Xerxes" and Strauss's "Capriccio" are the season's most alluring offerings. Because neither is frequently staged, they appeal to seekers of the unusual. As sheer entertainment, both offer abundant charms. And Santa Fe has assembled its starriest casts of the summer for them.
The Handel, on Thursday evening, was also Frederica von Stade's return to the stage after strained vocal cords forced her to cancel several performances this summer. Miss von Stade was in generally good voice, and if there were traces of huskiness in her middle and lower registers, the top of her voice was as pure and smooth as ever. 
 "Xerxes" has an impossibly twisted plot. The young King Xerxes is in love with Romilda. But Romilda is in love with Xerxes's brother Arsamene, who returns the feelings. Xerxes himself is betrothed to Amastre, who arrives disguised as a soldier only to hear that she has been forsaken. And Romilda's sister Atalanta covets Arsamene. Backstairs scheming, misdirected letters and the efforts of Ariodate (Romilda's father) and Elviro (Arsamene's servant) first put all asunder and then set everything right.
It makes great sense to stage a work of this kind in English. Steven Wadsworth, who directed the production, provided his own translation, with additional material by Carol Borah Palca. Mr. Wadsworth's text was often freewheeling, and there were times when he took questionable liberties for the sake of keeping the audience laughing. But overall, his rhymed and eminently singable text conveyed the spirit of the Italian original. And his thoughtful direction turned the text's repetitiveness into an advantage. Arias were not merely sung, but were staged in ways that drew different nuances from every repeated verse.
Mr. Wadsworth also transported the story from Xerxes' Persia, circa 470 B.C., to Handel's 18th-century England; but since the plot has nothing to do with the historical Xerxes, that hardly mattered. The production, designed by Thomas Lynch, used a single set, the exterior of a modest country house. But the staging's precise detail -- from Martin Pakledinaz's period costumes, to the candlelit, wallpapered rooms glimpsed through the windows and the servants occupied with mundane chores -- made up for the lack of scene changes.
There were no real deficits in the casting, musically or dramatically. At times, Miss von Stade's Xerxes edged dangerously close to her Cherubino; but if she overplayed the king's youthful, lovelorn side, she portrayed his vulnerabilities with a winning sympathy.
Dawn Upshaw was a joy as Romilda. She moved through Handel's ornate writing with incomparable ease. Her coloration invariably matched the demands of the text, and her supple performance proved again that she is a superb comic actress.
Arsamene was played by Brian Asawa, a countertenor who made an indelible impression at the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions winners concert a few seasons ago. Few countertenors produce a timbre as beautiful, as fully supported or as consistently well-projected as Mr. Asawa's, and his portrayal was as dramatically sensitive as it was firmly sung.
In the smaller roles, Mimi Lerner was a strong, touching Amastre. Erie Mills's model for Atalanta must have been Gracie Allen: she seemed ditsy rather than scheming, and she sang her music smoothly. George Hogan and Kevin Langan gave solid, comic performances as Elviro and Ariodate. Now and then some of the ornamentation went slightly awry, but for the most part the singers handled the decorative writing expertly. They were supported by generally fine playing from an orchestra of mostly modern instruments, with recorders, a lute and a harpsichord adding a hint of period flavor. Kenneth Montgomery was the conductor and kept things moving at a comfortable pace.
The Strauss operas have always been favorites of John Crosby, the company's founder and general director. Of the composer's 15 operas, the company has staged all but "Guntram" and "Die Frau ohne Schatten." The new "Capriccio," in an English translation by Maria Massey Pelikan, does not move the company closer to completing the series. But it is a ravishing score, and on Friday evening Mr. Crosby conducted a performance that illuminated many of its strengths as well as its principal weakness, a lack of economy.
But perhaps economy was not the order of the day. "Capriccio" was Strauss's last opera, and in turning down further projects, he described it as his "one testament." It is, after all, a treatise on opera itself. Using the story of an 18th-century French countess and her two suitors, the poet Olivier and the composer Flamand, Strauss explores (inconclusively) the question of whether words or music are more expressive. But the listener never cares much who wins the Countess. The artistic discussion is always the focus.
This abstract quality of the work is reflected fully in the production. Wolfgang Gussmann suggests the 18th-century setting with period furniture and costumes. But all the costumes and furniture are stark white, and they are set in a room with deep blue walls, devoid of detail. It is as if the characters and their debates are like fleeting clouds in an azure sky.
Sheri Greenawald was undaunted by the high tessitura of the Countess's music, and her portrayal fully captured the assurance with which the Countess controls her milieu. But Miss Greenawald was not entirely successful in making the text understood, a significant flaw in this wordy, philosophical work.
Mark Thomsen and James Michael McGuire gave vocally solid, dramatically sympathetic portrayals of Flamand and Olivier. Eric Halfvarson's La Roche came to life compellingly in his free-ranging discourse on the nature of art. Richard Stilwell's dry-voiced Count was passable, and Katherine Ciesinski's sultry portrayal of Clairon was a worthy contribution. Generally, though, the singers, like the characters they portrayed, commanded the attention less fully than the issues they sang about. Strauss probably would have found that pleasing.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Head-On Look at the Ethics of Hunting Animals

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Bloodties
Nature, Culture and the Hunt
By Ted Kerasote
Map. 277 pages. Random House. $22. 
 It is easy enough to dismiss as crackpot some of the thinking that opposes the killing of animals. Ted Kerasote, a nature writer, cites examples in his sensitive report "Bloodties: Nature, Culture and the Hunt," a book that ends up cautiously on the side of hunting. There are, for instance, his nonhunting neighbors where he lives in western Wyoming who take the lead of the civil rights and feminist movements and argue that killing animals -- whether for food or sport -- is, as the author paraphrases the case, "an expression of a long-standing patriarchal culture's enslavement of a minority group that must be ended." As this argument concludes, "Animals, like others who have been disenfranchised, must be given rights."
Mr. Kerasote makes a powerful case against such fanaticism. He once tried avoiding meat but found that there was no escape from killing animals. To embrace what he calls supermarket vegetarianism was to condone a system that does its own form of killing, by clearing land for farming, by creating "ecological traps" that attract and kill a variety of small creatures, by using pesticides, by carrying produce to market and by developing the fossil fuels needed for that transportation.
"In short," he writes, "being a supermarket vegetarian didn't take me out of the web in which animals are constantly dying to feed humans, it merely put their deaths over the horizon, making them, in the bloodless jargon of cost-accounting, externalities." Planting an organic garden wasn't the answer either, since like so much of the world, his part of the country wasn't suitable for such farming, and to drive somewhere to buy organic produce would only increase its fossil fuel cost.
No, Mr. Kerasote found that to kill a 150-pound elk would expend 79,000 kilocalories of fossil fuel energy according to an analysis done at Cornell University; whereas to consume the caloric equivalent in Idaho potatoes would use up 151,000 kilocalories of fossil fuel energy. Better to kill the elk, so long as he was honorable about it and looked the dying elk in the eye.
Yet Mr. Kerasote makes the case against hunting too, against the wanton harvesting of specimens just for the sake of cutting another notch in your sense of dominion. In a section that drips with subtle disdain, he introduces us to several trophy hunters hell-bent on shooting one of every creature that boarded Noah's Ark, and the biggest possible one at that. He even accompanies a few of them on a trip to Siberia to shoot Marco Polo sheep, and reports how one intrepid hunter killed an animal after it had been herded into shooting range by helicopters, no less.
So where is one to turn for an answer to the question, Is it wrong to kill animals? The power of "Bloodties" lies in the way it forces the reader to feel the inescapable tragedy of being both part of nature and outside of it, of having to participate in the violence of sustaining life and yet having to be conscious of the pain inevitably inflicted. The narrative begins with the author's visit to an Eskimo village in Greenland, among people whose only food source is the narwhals, seals and polar bears they can kill.
These people were slow to accept the author because they feared he was with Greenpeace, an environmental organization that, he says, brought economic hardship to the Eskimos by opposing the clubbing of juvenile harp seals in Newfoundland and thereby inadvertently affecting the killing of ringed seals in Greenland. But gradually they came to trust him, and took him along on some of their dogsled hunts.
Next he turns to the trophy hunters, one of whose number, an Alaskan billionaire, says of hunting: "To me it's the same as business. . . . It's goal seeking, it's thrilling, and it gives an extreme sense of self-reliance, self-accomplishment, overcoming almost any difficulty, because the hunter has to go across the river and up the mountain."
Finally, Mr. Kerasote embraces a synthesis, which unfortunately turns out to be none other than himself. This is not as pompously self-serving as it may sound. By looking inward, he can better describe the respectful form of hunting he advocates than if he had interviewed some like-minded person. But his prose in this final section suffers a little.
As a nature writer, he takes as one of his models Henry Beston's classic work, "The Outermost House" (1928), an account of a year spent living in a shack on a beach in Cape Cod. Mr. Kerasote's acute awareness of his surroundings goes well with the excitement of the Greenland hunt: "Over the ice cap the full moon had risen and, to the northwest, the sun skidded along the horizon, tinting the frozen sea the color of wild roses. When it set, the sky above it turned lilac, then lavender, then a clear and profound celestial blue containing one bright star."
But when he is back home in Wyoming, going through the daily rounds of a freelance writer, his sensitivity to nature can teeter toward tedious self-indulgence: "Spring! Spring at last! Spring at home, after so many months away. It's good to lie in bed in the morning, underneath the warm elk hide, as the first pale light takes away the darkness, and listen to the deer chewing the rose hip bushes just beneath the bedroom window, while the caw of ravens floats faintly in the air."
Still, it never takes long for Mr. Kerasote to turn up some new and curious aspect of the hunting debate. And when he has finished summing it all up, it's hard to argue with his final objective. This is to remove the gratuitous forms of pain from the world, and learn to inflict only "the instrumental pain caused by the honest biological clamor of our guts' wanting to be fed . . . which seems irreducible."

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
'Rising Sun' Is Old Business

BYLINE: By ROGER M. PANG

 BODY:
Asians in American movies are typically portrayed as comedians, geishas, villains or karate masters. In "Rising Sun," based on the book by Michael Crichton, history has repeated itself: The Asians are the villains.
The book is ostensibly a mystery revolving around the murder of a white American woman. Mr. Crichton's larger purpose is to present a dark vision of Japan's economic ambitions. Read either as a thriller or a tract, the book portrays the Japanese as hard-edged exploiters of an increasingly vulnerable America. 
 The movie isn't as offensive as the book; the Japanese do not bear all the blame. Even so, The Times's movie critic Vincent Canby correctly wrote: "It still offends. It directs attention not to the internal reasons for America's economic problems, but to inscrutable, generalized, unknown others from abroad.. . ."
Only one Japanese character in the movie has a multidimensional role -- a sleazy playboy played by Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa. The rest of the Japanese characters are muscle-head yakuza -- Japanese gangsters -- or blue-suited businessmen who want to take over the U.S. by any means necessary.
Asian-Americans worry that ignorant people may not differentiate Asians in movies from Asian-Americans. I am occasionally blamed for the bombing of Pearl Harbor, even though I am a third-generation Chinese-American. And ever since Asians immigrated to the United States, they have had to live with the stereotype of the sneaky invader.
Crimes against Asians increased by 44 percent in New York and 100 percent in Los Angeles County from 1991 to 1992. Last year in Florida, an Asian premed student was beaten to death by a group of white men after the student objected to a slur spoken by one of them. And I can't forget Vincent Chin, a Chinese-American, who was killed in 1982 by two unemployed, white American auto workers because they thought he was Japanese.
Hollywood needs to get real, not only about Asian-Americans but all Americans of color. It needs to stop stereotyping minorities. One place to start is to involve more minority writers in feature films. According to the latest report by the Writers Guild of America, fewer than 3 percent of the writers for major feature films are members of minority groups.
For a while it seemed the movie industry was showing some sense with the release of movies like "Dragon," which showed Asian actors in more complex roles. "Rising Sun" is a step backward.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 310 words

HEADLINE: Let's Take Closer Look at China's Prison Labor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am concerned with the tone and implications of "Get Serious About Chinese Prison Labor" (editorial, July 21). Having just returned from a tour of four penal institutions in China, I think the issue of prison labor needs a more balanced examination. 
 Prison labor is used extensively throughout the United States and most other penal systems. Products made by prison labor are placed in the streams of commerce in this country and abroad. Productive work is recognized and encouraged as a key element in every rehabilitative penal program. It is simplistic and unreasonable to condemn the export of goods made by prison labor in China without identifying the real issues that should concern us.
Are the conditions in which the labor is performed safe, humane and comparable to other workplaces within China? Do the profits from production support the penal institution and benefit the inmates who perform the work? Are the inmates who are selected to work fit, and do they receive sufficient nutrition and health care to perform the work?
The Chinese Government is demonstrating an increasing willingness to open its society and institutions to achieve trade and cultural exchange with the West. We should encourage this openness and use it for increased access for necessary inspection and verification of conditions of prison labor. But draconian threats and sanction-rattling will not result in the changes we seek.
We must take care that prison labor is not used as a pretext for imposing protectionist economic barriers that single out the Chinese for punishment. Within the restrictions of applicable law, the Clinton Administration must work with and not against the Chinese to bring them fully within the family of nations.
 
JANE BOND
Akron, Ohio, July 28, 1993
The writer is a judge of the Court of Common Pleas.

HEADLINE: Look Who's Deriding Deficit Remedies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Just Say No to Clinton's Package" by Ronald Reagan (Op-Ed, Aug. 3): I find it appalling that the man who got us into the deficit nightmare derides the first efforts to do something about it. While no one, including President Clinton, thinks the final budget proposal is a panacea, it is a step to quell the hemorrhaging embraced by Ronald Reagan and his ilk as they robbed from the future to pay for what was mostly defense toys. 
 However, the most embarrassing remark in the article is his statement that the President is ill advised to raise taxes on those who did well in the 1980's because, in Mr. Reagan's view, "practically every American benefited from that era."
I know that things may look that way from a lush ranch in California. But I invite the Reagans to walk the streets of any neighborhood in New York City. I would like Mr. Reagan to ask the people who sleep in doorways on every block with their children if the social programs he raided to pay for defense have made them better off. Or to ask the middle-class apartment owners who bought at inflated prices with exorbitant mortgage rates in a glutted market if they are better off now that they can't sell to break even. Ask any urban dwellers who lived through the 80's if all the Federal funds denied the nation's cities benefited their daily lives.
But what is most astounding to me is that the man who left us such a feeble economic legacy is spouting the same voodoo economics that put us in the straits we are in. Mr. Reagan's problem when he was in power was his myopia to the problems facing America; he simply waved the flag and told us all not to worry. He's still myopic.
 
DENISE R. GUILLET
New York, Aug. 3, 1993

HEADLINE: CLINTON DOUBLING FEES FOR GRAZING ON FEDERAL LANDS

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Returning to an issue set aside when it appeared to threaten the budget negotiations, the Clinton Administration announced today that it would more than double grazing fees for ranchers who use Federal land. The move is a major step toward reshaping Western land policy.
Environmentalists heralded the action and predicted it would reduce harm to wildlife, forests and streams that they say is caused by grazing on public land. 
 Western Republicans condemned it as a betrayal, while Democratic senators from the West said the measures were less severe than the proposals President Clinton had originally made in his budget -- proposals that they had persuaded him to drop.
 
More Changes Planned
 Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, who announced the fee increases and new controls over water rights and the use of public land, said changes in Federal land-use would be announced next month. He and other Administration officials described the move as part of a wide-ranging effort to reverse a century of Federal policy that promoted development in the Far West with Government subsidies.
The new land management policy, Administration officials predict, will mean that miners will begin paying royalties for mining gold and other metals, timber companies will no longer log national forests at below-market prices and farmers will begin to pay surcharges to irrigate Federal land.
"It's about our commitment and our responsibility to live more lightly on the land," Mr. Babbitt said. "It's about asserting our American heritage, the landscape, the resources and the culture that constitutes the American West."
 
A Victory for Babbitt
 The policy announcement represented a victory for Mr. Babbitt, who as a former Governor of Arizona has vehemently argued within the Administration that the President can overturn outdated land policies without committing political suicide in the West. His advocacy for environmental issues has been so strong that environmental groups lobbied against his appointment as a Supreme Court Justice two months ago when it appeared that Mr. Clinton might select him.
Administration officials said the grazing fee change, which would apply to owners of livestock that graze on 280 million acres of public range, should generate on average an extra $20 million a year for the Treasury as it is phased in by 1996 -- about $4 million less than the Administration had originally proposed.
The timing of the announcement appeared designed to help the President shed the impression that he had put aside his environmental principles to buy votes for his deficit-reduction plan, which Congress Congress by the thinnest possible margin last week. In February, several Western senators had threatened to withhold their votes for the Clinton economic plan unless the Administration took certain grazing and mining fee provisions out of the legislation.
The President acceded to their request, and was widely criticized for buckling under even though he said then that he would return to the issue with an administrative order. Theoretically, the order could be reversed by a vote of both houses of Congress, but the House has long supported similar proposals.
 
Sharp Republican Criticism
 Some Republicans in Congress sharply criticized today's move as a betrayal of ranchers. "This proposal is misguided and shows the lack of knowledge Secretary Babbitt and his extremist crowd have about current range land conditions," said Senator Conrad Burns, a Montana Republican. "Ranchers are the best stewards of the land."
But the reaction of Democratic senators from the West was far milder, with some saying they had expected the Administration's decision and did not feel that the President had gone back on his word. One Senate Democratic aide said that while Western senators could not have voted for legislation that included the grazing fees, they understand that they cannot win on every issue.
"I don't like it, but it's not as bad as it could have been," said Senator Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat who asked in February that the President take the proposed grazing and mining fees out of the economic plan. Mr. Reid said today that the decision could actually help ranchers if it brought "finality to the issue."
Administration officials said the timing of the announcement had nothing to do with the passage of the budget, but rather to happen before Mr. Babbitt left for a three-week trip to Alaska.
Under the Administration's new policy, monthly grazing fees will rise from the current $1.86 for each animal unit -- defined as a cow and calf or five sheep -- to $4.28 in three years. The value of such rights on private land is estimated at $5 to $15 depending on the land.
The level of grazing fees has long been a contentious political issue, causing disputes between Congress and the White House and between a handful of Western senators and the rest of Congress.
The fee of $1.86 per animal unit was set by the Reagan and Bush Administrations, although Federal leases are supposed to be set at fair market values. The House strongly objected to the policy, and in July 1991 passed a Bureau of Land Management authorization bill that raised fees to $8.70. But nothing close to that price could win approval in the Senate.
In Mr. Clinton's original proposal, monthly fees would have been increased to $5. The new fee the Administration has settled on still represents a subsidy, and it will grow as inflation widens the gap between the market and Federal prices as the new fee is phased in over three years.
"We believe that Government handouts to the livestock industry should be ended, not just reduced," said Melanie Griffin, a Sierra Club expert on land management issues. "However, what's more important than the fee is the change in mindset that this proposal represents."
 
'A Matter of Process'
 Still, White House officials said today that the action on the grazing fees was not a change of Administration policy, but a fulfillment of Mr. Clinton's original plan to raise grazing fees. "We always said it was just a matter of process," said George Stephanopoulos, a senior White House policy adviser. "We're just keeping our commitment."
Mr. Babbitt called the new fee "a reasonable balance between the need to sustain the health of range land and the need to sustain the economic health of rural Western areas." He said the Administration intended to announce new mining regulations next month, followed by new rules on timber and water rights.
The raising of grazing fees came in a package of new land-use regulations announced by Mr. Babbitt today. The Administration also established new standards for range lands, putting far more emphasis on environmental concerns than had the two previous Administrations. From now on, the length of grazing seasons on public lands will be shortened, the use of pesticides curtailed and grazing leases will be broken when ranchers are found to be mismanaging the land they use.

HEADLINE: With Budget Won, Sales Pitch Begins

 BODY:
President Clinton opened a drive yesterday to convince the American public of what he narrowly managed to convince Congress last week: that his $496 billion package of spending cuts and tax increases was worthy of its support.
The White House billed the President's visit to West Virginia as a victory lap to celebrate Congressional approval of his five-year economic plan. But his campaign-style rally reflected the Administration's view that though the plan had passed, it remained to be sold. 
 "Now we can truly say change has come to America," Mr. Clinton proclaimed. But the President was also aware of polls showing that public support for the plan remained no more than tepid.
Article, page A16.

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING;
What's Left From the Great Flood of '93

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9

 BODY:
In its two-month rampage, the great Midwest flood of 1993 cut an awesome destructive swath. It took 50 lives, left almost 70,000 people homeless, inundated an area twice the size of New Jersey, caused an estimated $12 billion in property and agricultural damage and stirred anew a debate over the nation's flood-control system and its policies.
The crest of the mighty flood, probably the worst ever to wash over the United States, roiled down the Mississippi past Cairo, Ill., today, and from there south the swollen waters will steadily lose their deadly potency because the river bottom widens drastically. 
 The worst is over in the great flood of '93 and the end is clearly in sight. Now come the damage estimates and the big cleanup, both certain to have their own anguish.
Still to be added up are how many little towns were drowned, how many homes and businesses destroyed and how many roads, bridges and stretches of rail swept away.
But enough is known to consider the flood devastating: about $200 million in damage was done to the nation's rail lines and bridges; hundreds of miles of highway were scarred; and farmers suffered about $8 billion in crop damage.
In the wearying effort to fight back the relentless waters, some 75 million sandbags by some counts were piled, though in the end at least 800 of the region's 1,400 levees were topped or breached.
But for now it is reassuring to the inhabitants of the upper Midwest to know that the most serious threat -- along with the record crests -- has subsided.
"The worst is past and the river is beginning to fall nicely," said Gary Dyhouse, the chief hydrologist here for the Army Corps of Engineers.
There is an epitaph, of sorts, to the flood of '93 on the levee here in front of the soaring Gateway Arch. It is a thin drying line of river detritus, now a full five feet above the Mississippi.
Five full feet.
That is how much the great river, the Father of Waters to Indians, has fallen since cresting a week ago at its highest level on record, 49.5 feet.
And the retreat is similarly under way all over the nine-state disaster zone. Everywhere the marauding waters are pulling back, back from sodden houses and stores and cars and fields and barns, back toward the ripped levees and the big oaks and cottonwoods that mark the normally languid edge of the region's rivers.
"She's pulling out," said Cliff Coppedge, a street cleaner in St. Charles, Mo., a town just west of here, as he hosed a pile of muddy debris back into the receding Missouri.
A month ago, satellite pictures found so much water covering the Midwest that the region resembled a sixth Great Lake. That lake is steadily shrinking, particularly in the upper reaches of the disaster region where the flooding started.
To be sure, it is a grudging, rear-guard retreat, not a rout. The Mississippi is still well out of its banks and still pressuring soggy levees. So is the Missouri.
"The worst is definitely over, but people need to stay on their toes," said Jim Brown, a spokesman for the Army Corps of Engineers. "We're dealing with what probably is the worst flood man has ever witnessed in this country, certainly the Midwest. Some levees could collapse even as the waters recede. The sun has to keep shining. Don't get complacent."
 
'The Water's Been Where It's Never Been Before'
 There are still plenty of places where another month will pass before the waters totally fall back. One of them is a 20-mile stretch of rich bottom land north of here that extends eastward from the outskirts of St. Charles all the way to Alton, Ill., near the point where the Missouri and the Illinois Rivers join the Mississippi.
No place in the entire flooded Midwest was hit harder by this watery avalanche caused by unseasonal rain that fell without surcease for six weeks. There are hundreds of farms and a dozen or more small villages out there that have been under 15 feet of water for two, three and even six weeks or more. Some will still be mucking out come first frost.
"The water's been where it's never been before," said Barb Margherio, whose house in Hardin, Ill., went under when the Illinois, Missouri and Mississippi combined record crests the first couple of days of this month.
Flood experts agree with Ms. Margherio. Some call the great flood of 1993 a "500-year flood," meaning that statistically over the centuries one of its magnitude should hit only once in every 500 years, though, of course, there is no guarantee that a similar or even worse flood will not occur again next spring.
This has been the kind of flood that at its absolute worst, when it was cresting here, was sending 7.5 million gallons of water past the Gateway Arch every second, six times the normal summer flow. Every 24 hours, enough topsoil slipped by in that coffee-brown turmoil to cover five 1,000-acre farms a foot deep.
But that was Aug. 1. Today, in St. Louis -- and places like Marshall, Minn., and Manhattan, Kan., and Des Moines -- the great cleanup from the great inundation had begun.
It is work with its own trauma, hard on the body, hard on the nose, hard on the pocketbook and, worst of all, hard on the mind and soul.
"God, I just hate it," Rachel Carlson lamented as she mucked out her basement in St. Charles, heaving up what looked through a layer of river goo to be a table leaf. "We worked so hard to have a nice place. Now it's like a sewer. Oh, Lord, how I hate it."
Then, somehow managing a mud-speckled smile, she bent back to her task, this time heaving up what looked to be a crushed picture frame.
Try as he might, Old Man River never managed in this summer of drowning human creations to drown the human spirit.
Work crews are moving in determinedly behind the receding waters, sometimes hastening them along toward drains with huge brooms. The crews are hauling off soggy sandbags, sweeping down streets and gathering up tree trunks, oil drums and other wretched refuse, including the occasional gar or catfish hung up in a fence-turned-gill-net.
 
Farmers, the Hardest Hit, Are Eager to Get to Work
 Across the Dakotas and into Wisconsin, then down through Nebraska and Illinois and into Missouri, fields that once resembled small lakes are beginning to dry out and farmers are itching to start fall plowing.
Hundreds of farmers along the Mississippi and Missouri and their tributaries lost most if not all of their crops. Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy estimated that 8 million acres had been flooded and that 12 million additional acres were too wet to produce crops, for a total land loss of 31,250 square miles.
The Midwest's farmers are probably the hardest-hit victims of the flood, by some estimates suffering close to $8 billion of the overall $12 billion in damage.
But their perennial optimism survives.
"Being out there in the field is what makes me happy," said Joe O'Day, whose 700 acres of beans and corn were wiped out when a levee near St. Joseph, Mo., collapsed.
Along the region's rail lines, repair crews have begun restoring miles and miles of washed-out rail bed and scores of collapsed bridges, repairs that rail officials say may cost as much as $200 million. Trains are slowly beginning to roll again, no longer forced to make 500-mile-long detours.
Barge operators, having lost as much as $300 million in revenue because of the flooding, are nudging tows filled with coal, grain and other material back onto the Mississippi and Missouri. During the worst of the flooding, most of the navigable rivers in the Midwest north of Cairo were closed to barges.
Out on the region's highways, at least on those now drying out, workers are dumping sand and rock into hundreds of huge gouges left by scouring waters.
In Missouri alone, engineers calculate that almost 500 miles of highways, including some sections of Interstate, have been seriously hit by the kind of deep, lengthy inundation that undermines and weakens a roadbed, leaving pavement subject to buckling and cracking when the first big truck passes.
Cost to repair: $150 million.
But most impressive and moving of all as the cleanup gets under way is the gritty determination of homeowners to restore what has been lost.
And a lot has been lost.
People are returning to find their dreams have been cruelly twisted into nightmares. Hollow-eyed and weary from frantic sandbag efforts that mostly failed, they make their way back into their living rooms and kitchens and dens, there to gasp and sob, transfixed by the enormousness of it all.
Then, wiping away the tears, they get on with it, trudging muddily in and out of the mess, trip after sad trip, hauling out soggy rugs, encrusted couches and water-logged family treasures, piling them and a lifetime of hard work and memories into reeking heaps on lawns of slime.
When Richard and Debra DeLaet returned to their home on the outskirts of Kansas City, Kan., what they found was typical: A neighbor's lawn chairs in the front yard, oil drums in the side yard, railroad ties in the back yard, their propane tank turned upside down, the flower box gone, and every single thing inside the house -- everything -- totally ruined unless it had been stored or hung at least five feet high.
The place smelled like a cesspool. A dead snake was stretched out on the living room floor. There was still 10 feet of water in the basement and, under that, a good 18 inches of muck.
Mrs. DeLaet headed for the Red Cross disaster center, where she picked up a cleaning kit that included a broom, a mop, a pail, bleach and ammonia. She's still scrubbing, worried about the disease and pollution lurking in the sodden mess, swatting at the ravenous mosquitoes that just love it.
"We've taken our carpets to the dump," she said, beginning a report that just as easily could have come from a flood victim in a thousand other places. "We're going to have to remove all the floors. We'll have to replace all the electrical fixtures, the fuse box, the furnace, the hot-water heater. And they say that once it starts drying out pretty good, more damage will appear -- the walls and such."
Like homeowners, cities and towns that have fallen victim to the flooding also face not only major cleanup problems but major expenses. Worse, many badly depleted their treasuries in the often futile fights against the relentlessly encroaching waters.
Small towns suffered worst of all, mainly because most big cities, the real exception being Des Moines, were protected by unusually strong levees.
Elwood, Kan., a town of 1,200 people on the Missouri, is still under so much water -- 470 of 500 houses and businesses -- that town officials are running what is left out of a Ramada Inn across the river in St. Joseph. The town's only bank, First State, is operating from an office building in St. Joseph.
"We're coming back!" boasted Marcia Sheppard as she pondered how to get her tipped double-wide mobile home back on its foundation.
Elwood and Ms. Sheppard and thousands of other victims of the flood can look to the Federal Government for help in coming back. There are any number of disaster loans and grants available, long-standing programs that cover everything including the cost of sandbags to replacement of homes, offices, barns and even fields of corn. And Congress just approved a $6.2 billion measure to aid in the flood relief effort.
But disaster experts say that, at best, only about half of the damage will be picked up by the Government. And flood insurance will cover relatively little of the rest since policies are expensive and not widely bought.
Government economists calculate that while the damage caused by this summer's flood may be the worst ever in this country, it is small considering the overall size of the American economy and thus unlikely to have much serious affect beyond the Midwest.
Which is small comfort to Peg Hazelwonder of East Hardin, Ill., north of St. Louis.
"This is like a death in the family," she lamented after returning from a boat trip to see her home.
Only the roof was above water.
And what of the damage to the huge, $25 billion system of reservoirs and levees designed to control such flooding by the nation's rivers? While no estimates are in yet, the damage is clearly huge and the failure of the system indisputable.
More than 800 of the 1,400 levees in the region were topped or breached. Most of them were berms built by towns, cities, counties and farmers, but more than 30 levees put up by the Corps of Engineers also failed and several reservoirs built by the Corps proved too small to hold the run-off from six weeks of unseasonal rain.
These failures have fueled a long-running dispute between environmentalists and levee builders about the wisdom of trying to rein in nature and build on flood plains. But this time around, the argument has a new twist.
A few days ago, the levee builders found themselves in the curious position of dynamiting a hole in one berm to relive flood pressure on another.
So it has gone in the great flood of '93, a watery rampage by nature like no other.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Issue Leads Bond Rally

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond shattered the 6.50 percent level yesterday, falling to 6.46 percent, as the bond market rallied across the board.
But the rally, traders and analysts said, was not necessarily a positive response to Congressional approval of President Clinton's deficit reduction plan late Friday. Rather, the rally resulted from a host of factors, including the fact that the 30-year bond seemed to take on a life of its own, an indication that its spectacular performance was not a reflection of overall market sentiment. 
 One sign of the differing moods in the market was that the price of the 30-year bond rose 27/32 and the yield fell to 6.46 percent, from 6.53 percent on Friday, while the rest of the market showed smaller gains. The price of the 10-year note was up 10/32 as the yield fell to 5.79 percent, from 5.84 percent.
In addition, while the yield on the 30-year bond is at its lowest level since 1977, when the Treasury began issuing 30-year bonds regularly, the yields on other Treasury securities, even the 10-year note, are above their recent lows. The yield on the 10-year note fell to 5.69 percent on July 16.
 
A Closing High for Dow
 In another odd sidelight of the financial markets, the bond market rally helped propel the Dow Jones industrial average 15.65 points higher, to a record of 3,576.08. [Page D6.]
Yet many people in the bond market said the new taxes in the deficit reduction plan would slow economic growth.
"I would have expected a rally in response to the budget, but to see it focused so exclusively on the 30-year bond is a little surprising to me," said Nicholas Sargen, the chief investment officer at Prudential Insurance's Global Advisers.
"The bond is in its own special zone," said William Pike, a managing director at Chemical Securities. The five-year note, he argued, "is a better barometer as to the way the market feels about interest rates." And, he added, while the price of the five-year note rose yesterday and the yield dropped to 5.11 percent, that was still in the middle of its recent trading range.
In addition, there are many investors who are positive about the budget package but for a cynical reason: They say tax increases in the deficit reduction plan will slow economic growth in the near future, making it much less likely that inflation, which is running at an annual rate of slightly more than 3 percent, will become a problem.
"What we've got is consistent with subdued economic growth and lower inflation," Mr. Sargen said. "It's more the cynical view."
Yet there was probably one clearer response to the approval of the budget. That came in the municipal market, where securities are tax-exempt and the higher tax rates approved by Congress should make them much more attractive. Yesterday, municipal bond prices were up a quarter to a half a point.
The rally in the government market comes on the cusp of the Treasury's quarterly auction of 3-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. Often, there is selling ahead of such auctions as traders and dealers get rid of older securities to make room for the new, and hope to drive prices lower so they can get the new securities at a lower price.
But that is not the case in this auction, which begins today with the sale of $16.5 billion in three-year notes. In the pre-auction or when-issued market, the yield on the three-year note fell to 4.46 percent, from 4.49 percent on Friday, while the yield on the 10-year note slipped to 5.76 percent, from 5.80 percent. The yield on the 30-year bond was down to 6.38 percent, from 6.45 percent.
Figuring out exactly why the market is moving is still a game of interpretation.
Howard Steiner, a senior vice president at Mitsubishi Securities, said many traders on Wall Street think the price of the 30-year bond is too high and the yield too low. But as the market continues to rally, they are forced to buy to avoid losses, adding to the momentum.
 
Seeking Higher Yields
 In addition, he said, there is still a lot of capital coming into the market from bond funds and much of it is seeking the higher yields at the longer end of the market. And because the key trade in the market is a bet that the differential between the yields of longer- and shorter-term maturities will narrow, investors and traders are buying longer-term debt.
There was also more talk yesterday that Brazil was buying 30-year bonds or would buy 30-year bonds as part of the debt deal it has made with its commercial banks. The country needs billions of bonds to strip into zero-coupon bonds, which will then be used to guarantee that the country will pay off the principal of the debt it owes.
At the shorter end of the market, yields are locked in a trading range because there is still a concern that the next move by the Federal Reserve will be to raise short-term interest rates to prevent a rise in inflation. This is why the yield on the two-year Treasury note, for example, which closed at 4.05 percent yesterday, is well above its 1993 low of 3.71 percent.
Following are the results of the Treasury auction yesterday of three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Clinton Takes His Plan to the People

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Aug. 9

 BODY:
President Clinton opened a drive today to convince the American public of what he narrowly managed to convince Congress last week: that his $496 billion package of spending cuts and tax increases was worthy of its support.
The White House billed the President's trip here as a victory lap to celebrate Congressional approval of his five-year economic plan. But his campaign-style rally this afternoon also reflected the view of Mr. Clinton and his aides that even though the plan had passed, it remained to be sold. 
 The President, who had to battle solid Republican opposition to the package, appealed for an end to "partisan rancor" when Congress turns its attention this fall to a free-trade agreement and his proposals to overhaul health care and welfare.
But he made a barbed reference to the repeated trips that Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, has begun to make even now to New Hampshire, where the first Presidential primary of 1996 will be held.
 
Bipartisanship Is Urged
 "We cannot have every great issue of the day decided on the basis of partisanship, scheduled around the next trip to New Hampshire," Mr. Clinton said. "We have got to do some of these things together."
Speaking from the steps of the gold-domed State Capitol, Mr. Clinton complained of a "withering fog of misinformation" from Republicans that he said had cast the budget package in a false light. He called attention to the legislation's $255 billion in spending cuts, issued an impassioned defense of its new programs and insisted that the burden of its $241 billion in tax increases would fall mostly on the very wealthy.
"Now we can truly say change has come to America," Mr. Clinton proclaimed to a crowd of several thousand people. But the President, who wryly thanked Vice President Al Gore last week for his help in winning a one-vote "landslide" for the package in the Senate, was also aware of polls showing that public support for the plan remained no more than tepid.
 
Selecting a State
 After praising Democratic legislators for their courage in voting for the package, Mr. Clinton told the crowd that "none of us was sent to Washington to keep our jobs; we were sent to Washington to help you keep your jobs."
In selecting West Virginia for the rally, Mr. Clinton chose a state whose demographics make its voters particularly likely to view his plan with favor. The unemployment rate here is 12.9 percent, the highest in the nation, and the President has promised that his budget package will create millions of jobs. Further, relatively few West Virginia families earn more than $140,000 a year in taxable income, the threshold for the plan's new income tax rate of 36 percent.
Only 4,442 West Virginia families will pay higher income taxes under the package, said Sylvia Matthews, a White House aide, while about 105,000 will become eligible for increased tax credits, the part of the package intended to lift working families from poverty.
That is a wider ratio than applies elsewhere in the country. But even so, Mr. Clinton and his aides emphasized at every turn today that nearly 99 percent of all Americans would escape any income tax increase.
Everything about the President's appearance here -- from the music that greeted Mr. Clinton as he arrived at the Capitol to the signs held aloft in the crowd -- was staged to portray the passage of the defict-reduction plan as a historic beginning.
"Change Has Come," read the placards, which had been distributed by Clinton aides, while audio speakers beneath the Capitol's flag-draped columns blared "New Sensation," a song by the band INXS, a heavy metal group whose name, pronounced "in excess," might seem a strange association for a President who might be subjected to accusations of overspending.
The visit here opened a brief season of extensive travel for the President, who in the next 10 days is to make stops in the Midwest, Colorado, California, Arkansas and Oklahoma.
The itinerary was to have been followed by a weeklong vacation beginning late next week in Jackson Hole, Wyo., at a ranch owned by Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger C. Altman.
But White House officials said today that a review of the ranch had found problems and that Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, were seeking an alternative location.
Among them, the officials said, is that the property is too far from the golf courses, restaurants and shops that the Clintons regard as necessary diversions. The officials also said there had been concern that the President's allergies would be aggravated in the hay-making season.

International
