HEADLINE: After Senate Loss, Abrams Tries to Stay in the Arena

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 9

 BODY:
By his own admission, Attorney General Robert Abrams lost last year's campaign for United States Senate because he committed the unpardonable political sin of letting his opponent, Alfonse M. D'Amato, define him.
As the four-term Democrat now prepares to run for re-election in 1994, he is trying hard -- perhaps a bit too hard -- to make sure that he defines himself. 
 Ask Mr. Abrams's press secretary to send a few newspaper clippings about the Attorney General's recent activities, and he faxes 41 pages, including an item from a Binghamton school district newsletter showing Mr. Abrams reading to a kindergarten class.
Ask Mr. Abrams if he has bounced back from his loss and you are likely to hear a discourse on every lawsuit filed, investigation opened and news conference held since January.
 
Busy, Busy, Busy
 There was the meeting with Henry G. Cisneros, the Housing and Urban Development Secretary, to talk about mortgage escrow practices, the settlement breaking the cable television industry's monopoly over its own programming, the legislation to increase penalties for carrying guns on school grounds. As he ticks off his accomplishments, referring frequently to notes scribbled on a legal pad, Mr. Abrams claps his hands for emphasis like firecrackers.
This is Bob Abrams as he likes to think of himself, the crusading people's lawyer, not the tax-and-spending, mud-tossing, political bumbler depicted by Mr. D'Amato last fall.
"People in the last six months have seen the real Bob Abrams again," he said in an interview last week, "the fighting Attorney General, the guy who's right out there, taking on the special interests, taking on the establishment, protecting us. Gee, that's the guy who got the biggest vote in the history of the office of Attorney General in New York State. That's the guy who was the first Democrat elected Attorney General in 40 years. That's the guy who won upstate and downstate, with Republicans and Democrats."
Mr. Abrams seems moved by his own self-description, almost as if he needed to convince himself. He knows, after all, that if he had persuaded 40,398 New Yorkers, out of 6.5 million who voted, to support him instead of Mr. D'Amato, he would have been making history last week by voting on -- and presumably for -- the President's economic plan. Instead, he lost by 1.2 percentage points and is now facing re-election with new vulnerabilities.
 
A Clinton, Not a Ford
 Until last November, Mr. Abrams had lost only one of 12 races -- his first campaign for Attorney General in 1974 -- in his 26-year political career. Now both Republican and Democratic rivals know he can be defeated.
Mr. Abrams contends that he emerged from his defeat with broader name recognition and a new strength of character. He is quick to search history for politicians who suffered humbling losses only to rise later to greater glory. He does not restrict the list to New York figures like his predecessor, Louis J. Lefkowitz, and former State Comptroller Arthur Levitt. He also finds reassurance in the biographies of Bill Clinton, Michael S. Dukakis and Richard M. Nixon.
"I'm not the first guy in politics to lose a race and to come back to the electorate again," he said. "The lessons are out there.
"I'll be ready for any and all comers," Mr. Abrams said. "If anybody thinks that this last loss by a hair means that I'm going to be a pushover, they've got another guess coming. I mean, I'm resilient."
 
Lingering Hostility
 And yet, there is lingering resentment from Democrats who feel that Mr. Abrams lost a race he should have won, squandering the chance to unseat Mr. D'Amato in a year when Mr. Clinton easily carried New York. And it may take a while for women and Italian-Americans to forgive what they see as Mr. Abrams's complicity in defeating Geraldine A. Ferraro in last year's primary. Mr. Abrams joined another candidate, New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, in repeatedly attacking Ms. Ferraro's ethics and family finances.
"There is a bitterness that is left by the Senate race that he will have to overcome with both women and strong Democrats," said Deborah Sale, the chief of staff to Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine.
William Cunningham, a Democratic political consultant, said that Mr. Abrams's "Teflon has been scratched and dented."
"One of his claims to fame when he started to run for Senate was that he had never lost, that he couldn't be beaten," said Mr. Cunningham, who works for the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, a potential Abrams challenger next year. "That's all gone now. It's a psychic hurt and it's also a marketing problem."
 
A Loser's Bounty
 The state Republican chairman, William D. Powers, said he is actively seeking candidates for Attorney General, although he is not ready to announce names. "His vulnerability is still there," Mr. Powers said. "It shows in our polls."
There is also talk of a Democratic primary. Mr. Hynes has not ruled out a race, said Mr. Cunningham. Neither has the Rockland County district attorney, Kenneth Gribetz. Both men are running for re-election this year.
Mr. Abrams said he has "every expectation of making a run for re-election." He has nearly $300,000 left from his Senate race, a sore point for many Democrats who feel the money, if spent, might have bought victory. He spent an unusual amount of time, 30 days this year, in upstate New York, where he ran poorly against Mr. D'Amato. He has two more trips scheduled this month, taking his wife and two daughters on vacations that include visits to newspaper editorial boards and civic clubs.
He recently mailed 10,000 campaign newsletters to supporters. Almost a parody of New York politics, the cover page features three pictures -- one of Mr. Abrams receiving the Thurgood Marshall Award from black civic leaders in Albany, one of him marching in the Puerto Rican Day Parade, and one of him dining with the chief rabbi of Russia.
 
Albany's Ruth Messinger?
 The Attorney General's vaunted public relations machine is humming again. When Mr. Abrams decided to make an issue of the cancer risks that may be posed by high-voltage power lines found near schools, he sent not one, not two, but three news releases -- one asking utilities to conduct a survey of electromagnetic fields near schools, one announcing that the utilities would comply, and one disclosing his finding that 115 schools are within 100 feet of the lines.
When an appellate court was deciding in February whether to order the continued confinement of Larry Hogue, a mentally ill man whose menacing behavior had created fear on Manhattan's Upper West Side, Mr. Abrams showed up for the hearing. Not to testify, he said, but simply to let reporters know that he felt Mr. Hogue should remain hospitalized.
And after the issuance of the Governor's report on the Crown Heights disturbance, Mr. Abrams flew to Washington to join his old nemesis, Mr. D'Amato, and other Republican officials in calling for a Justice Department investigation into the death of Yankel Rosenbaum, a rabbinical student killed during the violence.
"I just felt I should be there and it gave me and Al a chance to shake hands," he said, before breaking into a respectable D'Amato imitation.
 
Rumors of a New Career
 After Mr. Abrams lost last November, there were rumors that he would leave New York to join the Clinton Administration. Some talk had him going to the Securities and Exchange Commission or the Federal Trade Commission. Mr. Abrams said that he was "flattered at some of the outreach," but he declined to say whether a job was ever offered.
Some Abrams friends said he desperately wanted a Washington job as a way to save face. Others said he decided quickly that he wanted to continue serving as Attorney General in New York, waiting for another chance to run for either Senator or Governor.
Whether that chance will ever come is unclear. But many Democrats believe it will be difficult now for Mr. Abrams to move beyond his current position.
"You never say that someone is finished in politics," said Ms. Sale. "But I don't see what comes next for him and that must be very frustrating because he's devoted his entire life to it."
Mr. Abrams said it is too early to speculate. "I'll be out there working hard, strengthening the record," he said. "And I'll be prepared for anything that comes down the pike in the future."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "If anybody thinks that this last loss by a hair means that I'm going to be a pushover, they've got another guess coming," said Attorney General Robert Abrams, who is preparing his campaign for re-election. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Seeking Investment With Principle

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If one measure of influence in this power-hungry city is the number of people someone represents, Olena Berg, while hardly a household name, could well lay claim to being among the mightiest.
As the nation's top pension regulator, Ms. Berg, who took office last month, has a constituency numbering around 50 million. Her economic reach is even greater: she is the watchdog for $2.3 trillion in pension investments, nearly 40 percent of the nation's total financial assets. 
 How that money is invested, who manages it and who benefits from it are fundamental to the well-being of millions of American workers and have long-term consequences for the economy and for Corporate America. And Ms. Berg comes with strong notions: as the former Chief Deputy Treasurer of California, Ms. Berg was a trustee of that state's big pension funds, which broke the ground on shareholder activism and on investing in economically targeted projects to help the economy.
 
'Change Their Thinking'
 "We will be asking pension plans to change their thinking," said Ms. Berg, a 43-year-old Harvard M.B.A. who was a real estate executive before joining the California Treasurer's office in 1991. "Instead of thinking only about beating the market by another increment, we want them to think about how their investments are contributing to the long-run health of the economy."
In taking her new job, which has the official title of Assistant Secretary of Labor for Pension and Welfare Benefits, Ms. Berg is charged with regulating the pension industry and bringing legal action in cases of fraud. This is a position held in the mid-1980's by Robert A. G. Monks, whose speeches and regulations helped set in motion the shareholder-rights movement that has shaken up Corporate America with a new level of investor scrutiny. For his part, Mr. Monks said he was excited about Ms. Berg's appointment, especially because the post had been considered dormant in the Bush Administration.
With the shareholder rights movement well entrenched in American business -- and now rapidly expanding overseas -- Ms. Berg said her first order of business would be to focus on the controversial economically targeted investments: the use of pension dollars in nontraditional ways. The idea is that a nation strapped for jobs and with a shaky economy cannot afford to have nearly 40 percent of its free capital in passive stock and bond investments.
"This is the biggest lump of money in the world," Mr. Monks said. "How can you take 40 percent of the money out of the economy and hold it safe? Olena understands the need for prudent investing. But she also understands that these funds must be involved in the economy as a whole because they are so big."
Ms. Berg will encourage the pensions under her jurisdiction, which are corporate and union plans, to make investments that will create new jobs, businesses and housing while still earning a rate of return to protect the future retirees. Those investments might be in start-up companies, housing for the inner city or private companies.
This is in line with the goals of her boss, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, who sees the creation of new jobs and the improvement of existing ones as critical to a better economic future.
"Given the size of funds, it doesn't make sense to try to beat the market for a quarter," Ms. Berg said in an office decorated with personal photographs and Government-issue furniture. "When you are the market, as the funds are, you can't beat it. The goal should be an overall lifting of the economic boats by investing in ways that are economically productive and create more and better jobs. This is our mission, and it fits in with the Reich view of the world."
Anticipating critics, Ms. Berg added: "I can also tell you what economically targeted investments are not. They are not investments with a substandard rate of return."
Economically targeted investments have a mixed track record. There have been some notable failures: the multimillion-dollar losses in Kansas and Alaska from ill-fated mortgage investments; in Connecticut, the $25 million loss when the state pension fund tried to save Colt Industries, the firearms maker. But there have also been successes, largely in California, where the state pension plans have successfully invested in federally guaranteed inner-city mortgages, commercial real estate and private equity placements in growth businesses.
Ms. Berg said she plans to start a clearinghouse to provide information on successful targeted investments and to use her office as a bully pulpit to spread the word rather than to impose regulation. "The best system is for every pension fund to make decisions based on its own needs, its spectrum of investments and the interests of its beneficiaries," said Ms. Berg, who says she has gotten support from pension funds once the concept is understood.
Gordon Binns, chief executive of General Motors Investment Management, which invests $36 billion on behalf of G.M. workers, said he would not "reject any investment out of hand if it offers an appropriate return for the risk." Added Mr. Binns, who was himself briefly considered for Ms. Berg's job, "The economically targeted investment label doesn't scare me off, as long as it's not mandatory."
Ms. Berg's office does not regulate the public pension funds that have been in the forefront of shareholder activism. But those public funds, which represent municipal workers and teachers and are overseen by the states, closely follow the actions of her office and their leaders are delighted. "We like her," said Ralph Whitworth, head of the United Shareholders Association, an advocacy group. "She has a good understanding of corporate governance and has the background and tools to push an agenda."
One example of the influence of Ms. Berg's office on funds, public and private, was the so-called "Avon letter," a 1988 opinion stipulating that corporate proxies are a pension plan asset and must be taken seriously and voted. This opinion was considered a milestone in the shareholder rights movement because it forced pension plans not to vote automatically with management.
"We're looking for another Avon letter," said Nell Minnow, a partner in the Lens Fund, which was formed by Mr. Monks and which invests based on shareholder-rights principles. "Academic studies show that active investing can bring superior investment results, and it may be that some of a pension fund's assets will have to be diversified into a shareholder-activism component."
Just as Ms. Berg took office, the Campbell Soup Company made a ground-breaking announcement and said it would vote all its pension fund proxies according to shareholder activism principles -- the first corporate pension fund to join forces with the activists.
 
A 'Cautious Activist'
 Ms. Berg, a self-described "Army brat" who did not come to the United States until the age of 12, was graduated from the California State University at Chico. She worked in state government in finance, housing and community development before leaving to attend the Harvard Business School in 1982. Upon returning to California two years later, she became the president of a San Francisco real estate company and then moved to Los Angeles to become an executive at a real estate company specializing in troubled properties.
"After six years in the private sector, which I enjoyed, I found I missed the scope of public sector jobs," said Ms. Berg, who became the chief deputy to Kathleen Brown, the Treasurer of California, in 1991.
As Ms. Brown's representative on the California Public Employees Retirement System and the California State Teachers' Retirement System, Ms. Berg earned the reputation as "a very quick study" and a "cautious activist," said Richard Koppes, general counsel to the public employees' fund. "Pension funds have nothing to fear, but they will be challenged -- and should be, given the amount of money they have." The California funds, in fact, lobbied the Administration to appoint Ms. Berg.
In Washington, since her confirmation on July 24, Ms. Berg has been filling in what she does not know: How Washington works, the intricacies of the laws she oversees, making contacts with Treasury and Securities and Exchange Commission officials. She says she will continue the department's strong record of enforcements.
"You can't run over this woman," said Sarah Teslik, executive director of the Council of Institutional Investors. "She's a hard person in the right ways." Ms. Teslik said that Ms. Berg, by training and temperament, is a "very loyal deputy who understands the big picture stuff and won't talk out of school." Already, Ms. Teslik said, Ms. Berg has been careful to smooth the feathers of pension funds that have been alarmed by some of the bolder proposals of Labor Secretary Reich. "She's terrific eyes and ears for Reich, and she knows how to mend fences, when that's needed."

HEADLINE: Budget Cutters Discover Easy Target in Medicare

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
As one of the largest and fastest-growing Federal programs and one bearing the dreaded "entitlement" label at that, Medicare, which covers health care for the elderly, presented budget cutters with a plump target. And not surprisingly it took the biggest single hit, apart from the military, as Congress and the President wrapped up the new five-year economic plan last week.
Money for Medicare from 1994 through 1998 was trimmed by $56 billion, a 6 percent cut from the previously projected total of $971 billion. Another $8 billion was pared from Medicaid, the health care program for the poor, a 1 percent cut from $592 billion. 
 More surprising was the relative political ease with which the medical cuts, more accurately reductions in growth, were achieved. While legislators haggled over the numbers, they took it for granted that payments to hospitals and doctors in years ahead could be reduced by tens of billions of dollars without endangering patients or inflicting great hardship on anyone, at least in the short term.
 
Hidden Tax Is Seen
 When hospitals and doctors are pinched by Medicare, past experience has shown, they often make up some of the loss by raising rates for privately insured patients, a practice known as cost shifting. Thus, what is presented in Washington as a politically appealing spending cut is really an indirect tax on the country's insurance-buying companies and workers. It is a stealthy tax that legislators know they can get away with.
Last week's cuts were far from the reining in of medical entitlements that budget experts say must happen if the Federal deficit is ever to be tamed. But there is also a widely shared sense that this sponge has just about been squeezed dry -- that Medicare may have been cut as far as it safely can in the absence of major new constraints on the health care system as a whole. And that topic is expected to consume Congress in the coming year.
While advocates for doctors, hospitals and the elderly winced and groused at the cuts, their cries were muted.
"Medicare was the piggy bank they went to to achieve the magic formula," complained John Rother, chief lobbyist for the American Association of Retired Persons, referring to the President's political imperative of matching tax increases with spending cuts.
 
Tougher Struggle to Come
 But the affected interest groups seemed intent on keeping their powder dry for the more momentous brawl to come, after President Clinton announces his proposals for sweeping overhaul of the health system.
The largest single cut is in Medicare payments to hospitals, which will be about $22 billion below the projected $487 billion. Hospitals say Medicare already pays them less than 90 percent of their average patient costs. But most of the country's hospitals are doing well financially, and troubled public hospitals will still receive extra money.
"The cuts are significant, but they are not likely to lead to any serious reduction in services to Medicare recipients," said Stuart Altman, an economist at Brandeis University who heads a commission that advises Congress on Medicare payments to hospitals.
Medicare payments to doctors, previously projected at $228 billion, will decline by $9 billion. Promoting a national goal, doctors providing primary care, who are relatively underpaid, are exempted from the cut.
 
A.M.A. Avoids Fight
 Dr. James S. Todd, chief executive of the American Medical Association, said that while his group had registered its unhappiness with the budget bill, "we did not mount a huge campaign," in part because the organization feared that a defeat would result in more drastic measures.
But he added that further cuts in Medicare could cause real hardship, even jeopardizing patients' access to treatment. Many members of Congress who have happily slashed at the program up to now agree with that.
Mr. Rother of the retired persons' association said that the looming health care debate had changed the political equation. If the new cuts stand alone, creating an ever-wider gap between what doctors get for treating the elderly and what they get from privately insured patients, there will be "real damage," he said. But he said he hoped that national reforms would help even things out by also constraining the private sector.
The only direct cost to individuals in the medical cuts involves a small increase in the monthly premiums that Medicare recipients pay to the Government, intended to keep them at 25 percent of the cost of doctor care. Individuals will pay $56 a month in 1997, $7.40 more than expected, and the Government will collect $8 billion more than projected over five years.
 
Cuts in Medicaid
 In contrast with Medicare, the cuts in Medicaid do not involve reduced fees for doctors or hospitals, in part because states, which share Medicaid costs, generally set the fees and in part because the fees are already low.
The largest savings came easily. A 1990 law intended to give states the option of expanding personal care for the disabled had been accidentally written in a way that would require all states to start new programs. By making this optional, as originally intended, Congress shaved $4 billion from projected expenditures.
Other savings involve closing of loopholes that allowed states to gain more Federal matching money than Congress had intended, and tightening restrictions on the transfer of assets by middle-class elderly people who say they are poor and ask Medicaid to pay their nursing home bills.

HEADLINE: Consumers Wake Up to Increases in Cereal Prices

BYLINE: By VERONICA BYRD

 BODY:
Rosalind Fidelman, a retired bookkeeper in East Northport, L.I., calls cereal prices "disgraceful," bristling at the ever-higher prices she sees posted on grocery store shelves. The latest advance came last week, when the Kellogg Company, the market leader, wrote retailers that it was raising prices 2.1 percent, the company's third increase of the year.
And Mrs. Fidelman is not alone. Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General, sued in February to block Kraft's $450 million acquisition of RJR Nabisco's cold cereals. "These soaring price increases, far out of line with other food products, are a clear result of an overconcentrated industry," he said. 
 But in June, Judge Kimba M. Wood of Federal District Court in Manhattan denied Mr. Abrams's request to block the merger. The Attorney General has filed an appeal, which is pending. "The last thing this industry needs is less competition," Mr. Abrams said.
 
 
Five Big Players
 Last year, the top six companies -- Kellogg, General Mills, Kraft General Foods, the Quaker Oats Company, the Ralston Purina Company and RJR Nabisco -- had 90 percent of the industry's $7 billion in sales. With the Kraft-RJR Nabisco deal, there are now five big players. The Federal Trade Commission, which had no objection to the merger, voted 3 to 1 in 1982 to dismiss a 10-year-old antitrust case against three industry leaders.
Cereal prices rose 71 percent from 1983 to 1991, almost double the 37 percent increase in overall food prices, according to the Food Marketing Policy Center at the University of Connecticut at Storrs. Ronald W. Cotterill, an agricultural economist at the center, said that with prices averaging $3 a box, and in some cases topping $5, an average family could easily spend $15 to $20 a week.
Mrs. Fidelman, who lives with her daughter and three grandchildren, buys three or four boxes a week. Because she is retired, she said, she has time to look through newspaper advertisements for cents-off coupons and to go to stores that advertise sales. She even mixes some cheaper cereal with her grandchildren's favorite sugar-coated brands to save money.
 
 
Drawing the Line on Prices
 Given such consumer resistance, some analysts now see signs that price increases may abate. General Mills, the second-largest maker with a 25 percent market share, said last week that it had "no immediate plans" to follow Kellogg, which has 37 percent of the market, and increase cereal prices.
In contrast, when Kellogg raised prices on most of its cereals an average of 3 percent earlier this year, General Mills followed with increases of 3.5 percent, and Quaker Oats lifted its prices on some items by as much as 7 percent while dropping prices on others by as much as 9 percent.
Richard E. Lovell, a spokesman for Kellogg, attributed the increases to "an increase in overall business costs," but he declined to be more specific.
The overall costs of manufacturing breakfast cereals have remained relatively unchanged, the United States Department of Labor says. The costs of five of the eight main ingredients -- wheat, milled rice, oats, barley, corn, wheat flour, refined sugar and dehydrated fruits -- declined in both 1990 and 1991, the department said. Natural gas, hourly wages and paperboard box prices edged up 2.2 percent in 1991, and electricity rates increased 8.2 percent.
 
 
Consumer Disadvantage Seen
 One factor helping cereal price increases is that "there aren't many substitutes for cold cereal," said John M. McMillin, a food analyst at Prudential Securities. "Compared to other food categories, the consumer is definitely at a disadvantage."
Unlike many brand products that have lost market share to low-priced generics, cereal still commands brand loyalty, analysts say, and when children want their favorite brand, most mothers will indulge them.
Cereal makers argue that even with price increases, given the number of servings in a box, cereal remains a good buy.
"Cereal is a very good buy," said R. Craig Shulstad, a spokesman at General Mills. "Where else are you going to get convenience, taste and nutrition for between 15 cents and 19 cents a serving?"
But some analysts say that the one-ounce serving size used in such calculations is unrealistic. A hungry fullback can demolish a box in a single sitting.
Mr. McMillin notes that consumer resistance has increased since some prices have topped $5 a box. Some consumers are even switching from cereals to breakfast foods like oatmeal, bagels and yogurt.
 
 
Sales Are Down
 And cereal makers are feeling the pinch. Kellogg, based in Battle Creek, Mich., reported last month that sales dropped 2.7 percent, to $1.54 billion from $1.58 billion.
Ralston-Purina, the smallest cereal maker, with a 5 percent market share, said its net earnings in the third-quarter of its fiscal year, which ended June 30, were $66.2 million, down from $68.4 million a year ago.
Noting the recent slippage in earnings, Ronald B. Morrow, an analyst at Smith Barney Shearson, said, "Volumes have been slowing down, and growth is becoming more difficult." Cereal makers are "having to reduce costs to remain competitive," he said.
Still, Mr. McMillin said, the profit margin in the industry is "extraordinarily high," and a consumer would "be crazy to buy cereal without a coupon." He estimates that about 45 percent of cereals are purchased with coupons. Marketing costs -- advertising, coupons, promotional and retail deals -- total 30 percent of sales, he said.
 
 
Estimate of Profit
 Dr. Cotterill of the University of Connecticut estimates that producing a box of cereal costs roughly 40 to 50 percent of its list price and that "the rest is advertising, promotion and profits." About 15 to 20 percent is profit, he said.
Mr. Shulstad of General Mills agreed that a profit margin of 15 to 20 percent was about average, but he said consumers had the advantage of discount coupons. "Cereal is the most heavily promoted in terms of coupons," he said.
But Dr. Cotterill said: "Prices have increased dramatically. And even though some people are able to avoid the higher price if they have a coupon, only about 40 percent of cereals are purchased with coupons."
According to data compiled by Information Resources Inc. and based on the 52-week period that ended on Dec. 27, the estimated average price for a box of cereal in 1992 rose 5.3 percent, to $3. After coupons, the price was $2.23, up 8 percent, from $2.06 in 1991.
As he shopped at a Safeway store, Merrill Briley, a 44-year-old city maintenance employee in Portland, Ore., said, "I started buying cereals I don't even like because I have the coupons for them."
 
 
Increased Use of Coupons
 Coupons and two-for-one deals are a benefit to consumers provided they "have the time to consistently clip coupons and shop at several different grocery stores to get the best price," Mr. McMillin said. Still, the increasingly competitive industry has become too dependent on marketing for growth, he said, and that is one reason cereal makers have increased prices.
The increase in coupons reflects "a more price-conscious consumer, private-label penetration and the fact that Kellogg and General Mills are going head to head in competition," Mr. McMillin said. For example, the new General Mills cereal, Wheaties Honey Gold, is very similar to Kellogg's Frosted Flakes.
The cost of a box of puffed flakes or baked oats can take the snap, crackle and pop out of any grocery budget.
At one grocery store in New York City, a 15-ounce box of Cheerios was priced at $4.59. A 20-ounce box of Kellogg's Low Fat Granola was priced at $5.39. In Washington, a 20-ounce box of Raisin Bran was rung up at $4.09. And across the country in Portland, Ore., a 17-ounce box of Nutri-Grain was priced at $3.53.
 
 
Uh-Oh, Cheerios
 Dollar sales of Cheerios -- which account for nearly 10 percent of the ready-to-eat market -- were down last year for the first time since 1989, at $325 million, according to Nielsen Marketing Research. Cheerios' share of the market slipped to 4.7 percent in 1992 from 5.1 percent in 1990.
Some of that slippage, analysts and industry experts said, shows up in a rise in sales of cheaper, private-label brands, which grew by 34 percent for the year that ended October 1991, according to Nielsen. Still, the private-label brands account for only about $350 million of the $7 billion total sales in the industry and control 5 percent of the market.
"To think private labels will grow to 20 or 30 percent of the industry and provide a viable alternative is just not going to happen," Dr. Cotterill said. Many of the private-label brands will eventually be pushed out of the market by the major cereal makers, he said.

HEADLINE: Merchants Battle a Wave of Peddlers

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 9

 BODY:
Aaron Smitheimer thought he had seen it all until a peddler came into his Port Washington jewelry store and tried to sell his customers fake name-brand wristwatches.
"I pay taxes, I pay rent, I pay all the other expenses that go along with running a store, and here's this guy trying to sell watches to my customers," Mr. Smitheimer said. "Talk about chutzpah." 
 The peddler left when asked, but even after Mr. Smitheimer put a "No Soliciting" sign on the front door, it didn't stop the onslaught of entrepreneurs who carry their goods in fanny packs, knapsacks, suitcases and plastic shopping bags, and who seem to be spreading all over Long Island.
"The problem of soliciting has grown and grown," said Gary Hudes, a jeweler in Bellmore. "Sometimes they come in as often as three times in one day."
 
'Everything Under the Sun'
 Mr. Hudes said the peddlers hawk "everything under the sun" -- perfume, toys, lighters, jewelry, clothing, wallets, handbags, pots and pans.
"You name it," he said. "If they can't lug it around, they sell it out of the back of their cars."
What galls many merchants is that when the peddlers bother shoppers, store workers must stop serving other customers to intervene. "If you're busy, you don't have time to go after them. I think they count on that," Mr. Hudes said.
The peddlers also seem to count on the fact that they will rarely be confronted.
"If you ask to see their license, they say they don't need one or say that their company keeps it in the office," said Ralph Ekstrand, a pharmacist in Farmingdale. "And if I ask them if they pay New York State sales tax, they always say, 'Of course.' But they never give a receipt and never collect tax from their customers."
Mr. Ekstrand said he realizes that most of the peddlers are young people who are just trying to earn a living. But many merchants, faced with trying times, say the invasion threatens their livelihood.
"The issue of peddlers is the only thing our members want to talk about any more," said Roy Smitheimer, Aaron Smitheimer's son and the president of the Nassau Council of Chambers of Commerce, an umbrella organization of 40 community chambers of commerce, representing more than 6,000 merchants. "The peddlers represent a loss of tax revenue to the community and a loss of business to established businesses who are themselves suffering through the slow economy," he said.
While most towns require that peddlers be licensed, the regulations vary. To make enforcement easier, the Council of Chambers of Commerce has formulated a uniform peddlers code that it plans to ask each town and village to follow.
Among other things, the code would require applications for peddlers' licenses to include a sales-tax identification number, photo and fingerprint, which would then be submitted to the police for investigation. It also would increase the penalties for not having a license to as much as $500. Peddlers would also be required to get permission from the owner of a store or office before entering to sell their wares.
Chris Murray, the lawyer who drew up the code, said no one can prevent peddlers from doing business. But he said they have to abide by the laws, pay taxes and respect the rights of the store owners. "There's also a right for businesses to control what goes on in their property," he said.
 
Buying From Peddlers
 Suzanne Decker, a clerk in a Farmingdale pharmacy, admits that she has bought several items from peddlers. A toy puppy, in its original box, cost her about $12; the same item in a major store was priced at about $25 plus sales tax, she said. "You think about the loss of revenue to your area," she said, "but when you're living on a budget, you have to think about what's good for you.".
But the loss of revenue is not only through lost sales. In New York City, it is estimated that about $25 million in sales tax is lost annually to peddlers who pocket the tax.
"What you have is a little bit of tax evasion by a lot of people," the State Tax Commissioner, James W. Wetzler, said.
Until now, the department focused mostly on peddlers in Manhattan, but with the influx on Long Island, it is widening its scope.
Last year, the department proposed legislation that would require suppliers to file reports including the tax identification number and amount of sales to peddlers, who are considered independent contractors. Mr. Wetzler said this would at least provide a paper trail for the department to follow. The legislation did not pass, but it will be offered again this year.
One of the largest suppliers of goods to peddlers on Long Island is Impulse, a company with offices in Hicksville and Farmingdale. Impulse supplies a vast array of goods. A spokeswoman for the company, who would not be interviewed but provided a written statement, said that all the people who buy from them are independent contractors who are required to issue receipts.
She said that Impulse was unaware of proposed changes to peddling laws, but that the company would fight "any legislation which is over broad or has the effect of unfairly restraining direct salespeople from the marketplace."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The swarm of peddlers is so thick they are even going into established stores to hawk their wares. Ralph Ekstrand, a pharmacist in Farmingdale, L.I., has posted a notice behind his counter, "No Soliciting of Any Kind. Do Not Enter." But still they come. He offered his help to a customer. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bonds Help Dow Surge 15.65 to New High

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks moved higher yesterday, riding the crest of a surge in Treasury bond prices. The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index closed at new highs, and other indexes posted gains.
The Dow rose 15.65 points, to a new high of 3,576.08. The Dow's previous high was set on July 26, when it closed at 3,567.70. The Nasdaq composite managed a new high, rising 0.41 point to 718.49, surpassing the previous high of 718.08 set on Friday. 
 Trading was heavy yesterday. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 232.3 million shares, up from 221.2 million on Friday. The number of stocks posting gains outpaced losing issues, 1,210 to 804.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 2.04 points, to 450.72, and the Big Board composite gained 1.17 points, to 250.08. The American Stock Exchange composite increased 2.46 points, to 438.80.
 
 
Relief Over Budget's Passage
 Edward P. Nicoski, chief market strategist for Piper Jaffray Inc., said the market had an upward bias following the rally in bonds, as the yield on the 30-year bond fell to a 16-year low of 6.46 percent. Yields and prices move in opposite directions. He attributed the bond rally to investors' relief over the passage of the President's deficit-reduction plan.
More good news, Mr. Nicoski said, will come from the Government's quarterly borrowing, which begins today with the auction of a new three-year note. "It looks like the demand for the quarterly borrowing will be strong, making it a done deal and a healthy situation for the bond market," he said.
"What struck me is that investors have put the tax bill behind them and may refocus on the negatives like this spring, when select health care stocks were beaten down over uncertainty surrounding health care reform," Mr. Nicoski said.
Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment strategist of the First Albany Corporation, said: "The stock market was lifted on the interest-rate side of things. The decline in interest rates encourages investors to buy stock because there is not much alternative."
While passage of the budget plan did bolster stocks and bonds, traders said there was still some uncertainty ahead of the next round of reports on inflation.
 
 
Rally in Energy Stocks
 Energy stocks rallied yesterday. They were led by Chevron, which rose 1 7/8, to 86 3/8. Chevron has underperformed the market recently, so yesterday's gain could be called a technical bounce.
Technology stocks fizzled in the afternoon after showing strength earlier. Motorola fell 3/4, to 95 1/2. Microsoft and I.B.M. slipped 1/4 each, to 73 and 43 1/8, respectively.
Airlines and auto makers also combined to lift the market. General Motors rose 1, to 48 3/4, Chrysler gained 1 1/8, to 43, and Ford rose 5/8, to 52 1/4.
 In other market activity, Ace Limited, rose by 2 1/8, to 32 5/8. The Alex. Brown & Sons brokerage firm began its coverage of the stock with a strong recommendation to buy.
Charter Medical, which was up 1 1/2, to 21 1/2, said it had reached an agreement in principle to sell 10 hospitals to Quorum Health Group, a private company, for $335 million in cash and $5 million in a seven-year note.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues to Rise Amid Uncertainty in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher yesterday as weaker European currencies slipped in continued fallout from the loosening of the Continent's exchange-rate system.
Currency traders said the French franc, Italian lira and Spanish peseta dropped against the German mark as investors anticipated interest rate cuts in those countries. That, in turn, buoyed the dollar, which is used as an intermediary in many trades involving European currencies. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6970 German marks, up from 1.6955 marks on Friday. The British pound, meanwhile, fell to $1.4915, from $1.4990 on Friday.
The overhaul of Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism last week allows many currencies to trade in a wider range against the German mark. It also permits countries to lower interest rates, a move that can stimulate their economies but hurt the value of their currencies.
 
French Lower One Rate
 Yesterday, the Bank of France lowered its overnight funds rate from 10 percent to 9.75 percent. While the bank left more important rates unchanged, the move "points in the direction of French rates falling sooner rather than later," said Andrew Hodge, a vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert in New York.
Traders said the German mark also gained strength against other European currencies because it was reportedly being bought by European central banks that must repay loans from the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank. Central banks borrowed billions of marks in the weeks before the loosening of the European exchange rate system, as they tried to defend their currencies from speculative attacks.
The dollar also rose against the Japanese yen. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted 104.91 yen, up from 104.35 Friday. Currency traders said the yen fell against the dollar because of concerns about the new Japanese Government.
"The markets are still skittish about how the coordination between a center-left Government and the Government ministries and the central bank is going to proceed," Mr. Hodge said.

HEADLINE: A Free-Form Film Maker Who Spares All Expense

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
Critics often praise a director's work as "personal." It's a pretty safe bet that the films and videos of George Kuchar are not quite what they have in mind when using the term.
For 30 years, working several economic rungs below low-budget, Mr. Kuchar has reached for the glamour of Hollywood and pulled it right down to street level, where ordinary mortals with weight problems and bad skin wage unequal battle with their tawdry surroundings. 
 Mr. Kuchar, the subject of a month-long retrospective that began on Friday at the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, is right down there with them, a tortured romantic struggling with the cheap materials that life so stingily provides.
In "Hold Me While I'm Naked," an early classic, Mr. Kuchar (pronounced KOO-char) plays a film maker who coaxes his stars into making passionate love, then returns home to his shabby apartment in the Bronx, where he steps into the shower and slowly bangs his head against the wall. Like most of Mr. Kuchar's films, it makes do without such elements as plot, character or narrative coherence.
In "The Creeping Crimson," one of Mr. Kuchar's recent video diaries, he wanders the streets of the Bronx neighborhood where he grew up and comments on the local scene, holding his video camera at arm's length and training it on his face. Mr. Kuchar's nostrils emerge as major characters in their own right.
Mr. Kuchar, now 50, has made films in as short a time as 10 minutes, on a budget of $200 or so. He has shot greeting cards with doors on them as stand-ins for an interior. As a cost-cutting measure, he has shot with negative film, making his actors up in blackface and white lipstick.
"It turned out pretty interesting," he said in a recent interview in Manhattan, "although when people smiled, their teeth were black."
Mr. Kuchar produces, directs and edits his films. He does the sound and the lighting. He writes the scripts, quickly. "I work best under terrible pressure," he said. "Usually, I write as the actors are getting ready for the scene."
In a Kuchar film, there is no such thing as a second take. Or rather, the second take is simply added on to the first take and becomes part of the film. Anything goes, since the most characteristic Kuchar films embrace at least five genres simultaneously and consist of one climax after another.
"Gossamer Garbage: A George Kuchar Film and Video Retrospective," offers 64 works by Mr. Kuchar, beginning with short eight-millimeter films from the early and mid-60's, many of them made with his twin brother, Mike. Among them are "Tootsies in Autumn," "Lust for Ecstasy," "I Was a Teen-Age Rumpot" and "Corruption of the Damned," a film that, Mr. Kuchar once wrote, "bursts from its girdle of traditional Hollywood pyrotechnics and falls all over the place in a paroxysm of flabby sensuality, senselessness and insanity."
Mr. Kuchar's middle period sees a graduation to 16-millimeter and culminates in "The Devil's Cleavage," a 107-minute epic, and his last work on film, "Ascension of the Demonoids," financed by his one and only grant from the National Endowment for the Arts, a $20,000 bonanza that also paid for a video camera and thereby propelled Mr. Kuchar into a new creative phase.
In the last decade Mr. Kuchar has made video dramas with his students at the San Francisco Art Institute, where he has taught film and video since 1971, and a series of video diaries, which deal with various personal torments, his psychic development and his pet obsessions, especially weather.
Mr. Kuchar has made eight trips to El Reno, Okla., pointing his camera out the window of the same motel to record storms, clouds and the activity at a nearby trailer park.
Mr. Kuchar and weather go back a long way. After graduating from the School of Industrial Art in Manhattan (now called the School of Art and Design) with a major in illustration, Mr. Kuchar landed a job with NBC drawing the clouds on the weather maps used by Frank Field, the station's weatherman.
"He didn't know I had an interest in cloud anatomy, so he was delighted with the accuracy of the clouds on the map," said Mr. Kuchar, who became somewhat disillusioned with the job after it became clear to him that weather was not the focal point of the news program for everyone. "I realized that for most people it was sort of a throwaway event," he said, still seemingly a bit troubled by this.
 
Visiting a Famous Tree
 Somewhat more eventful is "Pilgrimage," a 1992 diary that chronicles Mr. Kuchar's journey to Watsonville, Calif., to visit a tree that became famous overnight when local citizens claimed to see the image of the Virgin Mary in its bark. "It's an uplifting film for the Christmas season," said Mr. Kuchar, who delivers most of his remarks deadpan. It's quite possible that he does think of the film as a holiday treat for the whole family.
"The Shame of Leila LaSeure," about a patient's affair with a psychotherapist, is another gift to the public. "With that one, I was thinking of making a picture that people could understand," said Mr. Kuchar, with the air of someone willing to try anything once.
Mr. Kuchar's admirers, who have included Andy Warhol and John Waters, are generally quite happy to be baffled. And Mr. Kuchar says it's fine with him if viewers leave the theater bemused, since confusion may inspire them to see his films a second time.
There may not be much time left, in fact. "With some of the films, there is only one print in existence, and the videos, who knows how long they'll last?" Mr. Kuchar said. "People say, well, in 10 years they'll turn to dust, but that's true of me, too. But I do hope the stuff will live on -- live on in shame."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Revenue-Sharing Ball Is in the Owners' Court

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:
Major league club owners meet tomorrow in Kohler, Wis., a city noted for the manufacture of sinks and toilets and bathtubs. Will it be the city where baseball goes down the drain?
That would depend on one's point of view, of course. 
 If the owners, for example, fail to reach agreement on a plan to increase the amount of revenue they share, the players wouldn't have to be bothered by the owners then coming to them demanding a cap on their salaries, which they won't accept anyway.
If the owners fail to reach agreement on a plan to increase the amount of revenue they share, they would leave their side in a quandary as to how to proceed. They also would leave Richard Ravitch, their chief labor executive, in such a dilemma that he very likely would have to resign.
If the owners reach agreement on a plan to increase the amount of revenue they share, some of their own brethern might try to scuttle it by going to court. A rumor is circulating in baseball circles that George Steinbrenner has already drafted papers for a lawsuit he would file against his colleagues if they try to take money out of his deep pockets.
The owners will meet at the American Club, a resort a few miles west of Sheboygan, tomorrow, Thursday and, if needed, Friday. Ravitch had hoped they could meet undetected, preserving the secrecy that has shrouded the entire revenue sharing matter.
"There's an extraordinarily strict confidentiality agreement that governs revenue sharing," one club executive said. The agreement, the executive added, includes a provision for disciplinary action against anyone who violates it, specifying a fine and also saying that anyone breaching the agreement would be subject to sanctions provided in the Major League Agreement.
But the agreement is so strict the executive wouldn't say how much the fine would be, and some others who were asked wouldn't even acknowledge that the provision exists. But one person said the magic number was $100,000.
Ravitch, citing the confidentiality agreement, declined to discuss specifics of his revenue-sharing proposals.
After sending a series of plans to the owners for their study and discussion, then digesting their comments, Ravitch recently sent out a proposal that is designed to serve as the starting point for debate in Kohler. Exact details of the plan have remained secret, but one fearless soul offered what was said to be a general outline.
"It all depends on what salary cap is ultimately agreed to by the union," the informant said. "The higher the salary cap, the higher a percentage of local revenue will be needed; the lower the cap, the lower a percentage is needed."
Last year's player payroll was $783 million. Using a round number, if the payroll were $800 million and the central fund, which includes money from national television, cable and radio and licensing, could pay $300 million of that total, $500 million would be needed from local revenue.
If local revenue, which includes money from local television packages and gate receipts, totaled $1.5 billion, the percentage each team would pay from its local revenue would be derived from the ratio of $500 million to $1.5 billion. Each club would put one-third of its local revenue into the payroll pool, meaning the Yankees and the Mets, for example, would have to pay more than the Milwaukee Brewers and the Montreal Expos.
"That's sort of in the general ball park," a club executive said, "but there's more to it. It's a terribly complicated process we're going through. It's not something that can be explained in a paragraph or two."
In another glimpse of what clubs might expect economically, a few days before the Baltimore Orioles were auctioned in United States Bankruptcy Court, the prospective bidders were given information indicating the Orioles' share of the revenue-sharing pot would be $8.7 million.
Whatever plan finally is put on the table for adoption, it will need 21 of 28 votes to pass. If it passes, Ravitch next would make a proposal to the union calling for a salary cap. The players would reject it, then decide if they should strike next month to pre-empt the owners from imposing crippling rules changes next winter. (Some owners are said to be prepared to vote for a plan, knowing that the players would kill it by refusing a salary cap.)
If the owners vote down any plan, the prevailing view is that Ravitch would resign. He has spent more than a year trying to convince the owners they need to increase their revenue sharing to save the game, and if they were to repudiate him, he not only would have no proposal to take to the players, but he also would have no strength with which to deal with them.
According to a view on the labor side, Ravitch may try to convince the owners to adopt a plan by telling them if they don't, he would have to resign and that would play right into the union's hands.
Ravitch would not talk about his strategy or his future, saying only that he would like to see the owners approve a plan.
"I want to steer it to a conclusion, not a specific conclusion," he said. "It's not for me to tell the owners how much money they should commit. It's up to me to explain all the alternatives."

HEADLINE: PERIPHERALS;
When Memory And Frill Collide

BYLINE: By L. R. SHANNON

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH it is an old song, "Thanks for the Memory" is still the favorite theme of personal computer fans, particularly those who have resisted moving to Windows or who have made only a partial changeover. Two columns last month about QEMM 7.01, Quarterdeck's new version of an old standard among memory managers, brought in spirited responses from both readers and software publishers.
It was mentioned that QEMM and a screen saver, Razzle Dazzle, did not coexist. A company expert in the Quarterdeck Forum in Compuserve, who had earlier suggested changes to deal with this, noted later: "You will probably find that some screen savers will interfere with system functions that are more important. However, a lot of our users have After Dark, and that seems to work fine." This avoided answering the question of what system function could possibly be more important than a neat screen saver. Then Road Scholar, the publisher of Razzle Dazzle, sent word that an updated version of the screen saver would work with the new QEMM. Meanwhile, a reader, Dick Netzer, senior fellow and professor of economics and public administration at New York University, wrote of version 6.0: "QEMM fights fiercely with Pyro," a screen saver, "and occasionally fights with Sidekick." 
 Helix, the software company in Long Island City, Queens, that helped develop DOS 6.0's Memmaker utility, sent a copy of Netroom 3.02, another memory manager.
Netroom, a DOS program that takes Windows into account, offers three levels of installation: Conservative, for those who wear both suspenders and a belt; Aggressive, for those who wear one or the other, and Custom, for the shamelessly daring.
The Aggressive installation is simple, though slightly fussy, and requires few decisions. At one point in the process, the program warns that it will have to remove references to QEMM from the autoexec.bat and config.sys files, although it considerately saves copies of the old files in case you want to restore them. There are also six utility programs -- disk cache, screen saver, screen accelerator, RAM drive, virus protection and something called D.P.M.I. -- that may be loaded as options.
Despite its macho name, Aggressive is gentle. QEMM had left 649,400 bytes of conventional memory free. Netroom settled for 593,072. More to the point these days, both programs made more than three megabytes -- conventional and extended memory -- available to Windows. And although Netroom did not freeze the keyboard, as QEMM had done when Razzle Dazzle was present, Netroom would not run the screen saver, either. Another reader, Ted Dolmatch, of Briarcliff, N.Y., formerly "an old and loyal Quarterdeck customer," got 634,528 bytes from Netroom 3, "without one hang."
Netroom is $99 for a single-user license. If you want more information, phone Helix at (800) 451-0551 or (718) 392-3100.
 
Still More Memory
 Qualitas, a software company in Bethesda, Md., takes a different approach with its two memory managers, 386Max 7 and BlueMax 7, which are $99.95 and $124.95, respectively. 386Max is for machines with 80386, 80486 or Pentium C.P.U.'s, particularly those running DOS programs either inside or outside of Windows, while BlueMax is specifically for I.B.M.'s PS/2 line.
If you are running a DOS character-based -- not graphics -- application in a DOS window, 386Max can provide it with as much as 736 kilobytes of conventional memory. That marks version 7 of 386Max as a transitional program for people who are working in a mixed DOS-Windows environment. Other features include a far easier way to write Program Information Files (PIF's) to configure DOS programs for Windows, and support for DOS 6's Multiconfig, which allows one to decide which of several alternate configurations will be selected at startup. Information is available by calling (800) 676-0386.
Memory Commander 4.0, a $99.95 memory manager from V Communications of San Jose, Calif., says it can make up to 800 kilobytes of memory available for graphics programs on V.G.A. systems, 920 kilobytes for text programs. Although it is essentially a DOS program, it, too, takes Windows into account and can provide configuration benefits for it as well. If you want information, call (408) 296-4224. Although Memory Commander has been designed for relatively unsophisticated users, the V Communications catalog contains routines for programmers as well.
All this memory managing had left the autoexec.bat and config.sys files in the resident 386 in a mess. So I tried to return the files to the way they were just after DOS 6.0 had been installed. Eventually, after a long series of error messages indicating that the effort had not been completely successful, I reinstalled DOS from scratch. Even with a clean slate, there was not as much memory available as there had been. But the machine will soon be passed on, when the 486 hotrod arrives, and memory shortages in it will be another user's problem.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Building A Living Monument

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN

 BODY:
THE call-in shows in Boston have moved along to something else. So it goes. There is a rumor that professional football is arriving in New England. The Yankees are in Fenway tonight for the start of a series, and a race is giving Red Sox fans reason to renew their happy hatred. So it goes.
All those hours of grief-stricken calls on the radio, inspired by the sudden death of Celtic captain Reggie Lewis two weeks ago today, seem as long ago as the last Celtic championship. Those heartfelt messages are slipping into the past. 
 They shouldn't. They won't. They can't.
Last Monday, when 15,000 mourners stood in stifling heat to pay their respects at Northeastern University and hundreds more lined the funeral route, the people had not been moved by dazzling commercials, catchy slogans or a calculated glibness magnified by the news media.
As the economics and values of the sports industry spiral out of control, all those people chose to endure the heat because they had been moved on some personal level. These were not consumers. These were admirers. A woman talked of the way Lewis had carried himself. A soon-to-be Northeastern graduate remembered a star athlete who always attended their class.
Richard Lapchick, director of the university's center for the study of sport in society, compared the crowd's remarkable diversity to two other memorable events: Nelson Mandela's appearance in Boston, when black and white children clung to tree branches along the banks of the Charles, and the funeral of Arthur Ashe.
"What athletes have to see," Lapchick said yesterday, "is there may be better athletes in the N.B.A. than Reggie Lewis, although he was a great player, but it was what he did in the community that took it to another level of appreciation."
As inspiring as the lines on St. Botolph Street became before the service, the scene of all those men and women and children standing in the sun was not as powerful as what Lapchick later saw on the ride to Forest Hills Cemetery, where Lewis was buried. He was sitting on a bus, part of a Presidential-type motorcade that passed slowly through Roxbury and Franklin Park, where seemingly permanent demographic lines had been drawn.
"There were Latinos in black neighborhoods," Lapchick said. "There were blacks in Latino neighborhoods. There were whites in both. I'm sure a lot of the white people in Roxbury that day had not walked in Roxbury before, or certainly not in many years.
"I was sitting next to a woman, and I was sure she thought I was being a snob because I was ignoring her. But I was uncontrollably crying from the time we pulled out."
It was not until much later that Lapchick was able to introduce himself. "I said, 'I hope you didn't think I was ignoring you.' She said she didn't notice because she was crying, too."
If every dried tear that has been created by this death could be matched by the type of quiet effort that characterized Lewis's 27 years, his legacy would have a value that transcends records and points and victories.
Reggie Lewis's life was about movement, subtle and effective. Just as the tribute of the people became powerful through its individuality, a living monument could be built through small but meaningful acts.
The Celtics may soon consider establishing the equivalent of baseball's Roberto Clemente Award for service to the community, an honor that could be extended to professional, college and high school players. But some of the most important work would come in response to the offer extended last Monday by Keith Motley, Northeastern's dean of student services.
"You can join Reggie's team," Motley said then. "You can volunteer at least 35 hours next year, so a young kid can see you in their life. And after you volunteer that time for Reggie's team, write down a note and say, 'I did it for Reggie.' "
The words are more important today than they were a week ago. They will be more important a week from now than they are today. So it goes. A response can be as simple or as extravagant as the inspiration. Learn C.P.R. Give blood. Search for the time to become a big brother or big sister. Find a way to cross those lines. Extend yourself back toward an old school -- not necessarily financially, but with advice and support for another generation.
And if the way you felt when you heard the news about Reggie Lewis moves you to some small effort, if you should write to say you were inspired by the bearing of someone you never knew, here is a good place to send that thought:
Ms. Donna Harris-Lewis
c/o The Reggie Lewis Foundation
P.O. Box 35
Dedham, Mass., 02027.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Reggie Lewis. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: 3d U.S. Aide Quits Over Bosnia

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Another State Department official has resigned in protest over the Clinton Administration's policy toward Bosnia and Herzegovina, officials have confirmed.
The resignation came from Jon Western, an analyst investigating reports of war crimes committed by Bosnian Serbs. Mr. Western said in a letter on Friday that he was quitting in disagreement with a policy that he said was not tough enough, officials said on Sunday. 
 His resignation, effective in two weeks, follows that last week by Marshall Freeman Harris, the chief specialist on Bosnia, and the resignation in August 1992 by George D. Kenney, who was the deputy chief of Yugoslav affairs.
A dozen State Department officials, including Mr. Harris but not Mr. Western, took their protest to Secretary of State Warren Christopher this year. Since then, several have sent memos to Mr. Christopher urging tougher action.
Mr. Western worked as an analyst in the Intelligence and Research Bureau, studying allegations of war crimes against the Serbs. He also dealt with Croatia and Slovenia, two other former Yugoslav republics.
Reached at his suburban Virginia home today, Mr. Western said he would not discuss his resignation until he leaves the Government payroll. He said he planned to pursue graduate studies at Columbia University.
"He quit to protest U.S. policy," a department official said of Mr. Western, insisting on anonymity.
United States policy on the Bosnian crisis has largely depended on economic penalties against the Bosnian Serbs' supporters in Belgrade, the capital of Serbia, although the Clinton Administration is trying to persuade its European allies to approve the use of force if the Serbian nationalists reject demands to end their siege of Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

HEADLINE: Iranian President Presenting a New Cabinet

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 9

 BODY:
President Hashemi Rafsanjani presented his Cabinet for parliamentary approval on Sunday, showing flexibility only on ministries that mainly regulate domestic affairs.
The Ministries of Foreign Affairs, Finance and Oil were kept intact, in what political analysts have interpreted as an effort to continue the less militant diplomatic and free-market economic policies of President Rafsanjani, who was re-elected to a four-year term in June. 
 The Ministries of Health, Higher Education, Housing, Defense, Commerce and Interior will be headed by new appointees, all with a university education and years of executive experience, leaving only two clerics in the 23-member Cabinet, in the Ministries of Information and Justice.
Conservatives, backed by the traditional merchant class, command a majority in Parliament and favor strict social al Islamic orthodoxy in a free market economic system. The are staunchly opposed to normalizing relations with the United States.
The state-run English-language Teheran Times reported that Parliament would begin debate on the Cabinet on Tuesday, with "two weeks to complete discussions and vote."

HEADLINE: Yes, There Is a Reason to Be in Somalia

BYLINE: By Madeleine K. Albright; Madeleine K. Albright is the United States permanent representative to the United Nations.

 BODY:
With the killing of four United States servicemen in Somalia on Sunday, more Americans may ask why we should care about the United Nations effort to restore that failed state.
President Clinton has said we have no choice but to protect our soldiers and make sure the mission succeeds. 
 Success is important not only for the Somalis -- 300,000 people died from war and famine before the United Nations approved intervention -- but also because anarchy may produce refugees, uncontrolled arms peddling and targets of opportunity for terrorists and their state sponsors. But peace cannot be made overnight. It will take time for people who have been shooting at each other to start trusting each other. Combatants must be disarmed, retrained and re-employed. Development aid must be delivered and efficiently used. Democratic institutions must be established. Those who disrupt the peace must be stopped.
Today, some criticize the U.N. mission in Somalia for supposedly departing from its humanitarian purpose by conducting military operations against the renegade warlord Mohammed Farah Aidid.
Legitimate concerns have been raised about the effect of these operations on relief efforts, about imperfect coordination among peacekeeping forces and about the possibility that Mr. Aidid will succeed in portraying himself as a victim rather than perpetrator of unwarranted violence.
By seeking to disarm Mr. Aidid, the U.N. is fulfilling its mandate in Somalia. The earlier, American-led intervention ordered by President George Bush was limited to humanitarian relief. But the currently applicable Security Council resolutions call explicitly for the disarming of Somali factions because humanitarian and political goals cannot be assured unless a secure environment is created.
The famine of 1991-92 did not result from the laws of nature but from the lawlessness of men like Mr. Aidid. Warlords used thugs who terrorized their fellow citizens, disrupting economic activity and forcing thousands from their homes. Mr. Aidid extorted money from relief workers trying to deliver food to starving children.
Unlike other Somali warlords, Mr. Aidid has obstructed U.N. efforts to end the violence and rebuild the country. He violated commitments made to the U.N. as soon he realized that he could not operate in a society governed by law. For him, piracy meant prosperity. His aim is to return Somalia to anarchy.
Mr. Aidid would like to drive the U.N. out by escalating the cost of staying. On June 5, his henchmen ambushed Pakistani peacekeepers, killing 24. Since then, his forces have killed four journalists, two Italian peacekeepers, at least six Somalis employed by the U.N. and now the four American soldiers.
The Security Council has responded by ordering the capture, detention and trial of Mr. Aidid. Failure to take action would have signaled to other clan leaders that the U.N. is not serious. Advocates of appeasement seem to forget that last year the U.N. tried to cooperate with Mr. Aidid and his counterparts. It did not succeed.
Yes, military operations can complicate and temporarily slow humanitarian efforts. But critics are wrong to suggest that relief and development work in Somalia has stopped. Except for some sections of Mogadishu, the distribution of goods continues. Children are no longer starving to death, thousands have been vaccinated and the flood of refugees has slowed to a trickle.
Work also continues on the political front. A dozen district councils have been established and two dozen more are on the way. Plans for re-establishing a national government are on track. Traditional Somali leaders and others with civilian leadership skills are starting to assert themselves.
It's no secret that U.N. command and control problems arose in Mogadishu during recent fighting, but those problems, primarily with the Italian forces, are being worked out. Such difficulties are symptomatic of the complexity of mounting international nation-building operations that include a military component. It is vital, however, that such problems be resolved in the future by policy makers in New York and not left to commanders in the field.
Normally, the U.N. is criticized for doing too little. In Somalia, it is being criticized for doing too much. Operations like the one under way in Somalia are sufficiently novel that problems and criticisms are inevitable.
The decision we must make is whether to pull up stakes and allow Somalia to fall back into the abyss or to stay the course and help lift the country and its people from the category of a failed state into that of an emerging democracy. For Somalia's sake, and ours, we must persevere.
