LENGTH: 1682 words

HEADLINE: Military Regimen for Teen-Age Dropouts

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NIANTIC, Conn., Aug. 6

 BODY:
It was 6:59 A.M. and Arthur Cole, 17 years old, was due in formation in front of his National Guard barracks at 0700 hours. The prospects were not good. Arthur couldn't find his regulation shoes (he was wearing sandals) and he couldn't find his Guard-issued pants (his bermudas were hanging so low his underwear was identifiable).
"Let's go!" barked his platoon leader, Vincent Lafontan, a former marine who was inspecting bunks. "Suck it up! Tighten up your racks!" 
 Arthur is a former drug dealer from New Haven, and he was not accustomed to his new hours. Until recently, he would go to sleep at 6 A.M.
In front of the barracks, at attention, stood 120 teen-agers from all over the state. They have one thing in common: all are high school dropouts who have signed up voluntarily for a new national program, financed by the Federal Government and run by state National Guard units on military bases, that is aimed at helping troubled civilian youths earn high school equivalency diplomas. If these dropouts succeed in the five-month program, they will get a $2,200 stipend from the Government as a reward.
 
Still a Few Rough Spots
 The young people have been told the program is of great importance to President Clinton, and on this, the official opening day for the first of 10 National Guard Youth Corps camps throughout America, they have been warned, "Look sharp: the President's men are coming to see us."
Of course, like any new marriage, this wedding of the military and these dropouts still have a few rough spots. "Oh man, we got to wear these hats?" said Arthur, finally reaching his platoon. He did 10 pushups for being late, then fell into formation.
Arthur is an orphan, and was eager to enroll here because he hopes to earn a degree and find a decent job so he can get his younger brother, Tai, out of foster care.
What is beginning in Connecticut may soon become widespread because its appeal cuts across the political spectrum while addressing two of the nation's most pressing domestic questions: What to do with the military in the post-cold-war era? And how to expand social service programs in a time of budget constraints?
The National Guard's Youth Corps Challenge program, which will operate in 10 states this year, is a case of guns as well as butter. It relies heavily on current and former military personnel to tutor, counsel and discipline the dropouts in preparation for their taking the test for a general equivalency diploma, or G.E.D. This will not be an easy task. The average reading level of the Connecticut group is the sixth grade; 74 percent did not complete their junior year of high school; nearly a third were expelled from school.
Among the program's supporters are Gov. Jim Edgar of Illinois, a Republican, who will open the project in that state on Sept. 1 at a recently closed military base, and Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, a Democrat who is chairman of the Armed Services Committee. In Connecticut, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., an independent, has enthusiastically endorsed the program.
It also signals the new President's priorities. Congress approved the program in 1992, but President George Bush did not propose any financing for it; Mr. Clinton signed a $44 million appropriation on June 11. Besides Connecticut and Illinois, youth corps camps will train a total of 2,500 dropouts the first year in Arizona, Arkansas, Georgia, Louisiana, Maryland, New York (Camp Smith in Peekskill), Oklahoma and West Virginia.
 
Reminiscent of New Deal

To supporters, the new youth corps is reminiscent of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal and the belief that government can be used creatively to put people back to work. Clinton aides say that while the program predates the President's national service program, it fits well with that strategy. And it has caught the public's imagination. In Illinois there were 1,000 calls to the National Guard's toll-free number in the program's first 24 hours.
The 10 pilot projects are being watched closely by military officials worried about budget cuts and ways to ease the transition of soldiers into a civilian economy.
"To put it undelicately, this is a way for the National Guard to create a role for itself in the 21st century," said Beth Solomon, an aide to Senator Nunn. "It's a post-cold-war response."
The corps is the brainchild of Dan Donohue, the National Guard public relations director in Washington. Press releases emphasize "a peacetime domestic return to the American people on their investment in defense."
 
Many Applicants for Posts
 About half of the Connecticut staff is on active National Guard duty or has served in the military. Mr. Lafontan, the platoon leader, whose job is a mix of counselor and barracks supervisor, spent four years in the Marines and is now a civilian with two bachelor's degrees. Tim Coon, who like all the classroom teachers is state certified, has taught in public high schools and is a lieutenant in the Army Reserve.
There are seven hours of classes a day, covering the academic areas tested for the equivalency diploma, as well as drug and alcohol counseling and job-readiness skills.
Financing is generous -- more typical of a military than a social welfare program -- and there were large numbers of applicants for the 46 staff jobs here. Mr. Lafontan and Mr. Coon will each be paid more than $30,000 a year. The spending per student is $18,000.
"Anybody who's anybody wanted this job," says Sgt. Daniel Henderson, a platoon leader who was the state's National Guard Soldier of the Year in 1991.
The dropouts are outfitted from head (red baseball caps) to toe (Adidas sneakers), get a $15 weekly allowance, books and briefcases. While they march in cadence and usually call superiors "sir," they would never be mistaken for regular military.
Lamonte Brockenberry's corn rows pop out of from the sides of his cap; Ramonita Arroyo's ponytail hangs out of a hole in the back of hers. Donald Bunn, a squad leader who barks orders at his fellow dropouts, wears a hoop earring in his left ear and a red stud in his right. On his way to class, Bunn, as he is known to his friends, spotted a Guard officer and shouted, "How you doing, colonel?"
To qualify for the stipend, the dropouts need to do more than simply get the G.E.D., which has come under criticism nationally as not carrying the weight of a high school diploma. They must also find a job or enroll in a college or training course.
If they are too young to take the G.E.D., they can earn the stipend by returning to high school. (There is no military obligation for participants.) After completing the five-month session, they will be assigned a Guard member from their community, who will serve as their mentor for a year.
Applicants are supposed to be free of drugs and not currently involved with the criminal justice system (including not being on probation or parole), although many have had such problems in their pasts. Bunn says he has been "in and out of jail for stealing a car and violating probation." Mr. Lamonte sold drugs and "carried a weapon." Arthur says he stopped dealing because he was scared. "I was shot at and pistol-whipped," he said.
In this first Connecticut group, 58 percent are black or Hispanic teen-agers, 20 percent are female and 44 percent are from the state's three largest cities, Hartford, New Haven and Bridgeport.
While today was the ceremonial opening day, the young people have been here two weeks getting oriented. The challenge at hand is clear. Of 172 accepted, 50 have already left. Most could not take the paramilitary atmosphere and asked to go home; about a dozen were expelled. Earlier this week, four were arrested at the camp by the state police for third-degree assault, accused of beating up a student in the barracks.
And yet, to spend time with the three-quarters who remain is to find considerable hope. They are motivated. They have not been ordered here by a judge or a parold board; they have all decided, for their own reasons, it is time to change.
"I ain't going nowhere without that degree," said Damon Mesite, who wears his ponytail tucked under his hat. "I've been screwing up for two years, fighting and stuff, and I decided I might as well do it now, make my family happy."
Bunn packed his duffel bag and nearly quit on Thursday, but changed his mind after a talk with Mr. Lafontan. "He told me I'm not really a quitter," Bunn said. "They chose me to be a squad leader, and I'm very good in my position."
Mr. Lafontan said, "Slowly but surely, Bunn's being fixed."
Mr. Coon, the teacher, has been surprised that some of the toughest dropouts have privately asked for extra tutoring.
Slowly, they seem to be taking to the discipline. Asked if he enjoyed the program, Rasper Pugh replied, "It's bearable."
 
Some Ready for College
 Mr. Lafontan said he has students reading on the fourth-grade level and others, like Malik Lyons, who is ready for college. "I look at Malik," he said. "To me it's a mystery why he dropped out of school."
Asked why by a reporter, Malik said he quit in the ninth grade just because he did not find school interesting. But later, during a class exercise in which they were supposed to make a list of surprises in their lives, Malik wrote: "Father in and out of jail. Mother had to raise six kids herself. When my mother was at work, my brother brought home troublemakers who hung around the house all day."
"This is the first time I really read anything in two years," Malik said.
Richie DeClet asked Mr. Coon if they could stand at attention when the dignitaries arrived, and the teacher approved.
"You're cool, sir," said Lauryn Marotto.
Arthur ran back to the barracks to find his Guard pants and Adidas sneakers, and returned looking smart and chewing on his toothbrush.
When "the President's men" arrived -- the highest-ranking among them was Deborah R. Lee, Assistant Secretary of Defense -- Mr. Coon shouted, "Squad, ATTENTION!" and they leaped up.
"Uncover!" Rasper barked, and they smartly removed their red baseball caps.

HEADLINE: Europe's Worry: A Generation of Leaders Not Up to the Task?

SERIES: A Continent Adrift -- Fourth of five articles.

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Confronted by political scandal, recession and the erosion of familiar comforts, Western Europeans have come to sense that the very people they chose to solve their problems have been in power too long to steer a dejected Continent through the shifting shoals that mark the close of the 20th century.
This year alone, France's Socialists have been ignominiously ousted from power, their counterparts in Spain have lost absolute control of Parliament for the first time in a decade, and an entire political elite has been decapitated by scandal in Italy. In Britain, Prime Minister John Major holds the dubious distinction of becoming his country's least-loved Prime Minister since polling began. And in Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's popularity is at an all-time low. 
 To judge from conversations in London, Paris, Bonn and Rome, a malaise has settled into a region unnerved by joblessness, a decline in social services and the apparent failure of a tired old guard of politicians to produce a vision of the future.
In Bonn, "there is real mental exhaustion" among leaders, said a senior official of the Free Democrats, the junior party in Germany's governing coalition, speaking on condition of anonymity. "Crisis management pervades all the issues, and improvisation only fuels the discontent."
 
Age of Lowered Expectations
 "For the first time, parents are saying that things are going to be worse for their children," said Martine Aubry, a Socialist who served as Labor Minister in France's previous Government. "Before, they saw society as constantly improving."
The bleakness is compounded by predictions in all four capitals of a surge in nationalism that has mutated into violence against foreigners, adoption of stricter immigration policies in France and in Germany and a rise in support for the chauvinistic Northern League in Italy.
Even as Europe's old guard struggles in vain to freshen its image -- Italy's Christian Democrats want to change their name to the Popular Party, and governing parties routinely recruit people in their '40s as junior ministers -- a new generation of leaders seems far from asserting itself.
In Britain, there's "a feeling that the Government can't cope and no other set of politicians could cope either," said Lord Rees-Mogg, former editor of The Times and a Conservative member of the House of Lords. He said that Britons' attitude toward their politicians "is one of psychological, almost clinical depression."
Since the fall of Communism changed the Continent's perception of itself as an increasingly cohesive and ever more prosperous bloc confronting other great blocs -- the Soviet Union, the United States and Asia -- the old calculations, and the politicians who based their careers on them, are faltering.
 
Politicians in 'Time Warp'
 "Europe's politicians are generally stuck in a time warp," said Anatole Kaletsky, an economic commentator in London. "They are preoccupied with the problems of the 70's and 80's, but the challenges ahead are going to be quite different from the past 20 years."
Some common strands are evident in the challenges facing Europe's political systems. Of all the nations of Western Europe, Germany and Italy seem to have been most unsettled by the fall of Communism. After the euphoria of German reunification faded, politicians in Bonn were confronted with the unexpectedly high costs of integrating the Communist east and the affluent west; with no East bloc specter to warn against, Rome's leaders have largely been stripped of their role as a cold-war bastion against Western Europe's strongest Communist Party.
Politicians are also drained by the battle with high unemployment -- 2.95 million are out of work in Britain and more than 3 million in France and in Spain -- at a time when global competition threatens to consign the welfare state to the history books.
In Spain, France and Italy, Socialist parties have all come under varying degrees of pressure. Corruption charges have brought the virtual demise of Italy's Socialists this year, and France's Socialists were trounced in parliamentary elections in March.
 
Right-Wing Ascendancy
 "The Socialist alternative has disappeared," said Tony Benn, a Labor Party lawmaker in London, reflecting an impression across the Continent that tough capitalist policies have won the day.
Even center-right parties are in retreat in Germany, Britain and Italy. And the ideological void is such that "the variables between left and right are much narrower," said Alain Duhamel, a conservative commentator in Paris.
In countries whose politics were long viewed as a contest between moderate left and right, commentators now tend to focus on the danger of allowing any party to govern too long. In a recent commentary on Conservative Party financing, a British Catholic weekly in London remarked that "being in power too long" produces a certain "whiff" of corruption. Nowhere is that more evident than in Italy, where a vast corruption scandal seems inextricable from the struggle between old and new.
 
Italy
Scandal Brings Calls for Renewal
 Possibly the most quoted comment about the nation's politics came from the Sicilian writer Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusa, who posited that, in Italy, everything has to change so that nothing will change.
That strain of cynicism suffuses what is without doubt Western Europe's most dramatic break with a discredited past. A corruption scandal that began in February 1992 has wrapped its tentacles around the entire business and political elite that has run the country since World War II.
Overwhelmed by evidence of graft, the Socialist Party of former Prime Minister Bettino Craxi has shriveled. The most senior echelons of the Christian Democrats are decimated. Giulio Andreotti, seven times prime minister and a symbol of postwar Italy, faces charges of corruption and association with the Mafia -- allegations that he denies -- and most of his most senior lieutenants are under investigation for fiscal wrongdoing.
So pervasive was the system of kickbacks that a former Health Minister has been accused of taking bribes from a private television station in return for publicly financed advertising on the dangers of AIDS. The biggest private and state companies have been implicated in the network of bribery.
As the standing of the old guard has plummeted, recent municipal elections have shown a rise in support for forces previously barred from the corridors of power -- the insurgent Northern League, particularly in Italy's wealthy northern region, and the former Communists, now known as the Democratic Party of the Left, in Italy's center.
The shift in voting patterns has begun to set off alarms -- in part because of the Northern League's embrace of xenophobia and in part because the decline of established parties has removed Italy's political center of gravity.
 
A Growing Divisiveness
 "The will to change is accompanied by a new form of intolerance and bitter local patriotism, which are dangerous because they tend to divide rather than unify," said Dacia Maraini, a prominent Florentine novelist and poet.
Warning that racist appeals could splinter this culturally diverse nation, one politician, Giuseppe Ayala, is seeking to promote a new centrist alliance to challenge the Northern League's leader, Umberto Bossi. "The greater the number of votes obtained by the League, the greater the threat to national unity," Mr. Ayala said.
There is little doubt that the people want profound political change. A referendum last April showed Italians overwhelmingly in favor of political reform. Municipal elections in June left the Socialists in complete collapse, and the once-powerful Christian Democrats with only a rump of support in their traditional southern domain.
While Italy has a new Government led by Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, a former central bank governor who has no political affiliation, the prospects for change are uncertain. The Italian Parliament, elected in April 1992, before the vast scope of Government corruption had become known, still reflects the old order. Dominated by a coalition led by Christian Democrats, it has little interest in calling new elections.
Only huge public pressure for change led the lawmakers to enact reforms last week changing the old system of pure proportional representation in Parliament, a system that had produced 52 unstable coalition governments since World War II.
The new rules, under which most lawmakers will be elected by direct ballot, are expected to reduce the number of parties in Parliament and make for more durable governments. But both Parliament and the Government seem reluctant to call a new vote before next spring.
Many political analysts say a parliamentary election next spring would probably help the Northern League translate its powerful support in the north into a strong parliamentary bloc in Rome. But it is unclear what else could emerge as politicians jostle to re-invent themselves. The only issue uniting new forces seems to be a rejection of the past.
"We must say it frankly: We have produced a political class which we can only be ashamed of," Mr. Ayala said recently.
 
Germany
Indecision At Europe's Heart
 In a recent opinion survey in Germany, 72 percent of the respondents thought it "scandalous" that former Labor Minister Gunther Krause used public money to pay his domestic help and cover the costs of a household move.
The amount involved, and the nature of the crime, may seem minuscule in comparison with what passes for corruption in Italy. Nonetheless, Mr. Krause resigned in May, just as Economics Minister Jurgen Mollemann had stepped down in January after acknowledging that he had written letters promoting a relative's business interests -- a common practice among German politicians.
In July, Interior Minister Rudolf Seiters resigned unexpectedly after a man described as a member of the Red Army Faction guerrilla group was killed at extremely close range in a shootout with an anti-terrorist squad in the eastern town of Bad Kleinen.
The impression created by the scandals, the resignations and the Government's frequent indecisiveness is that, after almost 12 years of rule sustained by the prosperity of the 1980's, the resolve of the Christian Democrats and their coalition partners, the Free Democrats, has slackened just as the country is facing up to the staggering financial costs of reunification.
"The population has the feeling that the basic problems are not being solved," said Meinhard Miegel, head of an independent research institute in Bonn.
In Germany, the challenges are immense.
 
Challenge of Absorbing East
 The cost of absorbing the wrecked economy of the former East Germany since October 1990 has been far greater than politicians or many ordinary Germans had expected. Millions of refugees from Eastern Europe poured into the country until tighter restrictions were imposed on July 1 eliminating the automatic right to political asylum. Inflation, unemployment and the unabated right-wing violence against foreigners haunt a Government that seems fearful of acknowledging the very weight of the problems.
"The violence happens, they get together to deal with it and then put it on the back burner," said an official of the Free Democratic Party, speaking on condition of anonymity. He lamented the absence of long-term strategies to cope with what many see as an alarming rise in neo-Nazism.
With elections looming next year -- and talk of a subsequent grand coalition of Christian Democrats, Free Democrats and Social Democrats -- opinion surveys show Mr. Kohl trailing behind his most likely challenger, the newly chosen leader of the Social Democrats, Rudolf Scharping.
Perhaps tellingly, neither man drew overwhelming support in the survey. The poll by the Allensbach Institute showed Mr. Scharping with 32 percent of the vote and Mr. Kohl with 24 percent. Equally worrisome, Government officials said, are predictions that far fewer Germans will bother to go to the polls next time than in previous elections.
Across Europe, people "are not particularly interested in selecting the most able people to be in charge of politics," Mr. Miegel said. Developments in France and Britain are putting that assertion to the test.
 
Britain
Tory Leader Sinks In the Polls

Whenever Prime Minister John Major peers across the Channel these days, it must be with a sense of envy. Even though the British leader says he has brought down inflation and sees the beginning of the end to his country's recession, poll experts estimate that only 19 percent of the British are satisfied with his performance as leader.
In Paris, by contrast, Edouard Balladur, another conservative Prime Minister facing similar economic and fiscal problems, is enjoying such overwhelming support after three months in office that one commentator calls him "the Balladur phenomenon."
Yet Mr. Major's problems are also strikingly different from those faced by Mr. Balladur. Personally he cannot shake off the impression that he is a "wimp," as he puts it. His Conservative Party has been in office for 14 years, a period overwhelmingly dominated by the tenure of his strong-willed predecessor, Margaret Thatcher. Even some of the party's senior members believe a spell in opposition would help the Conservatives regenerate.
In a reflection of its deep unpopularity, the Conservatives lost an important by-election in Christchurch, a middle-class stronghold for the party in southern England for the last 83 years. Many attributed the Conservatives' loss to Mr. Major's low standing and to what The Economist of London recently described as "the whiff of a party that is arrogant, out of touch and bloated by power."
Mr. Major's own party is riven with dissent over the Government's policy on fuller integration of the European Community, so much so that Mr. Major resorted to a high-stakes gamble by calling a confidence vote in Parliament -- where his party has a narrow, 17-seat majority -- to complete the debate on ratifying the Maastricht Treaty on European union.
"We've been through a difficult period," he acknowledged. "There have been difficult decisions that have had to be taken. Some difficult decisions lie ahead. I'm not going to be deflected from those difficult decisions."
Mr. Major's Government can also point to some economic progress, including signals that Britain's recession may be ending. The inflation rate is down to 2.8 percent, and unemployment has been gradually declining. But none of that seems to shake off the feeling that if general elections were held right now, the Conservatives would lose badly.
Deepening the mood of malaise, some commentators say, is a sense that the Labor Party opposition under John Smith has not seized the opportunity to present itself as a credible alternative the way the conservatives did in France in the parliamentary elections last spring.
Part of the problem is generational. Mr. Major himself is only 50, but to many Britons, his Government represents the tail end of 14 years of Conservative rule that set off the boom of the 1980's only to tumble into recession when the bubble of privatization burst.
Mr. Major, said Dottie Riley, a literary agent, "just does not inspire confidence."
Across the Channel, Mr. Balladur, 64, is doing the opposite, though no one is certain how long his appeal will last.
 
France
Voters in Search Of New Leaders
 Mr. Balladur offers the French a "reassuring," a patrician image of competence, says the journalist Pierre Hasky, even though his Government has been buffeted by Europe's currency turmoil and strong downward pressure on the French franc.
"He made fewer promises and gave no false hopes, so people take him seriously," said Mr. Duhamel, the conservative commentator. Such an approach caught the national mood at a time when, according to Ms. Aubry, the former Socialist Cabinet member, "the French don't want to be told stories anymore."
Mr. Duhamel remarked that Mr. Balladur was "politically still very young," having served in a top government post only once, as Finance Minister from 1986 to 1988 -- the last time parliamentary elections forced President Francois Mitterrand to "cohabit" with a conservative government.
None of that obscures the dilemma that Mr. Balladur runs the Government in loose consultation with Mr. Mitterrand, a 76-year-old Socialist who is as much a symbol of political longevity in France as Chancellor Kohl is in Germany or as Giulio Andreotti once seemed to be in Italy.
French parliamentary and presidential elections run on different schedules; the next presidential vote is set for 1995. That vote looms over French politics and reinforces the impression that the French, too, are living through an uneasy transition period.
 
Missing: The 60's Generation
 A slightly "younger" generation -- those who were high-school or college students during the street protests of 1968 -- has not made a significant mark, though Socialist governments have sought to appoint members of that age group to Cabinet posts. Some activists who were briefly viewed as potential challengers to the old elite, like Brice Lalonde, a former student leader of who now directs a political alliance of environmentalist groups, fared badly in the parliamentary elections.
Once again, the politicians mentioned as likely candidates for the 1995 presidential elections have a familiar ring.
In theory, Mr. Balladur became Prime Minister so that the leader of his neo-Gaullist party, former Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, could remain above the fray of day-to-day politics yet capitalize on any Government successes in making his presidential bid in 1995. The only problem with that calculation is that, after four months in office, Mr. Balladur is now running ahead of both Mr. Chirac and his conservative coalition partner, former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, in opinion surveys.
None of the poll ratings mask what is viewed in Britain, France, Germany and Italy as a fundamental gulf between people and politicians.
What the politicians offer, in varying degrees and with varying effectiveness, is management; what they do not offer is the broader vision that inspired the French under de Gaulle or the Germans under Adenauer. "French politics were too ideological, and now it's gone too far the other way; there's no ideology, no ideas," Ms. Aubry said.
After decades of certainty, even complacency, about its security and prosperity, it is difficult to tell what force could energize Western Europe again.
"The most important problem," said Mr. Miegel, the analyst in Bonn, "is a problem afflicting all our societies: All these states got too wealthy. They are very cushioned, very comfortable -- and generally have a lack of stimulus."
NEXT: Europe's unemployed but hopeful youths.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 11, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1326 words

HEADLINE: After Her Pivotal 'Yes' on Budget, Now the Fallout

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WYNDMOOR, Pa., Aug. 10

 BODY:
A vision of the future stared back at Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky from a table at Nick's Pizzeria the other day, and it did not appear altogether happy.
This was her first foray back home since her name became more than a mouthful Thursday night in Washington. She had changed her mind at the last minute and cast the vote that insured passage of President Clinton's economic package in the House, a stunning move for a freshman Democrat from a district in which Republicans outnumber Democrats almost 2 to 1. 
 Jay Moore, a 47-year-old veteran of the Vietnam War, not much of a fan of politicians to begin with, was slightly bemused to find himself in the same restaurant with the woman who represents him in Congress from the suburbs northwest of Philadelphia in Montgomery County.
 
Visions of Deceit
 "They're all deceitful," he said before Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky made her way across the room to shake hands and try to make sense of her date with history.
It was quite a story. Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky had widely proclaimed her opposition to the bill for not going far enough to cut spending and deal with the costs of social programs, and that is what she told anyone who asked: Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader who inquired the day before; party whips, as they leaned on House members all day Thursday; even Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger C. Altman, who called about an hour before the vote.
But as she had in voting for the House version of the bill in May, she waited until the end of the balloting in case her vote was crucial. This is not uncommon for undecided members or those from difficult districts. Routinely, party leaders ask them to delay voting, as they had of Pat Williams of Montana, Ray Thornton of Arkansas and David Minge of Minnesota. If their votes are then not needed, they are free to vote as they choose. If the votes are necessary, they are asked to consider the party first.
This time the party needed her, and as a result, she voted with the President -- but not before extracting a fig leaf or two to respond to critics for her 11th-hour reversal. At the least, she won assurance from the President of a conference in her district on the deficit in which Mr. Clinton and several Cabinet members would participate.
 
'Window of Opportunity'
 It was a political gamble -- she readily acknowledged that -- but also a chance to make a difference by adding a new voice to the mix. "A window of opportunity," she called it today during a visit to the Green Acres senior center here, where she found people more supportive than those at Nick's in Norristown. "I wasn't going to do it at 217. I wasn't going to do it at 219. Only at 218, or I was voting against it."
Predictably, in a region where people debate politics as passionately as the Phillies and the Eagles, reaction was swift and intense. In Montgomery County and beyond, Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky has been judged a patriotic heroine by some and a traitor by others.
But beyond labels and name-calling, she faces the larger question of political survival. Last year, she became the first Democrat to represent the district since 1916, defeating her Republican opponent, Jon D. Fox, by only 1,373 of 257,510 votes cast in a campaign in which she accused him of reversing his position on abortion rights. Yet she acknowledged that any chance for re-election might hinge less on sentiments of the moment than the willingness of angry constituents like Mr. Moore and other diners at Nick's to accept her explanation of why she changed her mind.
"Look, I have a terrible time not telling the truth," Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky said. "My staying there is not the issue. I don't possess that job. That job does not possess me. I'm not there to be popular. I'm there to do what's right. I will explain it; I just hope I have the time."
What is right, she has insisted since the vote, was seizing a chance to push a discussion of automatic-spending programs into the forefront of national debate, to make Social Security, welfare, Medicare and Medicaid more fair and efficient and a smaller piece of the budget. Entitlement programs, as they are known, now account for more than a third of the Federal budget.
To her detractors, voting for a bill to raise taxes was egregious enough. Changing her mind made it worse. Never mind the conference on entitlements, as many of them have said. She knows they are the ones she needs to persuade, but for now, it is unclear whether they can be or, because of their anger, want to be.
"I don't believe in people with two faces," Tom Borai, 59, a worker at a local tool company, said while Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky was eating lunch in another room at Nick's. "She stated she was not for it. Then after 15 minutes with Mr. Clinton she changed her mind. I do know that bothered a lot of people in this county, and I think it will hurt her in the next election."
 
Prospects for Re-election
 Sitting nearby, Ralph Herge, a 37-year-old landscaper who said he had voted for Mr. Fox, called her "a sellout" for relinquishing her position. Yet he applauded her explanation and predicted that alone might soften the damage in a re-election campaign.
"What she did, by telling us exactly what happened, seems to make sense," Mr. Herge said. "It may not hurt her if more of Clinton's stuff works. But if it all falls apart, then it will."
Mr. Moore, who was reared in South, said he had voted for Mr. Clinton only as a matter of loyalty to a fellow Southerner. But he said he had not cast a vote in the House race because of a general distrust of politicians who might raise taxes. That was why he continued to express skepticism, even after receiving assurances from Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky that she would help him if he ran into problems collecting veteran's benefits.
"She said she didn't think it was a good piece of legislation but she still voted for it," he said. "If it wasn't good, why did she vote for it? She said if she didn't, we'd still be in gridlock. But it doesn't make sense to me."
Still, Mr. Moore was satisfied enough with her sincerity to be "a little open-minded" about voting for her next year.
Not unexpectedly, Republican leaders in the district have vilified Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky, gleefully predicting that she had severely damaged her chances for re-election next year. Christopher J. Bravacos, executive director of the Republican State Committee, assessing the effect of Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky's vote, said, "It's premature to say it's suicide, but maybe Dr. Kevorkian is lurking." He was referring to Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the retired pathologists who has assisted people in committing suicide.
Mr. Fox, her vanquished opponent and one of three Montgomery County Commissioners, said: "She pretends to be a Republican and a reformer and a fiscal conservative. But the facts are, she's a typical tax-and-spend Democrat. She has lied to the taxpayer. Now, she's an insider career politician."
 
Democrats Assess Damage
 While Democrats have rallied to her side, applauding her courage, they at least acknowledge difficulties ahead.
"I'm sure her vote has done some damage," said Colleen S. Alexander, co-chairwoman of the county Democratic committee. "I don't think a lot of people really understand the difficulties involved with cutting entitlements. But by the time this all plays out, I think she'll be able to educate people, and maybe turn some of them around."
Edith Greenberg, the 70-year-old wife of Phil Greenberg, a resident of Green Acres, is among those already convinced.
"I'm scared and frightened," she told Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky. "I could live another 14 years, but how will I live? I might have to get a job. But it took a lot of courage for you to change your mind. Even if it costs me more, you were honest enough to say the plan was no good. Why do we want that? But things have to change, and I appreciate what you're doing."

She explained her decision to Jay Moore, a Vietnam War veteran, at a local pizzeria. (Bill Cramer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: JAPANESE PREMIER TACKLES U.S. TIES

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Japan's new Prime Minister used his first news conference today to emphasize his eagerness to improve strained relations and reduce Japan's huge trade surplus with the United States, but he rejected most of the tools President Clinton has insisted on using to do the job.
While the Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, said Japan would open its markets and reform its political structure, he suggested that Tokyo would not open its rice market, would not cut taxes to stimulate the anemic economy and would refuse to set targets for Japanese imports or for reductions in the trade surplus. The Clinton Administration has pressed for such targets. 
 In the hourlong news conference today, Mr. Hosokawa indicated that he was committed to change, but on a narrow range of issues, focused principally on eliminating corruption in Japan's electoral system.
In one respect, Mr. Hosokawa broke with tradition by plainly saying that he personally believed that Japan should admit its role in World War II. "I myself believe it was a war of aggression, a war that was wrong," he said.
 
Seeks Smoother Relations
 Mr. Hosokawa said that relations with the United States "should remain the core of Japanese foreign policy."
"As in the past, even more than in the past, we should try to operate U.S.-Japan relations more smoothly than before," he said.
But he said that he was generally happy to defer to longstanding policies on a range of other issues, including relations with Washington.
President Clinton has demanded measurable improvements in the trade relationship with Japan. He has sought to pry open formally closed markets, like that for rice, to remove barriers that discriminate against foreign companies and products, to encourage Tokyo to stimulate the faltering Japanese economy with a tax cut and to rely on numerical targets for increasing imports and narrowing the surplus.
 
Plans to Meet Clinton
 Mr. Hosokawa said he hopes to meet President Clinton soon, either in September at the United Nations or in November at a meeting of Asian nations in Seattle. He also said that he hopes to alter the Japanese economy so that its impetus comes more from domestic consumption than exports, and to deregulate the economy.
But overall, his ideas do not appear to be any more in harmony with Washington's than those of his predecessor, Kiichi Miyazawa.
"Currently, because of this very difficult economic situation, we don't think the climate lends itself to tax reduction," Mr. Hosokawa said, adding that numerical targets on trade questions are "somewhat inappropriate."
"Free trade and free-market economic principles are the basis on which we would like to correct the imbalance," Mr. Hosokawa said.
 
Moves Closer to Bureaucrats
 His new positions hewed much closer to the policies that have been articulated by Japan's powerful bureaucrats than his campaign pledges, a sign that for all his reformist credentials Mr. Hosokawa will be pragmatic.
Mr. Hosokawa took office on Monday as the head of a seven-party coalition that wrested power from the Liberal Democratic Party for the first time in 38 years.
But the Cabinet he announced on Monday is dominated by conservative former Liberal Democrats, and his comments today seemed to show that the bureaucracy of Japan's Government may prove more of an obstacle than Mr. Hosokawa had anticipated.
The best example of this shift was his attitude toward those suffering from what is called Minamata disease. Hundreds of people from Mr. Hosokawa's native prefecture of Kumamoto in southwest Japan have suffered painful long-term disorders and birth defects because of industrial poisoning of the waters at Minamata Bay.
The chemical company involved has agreed to provide compensation to those afflicted, but the central Government has refused to approve the deal because it would be tantamount to admitting Government responsibility for not acting more swiftly to prevent the poisonings. As Governor of Kumamoto, Mr. Hosokawa fought the Government. He said today, however, that he would accept the old policy.
"My feeling is unchanged, but my position has changed," he said. "The fact is that I am placed in a rather difficult position."

HEADLINE: Rich Aren't Rushing to Avoid New Taxes (Yet)

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
The Dreyfus Corporation, one of the largest distributors of tax-free mutual funds, ran full page ads on Monday, the first business day after the Clinton tax bill passed, offering a toll-free telephone number to discuss shifting investments into tax-exempt funds. Only 50 people responded.
Dreyfus is just one of the brokerage firms, mutual fund companies, financial advisers and private banks that have jumped on the new tax law as an excuse to sell products to their customers. 
 But so far, few of the high-income investors, whose Federal tax rate has been increased to as much as 39.6 percent, have done much to seek out tax breaks -- either in the months leading up to the tax bill, or after its passage by Congress -- according to executives who deal with wealthy clients.
"There has not been a lot of reaction to the tax bill thus far among our clients," said David W. Parsons, the head of financial planning at Chase Manhattan Bank's private banking unit. "Next April 15, people will realize they should have done something to cut their tax bills, then people will take a year to figure out what to do. The market has been changing so much, the individuals we talk to have been somewhat paralyzed."
This paralysis may confound those economists who predicted a rush into tax-sheltered investments. In fact, some have argued that raising tax rates on the rich actually would not bring in more dollars to lower the deficit. The view from those who sell investment products is that the Internal Revenue Service will have a bountiful harvest next year.
Tax rates for families with incomes of more than $140,000 a year, who file jointly, have been raised from 31 percent to 36 percent. Those with incomes of more than $250,000 a year will pay a top rate of 39.6 percent. The Clinton Administration says these changes will bring in $115 billion over five years.
But even if few people have made changes in anticipation of the tax increase, executives do expect an eventual shift of funds into more tax-sheltered investments. "History says changes in tax law change investor behavior," said Gerald H. Tankersley, the head of asset management at Prudential Securities.
One reason that there is no immediate rush into tax shelters is that there are not as many. The most lucrative tax dodges of the past, such as certain limited partnerships, were eliminated by the tax act of 1986 and not restored this year.
"This bill is purely a tax rate increase," said Paul Gordon, the head of tax planning at U.S. Trust Company, a New York bank that serves the wealthy. "It will just cost more, and the clients are not happy."
Investors would likely move more money into tax-deferred retirement accounts, such as 401(k) plans offered by employers, investment executives said. And the tax law, which does not raise rates on capital gains, creates a small incentive to prefer stocks that will appreciate in value over those that pay dividends.
The most widespread tax-sheltered investments are municipal bonds, which are free of Federal income taxes and usually the taxes of the state and local governments that issue them. Yet even leading municipal bond dealers, like Dreyfus, report limited impact from the tax bill.
That is not to say that no one has reacted to the prospect of higher taxes. At the retail brokerage unit of Lehman Brothers, 6 percent of the money that clients invested in taxable bonds has been shifted into tax-free bonds over the last year. And at Dreyfus, sales of tax-free funds are up 18 percent over last year.
 
 
Small Shifts
 But these shifts are small and come at a time when interest in all investments is increasing. "There has been such a great influx of cash into the markets recently," said Robert Silver, the head of the brokerage offices at Paine Webber.
Most of this money, however, has been from investors discouraged by low interest paid on bank accounts. "To be sure, we are the beneficiaries as people respond to the tax bill, but it's hard to tell how much," he said.
Indeed, many investors who would have benefited from tax shelters under the old law have not taken advantage of them. At Fidelity Investments, the country's largest mutual fund distributor, only 25 percent of the money invested in its money market funds, by upper-bracket investors, is in tax-free versions. "Most of the people who would be better off in a tax-free fund, oddly enough are not," said Neal Litvack, the head of marketing at Fidelity.
"Tax-free investing is complicated," he said. "It's hard for someone to see a yield of 4 percent on a tax-free fund and see that is the equivalent of 7 percent on a taxable fund." In fact, many stockbrokers and other financial advisers still recommend that their clients use taxable investments, Mr. Litvack said. "Those are the ones they understand and are comfortable with," he said.
 
 
Limited Effect
 On the other hand, for sophisticated investors, the new law should have limited effect, precisely because if they were optimizing their tax positions, they would already have had most of their bond investments in the tax-free variety. "Even before the passage of the tax bill, we were advising clients to look at tax-free bonds; changing the rate from 31 to 39.6 percent hasn't changed our outlook much," said Mr. Silver of Paine Webber.
Moreover, tax-free bonds are an alternative to taxable bonds for investors who need a steady income with less risk to their principal, such as retired people. They are not a substitute for stocks, which offer potential for more capital growth with more risk. Most brokerage firms continue to recommend that the bulk of their clients' portfolios be invested in stocks.
The tax rate on capital gains, which are earned from the appreciation of the price of an investment, remains at 28 percent, significantly lower than the highest rate on ordinary income. Thus investors have an additional incentive to buy stocks with long-term growth potential. Yet even this fact has not changed the amount of a portfolio most firms allocate to the stock market.
"It's a big tax increase, but not so big that we would change what we are doing," said Mr. Parsons of Chase. "One thing we stress is that clients need to be tax-wise, never tax-driven."
 
 
'Pretty Bearish'
 Perhaps the greatest effect of the tax bill has been to contribute to the uncertainty of many investors. "People are pretty bearish about the economic outlook," said Mr. Litvack.
He said that Fidelity's consumer sentiment study shows that investors are in the most pessimistic mood since last October. They expect taxes to keep going up, interest rates to rise and the stock market to fall, he said. As a result, Fidelity, like other investment firms, has noticed that more investors are becoming more conservative.

HEADLINE: Productivity Of Workers Falls Sharply

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
After rising steadily for almost two years, the productivity of American workers dropped between January and June, the Labor Department said today in a report that could raise worries about layoffs or renewed inflationary pressures.
The department reported that average nonfarm output per hour of work sank at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.5 percent from April to June, the second quarterly drop this year and the biggest decline in more than four years. From January through March productivity dropped at a rate of 1.6 percent. 
 Economists say that, in the long run, the paychecks of workers and the profits of companies depend heavily on their efficiency. Because wages continued to rise while productivity was falling during the second quarter, the labor cost for each unit of nonfarm business production leaped by 4.2 percent. Rising production costs force businesses to raise prices or risk watching their profits dwindle.
"The unit labor cost increase for the business sector is not favorable from the point of view of inflation pressures," said Edwin R. Dean, associate commissioner for productivity and technology in the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
 
Warning About Layoffs
 Michael R. Darby, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs in the Bush Administration, warned that companies might lay off workers if economic output continued its slow pace, saying, "You may see decreases in the hourly work force to match the output, rather than the other way around."
But some Wall Street analysts played down the significance of today's figures, saying some erosion in productivity was inevitable when employment was rising and economic output was increasing very slowly. Productivity, calculated by dividing output by employment, grew very quickly last year when the economy was expanding and few companies were adding workers.
"We've had two quarters in a row of sharp contractions of productivity," said Stephen S. Roach, a principal and senior economist at Morgan Stanley. "On the surface it seems disturbing, but you have to put it in the context of coming after seven consecutive quarters of steadily rising productivity."
Mr. Roach said that while companies might not lay off the extra workers they hired this spring, today's figures suggested they might not be hiring many more.
 
Several Estimates Used
 Some economists contend that quarterly productivity figures are unreliable because they are calculated from several estimates, including how many hours the average employee works each week. "The quarter-to-quarter numbers basically don't mean anything," said Barry P. Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
Today's announcement did not appear to affect financial markets, said Marilyn C. Schaja, a money market economist at Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette. "It's one of those sort of orphan numbers that doesn't get much attention," she said.
The decline in overall productivity came despite a 5 percent gain in productivity for manufacturing companies, which make up a fifth of the economy. Wall Street analysts attributed the overall decline to a steep plunge in services industry productivity, for which the Bureau of Labor Statistics releases no figures because of doubts about the data's reliability.
The restaurant, health care and temporary-services industries hired many workers in the first half of the year and these industries tend to have low, slow-growing productivity, said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company.
 
Lower Productivity Increases
 Annual increases in American productivity averaged about 1 percent during the 1970's and 80's, much less than the 2.5 percent increases in preceding decades. Many economists attribute some of the nation's lackluster economic performance since the Johnson Administration to slow productivity growth.
Second-quarter productivity was up only seven-tenths of 1 percent from a year ago. Pointing to strong growth in manufacturing productivity, Mr. Steinberg at Merrill Lynch said the Labor Department figures might have understated recent productivity growth.
Productivity could average 1.5 to 2 percent in the 1990's, he said.
But Mr. Bosworth said he distrusted the estimates of high manufacturing productivity because manufacturers were contracting out for many services, which made it seem as though they were producing more goods with fewer workers.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Outlines Plan to Stir Economy

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Looking toward the future by casting back to the revitalization of New York City's economy in the early 1980's, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor, yesterday released an extensive plan for the city's economy that stressed cutting the city work force by more than 16 percent, tax relief and an end to some fines that he said were driving small businesses from the city.
His proposals, delivered in a morning speech at the Sheraton New York before an audience of about 80 supporters and dismissed by the Mayor's office by dusk as "political plagiarism," were essentially a refrain from speeches he has given in recent months. 
 Though bulwarked by specifics, his plan -- billed as a major speech on the city's economics -- essentially offered no new ideas, economists familiar with the city budget said. It did, however, rework some proposals that have been kicked around at City Hall for years.
Among Mr. Giuliani's specific proposals were these:
*A 10 percent reduction in the size of the Mayor's staff.
*Reducing the size of city government to 1983 levels by cutting about 35,000 city jobs, of a total of 215,000, through attrition and early-retirement packages.
*A phase-out of the unincorporated business tax and the commercial rent tax and at least a 5 percent reduction in the hotel occupancy tax.
*An end to duplications of services provided by the city and the state in such agencies as the Civil Service Commission, the Department of Mental Health and the Department of Consumer Affairs.
 
Prediction or Quota?
 As Mr. Giuliani discussed sanitation and parking fines that have angered small shopkeepers, his handpicked audience roared with laughter when he pointed them to page 198 of the present city budget and a line item that predicts 8 million parking tickets in the current fiscal year as opposed to 7 million last year.
"How does he know that 1 million more people are going to be parking illegally next year?" Mr. Giuliani asked. "In fact, we all know that 8 million figure becomes a quota."
Many of Mr. Giuliani's proposals have long been backed by the Citizens Budget Commission and were quickly embraced by the private watchdog group yesterday. "I thought it was very good," Raymond D. Horton, the group's president said yesterday after reviewing a copy of Mr. Giuliani's plan. "These are the ideas and notions that the Citizens Budget Commission has really been emphasizing in recent years."
Yet critics of the plan countered that the proposals remained both vague and general. Hearing details of the speech while at a news conference in Elmhurst, Queens, Mayor David N. Dinkins criticized the Giuliani proposal as "generalities" and added: "That won't do. Not for a plan. You can't run a city like that."
The Mayor's office later took Mr. Giuliani to task for suggesting across-the-board cuts, an approach they said Mr. Giuliani himself called a "simplistic solution" in 1989. The Mayor's staff also attacked the proposal to reduce taxes, saying that such cuts would result in a $2 billion loss in revenue, "enough to pay for the police, juvenile justice and probation departments, all five district attorneys and the special narcotics prosecutor."
Mitchell L. Moss, the director of New York University's Urban Research Center and an informal adviser to the Dinkins campaign, said Mr. Giuliani's remarks called for easy fixes that would not work when put into practice. "Most of these things are the most popular and easy forms of rhetoric in New York," he said. "Everyone speaks about cuts, but no one says where they are."
 
'The Real Question'
 Felix G. Rohatyn, a leading Wall Street financier who is supporting Mr. Dinkins, also disagreed with generalized cuts. "Attrition is a very random and very ineffective way of doing anything," he said. "The real question is how do you have the cuts and have the unions go along."
In his first major policy speech of the campaign, Mr. Giuliani told supporters that it was time for "some straight talk," then assailed the Dinkins administration for losing jobs and weakening commerce. "Once, New York City was the undisputed business capital of the nation and the world," Mr. Giuliani said. "The sound of our commerce circled the globe." Now, he said, "what you hear is an ominous silence."
He criticized the Dinkins administration for backing a "taxing program without parallel," noting that city taxes had increased $2.5 billion in the last 13 months. The answer, he said, "is management -- and management starts with the Mayor."
His own plans for management would include trimming the processing time for arrests to several hours from 10 to 15 hours, using more civilian employees in the Police Department to free officers for police work, consolidating a number of city offices and contracting with private companies to provide city services wherever they can be accomplished more effectively outside the government's purview.
 
'Appeals to Us'
 "My broad reaction was good," said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry. "The only way you solve the problems of this city is through partnerships. And another thing that appeals to us is privatization."
Many who reviewed the speech said, however, that some of Mr. Giuliani's proposals have also appeared on the Mayor's agenda only to be turned back in Albany or dropped because of difficulties in pushing them past strong unions.
Privatization, for example, has worked effectively in Philadelphia, Phoenix and Chicago, Mr. Shelp said, and has drawn support from both sides of the New York City Mayor's race. "They have at least both now said they approve," he said.
Marc V. Shaw, the director of finance for the City Council, also responded positively, but cautioned: "It sounds good in theory, but the devil is in the details. Some of these things are a lot easier said than done."
 
Some Exemptions
 One of Mr. Giuliani's most detailed suggestions is sizing down city government from its current payroll of about 215,000 workers to a level of 180,000 within four years. That reduction, he said, would result in savings of $1.5 billion to $1.8 billion annually in the fourth year of the next mayoral term, generating savings that could be used in trimming taxes.
Mr. Giuliani said he would exempt some city agencies, including those involved with "children and public safety and parks and cultural affairs."
Giuliani proposals that won broad support yesterday included those encouraging government and business links, privatizing some public services and establishing enterprise zones.
"I think he has laid out the smart way to do it," said Mr. Horton of the Citizens Budget Commission. "I don't remember anything this specific from him when he ran in 1989. These things he is saying now, well, they are not new ideas. But we have been doing a kind of rough and dirty analysis here and, basically, what he says can work."

HEADLINE: In Summer Doldrums, Stocks Are Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday, taking their cue from a bond market now working its way through the Government's quarterly auction of new debt securities.
Ricky Harrington, senior vice president and technical analyst at Interstate/Johnson Lane of Charlotte, N.C., described yesterday's market performance as "typical summer doldrums that are measured not in days, but months, showing no progress in terms of the Dow." 
 "We have stayed at about 3,550 for more than a month," he said, "wandering within a narrow, 50-point trading range. On the positive side of the market you have low interest rates, especially in long-term rates, now at 16-year lows. Individually, stocks adjusted during earnings season, and now that that has passed, the market is without stimuli to break out of this range. Any move now above 3,600 on the Dow will be temporary."
 
Gains and Declines Close
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,572.73, down 3.35 points from a high set on Monday. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 255.5 million, up from 232.3 million in the previous session, as gaining and losing issues were close, with 1,002 up and 949 down.
Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks lost 1.27 points to 449.45, while the Big Board composite index slipped 0.45 point to 249.63. The Nasdaq composite dropped 1.41 points to 717.08, but the American Stock Exchange composite was 0.39 point higher, at 439.19.
Robert C. Walberg, equity analyst at MMS International, said "there was a lack of follow-through from Monday, but that's in keeping with the pattern set by the market over the past few months."
"The holding pattern is in keeping with what is going on in the bond market," he said.
Investors' attention was mainly focused yesterday on the first leg of the Treasury's quarterly borrowing, consisting of $16.25 billion in three-year notes. Today, the Treasury auctions 10-year notes. "Yields under 6.50 percent are hard to ignore," a trader remarked.
RJR Nabisco said that it was again increasing the size of its planned preferred-stock offering, which is expected today. The size of the deal is $1 billion, up from $750 million and doubling the originally planned offering of $500 million. It calls for the sale of 40 million shares of cumulative preferred stock at $25 a share, and is expected to have a dividend yield of 9.25 percent.
Another area of interest was retail stocks. Traders said that flood damage in the Midwest may increase sales. With a great deal to be replaced, they expect some investors to be looking at discount retailers.
 
Drug Stocks Down
 An article in The Wall Street Journal yesterday on drug stocks said the latest blow to the group was the provision in the budget bill that would reduce tax benefits for manufacturers from operations in Puerto Rico. Merck was off 5/8, to 30; Bristol-Myers Squibb was down 3/8, to 51 3/8; Abbott Labs down 1/2, to 23 3/4, and Johnson & Johnson dropped 1/4, to 36 1/2.
Scitex Corporation, a computer-software company, fell 1 5/8, to 25 3/8, after posting lower earnings -- 52 cents a share, compared with 75 cents for the second quarter -- as a revenue drop in Europe cut the revenue increase for the entire company to 9 percent.
Analysts' recommendations were behind some of the selling. Mirage Resorts dropped 2 1/4, to 47 3/4, when Oppenheimer reduced its rating of the stock to market performer, from buy. Comair Holdings, parent company of Comair Inc., a regional airline, fell as much as 1 1/4 before closing 5/8 lower, at 31, after Alex. Brown lowered its rating to buy from a strong buy, based on price.
But Alex. Brown raised its rating on Aldila Inc., a maker of high-quality golf club shafts, to buy from neutral, and the stock rose 3, to 32 1/4.

HEADLINE: New Chief at Empire Blue Cross Moving Quickly to Reduce Costs

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH

 BODY:
Moving swiftly to reverse years of financial decline, the new head of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans to cut costs by 10 percent, largely by reducing its staff through attrition, early retirement and layoffs, a company spokesman said yesterday.
The personnel cuts, as well as possible reductions in the use of rented office space, are intended to save the financially troubled insurer $50 million to $55 million a year, said Howard Rubenstein, a spokesman for Empire, which lost a total of $250 million in 1991 and 1992. 
 The cuts are part of a broad reorganization plan developed by Philip Briggs, who took over as chairman and temporary chief executive in July after months of tumult in Empire's upper management. Mr. Briggs has said that he found the company to be poorly managed and desperately in need of streamlining.
 
A Change in Focus
 The cuts signal a significant break with the company's longtime contention that its problems were not of its own making and could only be solved by help from the state, like rate increases and favorable legislation.
In addition to a financial and management retrenchment, Mr. Briggs plans to shift the company's focus toward "managed care" networks, which limit customers' choices but offer medical care at lower costs. More than 97 percent of Empire's 7.6 million customers now have traditional insurance policies that offer them a virtually unlimited choice of doctors, hospitals and other medical services.
The personnel cuts will come at a particularly difficult time for the company as it begins the transition to managed-care plans, including its health maintenance organization, Healthnet, and its newer and more loosely organized network of doctors and medical providers called Empire Blue Choice. Empire's attempts at managed care have been met with complaints of poor service.
Company officials have not determined how many jobs will be eliminated under the reduction plan, Mr. Rubenstein said. But calculated at an average of $35,000 in annual salary and benefits, the number could be as high as 1,500.
Empire, the state's largest health insurer, has 9,300 employees in locations from New York City to Albany and an annual operating budget of $520 million.
Meanwhile, Albert A. Cardone, who was ousted in May from his $600,000-a-year job as chairman and chief executive, has applied for unemployment compensation. His blustery style and fondness for expensive perquisites made him a lightning rod for criticism from customers whose rates have soared in recent years. Board members voted to dismiss Mr. Cardone after learning that he had kept important information about the company from them and that he was deeply disliked by top managers.
Mr. Cardone, who has homes in New Canaan, Conn., and Florida, filed his unemployment claim in Westchester County last week. He is eligible to receive the New York State maximum of $300 a week for 26 weeks, a total of $7,800.
Empire will not oppose Mr. Cardone's application, Mr. Rubenstein said. When an employee is dismissed, an employer may object under certain circumstances to the payment of benefits.
The matter of Mr. Cardone's pension and severance benefits from Empire, which could be as high as $2 million, has not been resolved. Mr. Cardone's lawyer, Steven Thal, said yesterday that he has had no discussions with Empire about the matter in recent weeks.
 
Devastating Losses
 Mr. Briggs's broad retrenchment of the company follows years of devastating losses and rate increases that averaged as much as 25 percent and forced thousands of New Yorkers to abandon their policies and go without medical insurance. Empire ended 1992 with only $40 million in reserve, an amount far below the $500 million considered safe by state insurance regulators.
Some of the personnel cutbacks will be made this year, but most will come in 1994, Mr. Rubenstein said. According to company projections, Empire will bring its reserves up to more than $100 million by the end of 1993. The $50 million in savings next year would shore up the reserves even further but would still leave the reserves far below the $500 million required by state law.
Mr. Rubenstein said the personnel cuts would be made judiciously. "They're going to make an effort not to impact service," he said. "They will be very carefully done."
 
Service Problems
 Empire officials have acknowledged that if they are to succeed at managed care, they must solve the service problems and complaints that have dogged Healthnet for years.
Mr. Briggs, a retired official of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, said shortly after taking over Empire that he believed the company was poorly organized and inefficient. He said he planned to cut overhead costs, reorganize the outmoded management structure and provide better service to customers.
He also said Empire would no longer seek special help from the state.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices of Pork Bellies Slide; Coffee and Oil Also Tumble

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Prices of pork bellies plunged yesterday for the sixth consecutive session as receding floodwaters in the Midwest encouraged farmers to dump hogs on the market.
Pork bellies hit a five-month high last week as hog sales were restricted, partly because of floods in the Midwest. Since Friday, producers have sold more hogs, of heavier weight than anticipated, traders said. 
 "The floods disrupted marketings and caused plants to close last month, so sales were light, but everyone is back in business now," said Charlie Andrews, president of Andrews &Associates, a brokerage firm based in Chicago.
Live hogs for October delivery closed 77 cents lower at $44.82 per hundredweight, after falling the $1.50 limit yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork bellies for February delivery closed $1.80 lower at $47.07 per hundredweight, after losing the $2 daily limit yesterday.
On other commodity markets, losses in coffee and oil helped drive the Commodity Research Bureau index to a three-week low. The index tracks the performance of 21 commodities and is a widely used gauge for inflation.
Coffee futures tumbled as concerns about a freeze and crop damage in Brazil subsided. September coffee closed 1.80 cents lower at 74.95 cents a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
Oil prices slipped as an OPEC committee recommended that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries maintain its current production levels. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for September delivery closed 3 cents lower at $17.52 a barrel. Heating oil was 0.20 cent lower at 50.01 cents a gallon and unleaded gasoline finished 0.41 cent lower at 53.63 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies on Possibility Of Rate Cuts by Europeans

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar rallied against most European currencies yesterday amid speculation that high unemployment would force several European Community nations to cut interest rates to stimulate economic growth.
In New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.7170 German marks late yesterday, up from 1.6970 marks Monday. 
 Gold prices fell as the strength in the dollar eased concerns about inflation. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery lost $2.40 an ounce, to $380.90. December gold, the most actively traded contract, also fell $2.40 an ounce, to $384.40.
Lower interest rates abroad make dollar-denominated deposits more attractive, bolstering demand for dollars.
Although it fell against the dollar, the German mark gained against weaker European currencies as investors bet that Germany probably would not cut rates as quickly as its neighbors.
 
German Rate Unchanged
 Yesterday, Germany held its key money-market rate unchanged at 6.80 percent, indicating that it might not soon lower its closely watched discount rate. Germany's discount rate stands at 6.75 percent, compared with 3 percent in the United States.
On Monday, the Bank of France trimmed a short-term rate to 9.75 percent, from 10 percent.
"People think there are big interest-rate cuts yet to come in Europe, and the dollar is gaining," said Ezra Zask, president of Ezra Zask Associates Inc., a currency-trading fund in Falls Village, Conn., that has $90 million under management. Mr. Zask said his fund had sold the Danish krone and other weak European currencies, betting that interest rates in those countries would fall.
The dollar slipped slightly against the Japanese yen, falling to 104.70 yen, from 104.91 on Monday. Several traders said they expected the dollar to remain below 105 yen in coming weeks as Japanese exporters continued to sell the dollar when it rose.
Japanese exporters must buy yen with the dollars they earn abroad to return revenue to Japan.
The British pound tumbled against the dollar after the Bank of England, in a quarterly report, said British inflation remained within the bank's targets. That prompted speculation that Britain would also lower rates. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.4675, its lowest level since June, down from $1.4915 on Monday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Bond Continues to Gain

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Treasury market appeared to take a breather yesterday as the Government began its quarterly auction of notes and bonds.
The yield on the current 7.125 percent 30-year bond due in February 2023 managed to slip to a new 16-year low of 6.44 percent, from 6.46 percent Monday, as the bond continued to rally on special factors, like the sharp reduction in their regular issuance by the Treasury. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, was up 10/32 of a point. 
 But in the rest of the market, from Treasury bills to 10-year notes, yields were mostly higher. The yield on the 6.25 percent 10-year note due in 2003 was up to 5.8 percent, from 5.79 percent, as the price dropped 2/32 .
Traders said the bidding at the auction of $16.7 billion of three-year notes was better than average and even a little stronger than was expected just before the bidding deadline of 1 P.M.
 
 
'Defensive' Action
 Dan Callahan, a managing director at Paine Webber Securities, said it appeared that some investors were buying the three-year note as a "defensive" action, while they waited to see how the other two auctions this week would turn out. He said investors and traders also wanted to get a better idea of what impact the new deficit reduction package, which President Clinton signed yesterday, would have on the economy.
He said that if the tax increases in the deficit reduction plan did slow the economy and kept inflation in check, the Federal Reserve was unlikely to raise interest rates soon. This makes buying 3-year notes, he said, less risky than the 10-year notes and 30-year bonds that were scheduled to be auctioned today and tomorrow, respectively, at a time when their prices are very high and yields very low. The three-year note, he said "is a good place to hide."
The average yield on the three-year notes wound up at 4.49 percent, up from the 4.27 percent average in the May auction but below the 4.73 percent in February and below the 4.69 percent in August a year ago. In late trading after the auction, the yield on the new note, with a coupon of 4.375 percent, was 4.47 percent, another sign of good demand.
The 4.49 percent yield was just above the yield of 4.48 percent the new note was trading at in the pre-auction, or when-issued market, before the trading deadline.
But the auction did not give a lift to the rest of the market. That is partly because the market had rallied on Monday ahead of the three auctions this week.
In addition, it often is hard to gauge what the impact on the market will be until more than one auction is completed.
 
 
Concern Over High Prices
 Going into this auction, although there appeared to be demand, some traders were still worried about buying these new Treasury notes and, especially, the 30-year bond, with the prices at or near recent highs and yields at such low levels.
Howard Steiner, senior vice president at Mitsubishi Securities, said he was worried about buying at the auction at a high price when the market had already had a good rally. "If the market runs up and I pay a lot at the auction," he said, "I have an expensive security after a long run-up." He said he would rather wait for the market to pull back a bit so he could get Treasury notes or bonds at a lower price. That way, he said, he would "have a cheap security in a bull market."
If many dealers find themselves with too many highly priced new issues this week, that could lead to a selloff after the auctions as they try to sell some of the new supply into the secondary market. Mr. Callahan of Paine Webber said such problems could develop with the 10-year note.
For the 30-year bond, it is hard to tell how the auction will go because it seems to be trading in a zone of its own, moving up in price and down in yield far ahead of the rest of the market.
 
 
Fewer 30-Year Bonds
 One big force behind this rally is the fact that the Treasury is cutting the total of new 30-year bonds issued every year and moving from four auctions a year to two. After the auction tomorrow, the next 30-year bond sale will not be until February. And over the next 12 months, the Treasury will sell only about $22 billion of bonds instead of the pace of about $37 billion a year that it had been selling.
The decision to reduce the sale of 30-year bonds grew out of the Clinton Administration's deficit-reduction effort. The reduction in the sale of 30-year bonds is part of a major shift from longer-term borrowing to maturities of three years and under, for which interest rates are lower.
The Administration had originally hoped to cut borrowing costs by $16.4 billion over five years. Its revised estimate is for a savings of $10.8 billion. But the Congressional Budget Office estimates that the savings will be less, totaling just $6.4 billion.
In when-issued or pre-auction trading yesterday, the yield on the 10-year note to be sold today was 5.77 percent, up slightly from 5.76 percent on Monday. The yield on the 30-year bond was 6.37 percent, down from 6.38 percent.
 
Corporate Bonds
 Citicorp sold $350 million of 12-year subordinated notes yesterday as it continued its program of switching lower interest rate debt for older higher interest rate debt that it can now redeem.
So far this year, Citicorp has sold $1.5 billion of new debt to pay off these older issues. The yield on the issue sold yesterday was 6.75 percent, 98 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the yield on the new 10-year Treasury note in the when-issued market. The lead underwriter was Goldman, Sachs & Company.

HEADLINE: 2.8% Growth Predicted for '94

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
A newsletter, Blue Chip Economic Indicators, reported today that the consensus of 51 economists is for 2.8 percent economic growth next year.
The findings of its survey, taken this month, compared with an annualized growth rate of 3.1 percent projected for the current July-September quarter and 3.3 percent for the final three months of the year. 
 The newsletter's editor, Robert J. Eggert, said many of the economists did not think that the full effects of the higher gasoline and income taxes in a law signed today by President Clinton would be felt until 1994, permitting faster growth now.
Thirty-six of the 51 analysts questioned lowered their economic forecast for all of 1993 since the previous poll, taken in July. The latest forecast projected economic growth of 2.5 percent, down one-tenth of a percentage point from July.
