HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Outlook Is Uncertain on Revenue Sharing by Owners

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Richard Ravitch, the architect of baseball's plan to increase revenue sharing among the 28 clubs, can count on a certain number of votes for adoption of some sort of plan. But it's the votes he isn't certain of that will determine the outcome of the owners' meeting in Kohler, Wis., that begins today.
The critical meeting will continue tomorrow and perhaps Friday as the owners try to reach agreement on a plan that would take effect only if the players then agreed to a salary cap. Because the players are opposed to a cap, the owners may be meeting in vain, even if they adopt a plan. 
 Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, presumably will open the meeting with debate on a proposal he recently sent to the clubs. Although details of the plan have been kept secret under a confidentiality agreement enforced by a $100,000 fine, some management people have talked about the general outline.
 
Looking to a Formula
 The plan, they have said, centers on a formula linking total player payroll to total local revenue. The percentage of local revenue each club would be required to put into the payroll pool would be determined by the amount of money needed to fund the payroll after national revenue is used and by the amount of total local revenue. Other factors apparently could add to or subtract from the percentage.
"The discussion," one management person said, "will be about whether each team puts in a different percentage or the same percentage. Will there be a limit on the high end as to how much each team has to put in, or no limit no matter how high the revenues go? That's what the big debate will be."
Listening closely to the debate will be Jerry McMorris, chairman of the Colorado Rockies, an expansion team that has become an instant large-revenue club, surpassing the economic position of many established franchises. Holding one of the uncertain votes, McMorris epitomized the dilemma facing the wealthier clubs.
"I'm open-minded," McMorris said by telephone from Denver. "Our club understands the need for this industry to get back on its feet, so we're very concerned with the long-term economic future of baseball. All that being said, we have a responsibility to the shareholders and the fans of the Colorado Rockies, so we have to look out for our own interest also. We paid what we thought was a large fee to get into this, and here we are one year later with what could be a tremendous economic change in baseball."
 
Going Beyond $95 Million?
 The Rockies and the Florida Marlins each paid $95 million for membership in the National League. The group that made the winning bid for the Baltimore Orioles in last week's court auction is paying $173 million to get into baseball. They are among the clubs that would not be thrilled to have to toss millions more per year into the revenue-sharing pot.
Before the Oriole auction, bidders for the team were told to figure that they would have to pay about $8.7 million from their local revenue if a plan was adopted. Larry Lucchino, the Orioles' president, will represent the club at the Kohler meeting, and even if he were to abstain, given the circumstances, his move would be tantamount to a negative vote because 21 votes are needed to approve a plan.
When Ravitch embarked more than a year ago on the task of persuading the owners that a new revenue-sharing plan was needed, the economic differences were viewed as large-market clubs versus small-market clubs. Now, though, the labels more realistically are high-revenue clubs and low-revenue clubs.
Denver isn't considered a large market, but the Rockies do have large revenues from their attendance, which will exceed 4 million this season. The Orioles are in a similar position because of the fans who have flocked to Camden Yards. Other clubs classified in the high-revenue group are the two New York teams, the two Chicago teams, Los Angeles, Toronto, Atlanta, Florida and Boston. To get a plan adopted, Ravitch almost certainly will need 4 votes from that group of 11 clubs.
On the other hand, if the plan is so watered down to induce the high-revenue clubs to vote for it, might some low-revenue clubs rebel, feeling that in this case something isn't necessarily better than nothing? Or would they take what they could get?
 
Selig Won't Speculate
 Going into the meetings, no one was predicting the outcome.
"I don't want to speculate," said Bud Selig of the low-revenue Milwaukee Brewers, the man running the major leagues in the absence of a commissioner. "There's been a lot of work done, a lot of thought given to all this, an enormous amount of time spent by lot of people. For an industry that never shared financial information, we've really done a lot of that. So all the necessary steps have been taken. What will happen, I don't know."
Ravitch, one club executive said, is not going into the meeting thinking his proposal is the one the clubs should accept. "He acknowledges this is a starting point," the executive said. "Clearly, there's a lot of work to be done."

HEADLINE: TRACK AND FIELD;
Young Hurdler Hustling, Both On and Off Track

 BODY:
Wanted: Part-time job for recent graduate of Georgia Tech. Qualifications: Degree in mechanical engineering, with a specialty in biomedical technology. Also able to run on the heels of the world-record holder Kevin Young in the 400-meter hurdles.
Derrick Adkins is not your typical 23-year-old unemployed college graduate. He is ranked second in the United States in the 400-meter hurdles, behind Young, the Olympic champion. Like Young, Adkins is on his way to the world championships, which get under way Saturday in Stuttgart, Germany, and is aiming for the 1996 Olympics. 
 In the meantime, he's looking for part-time work in his field, concerned about preparing for his future after track. He's even considering medical or graduate school, so he wants to work in engineering while he trains.
It's a lot to handle, but Adkins seems capable.
 
Born to Run
 He grew up in West Hempstead, L.I., and his running career took off at Malverne High. His father, Earl, a hurdler at Morgan State in the 1960's, coached his son, who showed early glimpses of extraordinary talent and then grew into a 6-foot-3-inch frame.
"His build is exceptional -- high cut legs, very long for his height," said Grover Hinsdale, the track coach atGeorgia Tech. "He is a very graceful runner with exceptional leg speed, very fluid, fast turnover. You're either born with that or you're not."
Hinsdale recruited Adkins, who was seeking a school with a solid academic reputation and a warmer training climate. Adkins has grown to love Atlanta and has made it his permanent home.
 
Winning Notice
 Adkins showed improvement each year at Georgia Tech, finishing in the top six in the N.C.A.A. championships his freshman and sophomore years. In his junior year -- 1991 -- he finished second, but 1992 was a disaster. He was on his way to victory but fell after the seventh hurdle. He got up and kept running, but finished eighth.
That's the way Adkins is -- he gets up and keeps running. He has not been touted as the next Edwin Moses. He doesn't hold any national records. Gold medals at the 1991 and 1993 World University Games are a few of his highlights. He ran the third leg in a 45.0 split for Tech's national champion 1,600-meter relay at the 1992 N.C.A.A. championships. Running on a sprained ankle, he failed to qualify for the 1992 Olympics, placing fourth.
But the competition still keeps a lookout for him.
 
Is His Best Yet to Come?
 Samuel Matete of Zambia, a former world champion, has long been his nemesis. Matete, who ran for Auburn, has the third fastest time in the world, behind Young and Moses, and beat Adkins at the 1991 N.C.A.A. championships. Adkins recently beat Matete at the World University Games in Buffalo -- the only time he has beaten him. Although Adkins had an unspectacular time of 49.35, he was running in a strong wind. "I would like to run 48 flat or 47.9, and if I can do that I'd like to in Stuttgart," Adkins said. "It's going to take a perfect race, perfect conditions."
Young's world record is 46.78. Adkins's best time is 48.69, accomplished in June in the United States championships in Eugene, Ore., where he finished second to Young (47.69) and qualified for the world championships.
"I'm satisfied right now with the way I'm running," Adkins said. "Kevin Young is on another level. He wins races by pretty good margins."
Hinsdale thinks Adkins will command respect.
"I'm not saying he can beat Young, but he is getting stronger," Hinsdale said. "He has a chance to be right in the mix of it. The timing should be perfect for him to peak."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Derrick Adkins, the second-ranked 400-meter hurdler in the United States, has shown considerable resiliency. (Rick Stewart/Allsport)

HEADLINE: A Brighter Day for Legal Services

 BODY:
Lawyer-bashing is an old story for the underpaid, overworked attorneys who represent the poor in more than 300 poverty law offices under the federally funded Legal Services Corporation. For eight years the Reagan Administration pummeled the program with abuse and tried to kill it, and for four years the Bush Administration neglected it. Now President Clinton has wisely chosen a new board of directors committed to breathing renewed life into the program.
Some of the 11 new directors are veterans of the bashings Ronald Reagan administered as a Governor and President. Others are bar leaders who lobbied to gain the organized bar's strong endorsement for the program. Still others are allies of President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton, who headed the board during the Carter Administration. All deserve swift confirmation when the Senate returns next month. 
 The hostility in high places stemmed from the audacity of Legal Services attorneys in challenging important officials and powerful business and agricultural interests. Earlier legal aid societies had been content to bail out debtors and postpone foreclosure dates. The idea of suing governors for failing to obey laws designed to help the poor, or growers for ignoring health standards on their farms, alarmed the comfortable in many states.
When President Nixon attacked the legal services program begun under the war on poverty, Congress created the corporation with Presidentially appointed directors subject to Senate confirmation. But Presidents Reagan and Bush packed the board with enemies of the program by issuing recess appointments that bypassed the confirmation process in every year but 1985.
Once confirmed, the new board will face formidable problems. Its budget of less than $400 million has lagged behind inflation and the increasing population of poor people. The directors must also seek renewed authorization from Congress, which since 1980 has withheld a new charter, partly because the program's leaders so often sought to undermine and even abolish it.
Those are impressive problems but they'll be easier to confront when the board of directors is in the hands of supporters of the program and its lawyers rather than the bashers of bygone years.

HEADLINE: Region Stands To Gain Little In New Budget

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
New Jersey, New York and Connecticut will be among the states that benefit least, while paying the most, under the economic plan that President Clinton signed into law today.
Economists, regional planners and executives have spent the last weeks poring over details of the Clinton budget and breaking the numbers down to suit their particular needs. Their calculations show that the three states rank low on nearly every measurement of new spending intended to boost the economy. 
 At the same time, because Connecticut, New Jersey and New York have many wealthy residents, they will pay a disproportionately high share of the income-tax increases.
 
Figuring Pluses and Minuses
 As home to some of the nation's major businesses and a huge restaurant industry, the region also is much more apt to feel a greater impact than other regions from the less publicized parts of the Federal budget, from the thousands of businesses that face a percentage point increase in the corporate income-tax rate to a sizable cut in business entertainment and meal deductions.
But if the plan works and the economy does revive, they say, it would push the Northeast ahead of other regions because of the large real-estate market here and a surge in the stock and bond markets.
"In the short term we may suffer more of an economic drag in the Northeast," said H. Claude Shostal, president of the New York City-based Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit organization that promotes planning for a 31-county area in the three states. "But long term, I think the plan is tremendously important to the economic health of the country and the region."
"The thing that we don't know is exactly how the pluses and the minuses offset each other," said Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist for Shawmut National Corporation, a bank holding company with its corporate operations divided between Hartford and Boston.
A central element in President Clinton's budget is an economic growth plan that the White House has said would add 8.3 million jobs nationwide over the next four years and funnel billions of investment dollars into states for schools, worker training, housing, bridges and roads, health care and research, tax credits for the working poor and tax incentives for business investment.
The Clinton plan calls for Connecticut to receive $1.44 billion, generating an estimated 39,320 new jobs, New Jersey to receive $3.55 billion, generating 94,614 new jobs and New York to receive $8.64 billion, generating 173,337 new jobs. Economists cautioned that the job estimates, while sounding precise, should be viewed as rough guides subject to political influence.
Kerry Sutten, a regional economist with the Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition, said, under the plan, the region ranks near the bottom in per capita Federal investments and in projected job growth.
 
Projected Job Gains
 "Some have argued that the Clinton plan is ignoring the Northeast and the Midwest," Mr. Sutten said. "The per capita investments going to the Northeast and Midwest are much lower than the South and the West."
Mr. Sutten said the increased spending per capita would place New York 41st on the list at $47.71 a person, New Jersey 45th with $45.55 a person and Connecticut at 49th with 43.86 a person. Rhode Island was 50th with $43.58. Mr. Sutten said he has not figured out how the White House arrived at the investment levels.
Projected job gains for the three states range from 2.60 percent for New Jersey, to 2.41 percent for Connecticut and 2.20 percent for New York, each of them below the 3.16 percent job gain projected for the Northeast as a whole and well behind the 9.26 percent job growth for the South or 11.22 percent gain for the West. The Midwest fared worst among the regions at 2.77 percent projected job gain.
The new Federal budget also sets a 36 percent tax rate for couples with taxable incomes of $140,000 and individuals at $115,000, an increase from 31 percent that is most likely to have a more concentrated effect on New York, New Jersey and Connecticut than any other region.
"We are going to pay more than our fair share largely because residents of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut per capita are among the wealthier people in the nation," said Mr. Shostal, the Regional Plan Association executive. "We have got more people who make more money."
Mr. Perna, the chief economist for the Shawmut banking group, said the higher tax rates for the region's wealthier residents was less of a problem than other parts of the budget.
"We tend to focus too much on income and not on wealth," he said. "At the same time that people are mentally recalling their income taxes, the worth of all their stocks and property is going up, too."
Experts said that other budget changes will deliver an above average blow to the region, especially in Manhattan, because of its concentration of restaurants.
The Clinton plan reduces to 50 percent from 85 percent the amount of business entertainment and meal deductions a company may deduct from its taxes.
 
Impact of Gas Tax
 "This is going to further destroy our tavern and restaurant business in New York City, and as a matter of fact, all across the nation," said Tom Slattery, a former president of United Registered and Liquor Dealers Inc., an association of 500 Manhattan restaurants and bars.
Mr. Slattery said that almost a third of the association's membership went out of business between 1987 and 1991 after President Reagan in 1987 cut the deduction for business entertainment and meal deductions to 85 percent from 100 percent.
"When that happened, companies started feeding their employees in-house and they encouraged their sales force to dine in-house and thereby wrote it off as a different tax expense," Mr. Slattery said.
In general, residents of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will fare better than most on the 4.3 cent a gallon increase in the Federal gasoline tax, which will increase the tax to 18.4 cents a gallon, because their gasoline consumption is less.
"We tend to use mass transit more and drive shorter distances to and from work," Mr. Shostal said, "so the gas tax will have less impact on us."
By dividing the total amount of petroleum used in the state by the numbers of households, the Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition compiled a state-by-state breakdown on the cost of the gasoline increase.
The cost per household would be an additional $43 a year in New York, $52 in Connecticut and $63 in New Jersey.
The national figure was $76 a year more to cover the increased tax. The state figures ranged from a low of $47 for Rhode Island to $150 for Wyoming. The District of Columbia had the nation's lowest projected increase at $34.
The Regional Plan Association has advocated that the local, state and Federal governments raise gasoline taxes even higher to pay for services.
"Gasoline is still the cheapest liquid in our society," Mr. Shostal said. "We were sorry to see the gas taxes as low as they were."
That position has placed the association squarely at odds with the American Automobile Association.
"It just seems that the motorist is the fall guy any way you go," said Max D. Winget, a spokesman for A.A.A. of Central New Jersey.

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the impact of the Federal economic plan on the New York region misstated the per capita spending for four states. The per capita spending for New York would be $477.07 (not $47.71), for New Jersey $455.51 (not $45.55), for Connecticut $439.50 (not $43.86), and for Rhode Island $435.82 (not $43.58).

HEADLINE: Art Dollars for Me, $10 for You, $10 for You

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ENCINITAS, Calif., Aug. 10

 BODY:
In the scrub-covered hills north of the Mexican border, three experimental artists supported by a Federal arts grant are handing out crisp $10 bills to illegal immigrants.
To David Avalos, one of the artists, the act of giving the money is a work of art and a political statement about "the interaction of physical space with intellectual space and civic space." 
 To Domingo Santiago, an illegal day laborer murmuring seriously with his companions as the artists explained their project, "It's strange, because people don't usually give us money."
 
'Outrageous' Giveaway
 To Representative Randy (Duke) Cunningham, Republican of California, the giveaway is "outrageous."
"I can scarcely imagine a more contemptuous use of taxpayers' hard-earned dollars," the San Diego lawmaker wrote the National Endowment for the Arts, which paid some of the costs of an exhibit that includes Mr. Avalos's work.
The befuddlement, the anger and the general hubbub that the handouts have stirred here in the San Diego area are also apparently part of the project, "Arte-Reembolso/Art Rebate," in which the artists are giving away most of a $5,000 grant.
The artists say they are trying to demonstrate the illegal aliens' role in the economy at a moment when public anger is rising over the cost to taxpayers of government services for those immigrants.
The moment the aliens received the bills, each signed by all three artists, some hurried to a nearby food truck, recycling their artworks into the economy by exchanging them for tacos and soft drinks.
"I don't think it's an accident that the piece happened right now," said Kathryn Kanjo, assistant curator at the Museum of Contemporary Art inSan Diego, which sponsored the work.
A spokesman for the endowment, Josh Dare, said the agency had not known about the project in advance or financed it specifically, and added, "These three artists are very adept at pushing people's buttons."
Mr. Dare said he expected the giveaway to be an issue next month at confirmation hearings for Jane Alexander, who was nominated last week to head the endowment.
 
Politicians' Response
 Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who has led attacks on the agency for financing such controversial projects as an exhibit of Robert Mapplethorpe's homoerotic photographs depicting sadomasochism, did not reply to a request for comment on the $10 handouts.
In recent days, Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, and Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, responding to the mood of their constituents, have visited the border and called for major steps to keep out illegal aliens. They slip across the border by the thousands every day.
Saying the country is "under siege" from the illegal aliens, the Governor said this week that the state should not provide them with such services as education and health care. In a letter to President Clinton, Mr. Wilson called for a constitutional amendment to deny citizenship to illegal aliens' children born in this country.
The artists -- Mr. Avalos, Louis Hock and Elizabeth Sisco -- insist that the aliens contribute to the economy through their work and the sales taxes they pay.
"It's interesting that it is the politicians and policy makers who choose to be irrational and that it's up to the artists to be rational," Mr. Avalos said.
 
Comedy in High Seriousness
 That responsibility seems to be never far from the artists' minds. They go about their business with the quiet seriousness of high comedy.
"We're going to do a little work here," Mr. Hock announced the other morning, alighting from his car at the edge of a strawberry field and approaching a group of illegal aliens who wait in the area to get work. As Mr. Hock shuffled through a stack of neatly numbered envelopes, the aliens shrank back, uncertain whether these were Federal immigration agents and the moment had come to run.
But the sight of the money held them. And soon, ready to accept the incomprehensible, they were gravely nodding as the artists handed them fliers that explained, in English and Spanish: "This $10 bill is part of an art project that intends to return tax dollars to taxpayers, particularly 'undocumented taxpayers.' The art rebate acknowledges your role as a vital player in an economic community indifferent to national borders."
As if to confuse the recipients still more as they kept a wary eye on the road for immigration agents, the fliers explained that the handout was supported by Federal and local government agencies.
The project received its grant from the San Diego museum as part of an exhibition called "La Frontera/The Border." The artists say that $500 of the grant is going into the costs of producing the fliers and photocopying the individual bills for their records, and that the remainder is going directly into aliens' pockets.
 
Part of $250,000 Project
 "The Border" is, in turn, one in a series of exhibits in a four-year project at the museum called "Dos Ciudades/ Two Cities," which received a $250,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. That amount is being matched 3 to 1 by the museum, with donations coming from the State of California, the City of San Diego and the Rockefeller Foundation. The museum is sponsoring "Two Cities" in partnership with the Centro Cultural de la Raza, a Hispanic cultural organization in San Diego.
Given the variety of sources and types of donations and the fact that fund-raising for "Two Cities" is continuing, Hugh Davies, the museum's director, said it was impossible to say what part of each $10 bill was from Washington.
In addition, he said, it was important to note that the national endowment financed only the four-year umbrella project and had no specific knowledge of the "Art Rebate" giveaway.
When the three artists were invited to participate, Mr. Davies said, "The N.E.A. had no knowledge, nor did we for that matter, of the specifics of what their commission might be."
Mr. Davies said the museum strongly endorsed the artists' freedom of expression. "With respect to the content of the work and whether we think it is a good art work or a bad art work," he said, "we really have no position on that."
 
Sharp Division
 Opinions on that question have been sharply divided in the San Diego area, where the project has been the subject of letters-to-the-editors' columns of newspapers.
"I think it's horrific what they are doing," said Garuda Terra, the owner of La Petite Boulangerie, where the artists decompressed over cups of coffee after a morning's work. "Why not pass out $10 to just anybody who pays taxes?"
But then, perhaps realizing that by her own reaction she had become part of the artwork's intellectual and civic space, and even possibly at her bakery, part of its physical space, she added: "But that's what they want. That's what makes it wonderful. If it hits enough nerves, it can make people respond."
At the endowment, Mr. Dare said that because of the recent controversy the agency was expediting a routine examination of how its money had been spent in the San Diego project.
The creators of "Art Rebate" are more than ready to be audited. Each new $10 bill, as crisp and vivid as a work of hyperrealism, is signed for by its recipient, sometimes with an X.
 
An Alien's Story
 At the edge of the strawberry field the other day, Mr. Santiago said he had been working illegally in the United States for 12 years. His 17-year-old son Jose, who has worked with him for three years, is in 11th grade at a local high school. Even working only two to four days a week at odd jobs, and earning $4.25 an hour, Mr. Santiago said he can make double or triple what he could back home. He tries to spend as little as he can on food and shelter and send the remainder to his family in Mexico.
As the three artists packed away their documents, Mr. Santiago and his companions had already gathered around two elderly women who had arrived to pass out religious tracts.
The men looked up and waved as the artists drove away, and one called out: "Come back soon. We'll be here."

HEADLINE: Pope's New America

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, Aug. 11

 BODY:
For decades, Popes viewed the United States as a steadfast ally against Communism. Now, as Pope John Paul II makes his first visit to the United States since the end of the cold war, that view has changed. For the Pope, the United States remains an indispensable part of his vision of a new world order, but maybe an unreliable one.
The Pope, who arrives here on Thursday and will meet with President Clinton in the afternoon, has said he loves the United States. But he clearly hates some things about it: liberal policies on abortion and what he regards as a culture that is increasingly self-absorbed and self-destructive. He admires American political institutions and recognizes the power of the American economy, but he has deep doubts about whether this country can measure up to what he sees as its potential and its responsibilities. 
 Despite the shared opposition to Communism and the close, sometimes covert, cooperation between Rome and Washington in keeping alive the dissident movement in Poland and elsewhere in Eastern Europe, John Paul has not hesitated to chastise American foreign policy. Before and during the Persian Gulf war, he repeatedly suggested that American actions in the region were precipitous or excessive.
 
Change in Emphasis
 "The Holy Father does not want a single-power world with the United States dominant," said the Rev. J. Bryan Hehir, a former international-affairs adviser to American Roman Catholic bishops. "But he also does not want the United States to 'come home' and worry only about health care."
"The old conversations between Popes and American Presidents would be about arms control, avoiding war and maybe Central America," said Father Hehir, who is now pastor of the Cambridge, Mass., parish near Harvard University, where he teaches. "The new one will reflect the Pope's concern about the future of international institutions like the United Nations and other multilateral agencies and whether the United States will provide the resources and the legitimacy essential for them to develop."
But the Pope's hopes for American leadership are countered by his doubts about American culture.
"He is worried that Americans are losing the strong and firm moral character they once had," said Michael Novak, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute whose writings in defense of capitalism are widely believed to have influenced the Pope's encyclical "Centesimus Annus" ("100 Years") in 1991.
 
Critique of United States
 In 1987, when John Paul arrived in the United States and met President Ronald Reagan in Miami, the Pope immediately thanked God for the American Constitution but then admonished "Americans who have received so much in freedom and prosperity and human enrichment" to share those blessings with the rest of the world. "A new birth of freedom" was required, he said, a "freedom to exercise responsibility."
John Paul's frequent laments about materialism, preoccupation with consumer goods, abortion and the breakdown of traditional sexual norms seem particularly aimed at the United States. Father Hehir and Mr. Novak agreed that the Pope's image of the United States was influenced by reports of sexual promiscuity and sexual explicitness in movies, television and magazines. The Pope, Father Hehir said, fears that American culture is "a culture without restraint or limits."
But the Pope is also known to have been deeply impressed by the religious feeling shown by Americans during his 1987 visit to six cities. Church leaders who spoke with him after the trip said he was surprised and moved by the crowds' reverence during worship services.
 
Ties With Presidents
 This is the Pope's third visit to the United States, not counting brief stops in Puerto Rico in 1981 and Alaska in 1984, and his fifth meeting with an American President. Papal meetings with Presidents go back to 1919, when Woodrow Wilson met Benedict XV at the Vatican; the first President to meet with a Pope in the United States was Lyndon B. Johnson, who greeted Paul VI in New York in October 1965.
But John Paul has had far more exposure to the United States than any other Pope. As Archbishop of Cracow, he traveled here twice before his election in 1978, stretching out a 1966 visit for several months. Nonetheless, opinions vary on how well he understands this country, especially its pluralism of faiths and ideas.
Mr. Novak maintained that the Pope was much more pro-American than many other leading figures in the Vatican who, he said, tended to suspect American capitalism and to disdain American culture as superficial.
 
'Explorer for the World'
 The Pope's critical attitude toward the United States might be more apparent today, Mr. Novak said, simply because "John Paul's attention is moving from the political and economic questions of the cold-war period, where the United States was a model, to the cultural questions, the cultural ecology, if you will, of the new world order."
"And that," Mr. Novak added, "is where he especially thinks the United States is vulnerable. The Pope sees the United States as an explorer for the world, for both good and ill, often for good in terms of free institutions and for ill or worse in terms of the output of Hollywood."
Father Hehir said something similar but believed that for all the Pope's concern about the internal condition of the United States the Vatican never loses its focus on the possible American role in vital international areas, like abetting a settlement between Israel and its Arab neighbors.
"The Vatican view," Father Hehir said, "is less concerned about whether it likes the United States or not than about the fact that it remains an indispensable force for change in the world."

HEADLINE: POPE CELEBRATES INDIGENOUS PEOPLE

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: IZAMAL, Mexico, Aug. 11

 BODY:
On the eve of his first meeting with President Clinton, Pope John Paul II today criticized injustice against indigenous people "from the Alaskan peninsula to Tierra del Fuego" and urged a new redistribution of wealth between the American continent's rich north and poor south.
The Pope arrived in this small town of 20,000 people in the Yucatan peninsula from Jamaica on the 60th overseas tour of his papacy. He is to travel on Thursday to meet President Clinton and celebrate World Youth Day in Denver, Colo. That visit is expected to illuminate fundamental differences between the Vatican and many American Catholics over artificial birth control, abortion and the ordination of women as priests. 
While the Pope repeated his conservative views on those issues in Jamaica on Tuesday, urging young people in particular to avoid what he called sexual misbehavior, he focused principally today on depicting the church as a defender and protector of indigenous Americans and on promoting a new economic order in the wake of the cold war.
"From Izamal, I want to launch an appeal," the Pope said, "to developed societies to overcome economic systems oriented solely toward profit and seek real and effective solutions to the serious problems that afflict wide sectors of the continent's population."
 
Unusual Reference to the U.S.
 The speech echoed other forthright denunciations of what the Pope sees as social and economic injustice in Latin America, but was unusual in its inclusion of the United States just one day before the meeting with President Clinton. While Vatican officials said there was no formal agenda for the 45-minute meeting in Denver, the Pope's comments seem intended in part to insure that social and economic disparity were discussed.
"My message is not only for those present here, but goes beyond the geographic limits of the Yucatan to embrace all the indigenous communities, ethnicities and peoples of America, from the Alaskan peninsula to Tierra del Fuego," he declared.
Along with Latin American indigenous groups he also listed Apaches and Eskimos as examples of the people he was talking about.
"My presence among you is meant as a decisive support for your right to space for your culture, your lives and your societies, as individuals and as ethnic groups," he told 4,000 people in a heat-baked church square painted canary yellow and white -- the Vatican colors -- for the occasion.
 
Symbolic Venue for Speech
 The Pope chose an unusual and possibly symbolic venue for his speech -- a Christian fortress-church on the ruins of a Maya temple that seemed eloquent with the overlay of alien faith that came with Columbus's Christianizing journeys five centuries ago.
"From the first steps of evangelization, the church was the untiring defender of the Indians, the protector of their cultural values and the promoter of humanity against the abuses of unscrupulous colonizers," the Pope declared, listing by name missionaries who had protested against the conquistadors' injustices.
The question of the church's historic role is still uncomfortable for some in Latin America who accuse missionaries of sheltering behind Spanish and Portuguese conquerors to enforce conversions among people who already practiced their own religions. Today, according to the Vatican's figures, some 52 million Indians live in Latin American countries, and the biggest group -- more than 25 million -- is in Mexico, forming 29 percent of its population.
Catholic bishops have frequently accused Latin American governments of discriminating against indigenous people and taking their land and rights, a theme the Pope pursued today.
 
'Shadow of Sin' on America
 "Unfortunately, it needs to be said that the richness of your culture has not always been duly appreciated, and neither were your rights as people and peoples always respected," the Pope said.
"The shadow of sin falls on America, too, in the destruction of your artistic and cultural creations and in the violence to which you were many times subjected," he said.
The Catholic Church, he said, "supports you in your legitimate aspirations and just claims."
"I know from many indigenous brothers and sisters that they were uprooted from their places of origin and deprived of the land they lived on," the Pope said. "There are also many indigenous communities throughout the American continent that suffer from great poverty. For this, the world cannot feel at ease or satisfied."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pope John Paul II watching dancers perform a Maya creation dance yesterday in Izamal, Mexico. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Vote in Atlanta Suburb Condemns Homosexuality

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARIETTA, Ga., Aug. 11

 BODY:
In a striking example of the emotional politics surrounding homosexual issues, Cobb County in suburban Atlanta has passed a resolution condemning homosexuality and is considering another that would require county-financed arts groups to meet "community, family-oriented standards."
Several communities around the country have passed measures aimed at combating political initiatives by homosexuals, but the resolution approved here -- although it carries no legal weight -- is believed to be the first one condemning homosexuality. 
 The proposed arts resolution, on the other hand, could break new ground in limiting government financing for even mildly controversial fare.
Critics of the resolution, which was passed Tuesday, say they are not planning to challenge it in court because, they say, its effect is more symbolic than real. But they say they will sue the county if the financing measure is passed on Aug. 24. The county will spend $123,000 of its $142 million budget on support for arts groups this year.
"We've already got lawyers lined up," said Gerry Weber, legal director for the American Civil Liberties Union.
The resulting uproar has stirred extraordinary feelings, both for and against the resolution, in the largely white, conservative, upper-middle-class suburbs north and east of Atlanta. And it has shown once again how homosexual issues, a major rallying point for the Christian right, have also come to symbolize a broader cultural divide in American life.
 
'New York of the South'
 "Atlanta is sort of the New York of the South," said Matt Sander, a 27-year-old businessman and aspiring politician as he ate lunch this afternoon at the Original Chicago Hot Dog Co. here.
He did not mean it as a compliment.
"This was a way to say we want to live by the standards set by the parents, not some of the things they allow in big cities," he went on. "It's an effort to keep Cobb County the way it was 20 years ago."
Opponents of the proposals said a strident, narrow-minded minority was trying to force its view of morality on the entire community.
Speaking at a public hearing on Tuesday before the commission voted, the director of the Atlanta Shakespeare Company, Jeff Watkins of nearby Decatur, criticized the resolution's supporters, saying: "Theirs is not the voice of God. It's not the voice of America, and it is not the voice of family values. Theirs is the voice of pride, prejudice, bigotry and tyranny."
But with a crowd full of church groups wearing yellow tags reading "Support Community Standards" cheering them on, the commissioners voted 3 to 1 in favor of the proposal. The measure says that "life styles advocated by the gay community are incompatible with the standards to which this community subscribes."
 
Measure Is Defended
 Commission Chairman Bill Byrne said today that the measure was not intended as an attack against homosexuals. He called it an attempt to go on record as opposing what he called special privileges for homosexuals. But he conceded that the resolution that was passed had no legal weight.
"We are saying the values we want to adhere to and build on are the traditional community standards," he said. "Reinforcing those values and those standards is the responsibility of the political leadership of the United States, from the President down to the mayor and city council of the smallest city."
Anti-gay measures have cropped up in as many as 20 states, including Colorado, Oregon, California, Florida and Michigan. Last month, the Colorado Supreme Court delayed the enforcement of that state's anti-gay constitutional amendment, pending a hearing.
Most of these measure seek to bar laws protecting homosexuals from discrimination or to prevent measures like domestic-partner provisions giving homosexual unions a legal weight equal to heterosexual marriages.
The debate here has diverse roots. Some residents had complained about the local Theatre In The Square's production of "Lips Together, Teeth Apart," which has references to homosexuality. The group gets $41,000 of its $800,000 budget from the county.
But when the controversy arose, the company was presenting "Smoke on the Mountain," a bluegrass gospel show that some patrons criticized as an attempt "to cram conservative values down their throats," said Michael Horne, a co-founder of the theater.
 
Spark From Atlanta
 A more important factor behind the resolution may be Atlanta's decision to give benefits to the live-in domestic partners of city employees.
"That was the spark," Mr. Byrne said. "If it didn't happen in Atlanta, this would not have happened in Cobb County." By the end, supporters were invoking things like President Clinton's support for allowing homosexuals in the military and Gov. Zell Miller's invitation to the Gay Olympics to hold their games in Atlanta as a reason for the measures.
Only one of the four commissioners, William A. Cooper, dissented. But opinions are clearly split in the community.
"People should be able to make their own decisions about how to live their lives," said Elizabeth Lively, a 27-year-old mother who was shopping with her 5-year-old daughter today.
But supporters supported the resolution, both on moral grounds and because they contend that homosexuals are seeking special privileges.
Mary J. Gilstrap of Cobb County objected at the hearing to " the portrayal of homosexuality as an alternative life style compatible with traditional family values."
But the issue surrounding the financing proposal to be voted on later this month may be more complicated.
Even Mr. Byrne, who supported Tuesday's resolution, said the vague wording of "community, family-oriented standards" might make the pending proposal unenforceable.
The county was flooded today with phone calls, many from outsiders and most of them critical, county officials said. An economic boycott has been mentioned, and Mr. Weber said the vote could come back to haunt the county.
"This is the first county that has done such a thing, and they have labeled themselves as a backward, stereotypical Southern county, and they will be treated as such by the business community," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Commissioners of Cobb County, a suburb of Atlanta, Tuesday passed the first of two resolutions condemning homosexuality in the community. During the vote, the measure's supporters stood waving "Support Community Standards" cards as those opposed sat silently in the front. (Barry Shapiro/the Marietta Daily Journal)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Yen Reaches Another High As Canadian Dollar Drops

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar continued to hit new lows against the Japanese yen today as investors bet that the enormous Japanese trade surplus would continue to push up Japan's currency.
The decline came even though the dollar rose yesterday against some other currencies, hitting its highest point against the Canadian dollar in more than five years. 
 Meanwhile, gold prices dropped again yesterday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery fell $5.60 an ounce, to $375.30. December gold, the most actively traded contract, fell $5.70 an ounce, to $378.70.
In Tokyo today, the dollar was quoted at 103.30 yen in afternoon trading, its lowest level since modern exchange rates were set after World War II, down from yesterday's Tokyo close of 103.77 yen. In New York late yesterday, it was quoted at 103.64 yen, down from 104.70 yen on Tuesday.
Traders said the yen was supported by the belief that Japan's new Government would continue the practice of running a large trade surplus.
Japan said yesterday that its merchandise trade surplus with the rest of the world jumped to $11.82 billion in July, from $9.23 billion a year earlier. Moreover, its trade surplus with the United States climbed to $4.68 billion from $3.81 billion.
The surplus pushes up the Japanese currency because it means importers of Japanese goods need more yen to pay for them, raising demand.
Hillel Waxman, the chief foreign exchange dealer at Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York, said speculators contributed to the dollar's fall. "It's just continued pushing by speculators trying to bring the yen to the 100 level" to the dollar, he said.
By contrast, the dollar yesterday reached its highest rate against the Canadian dollar in five years, trading at 1.3068 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2930 on Tuesday. Traders said the Canadian currency was hurt by low interest rates in Canada, mixed economic reports and concerns about national elections later this year.
The selloff came after Canada's bank interest rate -- charged for loans to banks by the central bank -- fell from 4.32 percent to 4.20 percent yesterday, its lowest level since 1964. Lower interest rates hurt a currency, since investments denominated in that currency earn less.

HEADLINE: FEAR OF POLLUTION AT MEXICAN PLANT

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The $1.6 billion sale to private investors of a huge thermoelectric power plant in northern Mexico has been thrown into doubt by concerns that pollution from the plant could blow over the border into Big Bend National Park in Texas.
The future of the nearly completed plant, which the Mexican Government had hailed as a first, shining example of its new effort to privatize the generation of badly needed electricity, is now mired in complex political bargaining tied to the North American Free Trade Agreement, officials said. 
 Officials of the Mexican Government and Mission Energy Company, the American concern that negotiated to buy the 1,400-megawatt plant along with a Mexican mining company, insist there is no conclusive evidence that its emissions would degrade air quality in Big Bend National Park, 130 miles northwest, as the United States Environmental Protection Agency fears.
But both sides say concerns about pollution across the border have been enough to generate a wave of American pressure for the plant to be refitted to meet not only the emissions standards of Mexico and the World Bank, which was to help finance the project, but something approaching the higher standards of the E.P.A. as well.
 
$300 Million to Cut Emissions
 Equipment to reduce the emissions to levels that would be permissible in the United States could cost the coal-fired plant as much as $300 million, Mission executives say. And that is much more than Mission and its majority partner, Grupo Acerero del Norte, say they will spend before renegotiating the 30-year contract under which they are to sell most of their electricity to Mexico's state-owned utility.
"We're kind of between a rock and a hard place," said Bob Dietch, a senior vice president of Mission Energy, a subsidiary of Southern California Edison. "Whatever the two Governments resolve, we will try to work with them." But, referring to the trade agreement, he added, "We've gotten caught up in the Nafta debate."
The struggle over the plant, known as Carbon II, underscores both how sharply the pressure to "harmonize" Mexican environmental standards with those of the United States has risen during the American debate over the trade agreement and the complications of doing so.
The Clinton Administration is expected to submit the agreement to Congress this fall so that it can be put into effect as planned next Jan. 1, and concerns about its environmental impact are a major obstacle to its passage. The agreement, which has already been approved in Canada and faces only a perfunctory legislative review in Mexico, would knock down most barriers to trade and investment among the three countries over 15 years.
 
Focus on Enforcing Laws
 In negotiations for a parallel accord to safeguard the environment under the trade pact, American officials have focused mainly on how to insure the enforcement of existing Mexican environmental laws.
But American and Canadian officials have generally accepted Mexico's claim that it cannot simply raise its environmental standards to their levels. Until Mexico's economy and enforcement mechanisms are strengthened, Mexican officials say, higher standards would probably be unenforceable, not to mention unfair.
Yet to some American environmentalists and Congressional representatives, Carbon II is a vivid example of the conflicts between Mexico's development and America's environment that have no clear solution. E.P.A. officials stress that they have no regulatory authority over the plant.
One senior E.P.A. official said that whatever solution the United States recommends it will likely be based not only on the emissions of Carbon II, but also those of Carbon I, a 1,200-megawatt generating plant that the Mexican Government owns and runs nearby.
The official said the E.P.A. will not necessarily seek to have the plants meet American standards, but to reduce emissions to levels that would safeguard air quality in the United States.

HEADLINE: Midway Will Fly Again

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 11

 BODY:
A new, smaller Midway Airlines plans to fly again soon from its old Midway Airport hub in Chicago, its president, Kenneth Carlson, said today. Midway, which shut down in 1991 as a result of a weak economy, fierce competition and some ill-timed business moves, intends to resume operating in November. Mr. Carlson said that the new airline would be able to offer fares 40 percent below standard coach fares. No actual prices have been announced. Mr. Carlson said the new Midway would eventually operate 25 or so aircraft, carry 2.1 million passengers on 72 flights a day and post revenues of roughly $250 million.

HEADLINE: Midtown Building Is Sold for Lofty $176 Million

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
A Times Square skyscraper that has stood for months as one of the most potent symbols of the commercial real-estate crisis in New York City was sold yesterday to the Morgan Stanley Group Inc. for $176 million, a price considerably higher than many real-estate insiders had thought it would bring.
The sale reflected more interest in the New York City office-building market than many people had expected, members of the real-estate industry said. Barry F. Sullivan, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said he thought the purchase could take the Times Square neighborhood "out of the pioneer stage and into the beginning of the long-run growth stage." 
 Mr. Sullivan said the deal, in addition to "virtually legitimizing the Times Square area," represented a significant commitment to the city by Morgan Stanley, which threatened to move to Stamford, Conn., last year and eventually decided to stay after receiving a large package of incentives from the city in exchange for a promise to stay in Manhattan and Brooklyn for 10 years.
"This is a 25-year deal anyway," Mr. Sullivan said of the building purchase. "It is an increased level of Morgan Stanley's commitment to the city" in a part of the city where the company's "presence will induce others to move there."
The buyer, Morgan Stanley, the huge financial services firm, said it planned to consolidate the 3,800 workers who are now at three Manhattan locations into the 41-story, 1.3 million-square-foot building at 1585 Broadway, between 47th and 48th Streets.
The seller was the lending group of eight banks that controlled the building, which went into what turned out to be a spectacular bankruptcy in December 1991 after its developer, David Solomon of Solomon Equities, foundered in the downturn of the New York market.
The list of the also-rans and their bids in the sealed-bid auction showed a degree of interest in the building far beyond what many had expected.
Industry insiders said the second-highest bid, $164 million, came from the Quantum Fund. The fund is overseen by George Soros, the Hungarian-born investor, with advice from Paul Reichmann, the patriarch of the Olympia & York real-estate empire, which had its own spectacular collapse in the spring of 1992.
Two other bids above $150 million, the minimum set by the owning bank group's adviser, came from Milstein Properties, a big New York family real-estate business, and Odyssey Partners, an investment boutique.
While the purchase price was higher than many had expected, the sale does not automatically herald a turnaround in the New York real-estate market. Morgan Stanley is in a different position than other would-be buyers in that it is buying as a user, and thus has different concerns than others might have.

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus Up

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus leaped nearly $2 billion in July from June, the Finance Ministry said today. It was the 31st consecutive month that the surplus has grown.
Japan's customs-cleared trade surplus with the rest of the world jumped to $11.82 billion in July from $9.23 billion a year earlier, the ministry said. In June it stood at $9.97 billion. 
 The surplus with the United States, the most vocal critic of Japan's trade policies, climbed to $4.68 billion from $3.81 billion a year earlier.
 Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, in his first news conference, said Tuesday that reviving Japan's economy -- which is passing through its worst recession since World War II -- and reducing the surplus with the United States were among his Government's priorities.
The July rise in the surplus came as exports outpaced imports by a wide margin because of the yen's recent gains against the dollar, economists said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Urged to Finance A Cleanup of L.I. Sound

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 11

 BODY:
The Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, called on the Federal Government today to "back up its regulations with real dollars and contribute its fair share" to the cleanup of Long Island Sound.
Mr. O'Rourke, speaking outside a hearing of the Long Island Sound Congressional Caucus here, said the Federal Government must make a financial commitment to the cleanup effort already under way by the States of New York and Connecticut, as well as local governments, environmental agencies and grass-roots citizens' groups. 
 "While local governments are ready and willing to accept their share of the responsibility for solving the pollution problems of Long Island Sound, we will need significant help from the Federal Government to achieve our goals," Mr. O'Rourke said. "The existing Federal and state financial infrastructure is simply inadequate to pay for the capital improvements and programs that will be necessary to solve the problems of Long Island Sound."
Mr. O'Rourke said that Westchester alone needed several hundred million for the cleanup.
 
Development Curb Is Feared
 Last December, after seven years of study, the Federal Government released a report, titled "The Long Island Sound Study Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plan." The report recommends limiting the amount of nitrogen that flows from sewage plants into the Sound, a proposal that some say would stifle development in surrounding communities. Up to $8.1 billion may have to be spent to limit the nitrogen releases, the report says.
The caucus, led by Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of Westchester, and Representative Christopher Shays, Republican of Fairfield County, was holding the third in a series of hearings on the report.
Mr. O'Rourke had to leave before he could address the hearing. But the County Planning Commissioner, Lynn Oliva, read a statement by Mr. O'Rourke, who warned that without the resources to carry out recommendations made in the Long Island Island study report, the cleanup effort would not be enough. "Without money from the Federal Government we will all be doomed to fail in our efforts, however well intentioned," the statement said.
Throughout the hearing, which was conducted in the Oakwood Island Pavilion at Five Island Park, with Long Island Sound's Echo Bay as a backdrop, speakers called on the Federal Government to contribute its fair share to the cleanup.
 
Nitrogen Flow Limited
 "This year, my colleagues on the caucus and I twice secured House passage of major increases in funding for clean water, totaling nearly $1 billion," Ms. Lowey said. "Unfortunately, the Senate killed both of these initiatives. But we will not give up. Providing additional resources to the Sound is a wise investment to our local economy and in the environment of our entire region," she said.
Gordon Colvin, director of the Division of Marine Resources for the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, praised Westchester County for its leadership in carrying out a policy not to increase the amount of nitrogen flowing into the Sound from its four South Shore sewage treatment plants.
"This will have a positive effect on reducing the nitrogen load to Long Island Sound," he said. "But attainment of our ultimate objectives will require that the strong Federal-state-local partnership continue. Key among the contributions of the Federal Government will be a provision of financial assistance."
Several citizens' groups also urged the caucus to keep trying to secure Federal aid for the cleanup effort.
Katherine Dieck, program coordinator for Citizens Campaign for the Environment, a group of 85,000 residents of New York and Connecticut, said: "Beach closure, fish kills, shellfish restrictions, decreases in the diversity of marine life that once flourished in these waters as well as other water quality problems, are still prevalent. Yesterday's future is upon us. Now is the time for action."

Lowey of New York, center foreground, and Representative Christopher Shays of Connecticut, right, held a hearing of the Long Island Sound Congressional Caucus in New Rochelle, N.Y., attended by officials and environmental and developmental groups. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Lower Rates Lift Dow to Another Record

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were mostly higher yesterday as the Treasury's auction of 10-year notes drew strong investor demand, rallying the bond market and lowering interest rates. For the second time in three days, the Dow Jones industrial average set a new closing high, finishing up 10.62 points at 3,583.35.
The previous high was set on Monday, when the Dow closed at 3,576.08. 
 "The market is still having trouble with a resistance zone that goes from 3,575 on the Dow to 3,585," said Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president and market analyst at Tucker Anthony Inc. "But it looks as if it's going to move through it in the next week or so. That would suggest an attack on the 3,600 to 3,640 region."
He said that while the market "looks higher in the near term, selling pressures are building and we expect more severe corrections to be introduced in coming months."
 
A Bad Day for H.M.O.'s
 Trouble areas in yesterday's market included health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, which underwent a meltdown as traders dumped shares of several stocks over concern about President Clinton's health care program. "Our opinion is that the selloff in H.M.O.'s is overdone," Mr. Laubscher said, "with some of the issues better buys than sells at these prices."
Traders said a draft of some of the plan's key features had been circulating within the investment community for the last several weeks. Kimberly Purvis, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, used the draft as a basis for downgrading several H.M.O. stocks in an investment report that the securities firm issued yesterday.
Among H.M.O. issues, Oxford Health Plans, a fast-growing company that operates in the New York City market and has been recommended by several investment firms, dropped 8 1/4, to 62 3/4, in Nasdaq trading.
Elsewhere, United Healthcare fell 6 3/4, to 52 3/4; Humana fell 3/4, to 10 3/4, and U.S. Healthcare declined 5 1/8, to 41 1/4.
A market bright spot was the semiconductor sector.
Semiconductor and computer stocks rose on a report by the Semiconductor Industry Association reflecting brisk demand for personal computers. As a result, issues like Intel, up 1 7/8, to 58 3/4, helped the Nasdaq composite to a new closing high of 718.77, up 1.69. The previous high, set on Monday, was 718.49.
The association reported that its book-to-bill ratio rose to 1.12 in July from a revised 1.11 in June, higher than expected because the summer months are usually slow for the industry. This means that chip makers had $112 of new orders for every $100 of products shipped last month.
Advanced Micro Devices rose 1 1/4, to 29 5/8, and Microsoft gained 1 3/8, to 72 3/8.
Mr. Laubscher said the buying in the semiconductor sector could overextend these stocks.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 268.3 million shares, up from 255.5 million on Tuesday. Advancing stocks outpaced decliners by 1,059 to 885.
 
Investor Reluctance
 For the most part, stocks traded mixed from the opening as investors were reluctant to make big moves before today's 30-year bond auction, which concludes the Government's quarterly borrowing. The Government will also release the July producer price report today and the Consumer Price Index on Friday.
Airline stocks were weak. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, declined 1 1/4, to 65; UAL, the parent of United Airlines, fell 3, to 143 1/2, and Delta Air Lines declined 1, to 51 3/8. Some analysts noted that the new Federal fuel tax would cost the industry $500 million a year after a two-year exemption runs out.
Elsewhere, Southern Pacific Rail closed at 15 in its first day of public trading, up from the 14 1/4 price on Tuesday when the 132-year-old company, based in San Francisco, offered 30 million shares.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Sustainability, or Seeking the Deficit Level That We Can Live With.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE Democrats bit the deficit bullet, but did they bite off a big enough piece? Not by Ross Perot's reckoning, or, for that matter, by Bill Clinton's.
Their assumption, widely shared across the political spectrum, is that the only acceptable deficit is no deficit at all, or at least none when the economy is running at full capacity. And last week's budget accord still projects a deficit equal to 3 percent of national income in 1998 -- about where it was before the bipartisan budget summit conference in 1990. 
 But to many economists, the long-term goal of zero-deficit at full employment is, at best, a crude rule of thumb. If the object is to buttress a Japanese level of national thrift, a zero-deficit alone is insufficient. On the other hand, if the goal is simply to sustain the Government's capacity to pay its bills, research by William Buiter of Yale University suggests that a balanced budget is not necessary. In light of the political cost of further deficit reduction, "sustainability" is a budget concept that could soon come into vogue.
When a company's debts increase, Wall Street doesn't assume the borrower is doing something wrong. Indeed, the fact that the company has access to cash suggests it is doing something right. What counts is the credibility of the company's promises to repay. And that, in turn, depends on its future revenues and costs.
Likewise, when a government adds to it debts the lenders' big question is whether they will be caught in a giant Ponzi scheme -- a game in which this year's creditors can get their money only if the government can borrow the interest next year.
The United States Government can never truly become insolvent since there is no limit to the number of dollars the Federal Reserve can create by tapping a few keys on a computer console. There certainly is a practical limit, though, to the rate of growth of Federal indebtedness that could be managed without printing money to pay the bills, thereby expropriating some of the lenders' assets by inflating away their purchasing power. And as in the case of a corporation, Mr. Buiter argues, that rate turns on the expected growth of revenues, current expenditures and debt service.
Mr. Buiter's arithmetic is intuitive. What economists call the Government's "primary budget surplus" -- the surplus of revenues over current expenditures -- must grow fast enough to keep pace with mounting annual interest payments.
Well maybe it is not quite intuitive, but the math is correct. And lo and behold, reasonable guesses about future interest rates and revenue growth rates imply that the five-year budget just passed by Congress will generate a deficit that is very close to sustainable. In 1998, Mr. Buiter estimates, interest obligations on the debt will exceed the primary budget surplus by about $40 billion -- a mere half a percent of national output.
There are catches. For one thing, $40 billion is nothing to sneeze at in the penurious new world of Federal budget-making. For another, it would be more accurate to say $40 billion and counting. As the President has repeatedly pointed out, deficits will escalate rapidly after 1998 unless the Government share of the national health bill is contained.
The deeper conundrum, though, is how to interpret sustainability. To Richard Cooper of Harvard, it does not matter how the debt is financed, as long as the borrowing does not crowd out resources available for the productivity-enhancing investment that propels rising living standards. Thus in a world in which foreigners are apparently willing to lend virtually unlimited quantities to the United States Treasury as long as they are confident that the dollar will retain its purchasing power, sustainability is what really counts.
But to Benjamin Friedman, another Harvard economist and a fire-breathing deficit hawk, "sustainability is just the outer bound" of what Washington can get away with. Deficits are a form of national dis-saving, he notes, subtracting from the already anemic private savings of Americans. Unless households have the insight and will to offset their Government's profligacy by saving more themselves, he argues, even sustainable deficits are very bad news.
Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution, goes a step further. "Saving is all that counts" in determining future living standards, he said. While the high rates of domestic investment permitted by open world capital markets are certainly desirable, it is the providers of the savings who will end up with the gravy. Thus Americans ought to be exporting savings as a cushion against diminishing investment opportunities at home, not importing it to finance today's old-age pensions and medical insurance.
From the Friedman-Bosworth perspective, then, the apparent sustainability of chronic deficit finance amounts to the worst of all possible worlds. For if the capital markets do not force Washington to pull up its socks, the prospect of pulling off this politically daunting task after 1998 seems remote.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Historical Society Gets N.Y.U.'s Help

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
New York University is taking over management of the library of the troubled New-York Historical Society, it was announced on Tuesday. In addition, the two institutions will develop joint educational programs, and the libraries at the university and the society will share their catalogues in a single database.
An agreement between the two institutions became effective Aug. 1. It was announced by Herbert S. Winokur Jr. and Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the chairmen of the historical society, and L. Jay Oliva, the president of New York University. Under the agreement, which is for a year but may be extended, Carlton C. Rochell, the dean of the university's library system, which has holdings of 3.7 million volumes, will oversee management of the society's library services and develop joint programs.
 
'Economie of Scale'
 At a stroke, the venture promises to cut costs for and to shore up management of the society, which has teetered on the edge of bankruptcy in the last four years and early this year was on the verge of closing its doors. At various times, talks were begun to see whether the society could be merged with the Museum of the City of New York or the New York Public Library. In a last-minute reprieve, as the society was laying off staff members, closing its galleries and cutting back on library hours, the State Legislature allocated $6.3 million to it in April, and the city provided matching financing in May. 
 "One reason this made sense is the economies of scale when we do the technical work of acquisitions processing and cataloguing," Mr. Rochell said of the agreement. "We have a large department dedicated to this, and we can absorb theirs, performing those functions at a much lower cost than they can."
The university, for its part, will gain computer access to the society's 700,000 volumes and more than 3 million manuscripts, maps and photographs, many of them dealing with Colonial American history. "The two collections, taken together, represent one of the two or three finest collections in the country in American history," said Mr. Rochell.
Under the new arrangement, the society's library will be open five days a week starting in early September, instead of the current three, and its database will be loaded into the university's computer system. This will allow scholars around the world to have access to both institutions through inter-network computer systems, and users of the society's library to have access to the university's catalogue.
 
Catalogue Backlog
 The university will oversee all acquisitions, processing and cataloguing for the historical society, and will help upgrade the society's conservation program. An immediate task is to clear up the library's cataloguing backlog. About a third of the library's holdings remain uncatalogued; only 40,000 items are ready to be loaded into the university's database. "We believe we can do all this at 14 percent less cost than when we were operating three days a week," said Mr. Ross.
Last year, the budget of the society's library was $685,000. With the university managing the library, Mr. Ross estimated, the figure will drop to $600,000. He said that although management duties were being taken over by the university, the library's staff would remain unchanged and the society would retain ownership of all materials in its library.
Plans also call for the two institutions to undertake joint publishing and documentary video projects, using the university's press and its video-production resources. And the historical society, whose galleries are undergoing a renovation that will take most of this year, will be able to mount temporary exhibitions at the university.
"We'd like by end of this year to have them in a state that they can say they have a sustainable professional level of operations," said Mr. Rochell. "If the society can become a productive center of research and scholarship, it's not just beneficial to the city, but to what we're all about as well."

HEADLINE: AD CAMPAIGN;
Mr. Giuliani as a Son of the Neighborhoods

BYLINE: TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:

ON THE SCREEN
 Camera pans in on row of brick houses, then moves down to pick up Mr. Giuliani dressed in a red short-sleeved shirt and sitting on the hood of a car. When he talks about the city's small businesses, the scene shifts to the Bronx Terminal Market while captions run across the bottom, saying "New York City has lost over 300,000 jobs in the last three years," and "Only 25 percent of N.Y.C. job loss can be blamed on national trends. Source: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics." At the end, Mr. Giuliani's face reappears, inset into a brilliant blue background with a slogan: "Rudy Giuliani: He'll listen to the people in every borough."
 
PRODUCER
Garth Group of New York. 

THE SCRIPT
 (Mr. Giuliani's voice) Some people call this an outer borough. I call it part of the heart and soul of New York City. I've lived here in Woodside, Queens. I was born in Brooklyn, lived in Queens, went to school in the Bronx, lived in Manhattan. I've lived or gone to school in just about every part of New York City. It's a city that I love. It's a city that I see as a city of neighborhoods. We have to listen more to the people who live in these neighborhoods in New York City; we have to listen to them when they tell us about the deterioration of the school system. And we have to fight back to make the New York City public schools the best in the country again. We have to listen to them when they tell us they want a higher quality of life, a cleaner city, a better city, a city that draws more business and has more jobs. We have to listen to them when they tell us that the city is crushing the small businesses of New York City. I mean, after all, that's the heart and the soul of the city, the small businesses. That's what we're being told by the people who live in these neighborhoods. I've been there, I've grown up there, that's where I come from, that's where my family comes from, and I've been listening to them for the last four years. And that's what they've been telling me.
 
ACCURACY
 Mr. Giuliani has spent time in each of the city's five boroughs except for Staten Island, but at the age of 7, he moved to Nassau County and only commuted back to Brooklyn for high school. The Giuliani campaign cites a May article in Newsday in which Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, is quoted as saying that national trends could be blamed for only one-quarter of the jobs lost in the city since 1979. But in an interview, Mr. Ehrenhalt said he had never made such an assertion and would have no way of knowing how to separate those job losses caused by national factors from those caused by purely local ones. In fact, the claim more closely resembles the findings of an analysis of econometric models conducted by Stephen Kagann, Mr. Giuliani's economic adviser, when he was chief economist for City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman in 1991.
 
SCORECARD
 One point of this ad is to paint Mr. Giuliani as an authentic son of his city, someone familiar with the corner of 33d and Third, and in tune with the city's concerns. While he never mentions Mayor Dinkins's name, his entire speech is an implicit rebuke of the Mayor's handling of problems from education to sanitation to the economy. By saying that he has been listening to New Yorkers' concerns for the last four years, Mr. Giuliani strongly suggests that the Mayor has not been. This ad could resonate powerfully with many voters in the boroughs outside Manhattan who feel they are too often ignored, but it might strike a less responsive chord among more liberal swing voters whose support Mr. Giuliani also badly needs.

HEADLINE: Russia-Japan Relations on the Rocks

 BODY:
Four barren islands in the Kurile chain stand between Russia and Japan. A reformist Russian Government is reluctant to return them for fear of stirring nationalist reaction at home. Yet without a commitment to their return, Japan is withholding substantial aid and investment that could propel Russia down the road to reform and recovery.
The impasse is not in America's interest. Washington wants its longtime ally Japan to regain what is rightfully Japan's, the islands Stalin seized at the end of World War II; and it needs Japanese capital to help Russia's economy. 
 With Washington's encouragement, the new Government in Tokyo could break the impasse. Tokyo could cough up more aid now and pledge a package of economic investment, promising to deliver it once Russia agrees to return the islands eventually. Limiting U.S. naval operations in the area could soften Russian military objections.
In 1956 Nikita Khrushchev offered to return the smaller two of the four islands with the signing of a peace treaty, but withdrew the offer in 1960 when the U.S. and Japan renewed their security treaty. In 1987 and 1988, Mikhail Gorbachev informally tried to revive the two-island formula but Japan was unwilling to accept that without some acknowledgment of Japanese sovereignty over the other two. It refused to offer substantial aid until that happened. But in March 1991 Ichiro Ozawa, then Secretary General of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, informally discussed an exchange of $26 billion in aid for eventual reversion of the islands. Now that Mr. Ozawa is the power behind the new Japanese Government, he could officially put that offer back on the table.
Efforts by the Russian Foreign Ministry to bridge the gap with Japan have run afoul of Russian nationalists, especially in the military, who fulminate about the loss of empire. That has discouraged initiatives from Japan.
Washington could encourage Japan to come up with more aid now, similar to the $50 million Tokyo is providing to help Moscow dismantle its nuclear arsenal. Giving aid in advance, far from weakening Japan's leverage, would avoid the appearance of trying to buy the islands that so infuriates Russian nationalists.
Washington can also reassure Russian admirals who fear the U.S. Navy could use the islands to pen their nuclear-armed submarines in the Sea of Okhotsk. The U.S. can pledge to slow the tempo of its naval operations in the area and avoid provocative maneuvers.
The U.S. has much to gain by brokering a deal that moves relations between Russia and Japan off the rocks.
