HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Cuomo Hits Hustings On the Backstretch

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo drove into the stable area at Saratoga Race Course at 9:15 this morning, checked the horses in Sally Lundy's barn, shook hands with some trainers between workouts and then got down to business: his campaign to reorganize racing in New York State.
 For the next four hours, working both sides of Union Avenue, he first met with officials of the horse owners and trainers on the backstretch and expressed support for their drive for higher purses and no shutdown of winter racing. Then he went to the Hall of Fame across the street, met with the trustees of the New York Racing Association and expressed hope for a joint attack on the problems besetting the business. 
He did not berate racing officials as fat cats and bad managers, as he has done in the past. But in his main message of the day, he told both sides that he would resist any shutdown of racing next winter for economic reasons. The racing association says it lost $9.5 million racing in bad weather last winter; the trainers say 3,500 jobs would be lost if they didn't race all winter.
 "We think winter racing generally is essential," he said, standing on the grass between the barns. "We know that N.Y.R.A. has a problem because winter racing costs money. But we want to see winter racing this year. If the Legislature doesn't come back this fall and do it, we'll try to deal with it ourselves."
 
Higher Purses a Goal
 In one of his few barbs on a day marked by conciliation, the Governor said: "I don't like the idea that N.Y.R.A. tells backstretch people they'll cut health insurance while they're still riding around in Jaguars."
 The Governor also said that he wanted higher purses but didn't know where the money would come from; he expected N.Y.R.A. and the Off-Track Betting Corporation to cooperate on a merger, and he would not lower the takeout on winning bets unless progress was made in solving the other problems.
 "We want N.Y.R.A. and O.T.B. to merge on their terms, not ours," Cuomo said. "We're insisting on some sort of unification, but we're not telling them how to do it. We don't want to do it by creating a greater government presence in racing."
 Allan R. Dragone, chairman of the board of trustees of the racing association, said later: "We had a very good meeting with the Governor. It was most frank and gracious. We promised to be as cooperative as possible. So, we shall see what we can get done."
 On the issue of winter racing, Dragone said: "We'd like to continue winter racing but not lose $9.5 million, as we did last year."
 The Governor was invited to Saratoga by the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association, which represents 3,000 owners and 300 trainers in New York. He picked a day when the 30 trustees of N.Y.R.A. were scheduled to hold their monthly meeting. He was accompanied by Vincent Tese, the state's director of economic development and chairman of the Governor's Advisory Commission on Racing in the 21st Century, which proposed in June that N.Y.R.A. and O.T.B. negotiate a merger but did not tell them how to do it.
 Albert Fried, president of the horsemen's group, said after the meeting: "When was the last time the horsemen met with the Governor? I don't know that we ever met."
 Cuomo also broached the issue of the New York Yankees, who have been threatening to leave the Bronx.
 "They may be dragooned to New Jersey, and New Jersey would pay for it with casino gambling," he said. "Some guy in the Bronx is going to say: Why not us? I've never pushed casino gambling, but it's an inevitable question that will come up.
 "And you can't go to the Meadowlands and play as the New York Yankees. You think of Babe Ruth, you think of New York. You win pennants, you draw people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo with Albert Fried, right, president of New York Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association at Saratoga. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Where AIDS Advances, Understanding Lags;
On Long Island, Patients Describe Suburban Exclusion Unmatched in Cities

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NESCONSET, L.I.

 BODY:
Peeking out from the clutter of papers on Anthony and Susan Scardace's refrigerator is testimony to a time of euphoria, before AIDS gave the family a guided tour through the dark side of suburbia. It is a snapshot of Mr. Scardace cradling his daughter, Victoria Marie, whose day-old face shines pink and impossibly playful.
The picture was taken at Mid-Island Hospital in Bethpage six years ago, where Mr. Scardace was a popular employee in the purchasing department. 
 But like a Polaroid photograph in reverse, the world captured in the picture has since dissolved. Victoria fought a series of AIDS-related ailments before she died of cystic fibrosis at 15 months. Mr. Scardace, who believes his supervisors mistakenly concluded he had the disease after seeing insurance claims for his daughter's treatment, became a kind of invisible man, steadily stripped of responsibilities and shunned by his co-workers.
 
Unmatched Isolation
 And Mrs. Scardace, who has not told her own family that she has AIDS, listens to relatives call the disease a God-driven thinning of the human herd, eliminating homosexuals, drug addicts and minorities.
These are the quiet ravages of AIDS on Long Island, which has the highest suburban rate of the disease in the nation. With 2,834 cases reported through the end of May, Long Island was the first suburb in the United States to qualify for financing under the Ryan White Comprehensive AIDS Resources Emergency Act, a Federal program that has funneled more than $2 million to Nassau and Suffolk Counties for transportation, clinics, food and dental programs for people with AIDS. Another 8,000 in Nassau and Suffolk have tested positive for H.I.V., and health-care experts estimate the true number may be double that.
Despite what experts call an epidemic on the Island, interviews with health officials, advocates and people with AIDS suggest that understanding of the disease and attitudes toward those it strikes lag far behind the progress of AIDS here. And while discrimination against AIDS patients is hardly unique to the suburbs, they describe an isolation unmatched in cities, where health centers, transportation and support services are more accessible, and sheer numbers make the illness less unusual.
The practical isolation is part of a deeper sense of exclusion. Many fear losing their housing, jobs, families and even friends, and weigh perceived slights against the dread possibility that word of their condition may have leaked out.
"You don't have a close-knit, cohesive community that can be a support system," said Jeffrey Reynolds, a spokesman for the Long Island Association for AIDS Care. "And the pervasive sense of denial is an obstacle to people seeking services and support."
"It forces many people into the closet, and that makes it very difficult to put a human face to AIDS," he added. "You're at an incredible risk of losing your job, your health insurance, your housing and being shunned by your neighbors." While legal protections against discrimination exist, he said, pursuing them is a drain that few people with AIDS can afford -- physically, financially or emotionally.
 
A Lack of Openness, Multiple Partners
 Despite scattered oases of openness on Fire Island and the East End, social life among gay people on the rest of Long Island largely consists of anonymous assignations at parking lots along major roadways and at bars -- a tendency that health experts and advocates say fuels the spread of AIDS. Men with multiple partners play a kind of sexual Russian roulette, while spouses unaware of the risk fail to take precautions.
"People who are homosexual in suburbia are going to be in that nuclear family situation, and that doesn't allow for a supportive monogamous homosexual experience, and they put themselves at enormous risk," said Louis Weiss, 27, who has worked in AIDS education on the Island since he tested positive for H.I.V. six years ago. "In being different that way, they've shortened their lives."
Mr. Weiss, who often runs AIDS-prevention workshops for teen-agers, said education is hobbled by a tendency among parents to avoid the issue. "It's left up to the schools, which are on that fence where they're trying to do the education, but getting the backlash from the P.T.A.'s and others."
Dr. Rose Walton, who trains health-care workers as director of the State University of New York at Stony Brook's AIDS Education and Resource Center, said the sense of secrecy runs so deep that many Long Island professionals who work with AIDS patients will hide the fact from their families and neighbors.
"I think we don't expect people to have AIDS in the suburbs," she said. "For the most part there's still a tremendous amount of denial. It's like, not in my backyard, but it's in everybody's backyard."
 
A Daughter's Denial; A Writer Feels Exiled
 Diana O., a mother of three who lives in Freeport, said a television reporter once came to interview her, but knocked on a neighbor's apartment door by mistake. A few months later, the neighbor moved; Diana still ponders whether news of her illness prompted the neighbor to leave.
In her own family, Diana spoke of her illness, but found relatives would no longer wash and cut her hair. "I have a daughter who tells people I have cancer," she said, and fell silent. "If that helps her out, it's O.K. If she's too ashamed to tell people her mother is dying of AIDS."
Patrick Daniels, a 57-year-old writer who is legally blind, believes that a local newspaper, The East Hampton Star, stopped publishing his freelance articles because a picture of him appeared on the front page of The New York Times in September 1992 with an article about older men with H.I.V. Although he agreed to be interviewed and photographed for the article, he clearly had not anticipated all the consequences.
He said The Star had accepted his work, which included book and music reviews, for five years, but has not published a word since the article about him appeared. Buried deep in one of his own articles, he had even mentioned his illness, but he believes it was the more prominent disclosure that led to his literary exile.
The loss of that role has changed the way he sees the bedrock of the East End community, to which artists, entertainers and a number of gay people flock each summer. "They have a facade of being awfully liberal, awfully understanding, awfully humane, but it's about a quarter-inch deep," he said. "What you have out here is real conservative. It's all right to come out of the closet if you stay in New York, but don't try it here."
Helen Rattray, publisher of The East Hampton Star, said that the recession had forced the newspaper to cut back its freelance budget, and that music criticism was "at the bottom of the list." She said the record of the paper, which won a 1987 award for its coverage of gay issues from the East End Gay Organization, was "beyond reproach."
"The point is we were cutting back on all kinds of freelance articles," Ms. Rattray said.
Still, Mr. Daniels is convinced that he was being shunned for his openness. The theme echoes through talks with patients struggling against the disease who speak of a second battle, often more taxing, to maintain their sense of dignity. And that often hinges on keeping secrets, even from the people they need most.
The Scardace family depended on the warmth of their families and Mr. Scardace's co-workers throughout their daughter's brief life. While Mr. Scardace testified anonymously on Capitol Hill in the hope his child could be given the drug AZT, which was then banned for children, colleagues, told only that the baby had cystic fibrosis, had a fund-raiser to help pay medical costs. The child died in 1988.
 
Exclusion Recalled, A Lawsuit Is Filed
 Mr. Scardace, who is suing Mid-Island Hospital for $5 million, dates his ostracism at work from the following year, when a new supervisor took over the purchasing department. Mr. Scardace believes that word of his daughter's condition leaked out.
A hospital official, a lawyer and the supervisor, Arthur Rego, denied discriminating against Mr. Scardace, and said those named in the suit had not even known of Mr. Scardace's wife's and daughter's condition.
But Mr. Scardace could not imagine why else he would be excluded from meetings and forbidden to speak with vendors. Virtually all his responsibilities went to other employees, his suit alleges.
His respect went next, he said. One supervisor would stand over Mr. Scardace's desk and complain, to no one in particular, of a foul odor, while another stopped addressing him by name, instead calling him "young man," he said. Co-workers apparently took their lead from their bosses, also ostracizing him, he said.
Phyllis Duntze, a former co-worker in the purchasing department, recalled the reaction of fellow workers who went along with Mr. Scardace's ostracism, though she did not know the family was suffering from AIDS. "There was a recession and everyone was fearful for their own jobs," she said in a telephone interview from her home in Wisconsin.
Mr. Rego, who has since left Mid-Island Hospital, said he did not eliminate, but "altered" Mr. Scardace's duties when he took over the purchasing department. He acknowledged that Mr. Scardace had not collected any unfavorable job evaluations at the time, but would not say what made him change Mr. Scardace's responsibilities.
He also said he "had no idea" that Mr. Scardace's wife and daughter had AIDS until he was served with the lawsuit. He referred further questions to the hospital's lawyer, Morris Tuchman, who also maintained that Mid-Island Hospital was unaware of the family's medical history and that it had not materially changed Mr. Scardace's 30-hour-a week job. Mr. Scardace also works full-time as a patrolman for the New York City Fire Patrol.
"Frankly, he gets the same salary in the same department working in the same job at the hospital, and in fact, he has a totally flexible schedule," Mr. Tuchman said. "It's very hard to articulate what it is that's been diminished. He's not sitting in a dark room all alone."
But Harold M. Weiner, who is representing Mr. Scardace, said the suit was really about Mr. Scardace's loss of standing and chances for advancement. "Despite what many people think, most people don't want to earn money for nothing," he said.
However the lawsuit is resolved, the turnaround among people who once embraced them has changed the Scardaces in fundamental ways. Though they have kept the illness a secret until now, Mr. Scardace has begun wearing a red ribbon to work. And the couple are braced for the reactions their public disclosure may draw from family members, at least one of whom has argued that people with AIDS should be placed in concentrations camps and exterminated.
Mrs. Scardace, who believes she contracted the disease when she was single and worked in a nursing home, once considered herself friendly and outgoing; now she avoids new friendships in the fear outsiders might peer into her kitchen cabinets and ask about the rows of prescription medicine. "I just don't have the energy for all the lies," she said.
Outside, the street seems idyllic; the laughter of children playing in the summer evening filters through the windows. Their house is nestled among others just like it, with neatly trimmed lawns and splashes of flowers. For a moment, it seemed nothing could disturb the tranquillity.
"It's because they don't know," Mrs. Scardace said, and gently closed the cabinet door.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 12, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday described the isolation felt by AIDS patients in suburban communities on Long Island.
It included a passage about the scarcity of opportunities for gay social life outside of parts of Fire Island and the East End, adding that such social life "largely consists of anonymous assignations" in parking lots and at bars.
 The statement was based on descriptions from people with AIDS, from their advocates and from other gay people on Long Island; the sources should have been specified.
Nevertheless, the characterization -- especially the word "largely" -- was overly general, and thus unfair.
The article should not have equated social lives with sex lives, and should have specified that the reference applied to some secretly gay Long Islanders, not gay people in general.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The ravages of AIDS have cut through suburbia, as well, where the isolation can be even more severe. "What you have out here is real conservative," said Patrick Daniels, a writer living in East Hampton, L.I. "It's all right to come out of the closet if you stay in New York, but don't try it here." (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: COURT BACKS PLAN TO PAY CUSTOMERS OF FAILED INSURER

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
A plan to rehabilitate the largest life insurance company ever to fail in the United States was approved yesterday by a New Jersey court. Under the plan, the 700,000 customers of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company will have full access to their money after a waiting period of up to seven years.
Unless it is delayed by legal appeals, the plan will finally give some sense of certainty to customers around the nation. The Newark-based insurer was taken over by the State of New Jersey in July 1991 after it became insolvent. 
 Under the rehabilitation plan, most customers will be guaranteed a minimum interest rate of 5 percent on their pension and life insurance savings while the company tries to rebuild its assets under state supervision. If they demand their savings before the company completes the rehabilitation plan, they will have to pay stiff penalties, starting with a loss of 45 cents on the dollar if they withdraw their money in the first year. But death benefits will be paid immediately.
 
 
Delays Cause Anger
 The rehabilitation process has been the greatest test to date of the nation's system of state-run guarantee funds that stand behind the financial products sold by insurance companies. Consumers who were owed money by Mutual Benefit, and banks that had made loans to the company and its subsidiaries, have expressed anger at the long wait, the low interest paid on their savings, and the uncertainty they have faced.
In his decision yesterday, state Superior Court Judge Paul Levy in Trenton rejected the objections of banks and other large creditors of Mutual Benefit that wanted to be treated the same as consumers in receiving access to their money as the company is slowly revived. If they had won, it would probably have meant less generous settlement terms for individual customers.
 
 
Creditors Study Decision
 A lawyer for the creditors said last night that they were still studying the decision and had not decided whether to appeal.
"We have made every effort over the past two years to insure that the company's policyholders are treated fairly," the New Jersey Insurance Commissioner, Samuel F. Fortunato, said yesterday. "We are pleased that the New Jersey court affirmed the principle that Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company's policyholders are entitled to priority over general and unsecured creditors."
In contrast to bank customers, whose accounts are guaranteed for up to $100,000 by the Federal Government, a customer with a policy or pension plan at a failed insurance company is paid from state pools. Each pool raises money by levying charges on all insurance companies that do business in the state. The funds are different in each state, however, and the protection they offer to different types of customers varies widely.
The failure of Mutual Benefit, which was founded in 1845 and was highly regarded in its field, involved such large sums and so many customers in so many states, that Mr. Fortunato determined that many customers would never receive all of their money if the company were liquidated and consumers were told to rely on their state guarantee funds.
Instead, after long negotiations between the insurance industry and state regulators across the nation, New Jersey developed a plan that would permit the company's new state-appointed managers to rebuild its assets over time. Real estate holdings, which the company has mostly been unable to sell, made up 63 percent of its portfolio at the time the company was taken over. The plan assumes that those properties can be sold or will increase in value in the coming years.
Like many insurers in the 1980's, Mutual Benefit sought to pay high interest rates on its investment products. To generate those competitive returns, it invested more than $5 billion in the real estate market and in leveraged buyouts of corporations. The company was taken over by New Jersey after the real estate market tumbled and anxious customers began to withdraw their cash.
Michael S. Meisel, a lawyer who represented the insurance commissioner and the company's rehabilitators in court, said yesterday that more than two years after its failure, Mutual Benefit had assets of about $8.8 billion while it owed $9.9 billion to individual policyholders and others.
 
 
Fear of a 'Meltdown'
 "If all consumers had been left to make claims against state guarantee funds, some would have been partly covered, some would have been totally covered, some would not have been covered at all," Mr. Meisel said. "It would have resulted in a meltdown of the company, and that would not have been in the public interest."
Under the current plan, customers who are not protected by their state guarantee funds will be protected by a consortium of 14 insurance companies that have volunteered to take responsibility.
One critic of the state guarantee fund system, Robert Hunter, the president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization in Washington, said yesterday that the fate of Mutual Benefit policyholders demonstrated that the guarantee fund system does not give consumers adequate protection.
Although many customers who have heard of guarantee associations think their savings will be paid to them quickly in case of a failure, Mr. Hunter said that in cases like this, the guarantee funds were never tapped at all. Rather, regulators told consumers that they would have to wait while new management rebuilds the insurers' assets.
"The thing that bothers me about all these wheeling and dealings is that nobody ever really activates the guarantee funds," Mr. Hunter said.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Praised by Control Board For Handling of Fiscal Problems

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The members of the State Financial Control Board, many of whom have criticized the Dinkins administration in recent months for its handling of New York City's fiscal problems, lavishly praised Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday for promising to take bold action after the mayoral election in November.
The timing was welcome for Mr. Dinkins, whose main opponent in the mayoral race, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate, has stepped up his attacks on what he describes as the Mayor's mismanagement of the city and its fiscal affairs. 
 The praise yesterday marked a major shift in the board's public assessment of the Mayor's commitment to fundamental, long-term changes in the size and structure of the municipal government. For much of the spring, many of the control board's seven members had expressed misgivings about the budget the Mayor proposed for the fiscal year that began on July 1.
In an extraordinary statement then, the board's three private-citizen members, appointed by the board chairman, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, said the Mayor was relying on questionable one-time revenues and had failed to take fundamental, long-term steps to shrink the size of city government to fit its revenues.
But yesterday, at an annual meeting in which the board reviewed the state of the city's finances, the members were full of praise for the Mayor. They explained their turnabout by citing substantive actions taken by Mr. Dinkins in the last two months to address short-term fiscal problems and by his promise to address the underlying, long-term problems after the election.
But the political context was unmistakable. The board members, most of whom are Democrats, were under considerable pressure to rally around the Democratic Mayor in a tightly contested re-election campaign.
The Governor, who appointed the three private citizens on the control board who had recently been so critical of Mr. Dinkins, said yesterday, "The Mayor can be proud of this solid fiscal record, which was accomplished in the face of an extremely severe recession."
And Stanley S. Shuman, one of the board's private members, read a prepared statement that he said represented the views of all three private members. Mr. Shuman said that they thought the Mayor had made "real progress" in reducing city spending over the last two months, that they were encouraged by a presentation made yesterday by the Mayor and that they now believed Mr. Dinkins had "assured his commitment" to taking bold steps to confront the long-term imbalance between the city's expenditures and revenues.
The city's fiscal affairs are always intertwined with politics, but seldom has the connection been quite so overt as it was during the control board's carefully choreographed, hourlong meeting at Governor Cuomo's offices in the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan.
The ostensible purpose of the meeting was for the board to take a vote, as it must by law each year, on whether the city's finances are in order. If the board decides, using complex standards, that the city's fiscal affairs are in disarray, it can vote to assert control over the budget, the kind of direct control that the board had when as it was created during the city fiscal crisis of the 1970's.
The board voted unanimously that the city's fiscal affairs were in order and that the board would continue to function as merely a monitor of the city budget, as it has since 1986.
 
'A Powerful Endorsement'
 And while virtually no one had suggested beforehand that the outcome was in doubt, the Governor hailed the vote as a significant victory for the Mayor. Mr. Cuomo called the vote "a powerful endorsement of the efforts of the city."
After the meeting, in remarks with reporters, the Governor insisted that the vote was important. "It's not perfunctory," he said. "This is test day. It's always in doubt, until it happens."
Mr. Cuomo -- who was criticized by some Dinkins supporters two weeks ago, when a state report that the Governor commissioned on the Crown Heights disturbances in 1991 sharply questioned Mr. Dinkins's leadership during the unrest -- said his praise for the Mayor's fiscal stewardship should convince people that he supports Mr. Dinkins politically and that he merely tries to speak honestly on the issues.
"That's my job as Governor," Mr. Cuomo said. "You have to tell the truth. Sometimes it helps and sometimes it doesn't."
Without mentioning them by name, the Governor took several jabs during the meeting at recent fiscal proposals by Mr. Giuliani and his running mate, Herman Badillo, the Republican-Liberal candidate for comptroller. Mr. Cuomo also employed self-mockery several times in congratulating the Mayor on balancing the city budget.
He noted once that Mr. Dinkins had balanced his budgets without resorting to what the Governor called "the schemes" that he has used to balance the state budget. Another time, Mr. Cuomo said, "I am very mindful that the Mayor has been able to do what I've been unable to do in Albany, and that is to produce balanced budgets on time with relative ease."
 
Too Optimistic
 Some board members indicated that they still had some concerns about the Mayor's budget for the current year. Several members said that they still believed some of Mr. Dinkins's assumptions were too optimistic and that he might have to revise the budget later in the year, as often occurs.
But the overall thrust of the members' comments were quite supportive. They said repeatedly that they had confidence in the Mayor's ability to keep the budget in balance, and they said they were encouraged by Mr. Dinkins's pledges to confront the city's long-range fiscal problems soon.
In individual remarks, board members credited Mr. Dinkins for having made more than $400 million in cuts to the municipal budget since late May, making it more likely, they said, that the $31.2 billion budget will remain in balance.
 
Fundamental Changes
 Many members also praised the Mayor for having appointed a panel of three distinguished former government officials, who are researching ways for the city to make fundamental changes in city expenditures and tax revenues that would achieve the long-term budget balance that board members and other fiscal critics have been demanding.
Mr. Dinkins appointed the panel on May 25, the same day that the three private members of the control board issued their critical statement -- the first time in 11 years that the private members had released such a statement.
The mayoral panel is to report back to Mr. Dinkins with its recommendations for broad actions to cut $2 billion a year from the city budget by Dec. 1, a month after the mayoral election. Donald Kummerfeld, a former deputy mayor who is a member of the panel, made it clear in a lengthy presentation to the control board that it would require "major changes" in the city government to produce such huge annual savings.
After Mr. Kummerfeld's remarks, Mr. Shuman, in his statement for the three private citizens, said, "We are encouraged by what we heard today from Mayor Dinkins and Don Kummerfeld."
 
Long-Term Problems
 He said the three board members were heartened to hear that the Mayor had committed himself to addressing the long-term problems, and that the city would no longer rely so heavily on the kind of nonrecurring revenues -- termed "one shots" by fiscal experts -- that it has used to solve short-term budget problems in recent years.
"We all agree that we can not repeat the kind of budget process which we had this year," Mr. Shuman said.
He also said he and other members were pleased that the Mayor had made substantial reductions in the budget in June and early July.
And he said that the goals of Mr. Kummerfeld's panel -- to propose large-scale changes that would save the city $2 billion a year through spending cuts and new revenues -- gave board members confidence in Mr. Dinkins's commitment to making bold, fundamental revisions in the city's finances.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Takes New Plunge Against Yen

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 13

 BODY:
The dollar continued its plunge against the Japanese yen in trading here today, hurtling downward toward an exchange rate of 100 yen to the dollar.
The dollar fell below 102 yen for the first time since modern exchange mechanisms were established after World War II. It was quoted as low as 101.80 yen early this afternoon before edging up to 102.35 yen later in the day, down 1.02 yen from the close of trading here on Thursday. 
 In late New York trading on Thursday, the dollar dipped to 102.91 yen, from 103.64 yen on Wednesday.
"This has all the signs of a pro-yen panic," Robert Alan Feldman, director of economic research for Salomon Brothers in Tokyo, said today.
Travelers and consumers who exchange money at less favorable rates than available on the currency market have already seen the dollar's value drop to less than 100 yen. At Tokyo hotels and at the currency exchange counters at Narita Airport, travelers were receiving 99.75 yen for each dollar today.
Propelling the yen's rise in the last two days was the release on Wednesday of figures showing that Japan's overall trade surplus for July had risen an unexpectedly sharp 28 percent from a year earlier. Its trade surplus with the United States was up 23 percent.
The figures fueled speculation that the United States might push for an even stronger yen to help cut the surplus, although Washington is no longer saying publicly that it wants the yen to strengthen. In addition, the surpluses leave Japanese companies with an excess of dollars they must eventually sell to convert back to yen.
Analysts said the yen has also been benefiting from its image as a safe haven from the currency turmoil in Europe.
Japanese officials raised new alarms today that the appreciation of the yen would make Japan's automobile and electronics exports less competitive and delay an economic recovery. Already, many analysts and industry executives have given up on a recovery occurring this year, a sharp departure from the sentiment a few months ago when some analysts were saying the economy had hit bottom.
The yen's rise is also prompting Japanese industries to move more production to other nations, spurring fears that Japan will lose manufacturing jobs.
"It is a serious situation," Hirohisa Fujii, the Finance Minister, said at a news conference this morning. He said Japan and other leading industrial nations should cooperate to stabilize currencies. Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa also expressed concern about the situation.
 
Up 18 Percent This Year
 However, Japanese officials have been making similar statements all year, but the yen has strengthened 18 percent since the end of 1992, when it traded at 124.65 to the dollar.
The Bank of Japan was reported to have intervened in the market today to buy dollars and sell yen. One currency trader, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that most of the demand for yen was coming from speculators outside Japan.
"We don't see much dollar selling by Japanese clients," he said. Many businesses here are closed this week for a traditional summer holiday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
A New Jersey court approved a plan to rehabilitate the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, the largest life insurer ever to fail in the United States. Under the plan, the company's 700,000 customers will have full access to their money after a waiting period of up to seven years. [Page A1.]
Shares of T2 Medical plummeted nearly 35 percent after the company said its earnings in the first and second quarters were far lower than previously announced because of "certain accounting irregularities and errors." [D1.] 
 Continental Airlines won't appeal Tuesday's verdict acquitting American Airlines of setting "predatory" prices with the purpose of driving Continental and Northwest Airlines out of business. [D3.]
Caterpillar will halt production of bulldozers for two weeks next month at its East Peoria, Ill., plant. [D3.]
Mercedes-Benz and BMW are planning to produce tiny, environmentally friendly city cars. [D3.]
I.B.M. is suing Conner Peripherals, accusing it of infringing I.B.M. patents for disk-drive technology. [D3.]

General Electric agreed to compensate New York commercial fishermen because of PCB contamination of Hudson River spawning grounds for striped bass. [B5.]
 
The Economy
Government data showed a continuing weak economy in which inflation is abating and retail sales have increased only sluggishly. That is good news for bond investors and for Clinton Administration officials counting on low interest rates. [D1.]
Floundering boat makers may have found a lifeline in a flat marine market. Several manufacturers have turned from monohull production to building catamarans, which are sailboats with two hulls, and trimarans, which have three hulls. [D1.]
Canadian worries have emerged as a sticking point in the negotiation of essential side accords to the North American Free Trade Agreement. [D1.]

International

HEADLINE: Trying Out New Image: The Combative Giuliani

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Shoulders hunched, his lips pursed, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor, punched and swiped at City Hall this week like a shadowboxer chafing to go glove to glove. After initially holding to a campaign memorable mostly for its positive visions of a future filled with safe streets, good schools and an expanding job base, Mr. Giuliani suddenly shifted his strategy by relying on a combination of put-downs, cold humor and even a slick background paper on the city's slow demise -- complete with graphs.
By week's end he had painted a vivid picture: that of a Mayor who is out of touch or often out on tennis courts, disengaged from the details of running the nation's largest city and prone to giving unwavering support to inefficient subordinates at badly managed agencies. Mayor David N. Dinkins, he asserted, has created a government that cannot meet a deadline, is riddled with incompetence and devoid of ideas. 
 "In the last few years, we've seen the basic quality of the management of the city decline," he told supporters early in the week. The greatest achievement of the Dinkins years, he said at another stop, has been the creation of an administration "effective at finding excuses for failure."
It was an older, more familiar Rudy Giuliani on the stump. While ads pounded away at his new image as a kinder, gentler candidate (still stung by childhood injustices and ever loyal to the Yankees), last week he sought out one group after another to court votes and bare his teeth.
 
A Warning Flare
 The reason for the shift toward a more combative strategy may be found in poll results that show him neck and neck with the Mayor and the numbers essentially static. Or it could just be a natural release of tension from a candidate who shouted, "Shut up! Shut up!" to supporters on the night of his defeat in 1989 and shouted epithets at a police rally at City Hall. Either way, the oratory marked a shift in tone and sent a warning flare to City Hall.
Through the week the Mayor mostly rode above the squall, stopping to interrupt his schedule only to scoff at the charges or defend his programs and progress. But staff members released a flurry of paper to counter specific charges and alert reporters to every perceived inaccuracy.
After Mr. Giuliani charged that the Mayor had pumped up the city's budget with $55 million in anticipated revenue from the sale of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, Edward Lewis, OTB's chairman, sent the candidate a three-page letter in which he countered Mr. Giuliani's assertions point by careful point.
 
'The Real Facts'
 "I am presenting here, for the record, the real facts, to stop this nonsense once and for all," he wrote. He contradicted Mr. Giuliani's contention that OTB is losing money and said Hazel N. Dukes, its president, has reduced operating expenses by $12 million, cut the work force by 19 percent, computerized the payroll and closed marginal branches.
When Mr. Giuliani attacked the Mayor's budget, a news release was out by dusk comparing "Giuliani claims" with City Hall "facts" and ridiculing him for calling the national recession "brief and mild." But the harshest cut was the counter that Mr. Giuliani, "in an attempt to fuel his campaign with some substance," had in fact modified City Hall programs and called them his own.
"Actually, they changed their story," Cristyne Lategano, Mr. Giuliani's press secretary, said the next day. "First they said his plan was all wrong. Then they complained that it was their plan all along."
The sparring left the Dinkins administration on the defensive and Mr. Giuliani elated. By dawn yesterday the challenger sounded almost out of breath on a morning radio show. "The mayoralty has grown out of control," he said on "Rambling With Gambling" on WOR-AM. "He has a kind of imperial style."
Hours later, he was cheered in a drizzle as he accepted the endorsement of the Uniformed Firefighters Association and charged that the administration was "incapable of doing anything even remotely on time."
Only rarely did Mr. Giuliani mention the incumbent by name. He didn't have to. Instead, he spoke of tennis courts and administrative bloat and then repeated his new mantra of good management.
When he left the campaign spotlight this week, he often relinquished it to surrogates with the same theme. Herman Badillo and Susan D. Alter, two Democrats who have joined the Giuliani campaign to run for comptroller and public advocate, appeared with him as his financial plan was unveiled. Both have agreed with charges that City Hall is overstaffed and inefficient and have vowed to cut their staffs by 10 percent, if elected, to match Mr. Giuliani's pledge to make cuts in the mayor's office.
But Mr. Giuliani's most colorful backer, and the one who seems to have an almost innate touch for New York City politics, was Curtis Sliwa, the head of the Guardian Angels, who rides the Giuliani wave at many public gatherings, his red beret bobbing above a sea of dark suits.
 
'Really Out of Touch'
 In Brighton Beach last weekend, Mr. Sliwa praised Mr. Giuliani, then took a city-sized poke at the Mayor. "There are these people who act like they would rather not be in New York," he said. "They'd rather be at a banquet at night with a cummerbund or maybe out hitting a tennis ball."
Leah Johnson, Mr. Dinkins's campaign press secretary, said Mr. Giuliani's assaults this week were filled with distortions and untruths. "Mr. Giuliani's recent commercials show that he is the one who is really out of touch," she said. "Mr. Giuliani is harkening back to some past time and manipulating nostalgia rather than really talking about the future."
The Mayor, she said, has spent four years working in the neighborhoods of the city to rebuild communities and strengthen the city. "Mr. Giuliani has done nothing in the neighborhoods in that time," she said. "He just is trying to get people to feel sentimental about the way things were."
Still more irritating, she said, was Mr. Giuliani's campaign promise to slash 35,000 jobs from city payrolls. "His whole financial plan is just a lesson in municipal Reaganism," she said. "His proposals are simply ludicrous."
If Mr. Giuliani kept his pledge to cut jobs while preserving services for children, public safety and cultural affairs, she said, he could not meet his quota. "If you deduct all those things, there are only 9,000 employees left for aging, health, transportation, sanitation, housing, general services, the Department of Investigation, corporation counsel, building and several other agencies," she said. "It's impossible."

HEADLINE: Now, Canada Objects on Trade Pact

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Canadian concerns have emerged as a sticking point for the first time in the negotiation of side agreements for the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Prime Minister Kim Campbell has rejected a compromise crafted by her own negotiators on labor and environmental safeguards for the accord, apparently resisting giving import-blocking power to United States companies that could be used against Canada. Analysts also said she was taking the tough stance partly for domestic political reasons. 
 Ms. Campbell is expected to speak by phone with President Clinton in a last-minute effort to resolve sticking points, Canadian officials said today.
"We have a bit of an impasse with our partners in the negotiations," she told reporters in Ottawa.
 
Positive Cast
 The Prime Minister said she hoped that the matter could be resolved "because I think we'd like to move ahead with the agreements."
Most aspects of the North American trade accord that have been viewed as problems in the United States have involved Mexico. Canada's cooperative role was more or less assumed; Washington and Ottawa already have their own accord, which took effect at the end of 1988.
The hardening now of Ottawa's position appeared to block plans by the trade chiefs of Canada, the United States and Mexico to initial an agreement in the next few days.
The Canadian stance was disclosed as reports from Mexico City indicated still another impasse, this time over pressure by the United States and Canada for the right to sue Mexico in its own courts for noncompliance with proposed environmental safeguards. A Mexican Government document obtained by the Reuters news agency said the possibility of suits "attacks the concept of sovereignty and is, as such, inadmissible."
The three Governments have been working for months on side agreements intended to appease American critics of the broad accord. The critics insist on some formula that could lead to trade sanctions against companies found to abuse national labor or environmental standards. Their main objective is to prevent Mexico from using the accord to attract companies that pay exploitative-level wages or pollute the air or water.
While Washington has insisted on binding provisions in the side agreements, Ottawa has resisted proposals that put new tools that could block imports in the hands of American companies. It fears that these might be turned not just against Mexico, but against Canada as well. "Our position is that they're quite unnecessary," Ms. Campbell said, adding that disputes were best resolved by using the Canadian legal system.
More than three-quarters of Canada's trade is with the United States, and Canadians are already nettled by American actions against important exports like steel, wheat and lumber.
"I think the Canadian Government is very keen on having a deal, but it cannot sell one to the public and to industry that increases our exposure to American protectionism," said Daniel Schwanen of the C. D. Howe Institute, a research institute here.
Canada's Parliament has already ratified the basic agreement, which would convert North America into a free-trade area of 360 million consumers with a combined gross domestic product of perhaps $6 trillion. Lower trade barriers, proponents of the accord say, would increase business opportunities and bolster growth and employment in all three nations.
President Clinton said during the fall campaign that the side agreements were pivotal in his support of the agreement. Some top Democrats in Congress say they will oppose the pact if the side deals do not require Mexico to overhaul labor rules and stiffen environmental protection.
Canadian analysts said they thought Ms. Campbell, who has been in office less than two months and faces elections by the end of October, was trying to establish credibility with the public. Standing up to Washington would hardly hurt that kind of strong image.
"There is certainly a little posturing in all this," said Alasdair Sinclair, a trade expert at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia. He and many others are convinced that Canada, having gone this far in the talks, will not back out, and that it is simply a question of finding an appropriate formula.
The dispute focuses on the power of the three-nation commissions that would identify infringements of labor and environmental standards. Under a Canadian proposal, the panels could fine a guilty party. Only as a last resort would trade sanctions be permitted.
But though this idea originated with her Trade Secretary, Tom Hockin, Ms. Campbell said it was not good enough and authorized an official to state her position to journalists. To some this suggested a rift with Mr. Hockin, though that could not be confirmed.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tom Hockin, the Canadian Trade Secretary, speaking after the last face-to-face talks with his United States and Mexican counterparts. (George Tames for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: G.E. to Pay Fishermen Over Polluted Striped-Bass Waters

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 12

 BODY:
Ending an eight-year fight, the General Electric Corporation has agreed to compensate New York commercial fishermen for income they lost because of PCB contamination of Hudson River spawning grounds for striped bass.
Under an agreement reached out of court Wednesday night, G.E. will pay up to a total of $7 million to 300 to 400 fishermen, including as many as 150 eastern Long Island baymen, who can prove they lost income as a result of a state ban on fishing for striped bass from 1986 to 1990 in marine waters off Long Island, and since 1976 in the Hudson River. 
 For 30 years until 1977, General Electric dumped PCB's into the Hudson, and only last month the company agreed to stem a new flow of PCB's into the river from a plant in Hudson Falls, 35 miles north of Albany.
The river is a major spawning ground for striped bass, a delicacy that once accounted for a large part of the yearly income for hundreds of commercial fishermen, including the dwindling number of full-time baymen on eastern Long Island plying a livelihood that dates from the Colonial period.
 
Lobster Pots or an Outboard
 "It's become an ever more difficult task to live a life full-time on the water," said Arnold Leo, the secretary of the East Hampton Town Baymen's Association. "This money could help buy a new truck, or get some lobster pots or a new outboard motor."
The company said it agreed to the settlement in part because the legal action had lasted eight years and "would take at least another decade to conclude." The plaintiffs included eastern Long Island baymen and fishermen from New York City and the Hudson Valley.
The company said it had agreed to create a fund of $7 million for claims made by the fishermen, which will be evaluated by a court-appointed neutral referee.
"Only those claimants who can demonstrate real economic loss will receive any money from the fund," G.E. said. There will be a cap on payments to individuals, the company said, but it did not give the amount.
 
Company Admits Little
 A G.E. spokesman, Jack T. Batty, declined to disclose whether the company faced other PCB-related lawsuits or had entered into other settlements stemming from the dumping of PCB's into the Hudson River from the late 1940's until 1977, when the company voluntary ceased the practice. He said the settlement did not mean the company was admitting that the PCB dumping may have caused damage to striped bass or lost income for the fishermen.
Congress banned the manufacture of PCBs, short for polychlorinated biphenyls, in 1978 after research showed that the chemical, which was used as an insulator in transformers, was highly toxic to fish and other animals.
The State Department of Environmental Conservation imposed a ban on commercial fishing for striped bass after amounts of PCB in the fish were found to exceed Federal limits, which were set at 5 parts per million in the late 1970's and lowered to 2 parts per million in 1986.
PCB, which is also a suspected carcinogen, was found to have accumulated in the fatty tissue of striped bass caught in the Hudson, New York Harbor and Long Island Sound and off the South Shore of Long Island. The fishermen say the chemical entered the fishes' food chain in the spawning grounds.
 
From Carolinas Northward
 After spawning in Hudson riverbeds, the maturing striped bass swim south into the East River, into New York Harbor and east into Long Island Sound and the Atlantic Ocean. They range near the coastline from the Carolinas northward, and also spawn in large numbers in Chesapeake Bay.
Mr. Leo of the East Hampton Baymen's Association and several other commercial fishermen were plaintiffs in a suit filed against G.E. in State Supreme Court here. The trial was to have begun on Aug. 19, but was postponed. The judge in the case, State Supreme Court Justice Mary Werner, must act on the settlement.
General Electric has said for years that PCB was discharged into the Hudson River from its plants in Hudson Falls and Fort Edward under permits granted by New York State.
In June, the owner of an industrial site in Albany, Vantrano Realty, sued G.E., complaining that a state-approved PCB cleanup plan the company is carrying out would fail to clean up the site. The suit is pending in State Supreme Court in Albany.
 
Settlement Cheers Baymen
 News of the settlement bolstered the eastern Long Island baymen. They have bitterly complained that state regulations have sharply limited the number of striped bass commercial fishermen may take during the season from July to November.
"It's just crazy that we are allowed to harvest so few of them," said Mr. Leo, who objected to state regulations allowing sport fishermen to catch up to one fish a day from May to December. He said the commercial limit for the baymen was set at 46 fish each season despite the abundance of the fish in offshore waters this summer.
Gordon C. Colvin, the director of marine resources for the department, said the restrictions on eastern Long Island were part of a conservation effort agreed to by 13 East Coast states where stripers range.
"There is no question that there is a substantial increase in the number of striped bass going on right now," said Mr. Colvin. "But that is exactly what is intended by the cooperative management program the states have agreed to."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Sometimes a Great Notion in a Prospectus Is Only That.

BYLINE: By Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
FEW things spook investors more than a company that goes insolvent. After all, earnings are the centerpiece of the stock investment game, and if a public company cannot even meet its financial obligations, investors run for the hills.
But with the gambling mentality of investors in 1993, a private company that is insolvent and is looking to pull itself out of the hole with public investment capital often looks just dandy. So it was with Hillside Bedding Inc., a retail mattress company based in the Bronx, that went public in February. 
 Hillside admitted in its prospectus that it repeatedly was unable to pay its financial obligations and that it was insolvent at the time of the offering. But, the prospectus said, the offering would change all that as the company used the money to settle old debts and start a huge expansion of its stores.
The expansion strategy won over the marketplace. At the offering, investors plunked down $17.20 for each unit that consisted of one share of common stock, one share of preferred stock and two warrants. The common stock began trading in the $8 range.
How are investors doing with their bet on the expansion strategy? The common share price has dropped sharply, but that could hardly be attributed to expansion: Hillside abandoned the strategy not long after it came public. And the company has not yet come around to letting its investors know.
In its prospectus, the company, which operates in metropolitan New York, listed some 20 stores it has in the region. A check of those stores showed that 12 -- or 60 percent of those in operation some six months ago -- are no longer open. Investment bankers who work with the company confirm that 12 stores have closed although they add that Hillside has also opened a few stores.
That could only be disappointing news for investors who were looking for the results of that expansion. Already, investors have seen their holdings shrink. Hillside stock, which reached a high last month of $10 a share, has been falling in recent weeks, closing yesterday at $3.875, down 25 cents in Nasdaq trading. That collapse has largely been the result of disappointment about the cancellation, by mutual agreement, of a foreign stock offering announced in May.
How can a company that was supposed to be growing actually be shrinking? Morton Swirsky, Hillside's chief financial officer, was said to be out of the office yesterday, and other executives did not return a telephone message.
But the company's investment bankers said Hillside simply decided to switch strategies -- something the company apparently planned to do all along, regardless of what the prospectus said.
"One thing Hillside didn't disclose in its prospectus, and I don't think it had to disclose, was its intention to operate differently in the New York market," said Keith Gil, a senior partner with Duke & Company, the investment banking firm that brought Hillside public. "Just opening more stores is not the answer."
That will surely come as a shock to anyone who has read the prospectus. "The company believes that its failure to operate profitably in the periods referred to above has been due, in part, to its inability to achieve economies of scale based on the number of company-owned stores in operation during those periods," the prospectus states in reference to the times the company failed to pay its bills. In other words, Hillside was going broke because it did not have enough stores.
These days, the company is talking about a joint venture with a competitor, Dial-a-Mattress. And it is rethinking its strategy in other ways that it has yet to announce.
"They feel and I feel that in the future they will be doing certain things that make it clear why they are closing stores," Mr. Gil said. "When that happens, people will know about it."
Let's hope that the strategy is something in which the investors actually want to invest.

HEADLINE: Sailing's New Course: Multihulls

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

 BODY:
The racing multihull has a formidable reputation in sailing, one of lightning speeds and scary rides. But a less intimidating breed of cruising boat is emerging, one that has become a lifeline for companies foundering in a flat marine market.
Several boat makers have turned from monohull production to building catamarans, which are sailboats with two hulls, and trimarans, which have three hulls. 
 The new multihulls are being redesigned with the cruising sailor in mind. They have roomy cabins built over the hulls, full galley areas, one or more staterooms -- instead of open bunks -- for sleeping, and full heads.
For some builders, the new direction seems to be working. Island Packet Yachts, a sailboat manufacturer in Largo, Fla., came out with the first multihull in its traditionally monohull boat line last October. Bill Bolin, the marketing manager for the company, said it had 21 orders for its $225,000 35-foot catamaran.
 
'A Big Boost'
 "In dollar value, the cats are now 40 percent of our business," Mr. Bolin added. "It has been a big boost."
Part of the selling job for manufacturers is in overcoming a public perception that multihulls are too wild for the average sailor. Pushed to the extremes, a racing multihull can be demanding. With nets stretched from hull to hull instead of a solid deck, such a multihull requires a trampoline artist to get from side to side.
Cam Lewis, a professional yacht racer from Vinalhaven, Me., recently sailed with a French crew in a record-setting 80-day voyage around the world. Mr. Lewis later described what it was like to cross the netting of their boat, an 86-foot catamaran, on a bad day: "It's like walking on a water bed in the back of a pick-up truck driven by a crazed teen-ager in New York City on a rainy winter night at rush hour," he wrote in Sailing World magazine.
But the new designs in multihulls require far less frantic sailing than their racing cousins. Multihulls ride on top of the waves like a waterbug, rather than pushing through the water as a monohull does, so there is less resistance. A multihull will stay relatively flat at sea rather than heeling, or leaning on its side, as a monohull with a keel will do.
The cruising multihulls are not as sleek as most of the all-out racers. But they also have less tendency to bury a bow in a wave, or sail like a hobbyhorse over choppy seas. And they still tend to be faster than a monohull of equal size.
Hugh Taylor of Martha's Vineyard, Mass., had sailed monohulls for 32 years, then switched to a 50-foot catamaran last year. His brother, the singer James Taylor, still sails a traditional wooden boat, but Hugh Taylor wants nothing of it. He charters his new catamaran, a custom design by Chris White of South Dartmouth, Mass., taking tourists to nearby islands accessible mainly by boat. In the winter, he plans to take the cat to the Bahamas for his own use.
"I'll never go back," Mr. Taylor said recently about his fondness for catamarans over monohulls. "Catamarans are fast, and don't take on any water. They are dry and stable. The stigma of them being capsizing boats is wrong."
 
An Increase in Popularity
 Mr. Taylor is one of a growing number of boaters enamored with the multihull. Sally Helme, a spokeswoman for International Marine Holdings, a consortium of marine accessories companies, which is based in Stamford, Conn., said her group had seen an increase in the popularity of multihulls in the last five years.
Ms. Helme said fewer than 10 percent of the 14,510 new sailboats built in 1988 were multihulls, compared with 12 percent to 15 percent of the 10,583 sailboats built in 1992. More significant than the numbers was the shift in the size. In 1988, at least 97 percent of the multihulls built were less than 20 feet long. In 1992, new multihulls were larger, with fewer than 60 percent in the 20-foot range.
Corsair Marine, of Chula Vista, Calif., went into business in 1986 for the sole purpose of producing trimarans. At that time the boating market was beginning to show the signs of a nose dive, a plunge that went off the deep end in 1989. But Corsair has weathered the slump comfortably.
It has sold 500 trimarans since then. They vary from a $40,000 24-foot boat to a $58,000 27-foot trimaran fully outfitted. The boat design includes a unique system for folding the two outer hulls, or amas, into the center hull so they collapse like gull wings when the trimaran is transported by trailer.
Sailboats make up 3 percent to 4 percent of the boats sold in the United States, according to the National Marine Manufacturers Association, based in Chicago, which tracks mostly powerboat sales, and International Marine, based in Stamford, Conn., the sailboat arm of the industry.
 
Far From Healthy
 The sales numbers are down from the industry's high point in 1988, when 14,510 sailboats were sold. In 1992, 10,583 sailboats were sold, up from the 8,672 in 1991. But the market is far from healthy.
Boating analysts have attributed the stagnant sales to the recession and the 10 percent luxury tax imposed in 1990 on new boats with price tags of more than $100,000.
The manufacturer's association had estimated that the tax, which has reduced sales of big powerboats and sailboats, cost the marine industry more than 20,000 jobs. The tax was repealed in President Clinton's tax package that passed last week, largely to rectify the job losses.
With full recovery a distant dream for the 112 sailboat manufacturers still in business in the United States, multihulls offer new opportunities.
PDQ Yachts, based in Whitby, Ontario, has also used the multihull to build a new business in lean times. John Farrow, the general manager of the PDQ office in Annapolis, Md., said the company had to expand its range of catamarans -- adding a third model to its line of 36-footers -- to keep up.
"This is the first year catamarans have gone mainstream," he said about the boats' growing prominence on the Annapolis waterfront.
Not everyone shares this optimistic view. Everett Pearson, a boat builder in Warren, R.I., and the president of a new sailing industry trade group, the American Sail Advancement Program, said most of the catamarans sold in the last few years were going into the charter boat industry.
"There really isn't that big a market," Mr. Pearson said.
 
Boats for Private Use
 Mr. Bolin of Island Packet Yachts disagreed. He said all but two of the buyers of the company's new 35-foot catamarans had bought the boats for private use.
"We were amazed at the inquiries after we announced the boat to the public last July," Mr. Bolin said. "We are still getting inquiries, two-to-one, the catamaran over our monohulls." Island Packet produces five monohull models, from 29 to 44 feet.
At $225,000 fully equipped, the catamaran is about $60,000 more than the company's 35-foot monohull. But the catamaran is almost as roomy as Island Packet's 44-foot monohull, which costs about $255,000.
Jeanneau, a French company that is one of the biggest boat builders in the world, with $100 million in sales last year, introduced its first multihull to the United States market, the Lagoon 37, last year. Since then, it has sold 22 of the $230,000 boats.
"There is an escalation of interest," said Wayne Burdick, the director of Jeanneau North America in New London, Conn.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Despite Rain, Denver Is a Mile High for the Pope

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, Aug. 12

 BODY:
There was rain, thunder and lightning, even a double rainbow in the evening sky.
But the skies could do nothing to compare with the exhilaration that filled Mile High Stadium upon the arrival of Pope John Paul II. For hours, young Catholics attending the World Youth Day events here this week had been streaming into the stadium, where they swayed, sang, clapped and danced to throbbing music from nations around the world. 
 The tension erupted into ear-splitting cheers for each step of the Pope's arrival: the helicopters setting down outside the stadium, the slow progress of the Popemobile inside and the opening of Pope John Paul's greeting: "I greet you all in the name of Jesus Christ. He is the way, the truth -- and the life!"
Separate sections of the stadium broke into flurries of shouts and flag-waving as the Pope named individual countries with young representatives at the event and offered greetings in different languages.
Jennifer Clifford, a 20-year-old junior at South Dakota State University who lives in Martin, S.D., struggled to explain her excitement. "You know how teen-agers go ga-ga over rock stars," she said. "Well, he's the rock star of our church."
There was religious seriousness amid the celebration. "Of course we are here to listen to one another, I to you and you to the Pope," the Pope told his audience. "But above all we are in Denver to hear the one true Word of Life." He asked the young people to give up their Friday midday meal and contribute its cost to an African hospital serving AIDS patients.
 
Hymns on Wheels
 As she boarded the 16th Street bus this morning, Monica Lonardo could tell it was no ordinary rush hour in Denver.
"People were singing hymns," said the 22-year-old jewelry saleswoman. "On the bus! At 8:30 in the morning!"
Songs echoed through downtown Denver in dozens of languages today, even during the rain, as 160,000 Roman Catholics from 70 countries celebrated the arrival of Pope John Paul II for World Youth Day. "Some people are so happy they cry," said Birgitte Nyavist, a 15-year-old German girl, who wore a floppy cowboy hat and a pair of new blue jeans.
To earn money for the trip here, Miss Nyavist said she tended her grandparents garden and cleaned their house for months. Other visitors said they held bake sales and went door to door for donations.
After the Americans, who are represented by 120,000 people here, the largest contingent is from Italy, with 12,000, followed by Spain and Canada, with about 7,000 each, and Mexico with 6,000. There are three participants here from Angola, and two from Ethiopia.
Many of the young Catholics wore T-shirts that read "I Got a Mile High With the Pope" and foam-rubber headgear cut in the likeness of a papal miter. And they shouted and waved and gave thumbs-up signs to other groups.
"Where are you from?" shouted a boy in one group. "We're from North Dakota."
"Italy," came the answer.
And there followed a round of applause for both Rome and Fargo.
Many of the foreign visitors arrived in the United States a week or so before the Pope's appearance. Nicole Widman, an 18-year-old from Lucerne, Switzerland, ticked off the big events on her trip across the West. "Hollywood studios, Grand Canyon, Rocky Mountains," she said, "and the Pope, of course."
 
Nothing to Sweep Up
 It has been called the "Catholic Woodstock," but it bears more resemblance to a well-mannered field trip.
The police have had virtually no disturbances to quell, despite the huge crowds.
Dean Dominguez, a janitor who usually spends the noon hour sweeping the sidewalk and collecting the garbage near his office building, instead was leaning on a broom, marveling at the tidiness of the visitors.
"These people are so neat and clean it's unbelievable," said Mr. Dominguez, who figured that littering must be considered a serious sin. "There's nothing to sweep up. They see a scrap, they pick it up. I've never seen anything like it."
 
They Must Be Fasting
 To hear the disappointed restaurant managers tell it, the young Catholics came to Denver with the Ten Commandments and a $10 bill -- and they're determined not to break either one.
"Business is off drastically," said Chris Myers, the owner of the Crocodile Cafe, which is usually packed at lunchtime, but today had plenty of empty tables. "All the Denver people got scared away by the hype and figured, 'We better get out of Dodge.'
"Meanwhile, we've got all these kids in town with no money. And the few 'papal people,' as we call them, come in and order the cheapest thing on the menu, and water. Of course, they're more into praying than boozing."
The World Youth Day gathering was expected to pump nearly $150 million into the local economy. Instead, stores and restaurants were sending workers home.
Tourism officials said it was all worth it, however, especially given the publicity to Denver from the 3,000 journalists here.
"People who have never thought much about Denver are watching their televisions and seeing the sun over the Rocky Mountains," said Rich Grant, a spokesman for the Convention and Visitors Bureau. "We couldn't buy this kind of attention."

HEADLINE: Clinton Hails Midwest Courage Against the Flood

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12

 BODY:
President Clinton today made his fourth trip this summer to the Midwest, this time to sign legislation providing $6.2 billion in Federal assistance to farmers and other victims of the record flooding there.
Mr. Clinton also paid tribute to the heroism of ordinary Americans in responding to the crisis. Among 19 citizens from nine states whom he honored was a 32-year-old maid from North Dakota who dived into a flooded basement apartment to rescue a trapped resident. 
 The President called such courage representative of a spirit that helped to avert wider disaster. Although the worst of the flooding is over, he said the region would continue to need help as it struggled to recover.
"It is easy to forget that much of the work remains to be done," Mr. Clinton said. He urged Americans to "allow our humanity to help reclaim the lives that are shattered."
The Federal aid package will grant reimbursements for some crops lost under high water and provide for the rebuilding of public works and housing ruined by the floods. The size of the aid more than doubled from $2.5 billion as the bill made its way through Congress, but even that will fall far short of covering the total damages, now estimated at more than $12 billion.
 
Borrowing in Emergency
 A fact sheet distributed by the White House listed $5.7 billion in new spending to be provided under the bill, but aides to Mr. Clinton said the measure would also allow about $500 million in money already appropriated by Congress to be devoted to flood relief.
Because Mr. Clinton insisted that since the flood was an emergency its costs should not be borne by tax increases or spending cuts. The Government will have to borrow money to pay for the relief package, meaning that its cost will be added to the budget deficit.
Mr. Clinton stopped in St. Louis on the way to Denver for his meeting with Pope John Paul II. The President is on his way to Oakland, Calif., as he begins a weeklong trip combining business with some vacation.
Those who received the Presidential commendations were selected by the governors of their states, but Mr. Clinton brought his wife, Hillary, and his daughter, Chelsea, to lend a personal touch to the celebration. He admired the tie of one man and accepted T-shirts, a cap and a coin from others as he mingled with 17 of the recipients and with the relatives of another, a National Guardsman who died in an accident as he assisted in the flood relief.
 
Varieties of Heroism
 The 14 men and 5 women were from North Dakota, South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Minnesota, Iowa, Missouri, Wisconsin and Illinois, the states hurt the most by the floods.
They included a South Dakota man, Doug Koch, who rescued victims on his Jet Ski, and a Nebraska state trooper, Mike McCann, who saved a family of seven threatened with drowning as their van was swept by flood waters.
Donna Marie Harsche, the North Dakota maid who was among the honorees, climbed through a below-ground window and went under the water to pull a man to safety on July 15 as his basement apartment filled with water from a flash flood.
Mr. Clinton, whose departure from Washington followed several trying weeks, said the flood could serve as a metaphor for any disaster.
With the record high waters, Mr. Clinton suggested, nature had once again issued a reminder "that we need to live our lives with a little more humility and always understanding that we are not in full control."
 
Revealing Reactions
 He declared, "How we face these misfortunes tells us a lot about ourselves and our friends." And he called upon Americans to salute the heroes of the flood "by firm resolve to go back about the business our daily lives as Americans, rolling up our sleeves and not wringing our hands."
"We know we cannot contain the fury of a river," Mr. Clinton said. "But we can and we must allow our humanity to overflow as well, to help to reclaim the lives that are shattered. That is what I have seen happen here in the Midwest."

Heavy Rains in Flood Areas
 By The Associated Press
 Still staggering from weeks of flooding, the upper Mississippi River Valley, was hit with a new round of heavy rain early yesterday that caused flash flooding, closed roads and evacuations.
Storms dumped up to 10 inches of rain in some sections of Minnesota and deluged parts of Missouri, Nebraska, Iowa and Illinois.
"If anybody's got a direct line to the Lord, tell him we surrender," said Pete Staude, general manager of the newly reopened Capitol Plaza Hotel in Jefferson City, Mo.
Rainfall of 5.5 inches early yesterday left 3 to 4 feet of water in the hotel's parking lot. The hotel had reopened on Monday after being closed for 11 days because flood waters blocked its doors.
The National Weather Service reported rainfall up to 8 inches from about 10 P.M. Wednesday to 3 A.M. yesterday in parts of Missouri hit hard by flooding over the past month. In Iowa, thunderstorms dumped 2 to 4 inches of rain across the southern and central parts of the state Wednesday night, flooding streets in Des Moines.

HEADLINE: Closing Arguments Heard by Jury In a Trial of 2 Ex-Detroit Officers

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 12

 BODY:
A prosecutor argued today that the beating death of a drug suspect had resulted from the police asserting "raw and naked power," while a defense lawyer called it a "life-and-death struggle."
In closing arguments, the Wayne County assistant prosecutor, Doug Baker, described a former officer, 53-year-old Larry Nevers, as an aging Detroit policeman proving his virility when he repeatedly clubbed the suspect, Malice Green, over the head with his heavy metal flashlight. 
 "This is grim determination," Mr. Baker said. "He is not going to be bested by this man in front of anyone else. It's the assertion of raw and naked power over Malice Green."
 
'Flushed With Victory'
 When the beating was over, Mr. Nevers was "the picture of a man covered with blood, his club covered with blood, flushed with victory."
Mr. Nevers and his former partner, Walter Budzyn, 47, are charged with second-degree murder. They face a maximum penalty of life in prison if convicted.
Mr. Green, 35, died last Nov. 5 outside a suspected crack house. He was confronted in his parked car by former Officers Nevers and Budzyn, who asked for his driver's license.
Witnesses say the beating began when Mr. Green, an unemployed steelworker, refused to open his clenched fist, which various witnesses said held either drugs, keys or a scrap of paper.
"It's a contest of wills," Mr. Baker said of Mr. Nevers's response. "And he's got the club, and he's beating, and it's not going to stop. This was the ultimate abuse of power. The real crime of Malice Green was that he affronted power, he didn't obey."
 
'Life-and-Death Struggle'
 But Mr. Nevers's lawyer, John Goldpaugh, said Mr. Green had done more than disobey a command to open his clenched hand.
Mr. Nevers testified that Mr. Green had grabbed the handle of his gun. He said he had been defending himself when he hit Mr. Green over the head five or six times with his flashlight.
"In Officer Nevers's mind and in Officer Nevers's heart is a life-and-death struggle," Mr. Goldpaugh told jurors.
When Mr. Green could not get the gun, he grabbed for his pocket knife, but pulled out keys instead, Mr. Goldpaugh said.
Mr. Goldpaugh described his client as a brave and decent man devoted to law enforcement.
"No, he can't run as fast as he used to," Mr. Goldpaugh said. "I don't know if he could ever jump that high. But he had experience. He knew the precinct. He thought he was making a difference."
 
Third Officer Also Charged
 A third officer, Robert Lessnau, 33, who arrived on the scene later that night, is charged with assault with intent to do great bodily harm and faces a maximum penalty of up to 10 years in prison if convicted.
Arguments by Mr. Budzyn's lawyer are scheduled for Friday, with jury deliberation to start on Saturday. Arguments for Mr. Lessnau, whose fate will be decided by Judge George W. Crockett 3d of Detroit Recorder's Court, will be heard on Monday.
Judge Crockett agreed earlier this week that jurors could consider reduced charges of manslaughter against former Officers Budzyn and Nevers.
A fourth officer, Sgt. Freddie Douglas, faces trial later on a misdemeanor charge of willful neglect of duty.
