HEADLINE: Police Scandal Is Giving Germans an Inside Look at War Against Terrorists

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, Aug. 12

 BODY:
A spectacular police scandal that has broken over Germany is giving people here their first inside look at the clandestine war between the police and terrorists that has been under way in this country for more than 20 years.
The scandal has all the elements of a spy thriller, complete with a top-level informant, a wild shootout at a rural train station and the prospect that two commandos from the country's most famous police squad may soon be charged with murder. 
 After a member of the terrorist Red Army Faction and a commando from the legendary GSG-9 police squad were killed in a botched ambush on June 27, Interior Minister Rudolf Seiters and the chief federal prosecutor, Alexander von Stahl, were forced out of their jobs. The scandal has continued to spread, and today prosecutors announced that they were considering charging two GSG-9 agents with "deliberate killing." Witnesses say one of the agents killed a Red Army member as he lay helpless in police custody.
In the wake of the June 27 assault, Germans have learned that for the first time in more than two decades of trying, detectives had managed to plant an informer inside the highly secretive Red Army Faction. They hoped that his work would ultimately allow them to stage a major operation aimed at destroying the group, but the June assault led to his unmasking and subsequent disappearance.
 
Bombing Allowed to Proceed
 The informer's work was considered so vital that when he told the police in March of terrorist plans to blow up a newly built prison, they allowed the attack to proceed rather than bring suspicion on him. The bombing virtually destroyed the prison, causing an estimated $100 million in damage.
Since the bloody shootout in June, much public attention has been focused on the figure of Klaus Steinmetz, 33, who for most of his adult life has been involved in leftist and anarchist protests in and around the cities of Wiesbaden, Mainz, Darmstadt and Frankfurt. In the mid-1980's, he helped organize a boycott of the national census, a "die-in" at an American military base and protests against the visit of President Reagan. He is also said to have taken part in several attacks against private and government property.
For most of the time Mr. Steinmetz was engaged in these actions, he was also a police informer, apparently recruited after he was arrested for petty crimes. Detectives monitoring radical groups in the area found his information useful, but it was only last year, after he received an extraordinary offer from the Red Army Faction, that he become one of the most important police informants in modern German history.
Red Army leaders had responded favorably to a January 1992 initiative by Minister of Justice Klaus Kinkel, now Foreign Minister, urging them to call off their campaign of killings in exchange for better treatment and possible early release for their jailed comrades. They issued a statement pledging to stop killing "leading representatives of the economy and the state" while they awaited further Government moves.
As part of their developing new strategy, the Red Army Faction decided to establish ties to militant leftists who lived legally and were not engaged in terrorism. In a series of clandestine meetings, Mr. Steinmetz became the first such contact.
 
First Infiltration
 In February 1992, Mr. Steinmetz traveled to Paris to meet Birgit Hogefeld, a Red Army member whom the police had been seeking for years. Their conversation marked the first time a police agent had been accepted into the Red Army Faction's inner circle.
"The detectives were electrified," Der Spiegel reported after the operation collapsed. "They had tried many times to place a spy in the core of the R.A.F., but had never come close to succeeding. Their man Klaus did it."
Mr. Steinmetz met Miss Hogefeld once more, and also met other Red Army members, reportedly including one who is wanted in connection with the group's last two victims, Alfred Herrhausen, chief executive of Deutsche Bank, and Detlev Karsten Rohwedder, head of the government agency charged with selling off formerly state-owned companies in eastern Germany. It was from those contacts that Mr. Steinmetz learned of plans to blow up the jail near Darmstadt.
On June 27, Mr. Steinmetz traveled to the eastern German town of Bad Kleinen for a third meeting with Miss Hogefeld. Another wanted Red Army member, Wolfgang Grams, was also present. The three met at the local train station, and as they walked through an underground passageway, the police opened their assault. It was later revealed that 54 police agents, most of them GSG-9 commandos, had been posted in and around the station.
Agents quickly wrestled Miss Hogefeld to the ground, but Mr. Grams fled up a flight of stairs. In a wild shootout in which 44 shots were fired, one GSG-9 agent was seriously wounded and another, Michael Newrzella, 25, was killed. Mr. Grams was not hit, and police agents managed to subdue him on one of the train tracks.
 
22 Witnesses Testify
 Twenty-two witnesses have reportedly testified that agents held Mr. Grams immobile for about 20 seconds, and that one of them then shot him through the temple from a distance of about two inches.
Unlike many other Red Army members, Mr. Grams was not wanted on charges of committing terrorist acts, but only of belonging to a terrorist organization.
In days after the assault, the full extent of the fiasco became clear. One GSG-9 agent had been killed, another had apparently killed a defenseless prisoner, and police had lost the best chance they ever had of penetrating the Red Army.
The subsequent finger-pointing not only cost Germany's Interior Minister and chief prosecutor their jobs, but also sparked calls for a thorough reorganization of the country's various police and security agencies.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl issued no statement about the criminal investigation opened today, but a few days after the shootout he visited the headquarters of GSG-9, to show his support for the unit, whose name in German, Grenzschutzgruppe, means border protection group. Later Mr. Kohl complained, "Much more is being said about the murderer of a police officer than about the officer who laid down his life."
 
Open Letter From Informer
 Mr. Steinmetz was "arrested" by police agents in Bad Kleinen who hoped they could conceal the fact that he was working for them, and he has not been seen since. Detectives close to the case have said that although Mr. Steinmetz knew that his meeting would be monitored by the police, he was not told that arrests would be attempted.
Soon after the assault, Mr. Steinmetz sought to defend himself in an open letter. Friends say he may have considered himself not a traitor, but a go-between who hoped he could negotiate a truce between the Government and the Red Army Faction.
For their part, Red Army leaders appear ready to resume the terror campaign to which they called a halt last year.
"If you don't allow us, that is, people who are fighting for a humane society, to live, then you must understand that your elites also cannot live," the group said in a statement after the Bad Kleinen shootout. "Even if it is not in our interest, war can only be answered by war."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A botched ambush in June in which a Red Army Faction terrorist and a commando from Germany's top police force were killed has led to disclosures that have given the public a look at a clandestine war that has been going on for more than 20 years. At the funeral last week of the terrorist, Wolfgang Grams, mourners accompanied the coffin behind the lead of a police officer in Wiesdan. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 14.26 Points as a Rally Sputters

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
An early rally by stocks aided by favorable data on inflation quickly fizzled yesterday. By the close, the Dow Jones industrial average had shed 14.26 points, to 3,569.09.
A contributing factor to the decline in stocks was the Treasury's auction of 30-year bonds, which did not go well and which pushed interest rates higher as a result. Higher rates do not bode well for an economic recovery. 
 The Labor Department reported yesterday that producer prices fell by two-tenths of a percent in July, and stocks rallied. But the Dow's failure to break through the 3,600 level after the better-than-expected news unleashed a wave of computerized selling programs, which immediately put stock prices under pressure.
The decline came as no surprise to some analysts who noted that the market had to work hard to set new highs recently on the Dow and the Nasdaq. Other indexes had not set similar highs, and traders said that if the market was robust, market barometers should move together.
 
 
A Delayed Reaction?
 Steven Resnick, senior investment strategist at Cowen & Company, saw yesterday's downturn as perhaps a delayed reaction by investors skeptical of the economic program in Washington.
"The recently passed budget was essentially an income-redistribution budget, and it will not be the last step," Mr. Resnick said. "And it's interesting that we didn't see a more immediate negative reaction by the market. This tells us something more important, which is investors, although they feel uncertain about Washington, are feeling positive about earnings reports in an overall weak environment."
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy, with 278.5 million shares traded, up from 268.3 million shares on Wednesday. The number of stocks that declined in price outnumbered stocks that gained, 1,075 to 849.
 
 
Rebound in H.M.O.'s
 Health maintenance stocks, or H.M.O.'s, rebounded slightly from a selloff on Wednesday. One trader said, "What usually happens after a bad breakdown is that the recovery doesn't fully make up for the smashing."
U.S. Healthcare, jumped 4 1/4, to 45 1/2, in heavy trading.
Elsewhere, gold stocks gave in to signs of low inflation in the producer prices report. Newmont Mining fell by 3, to 47 3/8.
The Labor Department's inflation report also showed a modest increase of one-tenth of a percent in food and energy prices. Analysts said this was the third consecutive report that showed inflation pressures under control.
Telefonos de Mexico, the Mexican telephone giant, fell along with other Mexican issues after Canada rejected a compromise on labor and environmental safeguards for the North American Free Trade Agreement. Telefonos' American depository receipts, which substitute for shares for many foreign companies, closed at 50, down 1 3/8.
Conner Peripherals Inc., a maker of computer disk drives, was down 3/8 to 11 1/4. I.B.M. sued Conner yesterday, accusing it of infringing I.B.M. patents for disk-drive technology. Conner denied the allegations. A Salomon Brothers analyst, Margaret Alexandre, raised her recommendation on the Equitable Companies to a "buy" from "hold," after the company reported better-than-expected second-quarter earnings. The analyst believes that the company has turned the corner of profitability. The stock was up 7/8, to 26 1/8.
Lands' End, the mail-order retailer said its second quarter earnings rose to 20 cents a share, compared with 14 cents a year earlier. Analysts had forecast earnings of 17 cents a share. The stock rose 2 3/8, to 32 1/8.
National Golf Properties, a real estate investment trust, made its initial public offering yesterday of 9.7 million shares priced at 20 3/8 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell 0.2% in July

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The Government released reports today showing a weak economy in which inflation has continued to abate and retail sales have grown sluggishly. That kind of "no news" is good news these days for bond investors and Administration officials counting on low interest rates to keep the recovery going.
Producer prices slipped two-tenths of a percent in July, the Labor Department reported today, after declining three-tenths of a percent in June. The falling prices charged by manufacturers and farmers offered further evidence that the inflationary pressures that were worrying the Federal Reserve this spring are unwinding and signaled that the floods in the Midwest had not unleashed much inflation. 
 At the same time, consumers seemed to turn more cautious. Retail sales edged up just a tenth of a percent last month, the Commerce Department said, largely because consumers were not buying as many cars and trucks and gasoline was less expensive, which reduces total sales revenues. While the report was not as weak as it looked at first glance -- spending on everything other than cars and gasoline rose five-tenths of a percent -- consumers were clearly settling down after a spring splurge.
 
Unemployment Claims Lower
 In a separate report, the Labor Department said that new jobless claims drifted down in the first week in August to 332,000, evidence that the job market is firming, but only slowly. That decline -- slower than the Administration would like -- mostly reflected the reopening of factories by the General Motors Corporation after a two-week shutdown. In fact, the four-week moving average of claims is at its highest level in four months, suggesting that the labor market is not likely to put upward pressure on wages soon.
The reports cheered bond investors, who pushed yields on 30-year government bonds to another low, 6.39 percent, in the morning. Yields rose again later in the day after a poorly received Treasury auction.
"It's a pretty benign atmosphere," said Edward McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The economy is growing slowly, and it's not generating inflation. But growth also doesn't appear to be dangerously weak either."
Today's bond market reaction was welcome news to the Clinton administration. Although the economic recovery is about half as robust as past ones, big public works projects are out of the question and the Administration is pinning its hopes for a lasting recovery on low long-term interest rates. It hopes these will stimulate private business investment and exports.
 
Long-Term Prospect
 The economic reports suggested that the economy is likely to remain subdued for a while.
As of July, prices at the producer level -- covering about a third of the economy -- were just 1.3 percent higher than a year ago and were heading down despite floods in the Midwest and drought in the South, which are hurting crops and raising corn and soybean prices. For the moment, the prospect of higher feed prices has prompted farmers to slaughter more beef and pork than they had planned and that is leading to lower meat prices.
 "This is a very big economy, and the Midwest is only one part of the index," said Tom Tibbetts, assistant commissioner for industrial prices at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "We could still get some effects, but the effects will be small."
Oil is one force on the side of deflation. Flush inventories and the expectation that OPEC will keep pumping more oil have pushed oil prices down to less than $18 a barrel from $21 a year ago.
 
Consumers Are Wary
 More important, though, are weak sales and heightened cost-consciousness among customers, both of which are making it difficult for businesses to raise prices. Excluding food and energy prices, prices edged up just a tenth of a percent in July, after falling by a like amount in June.
"We're working very hard, but we haven't raised prices yet," said Mary A. Lyons, president of Lyons Tool and Engineering, which has been supplying Ford for decades. "If you want to raise the price you have to show the product can do more."
Meanwhile, consumers, who spent the spring making up for their lack of spending early in the year by driving more than two million cars and trucks off dealers' lots, turned less expansive. Based on the July data, David Kelly, an economist at Economic Advisers Inc. in Boston, expects retail sales in the quarter that began in July to grow at just half the spring's annual rate of 7 percent.
The Commerce Department, which frequently revises its retail car sales figures substantially, reported that dealers' sales revenues, which include service, parts and used cars as well as new cars, dropped seven-tenths of a percent in July.
 
Lower Prices
 But some of the declines in sales dollars -- from grocery stores to drugstores to service stations -- reflect lower prices rather than less buying. Drivers, for example, are using more gasoline than expected this summer.
Consumers did spend somewhat more freely at department stores, clothing stores, furniture stores and building supply outlets last month.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Demand for 30-Year Bond Turns Weak

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
It could not have been a better warmup for a Treasury auction. The Producer Price Index for Finished Goods fell two-tenths of 1 percent in July, providing a little better inflation news than expected, and retail sales came in just up a barely noticeable one-tenth of 1 percent.
This left the Treasury selling 30-year bonds at a time when new data reassured traders, investors and speculators that inflation was in check, and that economic growth would not pick up enough to awake worrisome inflationary fears any time soon. 
 Add the fact that the Treasury is cutting its annual sales of 30-year bonds by 40 percent and it seemed that yesterday's auction of the 30-year bonds should have gone well.
But it did not. On the third day of the Treasury quarterly auction, traders, investors and speculators suffered a little indigestion as they bought the last $11 billion of the week's record $38.5 billion sale of 3-, 10- and 30-year securities. It appeared that dealers wound up with more 30-year bonds at too high of a price than they could stomach, so they started selling.
The sloppy auction put a chill on the long end of the market in the afternoon. The price of the old 7.125 percent 30-year bond due in Feburary 2023 rose more than half a point after the inflation report and the yield on the new bond in pre-auction trading slipped to 6.30 percent.
But by late trading, the yield on the new 6.25 percent 30-year bond due in August 2023 was up to 6.36 percent while that of the old bond was up to 6.44 percent, from the 16-year low of 6.42 percent set on Wednesday. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
Only the shorter end of the market ended with any gains, as the low-inflation and slow-growth themes further reduced fears of a Federal Reserve move to raise short-term interest rates soon. The discount rates on Treasury bills moved lower and the two-year note wound up unchanged at a yield of 4.05 percent.
Some traders suggested that there might be some lingering discomfort, which means traders and investors might sell for a few days as they regain their bearings. But that kind of market correction would be expected anyway, with yields for long-term debt at or near their lowest levels in more than 20 years.
"This does not necessarily end the trend to lower rates but it disrupts it," said John Costas, managing director of government trading at the First Boston Corporation.
Where the market heads after a short-term selloff, if there is one, will depend on whether the 30-year bond, which seems to be trading to a different beat than the rest of the market, continues to rally.
Some analysts are betting that the yield on the 30-year bond will fall enough to wipe out the spread, or differential, between the yield on the 10-year note and the 30-year bond. When comparing the yield on the 10-year note sold Wednesday and the yield on the new 30-year bond,that spread was 60 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
But other analysts wonder if the market has not already factored in all or most of the good news. They are not sure if the inflation numbers will continue to improve. And they are more confident that the economy will begin to pick up pace.
Mr. Costas of First Boston said the reason the 30-year bond auction did not go well "was simply the result of supply and demand not lining up." He said that it appeared that as the 1 P.M. bidding deadline approached, buyers decided that the new issue was just too pricey.
Jay Goldinger, a trader at Capital Insight in Los Angeles, said that given the positive inflation and economic backdrop for the bond and the expected impact of the Government's sharp cut in the total bonds that it would sell, many traders were just scared to go into the auction short -- that is, without holding the new bond. Otherwise, they would lose in a rally. So they bought them in the when-issued or pre-auction market, where issues trade in advance.
But, Mr. Goldinger said, that meant there were not many dealers who needed to cover short positions from having sold the new issue in advance. And that, in turn, reduced demand in the auction because few dealers had to bid aggressively to assure they would get the new bonds.
Because of the technical problem created by the switch from the old bond to new bond as it becomes the current issue after an auction, comparisons of where interest rates have moved can be confusing.
With one comparison, yields on both the old and new 30-year bond rose slightly yesterday, with the price falling from Wednesday's levels. The yield on the old 7.125 percent bond rose to 6.44 percent from 6.42. The yield on the new 6.25 percent 30-year bond ended at 6.36 percent, up from 6.35 percent in when-issued trading the day before.
But when the yield on the old bond, as it finished trading Wednesday, is compared with the yield on the new bond in the when-issued market yesterday, the yield fell, from 6.44 percent Wednesday to 6.36 percent yesterday.
By any measure, the average auction yield of the 30-year bond of 6.33 percent was the lowest since the Treasury began regularly issuing the bonds in May of 1977.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Continues to Retreat; Prices of Soybeans Plunge

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Gold prices dropped sharply again yesterday after the Government reported that its Producer Price Index fell by an unexpected two-tenths of 1 percent in July.
And in another sign of the lack of inflationary pressures, the Commodity Research Bureau index fell to a six-week low, pulled down in part by the selloff in precious metals, as well as a plunge in soybean prices after a surprising Government crop report. 
 On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery fell $7.90 an ounce, to $367.40. December gold, the most actively traded contract, dropped $8 an ounce, to $370.70. Meanwhile, September silver lost 12 cents an ounce, to $4.558.
"People are resuming their belief that we're in a deflationary market," said Jim Ayer, manager of the $160 million Gold and Special Minerals Fund at the Oppenheimer Corporation. "My prediction is that gold holds at $365."
Gold has fallen more than $40 an ounce after peaking around $410 in early August following a four-month buying frenzy fueled by concerns about inflation, increased demand from Chinese investors and turmoil in the European Community's Exchange Rate Mechanism.
"Low inflation and the changes in the E.R.M. spelled death for gold," said Jim Steel, an analyst at Refco Inc. "I don't think the gold market will recover from this. It won't be going back above $400 an ounce anytime soon."
A decline in demand for precious metals from East Asia also weighed on the market, said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber in New York. "Waning demand from the Far East hurt," Ms. Savaiko said. "And the P.P.I. really hammered home the reality that inflation isn't a problem, leaving people questioning why they're long gold."
Meanwhile, soybean futures plunged to a six-and-a-half-week low after the Agriculture Department's crop report showed less damage to the soybean crop than traders had expected.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, soybeans for November delivery fell 27 1/4 cents, to $6.56 a bushel. Other grain futures also declined. December corn lost 3 cents, to $2.44 1/4 a bushel. And December wheat lost 9 1/2 cents, to $3.11 1/2 a bushel, a one-month low.
The department projected the 1993-94 soybean crop at 1.902 billion bushels. Although lower than last month's estimate of 1.975 billion bushels, it was higher than traders had expected.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners Take Steps To Prevent A Strike

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KOHLER, Wis., Aug. 12

 BODY:
After a second day of marathon meetings, major league club owners tonight failed to reach agreement on the thorny issue of revenue sharing, but they took steps to remove the players' primary reasons for following through on their threat to strike next month.
After 28 hours of plotting, calculating and negotiating, two groups of owners adjourned without resolving their differences over how to get the richer clubs to help their poorer brethren. 
 While declaring his disappointment to forge an agreement but also his confidence to do so in the future, Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, tried to defuse the issue of a possible strike.
He pledged that the owners would not lock the players out of training camps next spring, and he said they would not declare an impasse in negotiations during the winter, meaning they would not try to change the work rules, such as for salary arbitration.
"The fans and the public are preoccupied with the pennant races, which they should be," Ravitch told a news conference. "It would be irresponsible to set an artifical deadline whatsoever in terms of achieving our understanding with the union. I want to make it clear right now whether this happens in September or shortly thereafter that in no way will the opening of the season be jeopardized by any actions of the owners."
 
Rich Teams' Veto
 While Ravitch's remarks were a bold statement of the owners' intentions, they seemed designed also to dilute the negative outcome of the two days of meetings here at the American Club resort.
"Though I'm obviously disappointed that we didn't achieve closure on a plan today," Ravitch said, "I believe an enormous amount of progress has been made."
The effort to reach an agreement on an increase in the amount of local revenue the clubs share was scuttled by a 10-team group of richer teams: the Yankees, the Mets, Los Angeles, Toronto, Boston, Baltimore, Colorado, Florida, Texas and St. Louis. The California Angels had been part of that group during most of a four-hour session Wednesday night, but Jackie Autry did not return to it today.
 
Shuttle Diplomacy
 Although proposals, counterproposals and variations on both went back and forth between the two groups of teams and progress appeared to have been made during the second half of the 15 hours of meetings today, the two sides in the end could not conclude the business Ravitch had brought them here for.
In effect, he said he will continue the shuttle diplomacy he used during these meetings, moving back and forth between the groups trying to secure their agreement.
"That is a process I will continue," he said. "I'll set up a mechanism to do that. I hope to tell you in the very near future there is total agreement among the clubs on how to redistribute revenue among themselves so we can meet our obligations to the players under the new economic system we will be proposing to them."
The owners' inability to adopt a new revenue-sharing plan will further delay the start of negotiations with the players. The owners voted last Dec. 7 to reopen the collective bargaining agreement that expires Dec. 31.
If the owners can adopt a new plan, they will ask the players to accept a salary cap, something the players always have opposed. Any new revenue-sharing plan would be contingent on the players' acceptance of a cap.
 
Depart in Darkness
 The owners, after meeting jointly and in two separate groups for 15 hours, departed under cover of dark, at 11 P.M., Central time, in six vans.
Emerging from their meeting at the American Club resort in groups of two and three, the owners left grim-faced and unsuccessful.
"Any agreement is a success," Ravitch had said earlier in the evening. He did not say what no success was.
The owners tried to put the best face on their failed efforts.
"It was a good meeting," Bill Giles of the Philadelphia Phillies said. "We're close."
Andy MacPhail, general manager of the Minnesota Twins, said a lot of progress was made, adding: "This isn't the end of the thing. The mood was upbeat."
George Steinbrenner of the Yankees had no comment on the failed talks. "What was the final score?" he asked, referring to his team's game in Boston.
In a late-afternoon development, the group of richer clubs sent a proposal to the others, triggering an exchange of proposals that resulted in what some owners viewed as significant movement.
"We're making progress," John Harrington of the Red Sox said before heading for a telephone to find out the outcome of the same game.
Harrington declined to disclose details of his group's proposals, but another member of that contingent said they centered on percentages of local revenue that would differ according to the markets, with the larger-market clubs paying a greater percentage of the total figure needed for the player payroll pool.

HEADLINE: $25 and Under

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov

 BODY:
On sunny days, Johnny's Reef Restaurant dances to the nostalgic beat of summers gone by. For 41 years, families, friends and lovers have come to this seaside restaurant at the southern tip of City Island, an incongruously small-town part of the Bronx in Long Island Sound, tenuously connected to Pelham Bay Park by a narrow bridge.
Getting to City Island is part of the fun. For first-timers, there is a shock on exiting the urban asphalt of the Bronx for the pastoral green of the park, and then a secondary shock on crossing over to City Island and entering what seems to be a small fishing village, with its boats and cottages. Of course the restaurants that line City Island Avenue, the island's main drag, make clear that the island's economy is largely dependent on hungry visitors. 
 Johnny's is at the end of the line, a rambling structure built on a slab of concrete jutting into the Sound. Inside, an assembly line of seafood "by the ton," as a sign says, is dished up cafeteria style, with the accent on things fried. Huge portions are handed out on paper plates, with plastic utensils, and carried on cardboard trays to either plastic tables inside or blue metal picnic tables outside, where dining is accompanied by serenading gulls and power boats.
But the restaurant is only partly about food. The good-time family atmosphere is the attraction, in maybe one of the few places where New York's polyglot ethnicities gather together in multi-generational groups. You may watch teen-agers still sandy from nearby Orchard Beach, or overhear a father seizing on the opportunity to be authoritative to his inquisitive youngster:
"Daddy, what are those buildings across the water?"
"That's Connecticut." (Actually, it's Kings Point, L.I.)
"Daddy, what are those wires above us?"
"Uh, those are for putting a tent up in bad weather." (Actually, they are fishing lines, strung above the picnic area to discourage diving gulls.)
Fortunately, Johnny's is a place where children can run off and toss french fries to the gulls, leaving exhausted parents a small window of tranquillity. Use that time to sample Johnny's best wares, mounds of greaseless fried shrimp on beds of fresh fried potatoes ($10), or fine fried oysters ($12). Fried whiting fillets ($6) were also good, though you must watch out for little bones, and a pile of steamed shrimp ($10), in a bright yellow butter sauce, tastes of the sea, in this case a garlic sea.
Corn on the cob ($1.75), served criminally flaccid, should be avoided.
All this is best washed down with big cups of beer or iced tea, though Johnny's has a full bar should the need strike.
The best time may be after the meal, for people-watching or just gazing out to sea at passing boats and birds. Or for walking up City Island Avenue for ice cream. At dusk, teen-agers cruise the avenue in cars as they do in any small town. For the truly nostalgic, there is a miniature golf course nearby, perhaps the perfect dessert.
Johnny's Reef Restaurant
2 City Island Avenue, City Island, the Bronx, (718) 885-2086. (Reachable by car or by taking the No. 6 train to Pelham Bay Park, then the Bx 29 bus.)
Best dishes: Fried shrimp, fried oysters, fried whiting, steamed shrimp.
Price range: $6 to $18.
Credit cards: Cash only.
Hours: Sunday through Thursday, 11 A.M. to midnight; Friday and Saturday, to 1:30 A.M.
Wheelchair access: Everything is on one level.

SECTION: Section C; Page 2; Column 3; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 549 words

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Basketball as a Metaphor for the Game of Life

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY

 BODY:
Theater for the New City has been touring the boroughs with its summer street program since the late 1960's, and it still exudes a strong whiff, as identifiable as sandalwood incense, of the decade that spawned it. Founded by George Bartenieff and Crystal Field, longtime fixtures of the Greenwich Village arts scene, the company mixes blatantly homemade sets, costumes that might have come from the bargain bins at Canal Jeans, quasi-Brechtian didacticism and a do-your-own-thing style of performance. These elements are shaped into a noisy theater of protest that blends right into the curmudgeonly hubbub of the New York streetscape in its dog days. The results are crude, chaotic and preachy, but everyone involved seems to be having a lively time. 
 The troupe's current offering is "Don't Worry: We're All Gonna Be Rich," which made its debut in the East Village and will be performed throughout the five boroughs over the next six weeks. Its 50-member cast comprises both amateurs and professionals of widely varying ages and ethnic backgrounds.
Written and directed by Ms. Field, with music by Chris Cherney, the show is built around what is less a plot than a central metaphor, in which basketball becomes a symbol for the importance of playing as a politically right-thinking team in a corrupt world. A group of city boys, united by their love for the sport, passes from adolescence into adulthood as it grapples with the demons of contemporary life: drugs, AIDS, unemployment and a host of sinister predators -- variously dressed in desert camouflage fatigues, a suit made of moneybags, and a jacket tricked up with elaborate circuits of wires -- who represent the military-industrial complex.
Ms. Field doesn't sustain her basic conceit with much logic or even clarity. In essence, the show is an occasion for a series of energetic, improvisatory sketches, which range from the death of a drug pusher to a birth in a department store. There are some athletic dances, a few rap numbers and a mournful ballad (adapted from Tchaikovsky and Goethe), which Ms. Field, playing a mother whose son has died of AIDS, delivers in a touchingly off-key warble. The ensemble was coached by the former Harlem Globetrotter Roman Turman, but it is difficult to play basketball convincingly on a 20-foot stage, and the ball tends to slip onto the street.
Toward the end of the performance, the cast members hold up a numbing array of cardboard signs with slogans like "Stop U.S. Terrorism" and "No More Nuclear Testing," and one of them tosses a large pink ball into the audience, admonishing, "We've all got a big game comin' up." By that time, "Don't Worry: We're All Gonna Be Rich" has come to seem less like a play than a Washington Square rally.
 
Don't Worry
We're All Gonna Be Rich
Written and directed by Crystal Field; lyrics by Ms. Field; music by Chris Cherney; production and stage design by Anthony Angel; props by Orlando Caquias, Jason Schuler and April Asher; costumes by Ilona Somogyi and Jonathan Cross; sound by Paul Garrity and Nancy Mannon. Presented by Theater for the New City, Bartenieff-Field. Performed outdoors. Call (212) 254-1109 for locations.
 
WITH: Joe Davies, Michael David Gordon, Jerry Jaffe, Terry King, Mark Marcante and Craig Meade.

HEADLINE: A Dream of Riches Seduces the Middle Class

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The headline on "The Would-Be Rich vs. the Truly Rich" (Op-Ed, Aug. 6) by James Grant, publisher of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, inadvertently highlights the endemic upward mobility that has deposited him and many other upper-income -- but not rich -- Americans on the wrong side of the debate about the Clinton economic package. 
 In "The Culture of Contentment," John Kenneth Galbraith suggests the existence in this country of a "contented" class, defined broadly as those who believe their interests are served by the political process and consequently participate in it. The contented protest vehemently when their economic self-interest is threatened (for example, by higher taxes). Also, fearing some kind of economic domino effect, they rally to protect those richer than themselves from higher taxes.
Someone at the middle of the wealth heap would rather think of himself or herself as part of the upper two-thirds than as part of the lower two-thirds. Advertisers take advantage of this tendency, the vanity inherent in the American dream, with product positioning that they call "aspirational."
"How higher marginal income tax rates will help the rest of us educate our children, start a business or buy a ranch is beyond me," Mr. Grant writes. It is appalling that he dares to group himself with the middle class and to wonder how he'll get his kids a private education in the same breath.
It's time for the would-be rich to stop running interference for the rich and then crying "foul" when they're asked to put their money where their mouth is.
 
EVAN BAILY
New York, Aug. 6, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 349 words

HEADLINE: A Dream of Riches Seduces the Middle Class;
Trickle-Down Cruelty

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Budget That Will Backfire" (Op-Ed, Aug. 6) by John H. Makin of the American Enterprise Institute is shocking and incorrect. Shocking in his unfailing belief in the feeble school of thought known as "trickle-down economics," and incorrect for the view that trickle-down economics could cure our economic woes. 
 Perhaps Mr. Makin was absent from the planet Earth during the last 12 years of Republican rule; otherwise he would undoubtedly be aware that when America gave trickle-down economics a chance, the budget deficit rose astronomically and that, frankly, the rich got richer and the poor got poorer.
Trickle-down economics works with the same ruthless efficiency as the biological model of the food pyramid, that is, at each progressive level, only one-tenth of the energy consumed is passed on. This means that nine-tenths of the energy consumed stays with the consumers.
To put that in trickle-down terms, John makes $1 million, of which he uses $100,000 to pay his five employees, who pass $2,000 each (for a total of $10,000) on to 1,000 needy people. Of John's $1 million, the needy see $10 each or 1/100,000 -- hardly a fair distribution of wealth.
More important, however, trickle-down economics resembles the model of the food pyramid because it is based on survival of the fittest, kill or be killed and competition over cooperation. In trickle-down land, the tired and the poor are discarded by the privileged and the wealthy or, if they are lucky, are made ditchdiggers and caddies. Trickle-down economics is a system laden with injustice and devoid of compassion.
Since "The Origin of Species" was published and natural selection became a household phrase, humankind has forgotten the other great lesson of biology: that, while competition helps life evolve, it is cooperation that brings life about in the first place. President Clinton's budget package puts higher taxes on the rich not to punish the rich, but to end competition and also to inspire cooperation. And it will work.
 
RICHARD C. CASE
Springfield, N.J., Aug. 6, 1993

HEADLINE: Steel Decision Will Cost American Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "A Wise Decision on Steel" (editorial, July 29), you maintain that it is good for the economy and Americans that the domestic steel industry lost its trade cases against subsidized and dumped foreign steel products. Lower costs, you state, will help makers of "everything from baseball cleats to automobile parts." 
 Such logic is shortsighted and self-destructive. When we find dumped and subsidized auto parts in our market, many consumers will be working in shopping centers or fast food outlets, and there will be a shortage of buyers able to afford a $15,000 car.
A prosperous economy needs prosperous consumers. Manufacturing jobs generally provide the kind of compensation and benefits a family can build a life around. Much of the newer growth in jobs in health care, hotels, restaurants and shopping centers does not provide the same standard of living. In my working lifetime, I have sadly witnessed steady erosion in the quality of our domestic employment. More than two million manufacturing jobs were lost in the 1980's.
This deterioration in the quality of our jobs is a prime cause of our economic problems. The most significant cause of this deterioration has been lack of an effective trade policy. Our failure to recognize and deal with the realities of global competition has led to our exploitation by our trading partners. The more than $1 trillion in unfavorable trade deficits we have experienced over the last decade should convince us that what we have been doing has not worked well for America or Americans.
A young generation is being told it will not live as well as its parents. We read daily of job eliminations and the difficulties of college graduates finding jobs. Our ineptitude in dealing with trade abuses has done a great disservice to our children and future generations. A truly wise decision by an arm of government would cause more domestic steel manufacturing -- not less.
 
C. A. CORRY
Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
USX Corporation
Pittsburgh, Aug. 2, 1993

LENGTH: 299 words

HEADLINE: Romania Offers Dramatic Data on Abortion

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the debate on abortion, advocates of choice have often urged that the consequence of making abortion illegal, or legal but inaccessible, will be much higher mortality among pregnant women who feel compelled to seek back-alley abortions. There are statistics available on this subject from Romania, which made abortion illegal in 1966, but then reversed itself under a new regime in 1990. 
 During the quarter-century in which abortion was illegal in Romania, abortion-related maternal deaths per 100,000 live births rose dramatically, from fewer than 20 in 1965 to between 120 and 150 in 1982-89 -- an increase of more than 500 percent.
Even more striking, abortion-related deaths, as a percentage of maternal deaths from all causes, rose from about 20 percent to nearly 90 percent. In 1966 Romania's maternal mortality rate resembled that of most other Eastern European countries; by 1989 it was at least 10 times higher than in any other European country.
Since the Romanians relegalized abortion, maternal mortality has dropped precipitously, despite adverse economic conditions.
The Romanian statistics are discussed by Patricia Stephenson and others in the American Journal of Public Health, No. 82 (1992), pages 1328-31, and are summarized in the World Bank's World Development Report for 1993, page 86.
These statistics deserve to be much better known, since they indicate some of the possible costs of a repressive public policy on abortion, particularly in a country where access to abortion has hitherto been relatively free. However, the Romanian statistics concern only maternal deaths and not other health complications that may be caused by illegal abortions.
 
BRUCE W. FRIER
Professor of Law, U. of Michigan
Ann Arbor, Mich., Aug. 2, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Civic Disorder and Liberal Guilt

BYLINE: By Richard Brookhiser; Richard Brookhiser, senior editor of National Review, lives on 16th Street.

 BODY:
Of all the neighborhoods of the gorgeous mosaic, Greenwich Village must be one of the gaudiest. Yet even there a group finds itself under political and cultural siege. Its members feel that their way of life is scorned and that their protests are mocked and ignored. Some wonder how long they will be able to hang on. This group is not the homeless or squatters or some religious sect. It is the liberal bourgeoisie.
For years, Tompkins Square Park in the East Village was a shantytown. If you weren't a bum, a beggar or a kid from the suburbs who called himself an anarchist, you feared to go there. A year ago, after a costly cleanup, the park was reopened. Today, disorder thrives in the central and West Village. 
 The obvious threats to law-abiding liberal Villagers and their way of life are external. Parks are drug emporiums. Boom boxes serenade at all hours. Threads of urine, left by undisciplined passers-by, trickle in the gutters. Peddlers choke the sidewalks with tables full of pilfered books and stinking incense. These are the little lesions that, as the sociologist James Q. Wilson explained, can threaten a neighborhood's health and life in the long run if left unattended. When anything goes, order is the first thing to go, followed by law.
The Village bourgeoisie is also menaced by its political leaders and their failure to take such problems seriously. When New York magazine recently asked City Councilman Tom Duane what ailed the Village, he reportedly blamed Ronald Reagan and George Bush. Mr. Duane knows there was an election last year, but when a politician gets a good line he runs it into the ground. Antonio Pagan, the Councilman from the East Village, took a different attitude, telling the reporter "it's O.K." for his constituents to be "angry" about the low quality of life. "How refreshing," one thinks; and then, "How depressing that this should seem refreshing." Simply by uttering truisms, Mr. Pagan comes across as a bold and original thinker.
But the liberal Villager's most insidious enemy is himself. When East Villagers were interviewed by this paper a year after the reopening of Tompkins Square Park, most said they were happy with the new state of affairs, though some worried that the problem of homelessness had simply been moved elsewhere.
But the whole point of shutting and relandscaping the park was to move the problem elsewhere. It doesn't mean that it stopped being a problem or that we shouldn't seek ways to solve it. It simply means that the homeless and their hangers-on shouldn't live in Tompkins Square. A park should be a park, not a flophouse or a no-income housing development.
Marx taught us to think of bourgeois as the name of an economic class. But it originally meant someone who lived in a "burg" -- a town or a city. It implied someone who was capable of leading a civil existence ("civil" and "city" spring from the same root).
New York keeps teaching liberals the lesson that civility matters. On the Upper West Side, the most recent learning experience was provided by Larry Hogue, the violent crack addict who terrorized Broadway. But the lesson never sticks.
New York liberals -- decent and agreeable people -- do not seem to believe that their way of life merits deference or support. Their lack of self-assertion is encouraged by activists and politicians who offer long lists of other causes claiming priority. But New York liberals let themselves be distracted because they don't realize that defending civility is an urgent task. They're wrong and they're paying the price.
Fixing the problems in the Village doesn't have much to do with who lives in Gracie Mansion for the next four years. New York needs a new frame of mind. Liberal New Yorkers, good bourgeois types all, have to stop thinking of themselves as bit players in the pageant of city life. It's time to clean the streets and not feel guilty about it. They can save the world tomorrow.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (94%); 

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (94%); 

COMPANY: NEW YORK MAGAZINE (54%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: ;NEW YORK CITY; GREENWICH VILLAGE (NYC) UNITED STATES (94%); NEW YORK, USA (94%); NEW YORK, NY, USA (94%);

SECTION: Section 1; Page 42; Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 482 words

HEADLINE: Bonds Rally as Inflation Fears Ease

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER, By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury prices rallied yesterday, pushing the yield on the 30-year bond to another record low as more investors pushed aside their fears of inflation.
The yield on the new 30-year bond slipped to 6.35 percent, from 6.36 percent Thursday in when-issued trading after the Government's auction. The price of the long bond was up 6/32 of a point. Prices and yields move in opposite directions. 
 "By and large, it was a good week for the Treasuries," Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said.
He noted a number of factors that created the downward drive in yields, including a quarterly Treasury refunding that "went reasonably well" and featured the last offering of 30-year bonds until February, when the Government begins selling them just twice a year.
There also were indications that European capital was flowing into bonds because of continued uncertainty over Europe's currency problems, Mr. Sohn said. Brazil and Argentina are attracted to Treasury securities for their debt restructuring and have invested here, too, he said.
The bond market was also helped by Government reports late this week that showed inflation was not an immediate threat. Inflation erodes the value of fixed-income securities.
Yesterday, the Labor Department said the Consumer Price Index rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in July, less than the two-tenths of a percent to three-tenths of a percent that the market had anticipated. The slight increase came after no change in prices in June and an increase of one-tenth of a percent in May.
On Thursday, the department's Producer Price Index showed the first back-to-back monthly decreases in two years.
"I'm having trouble seeing inflation with a pair of binoculars," Mr. Sohn said.
Douglas Schindewolf, an economist at Smith Barney Shearson, said the bond market also drew strength from a view that the Clinton Administration's tax bill, signed into law Tuesday, would impede economic growth.
Short-term Treasury issues rose 4/32 of a point to 7/32 of a point, while intermediate-term issues rose 9/32 of a point to 13/32 of a point.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, was up 2.36, to 1,314.38.
The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills was unchanged at 3 percent. The discount rate on six-month bills fell 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 3.10 percent. And the discount rate on one-year bills fell 4 basis points, to 3.25 percent.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 3 percent late yesterday, up from 2.97 percent on Thursday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10314/32 , up 2/32 from Thursday. The average yield to maturity was 5.64 percent, unchanged from Thursday.

HEADLINE: LAW;
More and More Clients, More and More Lawyers

BYLINE: By Laura Mansnerus

 BODY:
A RECENT survey by The National Law Journal confirmed that public esteem for the legal profession has declined sharply since the publication's previous poll in 1986. But hand-wringing lawyers might take heart from a finding nearly overlooked: Americans are apparently becoming more dependent on them.
Seventy percent of the respondents said they had "professional contact" with a lawyer in the last five years. In 1986, the figure was 52 percent. 
 "That was striking; it's a big change," said Marc Galanter, a professor at the University of Wisconsin Law School who was a consultant on the survey. The findings, from a July phone survey of 815 adults nationwide by Penn & Schoen Associates, appeared in The Law Journal's Aug. 9 issue.
Forty-six percent of those polled said they had dealt with a lawyer on personal matters, up from 36 percent in 1986. Those reporting contact with a lawyer in a business setting rose to 15 percent from 10 percent.
Beyond those categories, Professor Galanter said, "we don't have a clue" about what brings people to lawyers. Nor does the American Bar Association, which has conducted a survey on the demand for personal legal services but has no data yet.
The Law Journal poll does show, at least in personal matters, a sharp increase in dealings with lawyers among lower- and middle-income people; 54 percent of those earning $20,000 to $39,000 a year said they had dealt with lawyers. And in a reversal of the 1986 findings, those in the lowest bracket -- people with incomes below $20,000 -- were more likely than those in the highest bracket -- more than $75,000 -- to report some contact with lawyers for personal purposes. Lawyers are frequently consulted for such personal matters as taxes, wills, real estate purchases, divorce and bankruptcy.
"The hiring of lawyers is working its way down the economic scale," said Nicholas Carroll, author of "Dancing With Lawyers," a guide to finding and supervising a counselor.
One possible reason, Mr. Carroll suggested, is advertising. The Supreme Court ruled that lawyers could advertise in 1977, and such ads have increased significantly since the mid-1980's. "Advertising does something that lawyers didn't do 20 years ago," he said. "It tells what's for sale. People at the lower end of the economic scale had no idea 20 years ago what lawyers did. Now they do."
Court filings have increased in the last decade, though they account for only a small portion of what lawyers do. According to the National Center for State Courts, total civil suits filed in state courts rose 33 percent from 1984 to 1991. (Filings declined slightly in that period in Federal courts, but those courts handle only 1 to 2 percent of civil suits.) The number of lawyers has grown, too, at a pace faster than the nation's population has grown.
"It could be that they're making a market for themselves for smaller cases" with increased advertising and price competition, Professor Galanter said.
Lawyers say life's transactions have become more complicated.
Gary Burke of Burke & Burke in Melville, L.I., has drawn that conclusion from his own specialty, real estate law. "The best example," he said, "runs along these lines: When my parents bought their house in 1969, they went down to the corner to the neighborhood bank, shook the banker's hand, signed a note and a mortgage, and that was it." When they refinanced a few years ago, he continued, "they were so perplexed and confused that they said they didn't understand how they had bought the first time without a lawyer."

HEADLINE: Clinton Preaches Military Conversion to an Area Hit Hard by Cuts

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALAMEDA, Calif., Aug. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton sought to assure residents of this region today that his Administration stood ready to ease their economic burdens as it shuts down five major defense installations in the San Francisco Bay Area over the next four years.
The Bay Area will be the region hit the hardest by a broad Administration plan to shut down or scale back scores of military bases across the country. But Mr. Clinton said the effort would create more economic opportunity than is lost "if we do it right." 
 "None of these changes will be easy," he told sailors and civilians at the Alameda Naval Air Station, "but we only have one choice: We can make this work to help people, or we can let the future take its course."
Mr. Clinton won no more than tepid applause from the crowd, which was mostly made up of people who expect job transfers or layoffs as the military use of the station is phased out. That will begin later this year.
At least 33,000 military and civilian jobs are expected to be lost in the San Francisco Bay Area. The Pentagon has predicted that job losses on the eastern shore of the bay, in the Alameda and Oakland areas, could amount to 1 in 20.
California's economy is already troubled. Its unemployment rate climbed to 9.8 percent in July, three percentage points above the national rate. Mr. Clinton has repeatedly expressed concern about California's plight, but a local newspaper editorial complained this morning that he had yet to specify economic remedies.
 
Request for Specifics
 "We'd like to see the plan," said the editorial, in The Oakland Tribune. The newspaper said it backed Mr. Clinton's call for shifting from a defense-reliant economy but had yet to be told how workers would be trained and bases made available for civilian use.
The Administration plans to provide $19.5 billion over the next five years to retrain workers and convert bases; the communities affected by the policy will detail how they will use the money.
Today, the President spoke about the plan only in general terms. He promised to send Government teams to help "in everything from job training to resume writing."
As a first step for the Bay Area, Mr. Clinton announced a plan to allow the Port of Oakland to expand by leasing 200 acres of Navy property, much of it for $1 a year. He said he had also directed the Army Corps of Engineers and the Environmental Protection Agency to resolve a dispute so shipping channels can be deepened for modern container ships.
Mr. Clinton's visit was his fourth to California since he took office, a sign of concern about the economy here and how it could affect his political future.
Mr. Clinton delivered his remarks in the shadow of the aircraft carrier Carl Vinson, which he later visited. He stood in front of the guided-missile cruiser Arkansas, where the crew had hung a welcoming sign. Although no hostility was shown, as in some of Mr. Clinton's other military visits, many in the crowd seemed sullen about the burdens they will bear.
Diane Lester, a 32-year-old single mother of two children, said she expected to lose her job as a bookkeeper in a Navy warehouse.
"I've already had to talk to my parents about taking in my kids, because I don't know what I'm going to do for income," Ms. Lester said.
Before Mr. Clinton spoke, Larry Wagner, a 40-year-old mechanic who repairs military jet engines, expressed skepticism about Federal help. "All we're going to hear is appeasement -- promises that aren't going to be fulfilled," he said.
Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, joined Mr. Clinton for the day, but she also told reporters that she had "real problems" with the costs that the Bay Area would bear.

HEADLINE: The Free-Trade Accord;
3 NATIONS RESOLVE ISSUES HOLDING UP TRADE PACT VOTE

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Clearing the way for a big legislative battle, the United States struck deals with Canada and Mexico today resolving issues that have stalled approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement. But the deals did not mollify Congressional critics of the pact and left its political future in doubt.
The three countries agreed to set up two North American commissions that would try to insure the enforcement of labor and environmental laws from the Yukon to the Yucatan as the free-trade pact eliminates tariffs and other trade barriers across the continent. 
 "Nafta will create thousands of high-paying American jobs by unlocking access to Mexico -- a growing market of 90 million people that thirst for American products and services," President Clinton said in a statement.
 
Gephardt Remains Hostile
 But today's deal, the culmination of a yearlong gamble by Mr. Clinton, appeared to have failed to heal the Democratic Party's deep divisions on trade policy and win over powerful figures in Congress. Reactions were guarded, even hostile, from influential legislators like Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the majority leader.
"The announced side agreements fall short in important respects, and I am not optimistic that these defects can be successfully resolved," Mr. Gephardt said. "I cannot support the agreement as it stands."
Senator Daniel P. Moynihan, Democrat of New York and the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, which will consider the accord, studiously avoided any appraisal. In a terse statement, he said only that his committee would hold hearings after Labor Day.
The continued opposition leaves the President in the awkward position of relying on Republican support for what promises to be Congress's most bitter fight this autumn. Ross Perot, the Texas businessman who inveighed against the pact in his Presidential campaign last year, condemned the side agreements this evening and urged Congress and voters to oppose the pact.
 
New Laws Aren't Needed
 Today's agreements on side issues to the trade agreement do not require the countries to enact new laws, only to enforce those already on the books. The new labor and environmental agreements call for fines of up to $20 million on national governments and limited trade sanctions on countries that allow their companies to gain a competitive advantage by breaking domestic labor and environmental laws.
A third pact calls for annual consultations on any import increases that appear to be devastating an industry.
President Clinton spoke today to Prime Minister Kim Campbell of Canada, whose Government dropped its objections to the side deals late Thursday after the Administration agreed not to impose trade sanctions on Canada if it violated the deals.
Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said Mr. Clinton and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico clinched the deal with a 10- or 15-minute telephone conversation Thursday night, when Mr. Salinas offered to take steps to raise minimum wages in Mexico, an issue not directly addressed in the side agreements. Trade officials worked into the morning hours today to complete the deals.
Mr. Salinas told Mr. Clinton, and repeated in a nationally televised address in Mexico today, that his Government might allow Mexico's minimum industrial wage of $4.20 a day to rise with the increasing productivity of workers there.
But the minimum wage covers only about a sixth of the Mexican work force. Mr. Gephardt and other critics want broader action on wages, contending that Mexican companies have an unfair competitive advantage because of the Government's extensive wage controls. These controls cover much of the economy, not just minimum-wage workers, and have steadily driven down real wages in Mexico in the last dozen years.
The Administration had consulted with Mr. Gephardt on the wage issue and decided to proceed without his support after obtaining what American officials decided was the best deal they could get from Mexico.
 
Between 2 Falls Between Positions
 The agreements announced today appeared to fall between the positions of many Republicans and business groups -- who feared that strict additional requirements would burden the nations with unnecessary regulations -- and those of many of the opponents. The opponents have argued for broad side agreements to protect workers and the environment.
Republicans and business groups praised today's deals as another step toward Congressional approval of the overall pact, which would stimulate American exports by eliminating Mexico's large tariffs and other trade barriers. But some of the Democratic Party's most loyal constituencies, including labor unions and some environmental and consumer groups, said the deals failed to address their concerns that free trade could result in the loss of hundreds of thousands of American jobs to low-wage, heavily polluting factories in Mexico.
Mr. Clinton, who in his campaign and later said his support for the pact hinged on the side agreements, has refrained from campaigning for it while those agreements were in doubt. His tepid support has dismayed the pact's supporters, and even today the President issued only a written statement praising the deals, and mentioned them briefly in a speech on the conversion of military industries to civilian production.
 Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, announced the deals at a news conference here and then headed for the airport and a two-week vacation in Italy.
In his statement, the President said, "With these agreements on environmental quality and labor standards, the North American Free Trade Agreement has become a fair trade agreement as well."
Mr. Gephardt, a Missouri Democrat who is among the most influential members of Congress on trade because he ran for President in 1988 on a platform calling for more confrontational trade policies, condemned the agreements as inadequate. He declared for the first time that he was unable to support the overall pact.
Mr. Gephardt said he had not decided whether he would rally opposition or simply stand aside during the debate this fall. His stance is awkward for the Administration because Representative David E. Bonior, the Michigan Democrat who is majority whip, is also an outspoken opponent of the trade agreement.
Their defections leave Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the committee's chairman, to lead the charge. But Mr. Rostenkowski's leadership is threatened by his legal troubles in the House Post Office scandal.
The Administration also plans to pursue health care changes and a crime bill in Congress this autumn. Mr. Kantor said today that health care would be a higher priority.
A bloc of about 70 House Democrats tends to follow Mr. Gephardt's lead on trade issues, but only a dozen or fewer of them are still wavering on the pact, while the rest are opposed, according to vote counts by advocates of the agreement. But several members of Congress have estimated that the vote could come down to a handful of lawmakers in the House.
 Because the North American Free Trade Agreement is not a treaty, it requires approval by a simple majority of both houses of Congress. Treaties require approval by a two-thirds majority of the Senate.
To win in Congress, the Administration must also win its pending appeal of a recent ruling by a Federal District Court judge that an environmental impact statement must be prepared before any vote is taken. If the Administration loses the appeal, preparation of the statement would take many months.
Members of Congress have long predicted that the Administration would face a tougher fight in the House than the Senate, and that view seemed to be borne out today by Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the Environment Committee and has wavered on the pact. In a statement, he said, "If these side agreements live up to their billing, they may be enough to revive the Nafta."
 Two dozen Republican senators warned this summer that they might oppose the President if labor and environmental deals included onerous business regulations. But Senator John C. Danforth, the Missouri Republican who led the group, said today that he was satisfied with the deals and would support the pact.

HEADLINE: A Muslim Region Is Tugging At the Ties That Bind China

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KASHGAR, China

 BODY:
The men of Kashgar carry jeweled daggers, the women sometimes envelop themselves in veils, and donkeys and camels pull wooden carts along the streets. But the most striking sight of all is the Oasis Hotel -- or what is left of it.
On June 17 a bomb ripped apart the front of the hotel, located on a central square of this desert town. Muslim separatists aiming to create their own state are generally believed here to have set the bomb, which killed three people and shattered windows of buildings 100 yards away. 
 The blast is the latest reminder of the underground separatist movement here in the Xinjiang "autonomous region" in the far west of China. Chinese troops suppressed a small armed rebellion three years ago, and the ubiquitous troops and police roadblocks fuel a lingering antagonism that could apparently erupt again at any time.
If the Chinese empire disintegrates after the death of Deng Xiaoping, the frail senior leader who turns 89 this month, Xinjiang may be one of the first territories to spin off into its own orbit.
"We're like Kuwait -- we've been invaded," said a 27-year-old merchant in the bazaar as he relaxed on a wooden bench near the horse market. Ignoring the flow of passers-by, ranging from white-bearded old men to white-bearded billy goats, he pointed to the palm of his left hand. "This is Xinjiang," he said, speaking in Chinese.
Then he pointed to the fingers of the same hand. "These are China," he explained, and he brought them around to make a fist that crushed Xinjiang.
More than four times the size of California, Xinjiang (pronounced sheen-jee-ahng) is made up mostly of mountains and desert, speckled with ancient silk route oases like Kashgar. Most of Xinjiang's 16 million inhabitants are Muslims of Turkic origin, including Uighurs, Kazakhs and Uzbeks. The Uighurs speak their own Turkic language, and many members of other groups speak their own languages as well. Ethnic Chinese, or Han, account for only 38 percent of the people in the region, and they are concentrated in a few cities.
Tibetan separatism has aroused far more attention in the West, partly because of the prestige of the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader. But Xinjiang is in some respects a Muslim equivalent of Tibet, for it too is a border area with long but ambiguous links with China. Like Tibet, it was pretty much left to itself until the Communists came to power in 1949.
As in Tibet, periodic protests have been crushed by the security forces. But Xinjiang lacks a network of exiles abroad. Little is known of the separatists or how they plan to start a "holy war" to establish an independent country called Eastern Turkestan.
The Muslims in Xinjiang are mostly Sunnis, rather than members of the Shiite sect, which is predominant in Iran and is often associated with more militant activities. Yet passions run deep. By some accounts, signs of Islamic interest -- use of veils by women, study of Arabic to read the Koran in the original, attendance at Friday prayers -- are increasing steadily.
The would-be rebels of Xinjiang have been inspired in part by the enormous changes that have reshaped central Asia in the last few years.
In neighboring Afghanistan, Muslim guerrillas evicted the Soviet army, in the process producing a huge surplus of weapons that can easily be smuggled into China. And across the border in the former Soviet Union, Muslims established a string of independent countries, like Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan. So now to some people in Xinjiang, the aim of independence no longer seems hopeless.
 
Discontent Echoes, But So Does Fear
 "They have machine guns, and they shoot us, so it isn't easy," said a 44-year-old blacksmith in Kashgar." But we have a way -- Allah! Allah will help us."
Whether strolling the bazaars of Kashgar in the south of Xinjiang or riding horseback with the Kazakhs in the north, a visitor encounters frequent signs of discontent. But it is difficult to gauge whether the ethnic unrest is simply like the racial tensions found all over the world, including in the United States, or whether they are so profound that they threaten Chinese rule in the region.
So little is known about the public mood that it is not even clear that most people favor independence. Few local people speak Chinese or other foreign languages, and even in private many are reluctant to discuss political matters. Only after endless cups of tea, in the privacy of a herdsman's tent or a market stall, do the underlying animosities emerge.
"We don't like the Han Chinese," Khakhar, a 22-year-old Kazakh, said in Chinese as he smoked a home-rolled cigarette in a nomadic herdsman's tent two hours on horseback from the nearest road. "They're different from us. They don't herd. They don't ride horses. They're not Muslims. We just don't like them."
Khakhar, who like many people in Xinjiang uses just one name, expressed pride that Kazakhstan had risen as an independent country from the ashes of the Soviet Union. Could Xinjiang also become an independent country, he was asked.
"Yeah, it could," Khakhar said softly. "That would be a good thing."
Well-connected Chinese in Beijing say that the central Government is concerned that separatists are accumulating machine guns from Afghanistan and Pakistan.
By far the most serious episode was the April 1990 uprising in Baren, a rural township south of Kashgar. A report by Amnesty International says that the rebellion began after the authorities closed one mosque and banned construction of new mosques and Islamic schools.
Local peasants protested, and the Government sent more than 1,000 members of the security forces to quash the demonstrations. The protesters seized guns from the police and declared a "holy war," and by the Government's own count 22 people were killed in the resulting clashes.
The Government also reported that 200 people had been detained, but Amnesty International said that thousands of others may have been detained elsewhere in Xinjiang after the uprising.
One night recently, a mother was riding her bicycle down the street, with her son on a child's seat behind her. A half-dozen police officers were at the street corner, and they spotted a white package that the little boy, about 5 years old, was carrying. They stopped the woman and inspected her son's box.
It was harmless, and the police politely allowed the mother and son to continue. But to the dozen or so people watching the roadblock from the side of the road, the incident appeared redolent of nothing so much as the actions of an occupation army.
"Actually, we're the minority here," said a tall, relaxed Han Chinese merchant in Kashgar, laughing. "But the local people won't hurt us. They're afraid of us."
 
China Yearns For Xinjiang's Oil
 Any revolt in Xinjiang could encourage similar moves in Tibet and in the grassy plains of Inner Mongolia where Mongols live. Almost all Chinese regard these areas as their own, so that it would be politically extremely difficult for any Chinese leader to let them go.
China is particularly likely to want to hold on to Xinjiang for another reason. China's existing oil fields are running low, and within the next year or two China will become a net importer of petroleum. Only one domestic source may be able to meet China's energy needs: the Tarim Basin in Xinjiang.
Though remote and largely unexplored and untapped, the Tarim Basin is regarded as a hugely promising oil field. But the petroleum may complicate the politics of the region.
The Tarim Basin oil can be exploited only with investments of billions of dollars, money that will have to come from Beijing or from foreign investors.
The oil will go primarily to eastern China. That may leave the people of Xinjiang feeling that the Chinese are robbing them.
Moreover, once the investments have been made and the oil is flowing, Xinjiang would not have to pay an economic price for secession.
One factor in China's favor, as it tries to maintain control, is that Xinjiang -- like the rest of the nation -- is doing very well economically. Herdsmen are building up their flocks, and some are buying electric generators so they can watch television in their yurts on the plains.
Economic output in Xinjiang rose 10.2 percent last year, a very impressive performance by international standards. Yet local people notice that growth is still much slower than along China's eastern coast.
"It thunders a lot," a 50-year-old Han Chinese railway worker said of the Government's calls for reform and prosperity. "But it doesn't rain much."
China also benefits from the multiplicity of nationalities in Xinjiang. While Uighurs are the largest ethnic group, accounting for 45 percent of the population, they are still a minority. It is not clear how well the Uighurs could work with other minorities to build an alliance against China.
Moreover, the Government has tried very hard to win support from Muslims in Xinjiang. The standard Communist Party approach is to shower benefits on those who accept party rule and to repress mercilessly those who rebel.
Uighurs and minority groups have their own schools, for example, and teaching is conducted in their own languages. Television and radio broadcasts also use Turkic languages, so a large proportion of people in Xinjiang speak about as much Chinese as the average New Yorker.
Affirmative action programs give members of minorities preferential access to universities.The Communists also allow people to go to mosques freely.
 
Religious Freedom, But Political Fealty

On the other hand, any Muslim leader, or imam, who criticizes the Government risks immediate arrest. After the Baren rebellion, the Xinjiang authorities closed 50 religious sites in that district and ordered construction halted on 153 other mosques. In the Kashgar area, investigations were launched of some 12,000 religious figures.
In September 1990, the Government formally issued new rules requiring religious leaders in Xinjiang to support Communist Party rule and to "oppose national separatism."
The new rules also ban the teaching of religion outside of mosques or officially approved Islamic organizations.
The authorities seem concerned that the growing economic integration of Xinjiang with its Islamic neighbors is adding to the centrifugal pressures in Xinjiang. Likewise, increasing urbanization and growing mobility of local people may be feeding a nationalist consciousness.
So while it is difficult to know whether the tensions in Xinjiang are explosive or simply another in a long list of headaches for leaders in Beijing, the authorities are clearly alarmed. Just last month, after the bombing of the Oasis Hotel in Kashgar, Song Hanliang, the Xinjiang Communist Party leader, warned that the need to "cement national unity" is growing with the economic development in the region.
In a sign of the leadership's concern, he called on local party officials to do more to protect national unity, urging, "They should adopt substantial measures to guard against and oppose the sabotage of national separatists at home and abroad, to safeguard the unity of the motherland."
