HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 The Free-Trade Accord
The United States, Canada and Mexico reached agreement on side deals aimed at satisfying opponents of the North American Free Trade Agreement. But the deals did not mollify some Congressional critics, and the pact's prospects are in doubt. [Page 1.]
A horde of interest groups sprang into action either to praise or denounce the side agreements to the trade accord. [45.]
Canada's Prime Minister won a gamble in taking a hard line on labor and environmental issues. [45]
Mexico agreed to the very penalties for violations of labor and environmental laws that it had opposed: trade sanctions. [45.]
 
 The Economy
Americans are even more discouraged about the economy and their own financial situations than they were before the Aug. 6 vote on President Clinton's budget, according to two widely followed consumer-confidence polls taken in the first half of August. [33.]
Inflation has been negligible this summer. The Consumer Price Index inched up just one-tenth of 1 percent in July, driving the three-month rate to 0.8 percent on an annual basis. [42.]
 
 International
The South Korean stock market plunged 4.5 percent in reaction to financial reforms that include banning all transactions under false names. [46.]
 
 Companies
The Donna Karan Company will sell its stock to the public. The company provided few details, but people involved in the deal said that 11 million shares would be offered for $15 to $17 each. [33.]
Algoma Steel's experiment in worker ownership has yielded its first operating profit. [33.]
A ruling that Borland infringed on Lotus Development's copyrights is another blow to a company that has fallen prey to price wars, product delays and restructuring charges. [33.]
Prudential Securities says it is close to settling a class-action suit by investors in a 1980's limited partnership. [35.]
Fieldcrest Cannon plans to buy the Amoskeag Company, its longtime majority shareholder, for $137.6 million. [35]
Bristol-Myers Squibb won't renew a supply contract for its Taxol cancer drug with Hauser Chemical Research. Hauser's shares plunged, losing more than half their value. [35].
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose 3.6 percent in early August, as dwindling dealer inventories caused some shoppers to postpone their purchases. [35.]
 
 Markets
The dollar dropped below 100 yen, at least for American tourists and business executives who exchange money at banks and hotels in Japan. [33.]
Stock prices were was flat on the 11th anniversary of the start of the Great Wall Street Bull Market. The Dow industrials slipped 0.56 point, to 3,569.65. [34.]
Treasury prices rallied, driving the yield on the 30-year bond to another record low as investors pushed aside inflation fears. [42.]
Gasoline prices retreated, leading crude oil prices lower; traders said a recent plunge in stockpiles did not reflect a rise in demand. Gold and silver advanced. [44.]
 
 Your Money
Only 13 percent of Social Security recipients will be affected by the new tax law, according to Government estimates. [31.]
Cold calling by brokers has turned into a hot industry, but it's easy to get burned. [31.]
Americans are becoming more dependent on lawyers, even as public esteem for the profession has declined sharply. [32.]

HEADLINE: THE FREE-TRADE ACCORD;
Accords Fail to Redraw Battle Lines Over Pact

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
A horde of interest groups sprang into action today to praise or denounce President Clinton's new side agreements to the free trade pact with Mexico and Canada.
The new agreements on labor and environmental issues have changed virtually no one's position on the North American Free Trade Agreement. That is bad news for the Clinton Administration because the most organized and numerous pressure groups are those that fear they will be hurt by the pact, and the Administration was counting on the agreements to bring some of them around. 
 The over-arching purpose of the new agreements was to placate labor and environmental groups. Such groups have contended that the pact would flood the United States with cheap goods made in low-wage establishments that keep costs down by neglecting the environment and the safety and health of workers. None of these groups seemed willing to budge today.
 
'It's a Sellout'
 "It's a sellout, and we're not going to stand for it," William H. Bywater, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, said in a statement. "A fig leaf," added Jack Sheinkman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, which represents workers in the textile industry.
Environmental groups were equally unimpressed. "A pale shade of green window dressing," snapped Barbara Dudley, the executive director of the environmental group Greenpeace.
"It's limited progress, and we're glad to see it, but they've neglected a good chunk of the essential changes that need to be made," said J. Michael McCloskey, the chairman of the Sierra Club. Mr. McCloskey argued that the countries had failed to allocate enough money for cleaning up the border region between the United States and Mexico and that Mexican companies could even use the new pact to challenge American pollution-control laws.
Ross Perot, who made opposition to the trade pact a significant theme of his Presidential campaign last year, was equally harsh. "The North American Free Trade Agreement is another in a long series of one-sided trade agreements that damage our ability to create and keep jobs in the United States," he said. He said foreign lobbyists who favor the agreement "must not be allowed to dictate the future of working Americans."
 
A Big New Market
 Business supporters of the free-trade agreement welcomed the break-through in negotiations, though some companies expressed concerns that the side agreements would impose too many restrictions. The National Association of Manufacturers called today's agreements a "crucial milestone." There was similar praise from the United States Chamber of Commerce, a coalition of big computer companies and other business groups.
Both the debate and the impact of the free trade agreement extend far beyond the Washington Beltway to almost every part of the country. Huge retailers like Wal-Mart Stores and J. C. Penney want to open stores in Mexico and say that lower trade barriers are crucial because many of their products must be shipped from the United States to Mexico.
Computer companies like Apple Computer and Sun Microsystems as well as the Big Three American auto makers see Mexico as a large potential market and as a possible site for low-cost factories. A.T.& T. hopes to export more of its huge telephone switching systems.
 
'Mexico Is Very Strategic'
 Since 1987, American exports of electronics equipment to both Mexico and Canada have more than doubled and now total $19 billion a year. "Mexico is very strategic for us over the long term because we believe the Mexican economy will continue to grow and with that growth will add to the requirements for computers," said Chuck Mulloy, a spokesman for Sun Microsystems.
David Willette, vice president for operations at the Occidental Chemical Corporation in Dallas, said, "It's an important issue, because there are a lot of synergies between the United States and Mexico. Occidental, which produces industrial chemicals and petroleum-based products like PVC pipe, hopes to form manufacturing partnerships in Mexico and increase sales to that country.
Yet the fears of labor leaders also run deep and were not quieted by the new agreements. Union officials in California say the state has already lost thousands of jobs to Mexico in furniture-making, textiles and even electronic equipment.
"Our worry used to be that this would only hurt low-skill, low-paying jobs, but that has proved not to be the case," said Victor Munoz, a regional staff representative with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in Los Angeles. "When you're only paying workers a few dollars a day, you can train them for weeks. So Mexican workers are becoming a highly trained, highly productive work force. What we had been wanting was some sort of harmonization on wages as well as basic Mexican worker rights."
Under the new agreement, the three countries agreed to enforce their existing laws and to create three-nation commissions that could deal with complaints if the laws are not enforced. But critics of the side agreements say they provide little real protection.
"The commission process is unworkable," said Lori Wallach, the director of the trade program at Public Citizen, a nonprofit advocacy group. "Only a very narrow set of issues can even be studied. There are no time lines. The so-called teeth are inaccessible at the end of a long and tortuous path."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Near 100-Yen Level; For Tourists, It's There Now

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 13

 BODY:
The United States dollar crossed a historic threshold today when its value dropped below 100 Japanese yen, at least for American tourists and business executives who exchange money at banks and hotels.
In currency trading here, the dollar continued to fall rapidly, closing at 102.40 yen, down 0.97 yen from the Thursday close in Tokyo, and at one point in the day it hit 101.80, a record low since modern exchange rates were set in 1949. 
 Later in New York, the dollar again fell below 102 yen, ending trading at 101.85 yen, down 1.06 yen from the day before.
Traders say the dollar could officially drop below 100 yen as early as next week.
But Linda Ricketts, who is visiting from Alameda, Calif., crossed the psychological barrier today when she received only 99.75 yen for each dollar. That was the rate offered here today at hotels and by American Express, which pay less than the prevailing rate after subtracting their conversion charges.
"I was very disappointed," she said, describing her reaction when she received her yen. "I wanted to know what happened to the rest of it."
Currency clerks at major Tokyo hotels reported that travelers made wry faces and sarcastic remarks upon seeing the posted rates, and often walked away, hoping for more favorable rates another day.
The one-yen coin, a sliver of aluminum so light that it seems, if thrown in the air, that it won't fall back to earth, is now worth as much as the copper penny. But except for the fact that the arithmetic of currency conversion is now very easy, Americans here found little to cheer about.
"I think I attach a little bit of pride to the currency and feel a little bit inferior when the dollar is weak," said Frank Levy, a tourist from Boston.
For most people, however, the concern was more practical. The falling dollar and rising yen makes this city, known for $5 cups of coffee and $100 muskmelons, even more outrageously expensive for someone who thinks in terms of dollars.
"I'm not going to buy as much," said Rochelle Levy, Mr. Levy's mother, who is from Des Moines. "We're just walking the Ginza at night hoping the stores are closed, just to see."
 
 
Big Headache for Exporters
 The problems of American tourists are literally pennies -- or should that be yen? -- compared with those of Japan's giant automobile and electronics companies. Each one-yen drop in the value of the dollar can cost a big company millions of dollars in lost annual revenues as it converts sales abroad back into yen. In addition, Japanese products are becoming less competitive in the United States because their price has risen in dollars.
Japanese Government officials expressed concern today about the yen's rise, saying it could lengthen Japan's recession. They called on the leading nations to cooperate to try to stabilize currency values. Traders said it appeared that the Bank of Japan intervened in the market to slow the yen's rise by selling yen and buying dollars and German marks.
In 1970, the dollar was worth 360 yen, and as recently as 1985 it was worth nearly 240 yen. The long and pronounced rise of the yen reflects Japan's coming of age as an industrial power and its accumulation of huge trade surpluses as its automobiles and videocassette recorders conquered the world.
The yen, which was trading at 125 to the dollar at the beginning of the year, has strengthened about 18 percent since then, largely because of speculation that the United States and other governments will work to raise the yen's value in an effort to cut Japan's trade surplus.
 
 
Aggravated by Trade Figures
 The yen's appreciation began accelerating Wednesday, when Japan released trade figures showing its overall trade surplus had risen in July an unexpectedly sharp 28 percent from the year earlier and its surplus with the United States had jumped 23 percent.
"It would look to me now that the dollar-yen is bottomless unless the Japanese can come to some trade agreement with the Americans," said Eddie Wong, vice president for foreign-exchange trading at the Bank of America's office in Tokyo.
So far, however, Japan's surpluses have only grown, even as its currency has strengthened. In part, that is because Japanese industry has shifted to making more expensive products.
The overall trade surplus, measured on a customs-clearance basis, was $400 million in 1970 and about $106 billion last year. In other words, Japan's trade surplus each week is now five times as large as it was for all of 1970.
As strong as the yen is now, it was once much stronger. When the yen was established in 1871, it was worth the same as the American dollar, according to "The History of the Yen," a book by Noboyoshi Araki. With currency values at that time based on gold, the yen coin was given the same amount of gold as the American dollar coin.
As recently as the days after World War II, exchanges could be made at 10 yen to the dollar. But after Japanese inflation weakened the yen, the rate was officially fixed at 360 yen to the dollar in 1949.

HEADLINE: As Trading Slows, Dow Ends Up 9.22 for Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
What started out as a promising week for stocks ended in disappointment on the 11th anniversary of the start of the Great Wall Street Bull Market. Trading faded yesterday, leaving market barometers only slightly higher, as the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.56 point for the day, to 3,569.65, but up 9.22 points on the week.
Dennis E. Jarrett, the chief market analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company, said, "It was a typical summer Friday with volume on the low side." 
 The next two weeks, the peak vacation weeks and traditionally the slowest of the summer, should bring more of the same, he added. Mr. Jarrett said he did see some investors in auto stocks take profits yesterday, along with technology issues, which have been up the last few weeks.
Du Pont was the only real strength among the Dow components, after a better-than-expected settlement of a lawsuit that had contended that Du Pont's fungicide Benlate damaged crops. The stock rose 1 3/8, to 48 1/8.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 214.4 million shares, down from 278.5 million shares on Thursday. Gainers outpaced declining issues, 1,028 to 860.
 
 
Summertime Apathy
 Analysts at MMS International said yesterday's typical summer Friday trading might explain some of the market's apathy. But they also said the outlook for earnings improvement appeared less rosy amid the somewhat conflicting indications of slow inflation, as seen in the yesterday's report on consumer prices and limited growth prospects, as suggested by the University of Michigan consumer sentiment index. The Consumer Price Index inched up just a tenth of 1 percent in July, an increase that was lower than expected. The university's consumer index, based on a telephone poll of 280 families, slipped to 75.4 percent, from 77 percent, in the preliminary August tally.
Oil stocks were firm after Exxon said it expected prices to go up throughout the year; its stock rose 1/4, to 64 7/8.
Elsewhere, Baxter International fell 1 3/4, to 24. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs Jesse Brown announced that the Department of Veterans Affairs had suspended the hospital-supplies company from competing for new Government contracts, a decision based on accusations that Baxter had misled the agency's purchasing agents.
Bristol-Myers Squibb's notice to Hauser Chemical Research that their supply agreement would not be extended beyond the expiration date caused Hauser shares to lose more than 50 percent of value, plunging 7 7/8, to 6 5/8.
The Food and Drug Administration gave Schering-Plough approval to market its once-a-day oral drug to prevent angina brought on by coronary artery disease. The drug manufacturer's stock rose 1/4, to 58 1/2.
Motor Club of America rose by 1, to 3 1/4, after the property and casualty insurer posted second-quarter earnings of 48 cents a share, in contrast with a loss a year ago.
 
 
Auto Stocks Weak
 Auto stocks were weak. Analysts said sales of domestically built cars and trucks rose a modest 3.6 percent in the first 10 days of August. Chrysler was down 1/2, to 42 1/2; G.M. fell 1 1/2, to 45 3/4, and Ford was down 1/2, to 51 7/8.
The Bairnco Corporation, a manufacturer of electrical equipment, industrial products and specialty construction products, was named in an asbestos lawsuit, along with three units. Its stock fell 1 1/8, to 4 1/8.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 stock issues fell 20.11 points yesterday, or a tenth of 1 percent, to 20,745.17.

HEADLINE: Experiment in Worker Ownership Shows a Profit

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAULT STE. MARIE, Ontario

 BODY:
One of the largest North American experiments in worker ownership, at the big Algoma steel enterprise in the shadow of the International Bridge that links Canada to northern Michigan, has yielded its first operating profit.
As a result, this town of 83,000, which only two years ago feared economic devastation from the threatened closing of Algoma Steel Inc., its largest employer by far, is breathing a little easier. 
 "The wolf is still out there, but he's no longer at the door," Mayor Joe Fratesi said.
 
 
Brighter Prospects
 A less adversarial work environment and stronger demand for automotive steel have brightened the prospects for Algoma, Canada's third-largest steel company. And a United States trade ruling on July 27 denying American steel companies protection from certain imports from Canada and 20 other countries has removed another cloud.
W. Allan Hopkins, Algoma's new chief executive, a former marketing specialist for Stelco Inc., Canada's biggest steelmaker, is guardedly optimistic about the future.
"We are re-establishing our credibility with employees, suppliers and customers and stopping the bleeding of cash," he said in an interview at the headquarters building of the sprawling plant, guarded by phalanxes of Canada geese.
Algoma recently reported operating earnings of $3.2 million (Canadian) for the second quarter that ended June 30, up from a loss of $11.1 million for the first quarter.
 "If you had asked me a few months ago, I would have told you morale in this place stinks," Mr. Hopkins, 54, said. "But now I can say the situation is better, and we're even starting to see the success stories of worker empowerment."
Interviews with workers filled in the text for some of these stories.
"Before, you left your brains at the gate," said Nick Caruso, 48, a stationary engineer in the steam plant. "Now you take your brains through the gate and are allowed to use them. That's the big difference."
 Mike Kordupel, 43, who repairs instruments in the electrical maintenance shop, said: "We're a team now. We have input through committees. We're saving a lot of money because of ideas from the little guy. That's how we're going to survive."
The United Steelworkers of America, which orchestrated the employee buyout, is trying to transform traditional workplace concepts of workers blindly carrying out management orders.
Under the new arrangement, workers now control 4 of the company's 13 board seats. They have the right to approve major company actions, including layoffs. In addition, supervisors act less as bosses than as coaches and coordinators.
Tom Bonell, 42, vice president of United Steelworkers Local 2251, which represents most of the workers in the plant, said, "We want everyone to feel like they are owners and not just punch their butts into a shift."
Mr. Caruso said that in his department, the new owner-workers have already taken steps to reduce overtime. "Now we all cover for a man who books off for a day rather than work overtime or hire a replacement," he said. "We are learning more about each other's jobs now. We can double up."
Gary Premo, 40, a former locomotive operator in the mill, who now teaches one of the special union classes in workplace problem-solving, said, "It's still a them-and-us situation, but less militant now."
But Mr. Bonell, the union official who is the son of a steelworker who quit high school to shovel coke at the mill, says he is still not used to the owner-worker role, although he is convinced it will be the wave of the future. "We'll be the model across Canada," he said.
To become owners and to save the company from collapse, the 4,500 Algoma workers gave up 15 percent of their pay, which now averages $15.88 dollars an hour, or about $12 United States, and a week's vacation.
 
 
Threatened Shutdown
 In 1991, after undergoing a bitter strike and suffering huge losses, Algoma's previous owner, Dofasco Inc., decided to write off its entire $713 million (Canadian) Algoma investment. Dofasco, based in Hamilton, Ontario, is Canada's No. 2 steelmaker.
The realization that Algoma could be shut down galvanized the community and the union into action.
"The economic and social implications were totally unacceptable," said Frank S. Sarlo, a former steelworker who is now a prominent local lawyer. Mr. Sarlo and Mayor Fratesi organized community support for the buyout.
As it had done in the United States, the United Steelworkers put together a restructuring plan that was acceptable to the owners, lenders and managers.
The president of the international union is Canadian-born Lynn R. Williams, who is one of the leading North American advocates of worker empowerment.
Many of the union's ideas are borrowed from German and Scandinavian factories, where union-management panels have long studied production glitches, gaps in communication, design of the work station and other problems of the workplace, and where unions have long had representation on company boards.
The union, which represents workers in the United States and Canada, says it has put together about 25 worker-ownership plans, from small minority stakes to controlling interests.
Algoma, which once employed 12,000 people, is one of the biggest companies and the first in Canada to try worker ownership.
 
 
Employee Stock Plan
 Under the Algoma plan, which went into effect on June 1, 1992, the pay that workers sacrifice as their contribution to the company's solvency goes into a fund that will buy them 26.3 million shares, or 57 percent, of Algoma common stock in 1997, when the first phase of restructuring is completed.
Although the workers must wait four years before they get their stock, some of the other common shares, which were used chiefly to pay off creditors, are traded infrequently over the counter in Toronto.
Algoma shares, which traded at 20 cents (Canadian) as recently as July 12, were at 85 cents yesterday.
Each employee will receive an average of 3,000 shares. To attract its new chief executive, Mr. Hopkins, from his job as a senior vice president at Stelco, the new Algoma board authorized that he be issued 1,250,000 shares, originally worth no more than $10,000 (Canadian).
Union officials said the arrangement was essential to attract an executive of his caliber. The company's meager cash reserves kept it from otherwise offering an attractive compensation package. Mr. Hopkins's pay has never been disclosed, but it is estimated to be in the low six figures.
"The best thing that could happen to us all is for Al Hopkins to become a multimillionaire," Mr. Bonell of the Steelworkers said.
Algoma's operating profit helped reduce its net loss for the quarter to $4.5 million (Canadian), from $17.8 million, for the first three months. Dividends to preferred shareholders accounted for most of the loss.
 
 
'Bullish' on Steel
 The latest results have attracted some interest in Bay Street, the Wall Street of Toronto. Margaret Cornish-Kehoe, a steel analyst for Scotia McLeod Inc., a leading Bay Street brokerage firm, said she was "bullish" on steel because of the automotive pickup. She sees "continued recovery" for Algoma "on a cash basis for the next two or three years."
But, she stressed, "it remains to be seen whether the longer-term strategic issues," which she identified as the need to leave certain sectors like structural steel, "will be dealt with."
And as insulation from any further threatened disasters in steel, Mayor Fratesi is urgently trying to diversify Sault Ste. Marie's economic base with development initiatives in tourism, transportation and forestry.
Still, workers are optimistic about Algoma's grand experiment.
Ron Hayes, 38, who runs a continuous caster that makes tubular, rail and structural I-beams, said: "Communications are better. Now the men are saying, 'What can we do to make the quality better and take the bugs out?' "
And Terry Matthews, 39, who works in a quality-control lab at the plant, said: "It's more democratic now. They don't try to hide everything. They keep everything open."

HEADLINE: THE FREE-TRADE ACCORD;
Mexico Opts for the Sanctions It Bitterly Opposed

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Determined to see the North American Free Trade Agreement approved in a divided United States Congress, Mexico has agreed to the very penalties for violations of labor and environmental laws that it had steadfastly opposed: sanctions on trade.
But while the Government quickly came under attack today by opposition politicians and other critics for its reversal, the side accords to the trade agreement seemed to trouble the Mexican businessmen who might face sanctions little, if at all. 
 Prices of Mexican stocks shot upward today, with the major market index, the I.P.C., rising 3.69 percent, apparently in the hope that the accord was a big step closer to taking effect as planned in January.
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari moved quickly to sell the deal to his countrymen. In a radio and television address, Mr. Salinas said that with the Mexican economy stabilizing and a trade accord expected to improve the outlook further, the Government would begin raising the minimum wage in line with worker productivity.
Officials did not make clear how this pledge would be put into effect. Several economists said the move would probably have immediate benefits for the roughly one-fifth of Mexican workers who earn the minimum -- $4.21 a day. They said because that wage serves as a benchmark for the economy, Mr. Salinas's proposal would probably raise pay in areas like manufacturing.
The economists also said that higher wages would increase pressure on prices, just as the annualized inflation rate has been brought below 10 percent for the first time in years. And while productivity has been relatively high in recent years as big companies reduced their work forces while simultaneously increasing output, a higher minimum wage will put pressure on smaller companies to do the same, analysts said.
"It's a wonderful thing for the workers, except that now smaller companies will have an additional reason to lay some of their employees off," an economic consultant, Rogelio Ramirez de la O, said.
Political analysts said anything that seemed like an increase in the wages fixed by agreement among the Government, labor unions and business associations might strengthen the desire of Mexican workers for a trade agreement, one with consequences that are still only vaguely understood by most people here.
In his speech, Mr. Salinas repeatedly made the connection between freer trade and higher wages explicit. "The treaty we have signed and the agreements we have concluded today," he said, "will allow us to grow more, and advance our aims that the benefits of the change reach the entire population, and principally, the families of the most needy Mexicans."
The President glossed over Mexico's agreement to the United States' demand that trade sanctions be imposed as the punishment of last resort if a company failed to pay fines imposed for repeatedly breaking labor or environmental laws.
But Government critics hammered at the point, saying it proved that Mr. Salinas was willing to sacrifice Mexican principles and sovereignty by caving in to the United States days after Trade Minister Jaime Serra Puche had insisted that sanctions were out of the question.
Diplomats and others thought Mr. Serra had apparently created a fig leaf to cover the reversal, leaking a document saying he would never agree to allow foreigners to sue the Mexican Government in Mexican courts.
Even though legislators in the United States had never sought such a remedy for violations, but had asked for trade sanctions, Mr. Serra held out the promise of Mexico not being sued as a great negotiating victory.
The issue of sanctions seems to have been more important to the Government than to the businessmen who might face penalties.
"I don't see these accords as anything bad or threatening," said Lorenzo Zambrano, the chief executive of Cementos Mexicanos, one of Mexico's biggest industrial companies, in an interview. "The important thing is that the free trade agreement itself, and the agreements finished here, can now be sold to a mostly Democratic Congress in the United States. The real fight is still ahead, but at least we now have a fighting chance."

HEADLINE: New Quarrel Delaying Plans for Coliseum Development

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
Plans to develop the site of the New York Coliseum were delayed again yesterday by a quarrel between the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority over negotiations with Mortimer B. Zuckerman, three days before a city deadline for signing a contract with Mr. Zuckerman.
In the latest twist in the plan to build on the site at 59th Street and Columbus Circle, the Dinkins administration accused the M.T.A. of being unreasonable in its negotiations with Mr. Zuckerman, who has been seeking to scale back the project and to reduce the price of the land. 
 The M.T.A. rejected the city's accusation, but the city's charge appeared to set the stage for a new set of talks on the coliseum, this time with mediation by Vincent Tese, Commissioner of the State Department of Economic Development.
 
Victory for Zuckerman
 The city's decision was a victory, at least temporarily, for Mr. Zuckerman, and a setback for the M.T.A. Because of the complicated ownership and sale agreement on the coliseum, both the M.T.A. and the city must agree on Mr. Zuckerman's new offer for the site, one of the choicest for development in the city.
Mr. Zuckerman has been trying to persuade the M.T.A. to lower the price of the coliseum site from the level set in 1985, when he first agreed to buy it, and to allow him to both buy the land and build in stages. The perennially cash-strapped M.T.A. has been reluctant to cut the price, and has been wary of such a two-stage arrangement.
 
Proposals Scaled Back
 Mr. Zuckerman won the right to develop the property through his Boston Properties concern at the peak of the real-estate boom in New York. His plans have been scaled back twice after public criticism and court challenges, only to get caught in the crash of the office-space market, resulting in yet another scaled-back proposal submitted to the M.T.A. two weeks ago.
The Boston Properties proposal "needs improvement and refinement in a number of key areas before it would be acceptable to the city and, presumably, to the M.T.A.," Barry F. Sullivan, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said in a letter yesterday to Peter E. Stangl, chairman of the M.T.A. "Unfortunately, the M.T.A.'s actions suggest that it is unwilling to engage in a constructive dialogue with Boston Properties." Mr. Sullivan added that the M.T.A.'s approach was not in accord with a request from Mayor David N. Dinkins that the sides carry on "reasonable and responsible negotiations."
 
Latest Zuckerman Proposal
 Mr. Stangl could not be reached yesterday, but Robert Bergen, general counsel of the M.T.A., said: "We think we've been acting reasonably and responsibly for the last 10 months, negotiating with the city and with Boston Properties. This is the first time we've heard this allegation and we obviously reject it completely."
None of the parties to the talks would discuss the substance of the latest Zuckerman proposal, but it has been reported to include a first building with 700,000 square feet of office space and 150,000 square feet of retail space, to be followed at some time in the future by a second building. While the current price tag on the site is $338.6 million, people familiar with the talks have said Mr. Zuckerman wants to buy the land for the first building for $62 million, and to leave the price of the rest of the land to be negotiated later.
 
Price at Issue
 These people have said the M.T.A. does not want to leave the price up in the air while the agency holds the land for Mr. Zuckerman. Further, the M.T.A. is said to believe that Mr. Zuckerman wants to delay any building until the real-estate market becomes stronger. Mr. Zuckerman's option on the land keeps the M.T.A. from renting the exhibition hall at the site for anything except the most temporary uses.
Under the current agreement with Mr. Zuckerman, the M.T.A. would collect on a $33.8 million letter of credit that Mr. Zuckerman maintains as a down payment on the site should he fail to reach an agreement on the nature of the development by a formal closing date. Last month, the M.T.A. asked the city to join in issuing a formal notice of intent to close the sale in an effort to reach an agreement with Mr. Zuckerman or, failing that, to go on to other plans for the site.
But Mr. Sullivan pointed out in his letter that such a closing notice would end the city's influence over the site, and added that the city wanted to consider "the broader economic and planning ramifications of any use of the Coliseum site" rather than just the price of the land.

HEADLINE: 2 Polls Show Pessimism by Consumers

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Two widely followed consumer confidence polls taken in the first half of August show Americans are even more discouraged about the economy and their own financial situations than they were before the Aug. 6 vote on President Clinton's budget.
This suggests that most consumers, already as depressed about economic prospects as they were when George Bush was in the White House, have not accepted the Clinton Administration's assurances that its plan to raise taxes and restrain spending will help get the economy moving and benefit all but the richest Americans. 
 "It didn't do what the Adminstration hoped," said Richard Curtin, director of the Survey Research Center at the University of Michigan. "It didn't improve consumers' sense of confidence in the economy."
 
Reluctance to Raise Prices
 The sense of a sluggish economy found in the poll has contributed to reluctance by retailers to raise prices, reflected in an increase of only one-tenth of 1 percent in July in the Consumer Price Index. [Page 42]
Many Administration officials had predicted that passage of the President's budget would restore consumers confidence in Government and the economy. They cited the expected rebound in spirits, which could shore up consumer spending, as an important reason for higher income taxes not to slow the economy in the near term.
"There is no question that our opponents have been very successful in misleading average Americans about the tax implications in our plan," said Gene Sperling, deputy assistant to the President for economic policy, who admitted the White House had been less than effective in getting its message across.
A regular weekly poll by ABC and Money magazine showed a sharp deterioration in confidence immediately after the budget vote on Aug. 6. The consumer confidence index, based on the ABC/Money magazine telephone poll of 125 families, conducted on the weekend of Aug. 7 and 8, fell a sharp 7 points from the previous week. ABC/ Money magazine released the results, normally given only for four-week periods, to The New York Times today.
While consumers' views of the national economy and buying conditions changed only slightly from the previous week, the fraction who reported that their personal finances were in bad shape jumped from 46 percent to 53 percent, the biggest weekly jump in the poll's history.
"The White House message just isn't getting through," said Jordan Goodman, director of the ABC/Money Magazine poll. "Even the people who voted for Clinton feel betrayed."
A second poll, a proprietary survey by the University of Michigan, whose results are incorporated into the Government's official forecasting gauge, also showed that the consumer mood, already dismal, worsened in the first half of August.
 
Lowest Since Winter of '92
 Its consumer sentiment index, based on a telephone poll of 280 families in the first half of this month, declined from 77 points to 75.4 points, the lowest level since the winter of 1992 and down sharply from 83 points last December. The proportion of respondents who expected the economy to get worse in the next year jumped from 69 percent in July to 80 percent in the first half of August.
Two results in the Michigan poll particularly concerned Administration officials, who are among those who receive faxes with the polling data. One showed that 9 percent of Americans approved of the nation's economic policies in early August while 36 percent disapproved, the same proportion as in July. The other showed that, by a margin of 5 to 1, consumers described the news they had heard about changes in economic policy in negative terms.
While confidence is not the sole determinant of spending, the fact that spirits are not reviving at a time when income growth is sluggish concerns most economists.

HEADLINE: Consumer Price Index Up Bare 0.1%

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Inflation has all but disappeared this summer -- though not for good, by the assessments of government and private economists.
The Consumer Price Index, the broadest measure of inflation, inched up just one-tenth of 1 percent in July, the Labor Department reported today, driving the three-month rate to eight-tenths of 1 percent on an annual basis. That is the lowest for any three-month period since mid-1986, when oil prices came crashing down. 
 "We've had a real deceleration," said David Kelly, an economist at Economic Advisers Inc. "That's consistent with everybody getting more pessimistic about the prospects for a much stronger expansion."
The effects of the Midwest flood were hard to see, though the drought in the Southeast made fruit more expensive. Beef and vegetables prices headed lower and gasoline prices fell sharply, too.
 
Service Costs Are Subdued
 Further, core inflation -- prices for everthing but food and energy, which tend to fluctuate widely -- rose no faster than the overall index, even though air travelers are paying roughly 20 percent more than they were last summer during the airline fare wars. That is partly because service prices, even health care charges, which rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, have been remarkably subdued of late.
What is happening, it is widely agreed, is that the sluggish economic expansion is discouraging retailers from raising prices.
Today's report is good news for the bond market, where yields have fallen in recent weeks, and for the Clinton Administration, which had been predicting that the inflationary pressures that emerged this winter would unwind later in the year. In the first four months of the year, by contrast, consumer prices rose at a 4.5 percent rate.
But there are signs that price increases are looming. Colleges are already announcing large tuition increases for the fall, apparel makers are getting set to mark up clothing prices and the gasoline tax will add 4.3 cents a gallon at the pump as of Oct. 1. That, said Patrick Jackman, the economist responsible for the Consumer Price Index at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, will add a tenth of a percent to the index that month.
In a separate report today, the Commerce Department said business inventories increased in June by a modest two-tenths of 1 percent, the same as in May. June's increase left the ratio of inventories to sales steady at 1.47 months, the time it would take to use up stocks if sales continued at the June pace. The slow growth is an indication that business remains cautious about future sales.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Early August Vehicle Sales Rose 3.6%

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose just 3.6 percent in early August, compared with a weak year-earlier period, as dwindling dealer inventories caused some shoppers to postpone their purchases.
Brisk sales through May, June and July coincided with plant shutdowns for the changeover to new models, causing inventories to fall. 
 Sales of domestically built cars gained 2.8 percent in the Aug. 1-10 period, to 126,295, while sales of light trucks -- which include mini-vans, sport-utility vehicles and pickups -- advanced 4.7 percent, to 103,197. Vehicle sales of 229,492 compared with sales of 221,450 last year.
 
 
Annual Rate of 5.8 Million
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales in early August was 5.8 million, the same as a year earlier, but down from 6.5 million in late July.
"Certain models are in short supply," said David Healy, automotive analyst for S. G. Warburg in New York. In late July, dealers had about a 51-day supply of cars, lower than the 65-day supply that is considered normal. But dealers are trying to sell their remaining 1993 vehicles to make way for 1994 models.
Dealers generally report that they expect the sales uptick to continue. Bill Riggins, the new-car manager for Sims Buick-GMC Truck in Warren, Ohio, said orders of new vehicles were strong. He added: "We're optimistic. It's the only way to be. We expect a banner year."
In Detroit and other cities tied to the economy of the auto industry, car sales have slowed a bit, dealers reported, in anticipation of final contract talks between the United Automobile Workers union and the Big Three auto makers. Typically, auto workers avoid large purchases when there is a possibility they may soon be on strike.
For reporting purposes, cars built in North America are considered domestic. Sales of North American-made cars by the General Motors Corporation rose a slight 1.2 percent, to 53,241. The Cadillac, Saturn and Oldsmobile brands managed increases. Light-truck sales fell 6.2 percent, to 35,842, mainly because supplies of pickups were short.
Car sales by the Ford Motor Company gained only eight-tenths of a percent, to 39,094. Light trucks were up 13.7 percent, to 37,436.
 The Chrysler Corporation's domestic car sales were estimated at 12,600, up 31.3 percent from a year earlier. Light-truck sales were estimated at 23,300, up 8.4 percent. Ward's Automotive Reports estimates Chrysler's early and midmonth sales, since the auto maker reports sales only at the end of each month.
Sales of North American-built cars by the Honda Motor Company fell 13.8 percent, to 8,473. Honda will soon begin making a fourth-generation version of its Accord midsize car.
The Toyota Motor Corporation's domestic car sales fell 8 percent, to 5,526. Light-truck sales rose 61.6 percent, to 1,821.
The Nissan Motor Company's domestic car sales rose 27.1 percent, to 4,009. Light-truck sales were off 13.9 percent, to 2,887.
The Mazda Motor Corporation's car sales climbed 10.8 percent, to 1,335. Light-truck sales tripled to 612.
Mitsubishi Motor's car sales more than doubled to 1,535.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices for Gasoline Retreat And Gold and Silver Are Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Gasoline pulled back yesterday from its weeklong rally, leading crude oil prices lower, as traders said a recent plunge in stockpiles did not reflect a rise in demand.
On other commodities markets, gold and silver rose as traders shrugged off this week's second report by the Government that inflation was under control. 
 Gasoline futures soared almost 5 cents a gallon this week, as several big refineries were forced to shut their gasoline-producing units and independent and Government reports showed a sharp drop in inventories.
"It's a three- to five-week phenomenon," said Bill O'Grady of A. G. Edwards. "Stocks always fall this time of year as refiners unload summer specification gasoline. It isn't like there's a permanent increase in gasoline demand."
Yesterday, unleaded gasoline for September delivery fell 0.08 cent, to 56.30 cents a gallon, on the Mercantile Exchange in New York. And crude oil fell 4 cents, to $18.13 a barrel. But heating oil rose 0.95 cent a gallon, to 53.70 cents a gallon.
Precious metals rebounded from their recent losses. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery rose $1.90 an ounce, to $369.30. December gold, the most actively traded futures contract, also gained $1.90 an ounce, to $372.60. September silver rose 6 cents an ounce, to $4.62.
The gains came even though the Labor Department said consumer prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent in July, less than the two-tenths of 1 percent that traders had expected. On Thursday, the Government said its Producer Price Index fell two-tenths of 1 percent in July.
Gold prices have plunged about 4 percent this week and more than 9 percent, or $38 an ounce, since July 30. The decline came amid signs that inflation is under control, that demand from investors is easing and that tensions in the European Community's Exchange Rate Mechanism are cooling.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Making a Will
Q Is it necessary for a person who was recently married to have a will, and if so, how often should it be updated?
 
 JOHN R. KAUFMAN, Durham, N.C.
A Yes, you need a will to legally establish that your estate will be managed and divided as you wish. Otherwise your property passes according to strict state laws, and your estate may be disposed of in a way you would not approve. 
 In New York, for example, if you die without a will, your surviving spouse gets the first $50,000 and half of the balance of your estate, and any children would get the rest.
Once you have a will, it should be kept current by reviewing it at least every three to five years, unless there is a major change in tax laws affecting estates, according to Robert W. Benjamin, a partner in Esanu Katsky Korins & Siger, a New York law firm.
"Certain events should automatically trigger a new look at your will," Mr. Benjamin added. "These include the birth of a child, a significant change in your financial status, a move to another state and the death of an executor or guardian named in the will."
 
Mortgage Investments

 
Q I've heard of collateralized mortgage obligations. What are they?
 
 JEFF NEECK, Manhattan
A A collateralized mortgage obligation, or C.M.O., is a multiclass bond backed by a pool of mortgage pass-through securities. It allows for the principal and interest, as well as any prepayments, to be allocated to different classes of investors to meet specific investment requirements.
The timely payment of principal and interest on most C.M.O.'s is guaranteed by the Government National Mortgage Association (Ginnie Mae), the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac). These agencies buy mortgages from financial institutions.
"When interest rates are declining," said Heather L. Ruth, president of the Public Securities Association, "C.M.O. investors may find they get their principal back sooner than expected and have to reinvest it at lower interest rates. On the other hand, if interest rates rise and prepayments are slower, investors may find their principal committed for a longer period, causing them to miss the opportunity to earn a higher rate of interest."
 
Settling Disputes
Q What is the difference between arbitration and
mediation?
 
 NAOMI FELDHEIM, Great Neck, L.I.
A "Arbitration is the referral of a dispute to one or more impartial persons for a final and binding determination," said Robert Coulson, president of the American Arbitration Association. "Parties can exercise additional controls over the arbitration process by adding specific provisions to their contracts' arbitration clauses."
Arbitration is usually used to settle disputes between securities firms and dissatisfied customers.
Mediation is a process that lets people negotiate with the help of a neutral third party. Mediators do not have the authority to decide issues but try to assist in resolving the dispute.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
EURO DISNEY REPORTS A DEFICIT OF $83 MILLION

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
Euro Disney reported yesterday that it lost 500 million French francs, or $83 million, in its third quarter as the theme park struggled to attract visitors while Europe experiences economic troubles. Euro Disney said revenue at the year-old park east of Paris fell 2 percent, to 1.47 billion francs, or $244 million, in the quarter that ended June 30, from 1.5 billion francs in the corresponding period last year. Revenue was lower even though the park was open fewer days in the year-earlier period. Euro Disney opened on April 12, 1992. The company began re-evaluating its operations last month and is considering a restructuring, a spokeswoman, Debra Gawron, said. The Walt Disney Company, based in Burbank, Calif., owns 49 percent of Euro Disney and last month reported a 17 percent rise in profits for its third quarter, despite the troubles of Euro Disney.

HEADLINE: U.S. Cuba Law Includes More Communication

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Cracks in the Cuban Permafrost" (editorial, July 16) criticizes the Cuban Democracy Act, which I sponsored.
"From Whom the Cuban Bell Tolls" (editorial, July 28) praises the Clinton Administration's new telecommunications policy, which will make possible greatly increased communications with Cuba. 
 You fail to understand the larger strategy behind the Cuban Democracy Act and the telecommunications policy and the implications of both.
The policy is the result of the law. Administration guidelines state their purpose is the "implementation of the telecommunications provisions of the Cuban Democracy Act."
The strategy has been to tighten the economic embargo to increase pressure on the Castro regime while permitting a flood of information into Cuba from outside by liberalizing telecommunications, direct mail and travel. Your opposition to the Cuban Democracy Act demonstrates a lack of either consistency or understanding.
 
(Rep.) ROBERT G. TORRICELLI
Washington, Aug. 1, 1993
 
The writer heads the Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs.

BAD SCIENCE: The Short Life and Weird Times of Cold Fusion, by Gary Taubes. (Random House, $25.) It seemed too good to be true and it was, showing that true scientists, properly motivated, can deceive themselves like anyone else.
CAST A SPELL, by Bette Pesetsky. (Harcourt Brace, $21.95.) A witty, observant novel (the author's fifth) that exposes the sad reality of the life of Miz Magic, a professional illusionist.
DENYING THE HOLOCAUST: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory, by Deborah E. Lipstadt. (Free Press, $22.95.) A historian untangles the perverse and ingenious arguments of those who say there was no Holocaust.
EXTREME CONDITIONS: Big Oil and the Transformation of Alaska, by John Strohmeyer. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A journalist's account, full of old-fashioned outrage, of the self-destruction of a nouveau riche state.

THE HIDDEN LIFE OF DOGS, by Elizabeth Marshall Thomas. (Peter Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) What do dogs want, feel, even think? A close, sympathetic observer's data make this a profoundly unsilly question.
IF YOU KNEW ME, by Anne Roiphe. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) The evocative language of this novel supports the improbably successful grasp at happiness of a newly met middle-aged couple.
THE LAST EMPIRE: De Beers, Diamonds, and the World, by Stefan Kanfer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) A lively history of the world's most enduring cartel and its control of the diamond market, regardless of war, peace or revolution.
A MOMENT OF WAR: A Memoir of the Spanish Civil War, by Laurie Lee. (New Press, $17.95.) An English poet and memoirist's bleak, understated, metaphorical monument to his ragged brigade of international volunteers.
MONKFISH MOON, by Romesh Gunesekera. (New Press, $16.95.) Everyone feels afraid and guilty in this melancholy first collection of fiction from Sri Lanka, a rapidly imploding nation.
PHILIP LARKIN: A Writer's Life, by Andrew Motion. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) Pre-eminently the modern poet of death, Larkin in this biography by a poet and friend is overtaken in life by the postures of his poetry.
THE REST OF LIFE: Three Novellas, by Mary Gordon. (Viking, $22.) Each of these cautionary tales concerns an alive, complex, contemporary woman, and each of the women is wounded by an obsessive, unequal relationship with a man.
THE SIXTIES: The Last Journal, 1960-1972, by Edmund Wilson. Edited by Lewis M. Dabney. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) The fifth and final volume recorded by the great, voracious man of letters, on whom nothing was lost.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 4; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2777 words

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Universities as Landlords;
When the Landlord Is a University

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
RUTGERS UNIVERSITY has some 335 surplus acres fully permitted for development and zoned for light industrial use near its campus in New Brunswick, N.J.
But as hungry as it is for a developer, particularly in this down market, Rutgers won't even talk to people who want to put up manufacturing facilities.
"We see developing our surplus land as building our own neighborhood, and manufacturing is not what we have in mind," said Mark Rozewski, the university's director of physical and capital planning. 
 Chicago's DePaul University, desperate for more classroom and administrative office space, recently bought the old Goldblatt Department Store in downtown Chicago.
Last month the university announced that it was turning the building's 60,000 net rentable square feet of retail space into the Chicago Music Mart, a cluster of stores that sell sheet music, antique instruments and other music-related merchandise.
"We could have gotten much higher rents from shoe stores or discounters," said Kenneth A. McHugh, DePaul's executive vice president for operations. "But we have an outstanding school of music and we wanted retail uses that fit the university."
People rarely think of them as such, but universities are major factors in the real estate market. According to the National Association of College and University Business Officers, about 4.3 percent of university endowments are invested in real estate. And often those numbers do not include the universities' vast holdings on and around their campuses, much of which they have leased out for private use.
YET the widespread gloom that has hung over every aspect of the real estate industry in recent years is conspicuously absent from the campus. As nonprofits, universities have few tax problems to worry about. Rarely have they gone into debt to buy their holdings, which means that rarely do they have to unload land or buildings at rock-bottom prices to bolster cash flow.
But perhaps most important of all, universities look for far different things from their real estate holdings than do almost any other investors or developers.
Indeed, real estate viewed through academic eyes looks a lot different than it does through those of developers.
When developers build buildings or centers, they generally want to get their money out and move onto the next project. Universities worry about image, about town/gown relations, about the impact of land use on the university's character a century from now.
They do buy land for income purposes. But far more often they do so for nonfinancial reasons. In some cases, they are buying land or buildings to accommodate new programs or to house faculty and students. In others, they are trying to create a buffer zone between their campuses and any commercial or industrial development. And in still others they are trying to preserve the character of the surrounding community so their campus remains attractive to future students and faculty members.
"You never want to soil your own nest," said Robert J. Wolfe, president of Picus Associates, which manages Princeton University's local real estate.
THAT attitude is manifest throughout academia. It has put universities into projects that developers might never touch -- or kept them out of ones that might make developers salivate. The developments they do get involved with look very different from the way they would if a land speculator put them up.
Take Princeton Forrestal Center, which developers built on part of a 1,700-acre chunk of land that Princeton University owns in Plainsboro. The center includes a shopping center as well as many corporate headquarters and office buildings.
More significant is what it does not include: No strip shopping centers abutting Route 1, even though those are often the most lucrative way to develop such land. And no development at all on the 500 acres separating the campus from the center. "We definitely wanted a buffer zone," said Mr. Wolfe.
Buffers are not just esthetically pleasing; they also represent reserves of land that the university can use far into the future. In fact, few universities will sell the land they hold. If they wish to develop it, they insist on long-term ground leases so that when the leases expire they have the option to reclaim the land for their own expansion.
Universities without a lot of land often find it takes a great deal of ingenuity to expand. Over the last decade Columbia University, now squeezed onto 36 acres on Morningside Heights, has built a rare-book library on top of Butler Library and a computer-center below Sherman Fairchild Center. Next month it will dedicate the Morris A. Schapiro Center for Engineering and Physical Science Research, which is shoehorned behind the business school on 121st Street between two other science buildings. A few years ago it tried to build a gym in nearby Morningside Park but abandoned the plan when local residents protested.
Still, while few universities want commercial developments sitting on top of the student union, most want them comfortably nearby. The hope is that corporate tenants will hire graduates, use faculty members as consultants and otherwise cooperate with the university's research. In fact, that latter goal is so prominent that many schools try to woo tenants to research parks with fact sheets touting the university's research breakthroughs, faculty and expenditures.
PENN STATE UNIVERSITY is currently developing a 130-acre, 1.5-million-square-foot research park in State College, Pa., less than a mile from the campus, that will include a hotel, conference center, laboratory and mixed-use office building, and the possibility of four more buildings in the future. The park, being developed by the Morlok Vernon Group, is scheduled to open in mid-1994. The whole first half of the park's four-color brochure dwells on the university's research acumen; facts about the park itself, access to transportation and such, are left to the end.
That approach is not always successful, though. The 40-year-old Cornell Business & Technology Park, less than five miles from Cornell University's Ithaca, N.Y., campus, languished for years, in good part because the university wanted only tenants who would be involved in Cornell research.
In the late 80's Cornell removed that restriction and the park now has 15 buildings with companies that employ about 1,000 people. A local hospital is building a center at the park, and a local developer has leased some of its land to build corporate structures.
"About half our tenants are local companies who don't care that Cornell owns the land, and a lot of them are companies that were directly spun off from Cornell research," said John Majeroni, Cornell's director of real estate. "We're still not having a lot of success attracting people from outside the area who want to interact with Cornell."
Some progress has been made, though: the Cornell park has landed a small British company that makes components for supercomputers and the Food Network, which does the recipe research for SlimFast.
Rutgers has had better luck wooing tenants with the carrot of its resources. It got the New Jersey State Bar Association to build its headquarters on five acres of Rutgers-owned land, in part by guaranteeing access to the university's law libraries. And the HIP/Rutgers Health Plan, a health management organization, is building a 60,000-square-foot headquarters on Rutgers land in New Brunswick. One reason is that a large part of its clientele will be faculty members and staff of 8,000 people.
But just as universities use their academic resources to woo tenants, they also use their land resources to woo community favor. Nearly all the schools let community groups use their meeting facilities for cost. Some let them use athletic facilities as well. And nearly all make sure the communities sign off on projects before they build them.
Princeton, for example, sold Palmer Square, a downtown mixed-use development, when it "became clear that the town and the university would never agree on anything that made economic sense," said Mr. Wolfe. And seven years ago Princeton bought 500 acres abutting Forrestal Center from Princeton Nurseries, intending to develop it for housing and office use. It abandoned the plan when local residents complained that it was too dense.
"A regular developer would have felt compelled to move over the objection of the community or at least to try to work out a compromise," said Mr. Wolfe. The university will again look at plans to develop the land when the real estate market turns up.
New York University, which owns about 3.5 million square feet in and around Greenwich Village, has been regularly turning away offers to buy buildings nearby, even though it could eventually use them. It did recently buy the Fairchild building, at 7 East 12th Street, to use for administrative offices, and the Carlyle Court Apartments, at 21 East 15th Street, to use as dormitories. But it has little else on its acquisition agenda.
"We are very careful not to give the impression of buying up the neighborhood," said Robert Goldfeld, vice president for administration. "We want to be thought of as good citizens."
ARGUABLY, the City University of New York holds the trophy for sensitivity to town/gown relationships -- probably because, as an amalgam of some 21 state and city-sponsored schools, its real estate decisions are approved and financed by governmental agencies.
CUNY bought an industrial building in the East 20's to house a new computer center and library for Baruch College. Donal E. Farley, who just retired as senior vice chancellor for facilities and planning, recalls that the building had been chosen in good part because it was least disruptive to the neighborhood, and that the State Dormitory Authority, which financed the building, hired a relocation consultant to help the dozen or so tenants in the building find new offices.
"The public sector in general pays more attention to keeping relocation pain to a minimum than a bottom-line-oriented commercial firm," Mr. Farley said.
Public ownership has worked to CUNY's benefit: The state transferred its shuttered Willowbrook Developmental Center for severely retarded children to the university, which has extensively renovated and expanded the site. It will soon open as a new 200-acre campus for the College at Staten Island. The college will be closing its St. George campus in September and its Sunnyside campus in late 1994.
With the recession still hanging on, good town/gown relations have hinged as much on promoting development as on curbing it.
Harvard recently gave Cambridge a chunk of land to use for low-income housing. Columbia sought -- and found -- a record store, cafe, bakery and casual clothing store to occupy retail space in some of the 166 apartment buildings it owns in the Morningside Heights neighborhood, after neighborhood residents said these were the services they needed. Cornell sank some $600,000 into landscaping at East Hill Plaza, a shopping center it owns near the Ithaca campus, also at the request of local residents.
"I'm sure we did a lot more than a local developer would, because we're conscious that everyone knows that Cornell owns the place," said Mr. Majeroni.
The New Brunswick Housing Authority is buiding a 672-student dormitory next to the New Brunswick train station, on Rutgers's agreement to lease it for 30 years. And the university is breaking ground this month on a $42 million, 165,000-square-foot state-financed Civic Square Development in downtown New Brunswick that will house Rutgers's Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, its Center for Urban Policy Research and its Mason Gross School of the Arts.
"If we move these bodies, with their purchasing power, into the core of the city, we will be preserving the economic viability of the neighborhood," said Mr. Rozewski.
That has been a primary goal in Yale University's real estate strategies. In 1987 Yale dedicated $50 million of its endowment money to the New Haven Initiative, a plan to promote economic development in New Haven. "The future of Yale University and the future of the city of New Haven are inextricably joined," Benno C. Schmidt Jr., then Yale's president, said at the time.
Already the university has invested $12.5 million in the Ninth Square project, a mixed-use development downtown. It has also put smaller sums, either as outright investments or as interest-bearing loans, into low- and moderate-income housing projects and retail renovations. And, it recently lent another $1.7 million to the Science Park Development Corporation, which runs Science Park, an "incubator center" for fledgling businesses built several years ago on land donated by the Olin Corporation, and in which Yale already is a major investor.
Of course, the criteria are a lot different for real estate that universities buy for investment purposes, either near their campuses or thousands of miles away. In those cases, they do so for the same reason as private investors: profit, pure and simple.
But universities differ widely in their views of real estate as an investment.
New York University, for one, refuses to touch it. "Why should we invest in an entrepreneurial, difficult business where people can lose lots of money?" asked Mr. Goldfeld.
OTHER institutions answer, because there are irresistible bargains to be had. Harvard and Princeton are buying aggressively. And Cornell, which hasn't invested in real estate for four years, is ready to go back into the market. As of the end of May only about $32.8 millon of Cornell's $1.2 billion endowment was invested in real estate, but James S. Clarke, Cornell's associate treasurer for investments, expects that number to go up pretty soon.
"We won't bet the farm on real estate, but its attraction relative to other investments has shifted considerably," he said.
If a pattern on attitude towards real estate does exist, it is based on size of endowments. "Institutions that have the most assets to invest are the ones that have tended to diversify into real estate," said an executive at Cambridge Associates, a Boston-based financial consulting firm that collects data for the college business administrator's association.
Indeed, Harvard, whose endowment of $5.2 billion is the highest in the country, tries to keep 7 percent of its money in real estate. As of June 1992, the last time it reported figures, that percentage was down to 4.8. But the drop reflected the lowered value of Harvard's holdings, not any large-scale sell-off. In fact, the university owns 17 investment properties around the country and is looking for more.
"We've been taking advantage of market opportunities," said Robert Scott, Harvard's vice president for finance.
SO has Princeton. The university, which had virtually no money invested in real estate through the 1980's, has over the last 18 months bought majority interests in two office buildings in Washington, several apartment complexes in the Southwest and an office building in Tampa. Now, roughly 3 percent of its $3.3 billion endowment is in the real estate market, and Randall A. Hack, president of the Princeton University Investment Company, says the target percentage is higher than that.
"This is a cyclical buying opportunity that has not been seen for decades," he said.
Universities are likely to keep adding to their real estate holdings, as much at the urging of outsiders as at their own desire.
Companies and individuals are donating more real estate to colleges, taking tax writeoffs for troubled buildings. A notable recent example was the General Electric Company's gift to Columbia University of 570 Lexington Avenue, a 50-story, 428,000-square-foot building on 51st Street valued at $40 million. G.E., which will continue to occupy a third of the building and pay Columbia rent, gets a tax deduction and a painless way to get rid of a building that is two-thirds vacant. Columbia gets a free building, which it will probably use to expand such programs as business, journalism and international affairs.
Developers, meanwhile, are looking to cash-rich universities as partners in developments, now that few banks will make construction loans. Brokers, too, are storming the campus, looking for sales.
"There's hardly a broker around that doesn't call me at least once a week," said DePaul's Mr. McHugh, who says that DePaul has bought close to $7 million in real estate in the last couple of years -- at prices 25 percent below what they would have been in a heyday market.

HEADLINE: Volvo Tennis Tournament Returns

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
WHEN the Volvo International tennis tournament moved from Stratton Mountain, Vt., to New Haven three years ago, the consensus among business and civic leaders was that it would give a big boost to a city scarred by a soaring homicide rate, high unemployment and other problems.
Matthew Nemerson, the president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce, was one of many who predicted that the tournament would generate substantial revenues and tourist development for the city. 
 But that has not happened. The Volvo's first three years in New Haven have been marred by setbacks like the elimination of many top players in the early rounds, bad weather and a cracked stadium court that resulted in the postponement of three sessions last year.
The cracked surface touched off acrimonious exchanges between New Haven's Mayor, John C. Daniels, and John DeStefano Jr., a political rival of the Mayor who is executive director of the Tennis Foundation of Connecticut Inc., the nonprofit organization that operates the stadium.
Still, the tournament has drawn well, with attendance increasing each year, and has consistently offered a strong field of players.
Among the 56 in the singles field when the Volvo opens at the Connecticut Tennis Center tomorrow will be the defending champion, Stefan Edberg of Sweden; Andre Agassi, the 1992 Wimbledon champion; MaliVai Washington, who lost to Mr. Edberg in last year's final, and Ivan Lendl and Mats Wilander, both Greenwich residents and former United States Open champions.
 
Two Semifinal Sessions
 Afternoon and evening sessions will be held inside the 15,000-seat stadium, off Derby Avenue (Route 34) near the Yale Bowl, and on five outside courts, all of which are asphalt based, from Monday through Saturday. (This year, for the first time, the semifinals will be held in two separate sessions on Saturday, at 11 A.M. and 6 P.M., thus guaranteeing more ticket sales). The final will be played at 1 P.M. on Sunday.
In addition to the singles event, there will be a Legends tournament that will include stars like Rod Laver, Ken Rosewall and Ilie Nastase. Ticket prices, which increase as the tournament goes on, range from $10 early in the week to $54 for box seats next Sunday.
"This has to be a big year for us," Jim Westhall, the promoter, said. "I don't think we'll have the problems we did last year, but if we do, it will be the last bite of the apple."
Mr. Westhall, whose New Haven-based company, Jewell Productions Inc., organizes and promotes the $1 million event, moved the tournament to New Haven after having previously moved it from Bretton Woods to North Conway, both in New Hampshire, and then to Stratton Mountain in Vermont.
Mr. Westhall, who has been associated with the tournament since 1971, said in an interview he was not suggesting the tournament was in jeopardy. "It doesn't mean we're going to leave," he said. "I doubt if Volvo is going to drop out, even though they've been cutting back on other sports. We're in the process of talking renewal for next year."
Volvo officials have said that, in light of the current economic climate, they can only contract for the tournament year by year.
 
Tax Revenues Fall Short
 If Volvo were to drop its sponsorship, or if the tournament moved to another location, New Haven would be left with a stadium that has little potential for any other use. When it was built in 1991 at a cost of $15 million -- paid for by state bonds -- the expectation was that it would be the site of concerts and other events. But only one concert and two satellite tennis tournaments have been held there.
The satellite tennis tournament, which was sponsored by the Pilot Pen Company and which preceded the Volvo in 1991 and 1992, was not held this summer because of poor attendance and most likely will not be staged in the stadium again. Thus the stadium has not been used since last year's Volvo and has in effect been in use only four weeks over the last two years.
Originally, those eager to bring the Volvo to New Haven estimated that tax revenues from the tournament and other events held at the Connecticut Tennis Center could produce as much as $500,000 a year for the city. In fact, the city has received far less -- only $90,000 last year, for example. Both Mr. Westhall and Mayor Daniels said they were disappointed that the stadium had essentially sat idle.
"I realize that the economy has not been conducive to concerts, and we certainly would like to put them on," Mr. Westhall said. "That's one of the reasons we came down here."
Mr. Daniels said: "The stadium itself has not been fully utilized, partly due to a sluggish economy and a slowdown in the concert tour business. We have high hopes for the future, though, and we'e talking about scheduling special events and entertainment packages with Governor Weicker and Tennis Foundation officials."
Under an agreement with residents of nearby Westville, a quiet residential section of New Haven, the foundation has agreed to limit concerts to no more than 10 a year. But Mr. DeStefano said that, at best, only about a half-dozen could be staged in any given year. So far, though, only one has been held since the stadium was built.
Mr. DeStefano, who lost out to Mr. Daniels in a Democratic primary four years ago, is the party's nominee for Mayor this year (Mr. Daniels, now serving his second term, is not seeking re-election).
 
'A Fabulous Thing'
 Mr. DeStefano and Mr. Westhall have both tried, unsuccessfuly so far, to book a women's tennis tournament at the tennis center, and the promoter held out hope of obtaining, besides concerts, "an occasional Davis Cup match," the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and some volleyball events.
But so far none of that has materialized, and some fear that, should the Volvo tournament fold, the Connecticut Tennis Center would become a white elephant that would have to be paid for by state taxpayers. That might not sit well, particularly in New Haven, one of the nation's poorest cities.
When the stadium was proposed, officials of the Tennis Foundation and the state said that tax revenues generated from the tournament would pay the debt service on the 20-year state bonds, which will total about $33 million in principal and interest. At the same time, the New Haven Downtown Council estimated that the Volvo event would produce more than $53 million for the state during the life of the bonds.
So far, the tournament has hardly been profitable for anyone. "We lost a lot the first year and then made a few bucks the last two years," said Mr. Westhall, whose offices overlook Long Island Sound but who still lives in New Hampshire, commuting there on most weekends. "If we're not careful, we could lose a substantial amount this year."
If the Volvo has fallen short of expectations as a revenue producer, it has been beneficial in other ways, Mr. Nemerson of the Chamber of Commerce said.
"It's been a fabulous thing for the city," he said. "It results in a magic week for the city. And it's great for the city because of the national media exposure. It gets everybody excited, and everyone is on their best behavior."
Others are far less sanguine. As Mayor Daniels concedes, few residents of New Haven pay any attention to the tennis tournament. However, a sizable number have turned out for a free street festival, sponsored by a beer company, that is held on a four-block-long stretch of Chapel Street in downtown New Haven each day of the tournament.
Downtown businesses expressed chagrin at the Volvo's scant impact on the city. "We were told that the tennis tournament would bring us more business, but it hasn't," said Evelyn Schatz, the president of the Chapel West Special Service District, which includes 138 downtown property owners. "The restaurants and other businesses are disappointed. And the tournament hasn't done anything for the hotels, except for the one where the players and officials stay. The people go to the tennis, and then they go home. And the people who come to the festival don't go to the tennis."
"Maybe a handful of the tennis fans comes downtown," said Mrs. Schatz, who is also president of the 25-member Restaurant Association. "Everyone expected it would help business, but it really hasn't. It's been disappointing."
