HEADLINE: The New Millionaires: Making It In Tough Times

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
THEIR megabucks didn't come from Publishers Clearinghouse, a state lottery payoff or a reclusive relative's will, and they haven't been on "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous" -- not yet, anyway. But despite the recession and its still-uncertain aftermath there are a lot of new millionaires out there.
Just how many is unclear. PSI, a financial services research firm in Tampa, Fla., says there are now about 3.7 million households in the United States with a net worth of $1 million or more, an increase of 900,000 since 1989. Relying on income-producing assets as its yardstick, the Claritas Corporation, a market research firm in Alexandria, Va., puts the number at 1.04 million, a gain of more than 50,000 in the same period. 
 How could the ranks of the rich keep rising in such seemingly bad times? In some cases, corporate upheavals helped push middle-managers into the millionaire category; delayering and restructuring left them with severance packages that could be used to bankroll entrepreneurial ventures. Often, it was just a case of the well off getting better off: many had $800,000 or $900,000 by the late 1980's. Still others made their millions on the basis of the age-old combination of talent, timing and luck.
Several of those factors were at play in the case of five new millionaires in the New York area. Mary Rodas, for example, found that she had a Midas touch marketing toys. But four also made their fortunes, in part, precisely because times were bad.
* Napoleon Barragan profited from bargain-price merchandising with his Dial-a-Mattress business.
* Harriet Newman Cohen, a divorce lawyer, saw her practice boom as the recession's pressures and problems tore more marriages apart.
* Steve Davies, owner of a computer repair company, caught a cost-conscious wave among corporate clients eager to put off the purchase of new equipment.
* Barbara Corcoran turned unwanted co-ops and condominiums into a gold mine by mass marketing at the right price.
Together, the stories of these five say a lot about the troubled economy and how people managed to prosper in it. Some did it just by barging ahead, not giving a second thought to the sagging business environment. Others had to overcome cash crises, heavy borrowing and the nail-biting, nerve-straining fear that they could just as easily end up in bankruptcy court as on Millionaire's Row.
 
Mr. Dial-a-Mattress
 Napoleon Barragan knew he had made it when a call came in shortly before Bill Clinton was inaugurated. The caller gave the name of a guard at a White House gate. A discount mattress for the Lincoln bedroom? Mr. Barragan did not think twice. "We sent a special truck," he said. "We really wanted to impress the President."
It was one of the few sales that Mr. Barragan's Dial-a-Mattress company did not ring up -- the order turned out to be a hoax. Even so, it showed how far Mr. Barragan has come in the 24 years since he arrived in New York from Ecuador and took a factory job in Queens. His wife became an Avon lady. By 1978, they had saved enough to open a furniture store when he saw a newspaper advertisement for "Dial-a-Steak."
"I didn't call," he says, but he did copy the idea. With two telephone lines, he ran a classified ad for a $59 mattress that could be delivered quickly.
The business has taken off in the last five years as commercials on everything from Howard Stern's shock-jock radio program to late-night television movies have spread the message to recession-shocked bargain hunters. Having honed its low-overhead techniques, the company was ready to cash in on high volumes in hard times.
Now, Dial-a-Mattress has 185 employees and annual sales of $30 million. And Mr. Barragan, who is 52, is a millionaire.
On a typical day, each of the company's 48 "bedding consultants" handles about 30 calls and averages 10 sales at $400 each. "In each 5-by-5 cubicle" where a consultant sits with a telephone and a computer, "we do more business than the traditional showroom," Mr. Barragan says. And faster. The average Dial-a-Mattress sale closes in 7 to 10 minutes. In a store, it takes 25. "The amazing thing is, we are able to communicate better on the phone," he said.
One reason is that Mr. Barragan has figured out how to sidestep customers' excuses. Have to talk to your wife or husband? Dial-a-Mattress has three-way calling.
Which brings up the company's phone number, the thing that taught Mr. Barragan, who had been a private-school teacher in Ecuador, that Americans have trouble spelling relatively simple words like mattress. When customers complained that they were getting a wrong number, Mr. Barragan had the bedding consultants ask what number they had dialed. It turned out that they had been leaving off the second T, not the last S as his commercials implore them to; they had been dialing MATRESS. Realizing that 10 percent of his customers weren't even reaching him, Mr. Barragan promptly got the one-T number.
Now, whether via his one-T or two-T 800 numbers, Dial-a-Mattress is selling 10 times what it was selling five years ago and in more markets: Philadelphia, Washington, Miami and Los Angeles as well as New York. "It's just a matter of advertising," Mr. Barragan said.
 
Mary Rodas: An Early Entrant
 The financial pages of the newspaper are spread out on her desk in Manhattan's Flatiron District. Mary Rodas is checking on how her stocks have been doing.
"I picked Disney because I grew up with it," she says, running a finger down the stock tables. "I picked General Electric because I remember the light bulbs Dad put in the lamps in the building where he was the superintendent. Hershey? Every time I'm in a drug store, I grab a Hershey bar. Once I was having some Luden's and I turned the box over. That's how I found out it's a Hershey company, too, so Hershey does great in winter -- all those cough drops."
Mary Rodas is 17 years old.
There are those who say the way to a million dollars is connections, connections, connections: on the golf course, on the dinner-party circuit, in the board room. Ms. Rodas made her connection when she wandered into a neighbor's kitchen when she was just 4. The neighbor was putting tile on the floor, and, she said, "I criticized his work."
The neighbor was Donald Spector, an inventor who holds more than 300 patents for everything from aromatic record players to swimsuits that change color to sculpture made of popcorn. Before long, Mr. Spector was turning to Ms. Rodas for advice about his inventions, particularly when it came to toys -- and her marketing instincts proved to be the missing ingredient needed to turn his flights of fancy into bankable products.
It has been a profitable partnership for both of them. Now Mr. Spector's toy company, Catco Inc., has sales of $70 million a year, he said. And Ms. Rodas owns 5 percent of the business, where she serves as vice president for marketing while still going to high school.
The teen-age tycoon started out humbly enough. "In third grade, I took one of his inventions to school," she said. "Nobody in my class liked it. Then I took it to the fifth grade. They loved it. In marketing terms, that's called demographics. I didn't know that. I just did it."
Five years ago, Mr. Spector invented a plain white sack with a balloon inside, a kind of lightweight bean bag that can be tossed across a room or playground. "He goes, 'What should we do?' I said, 'Bright colors.' He put on solids. I said, 'No, bright colors.' He put neon colors. I said, 'No, something Hawaiian.' " The result was Balzac, which quickly became one of the best-selling toys at F.A.O. Schwarz. (The name? "It's a balloon in a sack," Ms. Rodas said.)
Even though Ms. Rodas is older now, her research methods haven't changed much -- now she uses her private school as her marketing crucible. "A lot of toy companies use kids in a room with one-way mirrors," she said. "With me, I'm in school. My little fourth- and fifth-graders, they say, 'Mary, this is cool.' They'll tell me straight out. They're not intimidated by me."
Along the way, Ms. Rodas became a millionaire. The trappings were one indication: she rode around in a limousine. ("I needed a limo because I was too young for a driver's license.")
Mr. Spector said her money goes into a stock portfolio and a savings account. He didn't disclose the amount of her salary but did say that Catco has also set aside money for her college expenses and is paying her private-school tuition, about $12,000 a year. Ms. Rodas lives with her father and stepmother in New Jersey; her mother died four years ago.
This millionaire has definite ideas about how to spend her money. "When I was 14, I said, 'Pops, I'm going to pay for my own college.' " Where? "Harvard. Yale. At least I don't have to worry am I going to get a scholarship." But as she recently discovered, being rich won't guarantee a high score on the Scholastic Aptitude Test, which she took a few months ago in her junior year. "The math part was easy," she said. "The English part was hard."
 
Harriet Newman Cohen: Serving Those in Distress
 Maybe Arnie Becker, the sleazy, can't-keep-from-getting-involved-with-the-clients divorce lawyer on "L.A. Law," was a millionaire from the beginning. Harriet Newman Cohen was not. Her real-life practice on the opposite coast began with a case that paid nothing: her own divorce.
Eighteen years later, Ms. Cohen is a senior partner at Beigel & Sandler in Manhattan, billing $400 an hour and charging $15,000 for a typical case (she calls it a "negotiation"). But even with high billings -- and high-visibility clients like the actress Linda Lavin -- it took the recession to make her a millionaire.
"Suddenly, this was a growth industry," she said. "The economy got bad, which meant the divorce business was good. Women came to me because I was identified as a feminist. Men came to me because they knew that a woman has instant credibility when we go into court." What her clients got was someone they could call 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, a kind of professional best friend as well as a lawyer. "I sort of became a full service to people in distress in extremis," she said.
She added T.L.C. to her legal arsenal because she remembered the fear she felt during her own divorce. She had gone to law school when her four daughters were in their teens and her marriage was sputtering. "I realized I was really awfully good at this specialty," she said. But she was frightened, too, about the future -- "about whether I would have the kind of relationship where I would have a best friend, a husband, a lover. I said, 'I have so much baggage.' " (Eventually, she married again; her husband, a hospital administrator, has a daughter and a son from his previous marriage.)
And what about the cliche that only a fool would have herself as a client? "Well, the law at that time was not as complex as it is today," she said. "Today, nobody should represent himself."
Coming from Arnie Becker, that could sound self-serving. But Ms. Cohen, 60, does not seem to be in practice for money alone. "Matrimonial lawyers generally feel they are undercompensated compared to other lawyers," she said. "Well, they get plenty. It shouldn't cost more for a lawyer than the settlement, but too often, it does."
 
Steve Davies: Taking the Plunge
 Before Steve Davies, 42, got where he is today, "I got bored." He had been a fast-track executive with Barclay's Bank for 12 years, but was tired of handling low-risk loans and dealing with the bank's old-fashioned hierarchy. When a customer offered him a job running a computer supply company in 1986, he jumped. A few months later, sales floundered and Mr. Davies bought the company's maintenance subsidiary.
"I was scared," he said. "I felt like I had bitten off more than I could chew. And I didn't do much due diligence."
On his first day as an owner, he had 10 customers and an idea: that a relatively small, independent company could provide repair services for mainframes and other computers at lower prices than manufacturers like I.B.M. and Digital Equipment. Now U.S. Computer Maintenance Inc. has 750 customers and revenue of $7 million a year. "It's like health care for computers," Mr. Davies said, "but you don't pay the deductible."
But by 1989, it was the company, not the customers' computers, that needed intensive care. A cash-flow crisis forced Mr. Davies to mortgage his house for $60,000, then sell it and pour in another $50,000 before sales of maintenance contracts (average annual cost: $7,000) picked up.
"The recession has been a wonderful thing for us," he said. "Everyone became much more conscious of the need to cut costs and leery of capital investments. They don't buy new machines and they need service on the machines they have."
Customers who visit Mr. Davies's warehouse-style headquarters in Farmingdale, L.I., find a roomful of backup computers to use if their machines go on the blink. Or, he said, "If they've got a 6200 and want to see the difference in a 6410, they can come and run benchmark tests." What is the difference between those two Digital Equipment computers? "I don't know," Mr. Davies said. "The secret is hiring people who are better than you are. Being nontechnical is an asset. I can't possibly fix this. The day you see me come in with a tool box is the day you should cancel."
In Mr. Davies's parking space is the one sign that he has crossed the million-dollar threshold, a Mercedes 500 convertible. Having a Mercedes was a lifelong dream, he said; the Mercedes replaced a Cadillac Allante, which replaced a Mitsubishi Gallant.
He and his wife spent a week at a Club Med earlier in the year -- their first vacation since 1989 -- and he wants a bigger house. "But," he says, "I can't afford it yet."
 
Barbara Corcoran: A Room With a View
 Barbara Corcoran's office has one of those million-dollar, only-in-New-York views. Yes, that is the Plaza Hotel down there. But it took Ms. Corcoran's real-estate brokerage business five years to bounce back after the market slumped and make her a millionaire.
Things were dicey almost from the moment she moved in, less than a week after the stock market crash of 1987. She had spent most of a $350,000 loan from Citibank on remodeling and furnishing the office. Customers simply stopped calling; sales evaporated, and some employees' paychecks plummeted 75 percent for lack of commissions. "By the end of '88, we were buying time with bill collectors, romancing the ad agency, the paper supplier," she said. "We became specialists at prolonging our debt."
Ms. Corcoran, now 44, borrowed more, mortgaging her weekend house in Pawling, N.Y., for $300,000. She sold her one-bedroom co-op on Gramercy Park for a $100,000 profit, moved into a rental and put that money into the business, too. "Within three months, all that money was gone," she said. "It was shocking to me how your own net worth could disappear so quickly."
She started teaching sales courses at New York University and Marymount Manhattan College "for pocket money." (Her classes turned out to be good places to recruit brokers.) Back at the office, she cut everything she could to stay afloat. One salesperson offered to work for nothing. Another offered Ms. Corcoran her $180,000 retirement fund. Ms. Corcoran says she turned down both.
The big break came in 1990: she was asked by the Mendik Organization, the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Equitable Life Assurance Society to sell "the dregs of the earth -- small, grossly overpriced apartments" in a handful of apartment complexes they owned in Manhattan.
"My immediate reaction was, forget it," she said.
But she held her tongue and figured out how to avoid the time-consuming open houses and endless haggling over prices that make brokers wary of selling low-end apartments. She proposed a one-price-for-all sale: $175,000 buys any apartment in the portfolio, with floor plans and other particulars spread out in one sales location. Still, with no money for advertising, she worried about getting the word out to buyers. She tried psychology, hinting at big bargains. "I told my salespeople, 'Only tell your closest friends.' I had practiced in the mirror, I had to come across a certain way. 'Better off coming early.' "
The strategy worked. Sale day was "like a California gold rush," she said, with customers lined up an hour before the doors opened. She sold 81 apartments that day, and another 109 in batches over the next four months.
The sales netted the firm, the Corcoran Group, more than $1 million in commissions, which erased the debt problems. By then, the co-op and condo market was picking up again, and by the beginning of 1993, Ms. Corcoran's net worth had crossed the $1 million mark.
"A millionaire sounds like Easy Street," she said. But she insists that is not where she lives, even though she did buy an apartment and renovate it -- total cost, about $400,000. And that view of the Plaza? "I never see it," she declared. "I'm so busy."
 
 
 
GETTING READY FOR THE NEW TAXES

They don't expect to be squeezed out of the seven-figure category, but some of the new millionaires are already huddling with their accountants and worrying about the higher tax rates in President Clinton's newly enacted economic plan.
Barbara Corcoran, the real estate broker, has already heard her accountant's litany about the higher marginal tax rates, the special surcharge for the wealthy and the continued phaseout of deductions and exemptions "I didn't ask him to be specific about." The well-to-do will now find the top tax brackets are in the neighborhood of 40 percent. Ms. Corcoran figures her disposable income will drop 10 percent.
"What will be, will be," she said. "I'm also expecting a larger accounting bill." Not to mention a new deduction: She is pregnant. But her main concern is that she will have less to reinvest in her business.
By contrast Harriet Newman Cohen, the divorce lawyer, and Napoleon Barragan, the discount mattress retailer, seem unfazed by the prospect of paying more to the I.R.S.
"This is a wonderful country and I couldn't have had success like this anywhere else," Ms. Cohen said, "so it's O.K. with me. I know it's going to be a big bite, but I have to pay back for the opportunity."
Mr. Barragan said President Clinton had "no other way to go" than to push for higher taxes on the rich.
Mary Rodas, the 17-year-old toy marketer, took issue with that, echoing Ms. Corcoran's concerns. "He doesn't understand the concept that the money that goes for the extra taxes could be used to expand the company," she said of the President.
But she has another beef. "I can't vote," she said. "That's taxation without representation."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Hog Heaven: High Rates In Hot Nations

BYLINE: By Saul Hansell

 BODY:
The world is not a friendly place for cash these days. As recession rolls from the United States to Japan to Europe, there is less demand for money and interest rates keep falling. For a while, those that looked after money market mutual funds and other short-term investments looked to Europe because many countries there were forced to keep rates high in order to keep their currencies on a par with the German mark. But after the decision two weeks ago to let European currencies float freely, rates will fall.
And so investors are increasingly tempted to send their money far off the beaten path. They are being lured by offers of rates from 7 percent in Thailand to 9 percent in Argentina, 10 percent in Indonesia and 14 percent just over the border in Mexico. 
 "The bond market is full of yield hogs, people who will throw their money at the highest-yielding currency," said James Clair, a senior corporate bond trader at Brown Brothers Harriman.
Ironically, the increased interest in Latin American and Southeast Asian currencies is in large part a bet on the strength of the dollar, to which they are generally tied. Most investors see the dollar appreciating against both the yen and the European currencies.
Japan presents its usual conundrum -- a wide gap between market trends, which have pushed the yen to a record 102 to the dollar last week, and the fundamentals, which argue for a level of 120 to 130.
Thus money has flowed into developing countries, now that they have refinanced their past-due loans and embraced free-market economics. Indeed, now some 60 percent of the $16 billion in short-term debt issued by the Mexican Government is owned by foreigners, especially American mutual funds. The Mexican Government has devalued the peso steadily at about 5.5 percent a year. Yet 28-day itstreasury bills yield 13.91 percent, compared with 3 percent in the United States.
Southeast Asian countries generally tried to keep their currencies stable and relatively low compared with the dollar to encourage exports. The biggest downside of these markets is the limited supply of investments. "You have to virtually beg the Thai Government to borrow money from you," said Adam M. Greshin of Scudder Stevens & Clark, which has put 5 to 10 percent of its $4 billion in global bond funds into developing markets.
How could the yield hogs be turned into burnt bacon? While the markets seem orderly now, they are extremely fragile. If, for example, the North American Free Trade Agreement is delayed in the Senate, foreign investors may well bail out of the peso. And domestic politics, of course, can undercut economic policies that are attractive to foreign investors.
Still, there is considerable risk in the industrial countries as well. "With the volatility we have seen in Europe," said Peter Frey of J.P. Morgan, "Mexico and Argentina seem like pretty predictable places."

LENGTH: 1616 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/August 8-13

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
To Trim Itself for a New Era, Johnson & Johnson Cuts 3,000 

Second-quarter sales: $3.54 billion. After-tax profits: $495 million, up 9.5 percent over the 1992 quarter. This may not sound like a company that would cut 3,000 jobs, but it is. Johnson & Johnson announced last week that it will eliminate that many positions, through layoffs and early retirements, by the end of the year. The company, whose main products are prescription drugs, hospital supplies and consumer products like Band-Aids and Tylenol, hopes to save more than $100 million a year from the trims. Why perform such surgery on an apparently healthy company? The reason, of course, is the expectation of strong pricing pressures in a new era of cost-conscious health care. Nor is Johnson & Johnson unique. From insurers to hospitals, "all the health care companies are battening down the hatches," said one analyst. Indeed, in recent months drug companies alone have announced job cuts of at least 18,000.
 
American Prevails in Fare Case
 
"It's like a hole in one," exulted an American Airlines lawyer last week after a Federal jury quickly dismissed unfair-pricing claims brought against the company. But the stakes in the case -- brought by Continental and Northwest airlines -- dwarfed anything you might see on the links. American stood to lose up to $3 billion if the jurors found that it was trying to drive the plaintiffs out of business when American's chief, Robert L. Crandall, instituted low, tiered fares last summer. Summer travelers, meanwhile, hoped the verdict might mean the start of fare cuts that have been uncharacteristically rare this season. Some suspect that Continental and Northwest, loathe to do something they were suing American for doing, have been postponing any summer price drops until the case was concluded.
 
Woman Gets Top Columbia Spot
 
Columbia Pictures has named Lisa Henson, a Warner Brothers executive, as its new president for worldwide production. Ms. Henson, who has helped produce such Warner hits as "Batman" and "Lethal Weapon," was tapped for the job by Mark Canton, her former Warner boss and the current Columbia chairman. Ms. Henson, 33, joins the very small circle of high-level Hollywood women executives, joining Sherry Lansing, the head of Paramount Pictures, and Stacy Lasally, president of production at Tri-Star. Ms. Henson is no stranger to the world of entertainment. Her father, the late Jim Henson, was the creator of the Muppets of "Sesame Street."

Unisys: Downsizing Goes Up
 
Downsizing has now gone about as far up the corporate ladder as it can. The president of the Unisys Corporation, Reto Braun, is leaving to run a $2 billion Canadian company, and Unisys will not replace him. "Speed is far too important in this business to have any extra layers of management," said James A. Unruh, the computer company's chairman. Others share the sentiment. G.E.'s chairman, John F. Welch Jr., has long seen no need for a president; Louis V. Gerstner Jr. of I.B.M. concurs. Why ax the presidency? The academic answer: As companies delegate more duties to their lines of business -- the current fashion -- these top-shelf officers are less needed. But one consultant had a more street-wise response: "It depends on what the top guy wants," he said, "and not much else."

Court Backs Mutual Benefit Plan
 
Better late than never. So thought the 700,000 customers of the nation's largest failed life insurer last week, when a New Jersey court approved a restitution plan. The insurer, 148-year-old Mutual Benefit Life, will pay its customers in full -- with 5 percent interest too, at least for some. How is this possible for an insurer who is $1.1 billion in the hole? Simple. Instead of liquidating the company and paying customers part of the money owed, New Jersey decided to keep it in business. But there's a catch. Customers may have to wait up to seven years to get their funds back. They can get their money earlier, but it'll cost -- a whopping 45 cents per dollar during the plan's first year, for instance.

Saturn Recalls 380,000 Cars
 
A car has 20,000-odd parts. Problems with one of them, the alternator, have led the Saturn Corporation to recall more than 380,000 autos for repair. The defect has sparked engine fires in 34 Saturns, but no injuries or deaths. The flaw affects all Saturns made from 1991, when G.M. established the Saturn subsidiary, to mid-April 1993, when the problem was uncovered. As recalls go, Saturn's seems easy: The company will fix 90 percent of the faulty cars within three months, for about 20 minutes per car and a total bill of $8 million.
 
 
 
ECONOMY

 
Federal Grazing Fees to Grow
 
Ranchers will find it hard to swallow, but the Administration has announced plans for a large rise in grazing fees on Federal lands in the West. Affecting 280 million acres, the plan will increase monthly fees from $1.86 per animal unit -- defined as a cow and a calf, or five sheep -- to $4.28 by 1996. The move will earn the Treasury about $20 million a year, but the monthly fee is still less than the $5 President Clinton originally proposed, and much less than the $5 to $15 fees charged on private lands. The grazing-fee rise is just the first of planned Administration reforms of private use of Western Federal lands. Miners, timber companies and farmers who now pay below-market rates to use public lands can all expect Federal fee increases.

Deleverage: Word of the 90's
In the 80's it was leverage; now it's deleverage. Companies in the 90's are selling assets to slash debts. Last week's examples: Westinghouse will sell $1.1 billion in electrical businesses to the Eaton Corporation; the deal will reduce its $5 billion debt from junk bond and real estate forays. And, to pare its $1.1 billion debt, Charter Medical will sell 10 hospitals to Quorum Health for $340 million.

Productivity Falls -- Again
 
After nearly two years of growth, productivity dropped for the second quarter in a row, the Labor Department reported last week. Measured by worker output per hour, productivity fell at a 2.5 percent annual rate between April and June, following the first quarter's 1.6 percent rate drop. But the second-quarter decline was hardly uniform. The manufacturing sector, which accounts for one-fifth of the economy, increased productivity at a 5 percent rate, for example, while Labor reported sharp but unspecified productivity declines in restaurants, health care and other service industries. Are economists worried? A bit, but some note that services productivity is hard to measure -- which is why Labor doesn't release specific figures for that sector. And other experts put the two-quarter drop in context, noting that it comes on top of seven consecutive quarters of growth.

Online Is In Line for Profits
 
"The check is in the mail." That popular lie may be obsolete soon, and a tiny company now has a big patent riding on the change. Although experts believe many future bill payers will pay by home computer rather than by check, the industry was stunned when Online Resources and Communications of Fairfax, Va., secured a patent for an at-home bill-paying process. The patent may apply not only to banking services, but to pay-per-view television, computer stock-trading and other at-home transactions. One observer says the patent covers an act that will be as common as hooking up an answering machine. Online may not be tiny much longer
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Pepsi's $500 Million for Poland
 
Pepsico announced last week its plan to invest $500 million in Poland over the next five years. The investment -- double the $250 million Polish investment that Coca-Cola revealed in March -- is sure to escalate the cola wars for Poland's 38 million consumers. But only 40 percent of the Pepsi stake will go to soft drinks. An equal amount will go to the snack-food market, and the other 20 percent will finance Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurants that Pepsi plans to build in Warsaw and other Polish cities. Pepsi has shown growing interest in international markets recently. Since April, it has announced two other five-year plans: a $750 million investment in Mexico, and a $115 million investment in Hungary.
 
Germany Plans Cuts in Welfare
 
Burdened by the costs of reunification, Germany is planning the first cuts ever in its generous postwar social programs. The reductions would cover all kinds of welfare benefits, from unemployment compensation to pensions to child care payments. The maternity stipend of $235 per child will be completely eliminated, for example, and unemployment compensation benefits will be shaved by 3 percent. If Parliament approves, the cuts would save $45.2 billion per year -- an impressive sum until compared with the $62.5 billion yearly minimum Bonn pays for reunification. Meanwhile, Germany may soon be joined in such cuts by other European nations burdened by the recession.

'John Doe' Banned by Seoul
 
In a long-awaited anti-corruption move, South Korean President Kim Young Sam has decreed that the use of incorrect names on bank and brokerage accounts will no longer be permitted. No one knows the precise extent of the longtime practice, which is used to avoid taxes and to make secret political donations. For instance, while officials know that 3 percent of brokerage accounts have "false," or fictitious, names, an unknown number have "borrowed" names from others. Users of wrong names, whether false or borrowed, have only two months to stop. After that, they'll pay a 60 percent fine -- in real money.

LENGTH: 1754 words

HEADLINE: Winners as Well as Losers in the Great Flood of '93

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
THE losses from the flooding in the upper Midwest this summer continue to grow. So, in other cases, do the profits.
On the negative side, there has been damage estimated at $12 billion. Experts say the economic toll could continue to mount for weeks to come, even as the Mississippi River and its swollen tributaries slowly subside. Barge traffic is not expected to resume on much of the river system before the end of the month, even under the best of circumstances. Railroads may need several months to return to their finely tuned schedules. Truckers will be slowed by road and bridge repairs. 
 The disruptions to the transportation system, in turn, will force manufacturers, retailers and other businesses to scramble to satisfy customers, adding to overhead costs.
There are other burdens to come that few are anticipating. For instance, towns and counties, many already struggling to balance their budgets, may have to raise property taxes sharply on homes and businesses unless the Federal Government can be persuaded to pay the entire tab for rebuilding local roads, bridges and sewers. Local politicians say there is little hope that state governments, which are equally hard pressed, will bail them out.
For each blow suffered, though, there have been strokes of good fortune. The unflooded laundromat up the street from the submerged one enjoys a boom in business. The hardware store sells out its pumps and home-repair equipment. The farmer on high ground gets higher prices for soybeans and corn. Local contractors and aerial-survey firms get a lot of new business.
For others, the good fortune may take longer to become apparent. Somewhere among the flooded merchants, undoubtedly, are entrepreneurs who will use their insurance payments to set up different businesses that may be far more prosperous than the ones they had been pursuing before the flood came.
In addition, as recently shown in south Florida following Hurricane Andrew, the process of recovering from natural disasters brings billions of dollars of Federal emergency-relief and insurance money into the stricken region. Eventually, there may be a positive jolt to the local economy. Bank analysts, for example, say that except for a few tiny community banks with nearly all of their business in the hardest-hit areas, banks in the region stand to make more from new lending than they will lose from unsecured losses.
Following is a preliminary, incomplete scorecard of business winners and losers from the flood of 1993.
 
The Winners
 Farmers: The eastern Midwest, outside the flood area, expects close-to-record corn and bean crops, and higher prices than last year, providing the crops can be harvested before the first frosts. Even in hard-hit states like Iowa, farmers on high ground may come out with enough of their crops to earn more than they did from the record yields of 1992, thanks to higher prices.
Monsanto: Heavy rains kept farmers from tilling fields and nourished weeds, creating record demand for Monsanto's Roundup, the world's best-selling herbicide. Farmers will probably plant more acreage next year to make up for shortfalls this year, leading to continued high demand.
Fertilizer companies: The IMC Fertilizer Group, the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan and Arcadian Partners L.P., three of the big publicly traded fertilizer companies, and many privately held cooperatives expect a big jump in demand next year not just because of increased acreage but also to make up for nutrients washed from soil.
Pioneer Hi-Bred International: The nation's largest provider of corn seed has huge stocks and stands to gain market share from small, local competitors whose seed crops were damaged, as well as added sales from expanded planting next year. A minor side benefit for breeders like Pioneer with broad product lines: the corn strains that do well even in this extremely wet summer can be identified for future breeding programs.
Pumping-equipment makers: Sta-rite Industries, the Delevan, Wis., subsidiary of Wicor, is the main supplier to Sears, Roebuck and other retailers of sump pumps and related hoses. It has been operating at triple the normal summer production rate for five weeks to meet demand from the flood zones. Rivals like Wayne Burners and Water Pumps (a unit of Scott Fetzer, owned by Berkshire Hathaway), Simer Pumps (the Rival Company) and F. E. Myers (Pentair Inc.) have also been seen a surge in demand.
Chicago Board of Trade: Trading soared in the exchange's grain futures and options pits, setting a monthly volume record forJuly.
Lawyers: "The first priority for everyone was to keep customers operating," noted Ernest Micek, an executive vice president at Cargill Inc. "The second job, which a lot of people are just getting to, is sorting out the costs." That will require heavy scrutiny of contracts and may lead to litigation for some companies. Expect insurers to be drawn into many of the battles. Lawyers will also be in heavy demand as businesses try to make Federal relief programs work to their advantage.
 
The Losers
 Farmers: Hundreds of farmers along long stretches of the Mississippi, the Missouri and several tributaries lost most if not all of their crops to flooding. Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy estimated the flooded land at 8 million acres and said 12 million more acres were too wet to produce any crop -- for a total area about the size of South Carolina. Hundreds of thousands of other farmers from Minnesota to Missouri and as far west as eastern Nebraska expect reduced yield because of soil saturation from heavy rains and wind damage to crops with shallow root systems.
Grain elevators: From the Mississippi to the eastern edge of the Great Plains, grain elevators, many of them owned by small operators and farm cooperatives, will suffer losses because they are unable to ship stocks already on hand; over the longer term, they will also be hurt by smaller harvests.
Livestock and poultry growers: Feed prices are headed up. One of the harder-hit big producers will be Tyson Foods, said Leonard Teitlebaum of Merrill Lynch. He has cut his projected earnings for this year by 5 cents a share to a new range of $1.25 to $1.30. But Tyson Foods is probably better positioned than smaller competitors because it has more cost-plus contracts with major customers that allow it to pass on increased expenses, according to John McMillin at Prudential Securities.
Food Processors: Archer-Daniels-Midland estimated recently that the flooding is costing it $1.5 million a day. The flooding has kept 75 percent of its barges tied up, forced rerouting of many of the remainder and reduced loadings. ConAgra's flour mills at Alton and Chester, Ill., were flooded. The company's Montfort meat-packing subsidiary also had two plants shut in Iowa for several weeks, and barge operations were idled. But other divisions such as ConAgra's agrichemicals distribution business may have benefitted and analysts say the overall losses will be minor. Privately held Cargill, the largest of the three giants, has also suffered "substantial losses," mostly because of logistical difficulties. One example: 100 tank cars of high-fructose corn syrup were bottled up in Kansas City freight yards so long that soft-drink bottlers on the West Coast used sugar instead. Hardest hit in the group has been Hubinger, now a French-owned concern; its Keokuk, Iowa, corn processing plant has been shut for more than a month because of flooding.
Barge lines: The American Commercial Barge Line, the nation's largest barge operator, based in Jeffersonville, Ind., had more than one-third of its 3,500 barges idled on the Mississippi. The industry as a whole is losing $3 million a day in revenue from the shutdown, according to its trade group. But the bottom-line impact is much less. American Commercial, for example, has laid off workers and shut down terminals to cut costs. CSX, its parent, figures the loss to net income will be less than $5 million for the quarter. Much of it could be recouped if the rivers are opened by September. Barge operators would have a heavy backlog and could raise prices during what has historically been the industry's busiest season.
Railroads: All of the major railroads serving the flooded regions face losses in the tens of millions of dollars for repairs and higher operating costs. The Santa Fe was especially hurt by the 25-day closing of its double-tracked main line from Chicago to Kansas
City. Others with big losses include the Burlington Northern, the Union Pacific, the Norfolk Southern and CP Rail of Canada. But small short lines face the most crippling losses. The largest of those endangered lines is the Gateway Western, which lost a large section of its main line from St. Louis to Kansas City, and faces almost certain bankruptcy without Federal aid.
Amoco: The Midwest's biggest oil company suffered from reduced travel throughout the rainy season and a wide range of flood-related disruptions. Amoco's chemical plant in Peoria has automated unloading facilities for barges; with barges grounded, the plant got supplies by rail, but handling them was much more labor intensive and expensive. And Amoco's oil pipeline to its Whiting, Ind., refinery was hampered when a pumping plant in Niota, Ill., was flooded.
Insurance companies: The industry projects losses in the range of $600 million to $1 billion, far less than the hit it took from Hurricane Andrew. Most flood and crop insurance is ultimately the liability of the Government, even if sold through the private sector. Business interruption insurance often carries very high deductibles and only big businesses are typically covered for it in flood situations.
Tourist-related businesses: The St. Louis arch became a popular destination for folks wanting to view the Mississippi in full flood, but many other tourist destinations have suffered. Hannibal, Mo., the birthplace of Mark Twain, had 10 percent of its normal traffic in July. Even Branson, Mo., the country music center 200 miles from any significant flooding, saw a major dropoff in visitors. In Iowa's northwestern lake country, boat dealers and clothing shops that cater to tourists began slashing prices on merchandise to end-of-season levels last month, nearly a month ahead of normal. The Mississippi River Parkway Commission estimates that 50,000 guest beds have gone unfilled each night in Minnesota, Wisconsin, Iowa, Missouri and Illinois.

HEADLINE: At Work;
New Reminders on Harassment

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
IT may be true, as the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission contends, that the agency's new regulations on harassment in the workplace break no new legal or policy grounds. But the regs, which will be published for comment by the public as soon as the Office of Management and Budget and everyone else within the Government has had his or her say, may by their very existence send a message to companies about firming and toning their harassment policies.
The regs are in the pipeline at least in part because sexual harassment has received so much attention in the last few years, obscuring harassment based on race, religion, national origin and disability. They are a reminder that all forms of harassment are discrimination and that proving it rests on similar legal arguments. 
 "Other harassment also violates anti-discrimination law," said Dianna Johston, an E.E.O.C. assistant legal counsel in the Title VII equal pay division, who said the different types of discrimination rested on similar arguments. "We felt a need to consolidate the rules in one place."
The regs draw on bits and pieces of anti-discrimination law, agency rulings and previous E.E.O.C. publications like the National Origin Guidelines. A refresher course, from the draft copy of the new regs:
* Employers have a duty to maintain a working environment free of harassment based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age or disability.
* Conduct is harassment if it creates a hostile, intimidating or offensive work environment, unreasonably interferes with the individual's work or adversely affects the employee's employment opportunities. The conduct includes such things as racist epithets, raunchy jokes and ethnic slurs, and usually, though not always, has to be systematic.
* The standard for evaluating harassment is whether a reasonable person in the same or similar circumstances would find the conduct intimidating, hostile or abusive. The perspective of the victim -- his or her race, gender, age, place of origin, etc. -- has an important place in the evaluation. "You take into account particular sensitivities or histories," Ms. Johnston said. "Men might regard some jokes as flattering. Women don't agree."
* Unwanted sexual conduct is not the only form of sexual harassment. "Gender-based animus" is also harassment. "It usually occurs where women have gone into traditionally male professions," Ms. Johnston said. "Male co-workers might try to make her life miserable." However, men entering traditionally female professions could also be victims of gender-based animus.
* Employers are liable for the acts of those who work for them if they knew or should have known about the conduct and took no immediate, appropriate corrective action. Employers who fail to draw up explicit, detailed anti-harassment policies and grievance procedures may put themselves at particular risk. "Employers are not required per se to have policies," Ms. Johnston said, but if they do not, employees can assume "the supervisor is acting with the imprimatur of the company."
SOME civil rights lawyers are less cautious than the E.E.O.C. about the new regs' potential impact. "It seemed they felt a need for a clear statement," said Stephen Paskoff, a former E.E.O.C. lawyer and civil rights litigator who now teaches companies how to follow workplace law. "It says that we are going to treat other things with as much seriousness as sexual harassment."
Companies have jumped on the sexual harassment training bandwagon, Mr. Paskoff said, to the detriment of other concerns. "Men often feel harassment workshops aren't for them," he said. Companies get their employees' attention more quickly by making it clear they are concerned about all forms of harassment. "Companies should indicate there is a global behavioral standard they expect their employees to follow. If we say sexual jokes are inappropriate, we can use that as a model to say why age-based or raced-based jokes are inappropriate."
Perhaps with the optimism of the committed trial lawyer, Mr. Paskoff said he expected the codified guidelines to have some impact on plaintiffs' chances in court. They may make it harder for the courts to ignore the E.E.O.C. as they decide discrimination cases. "The courts can get around it, but at least it requires them to look at it," he said.
 
 
 
A LEGAL FIELD TO WATCH
IS discrimination law, once a legal speciality beloved only by idealists devoted to poverty, about to move uptown?
Stephen Paskoff, a civil rights lawyer, has been building a business on companies' worries they may run afoul of workplace civil rights law. As president of Employment Learning Innovations in Atlanta, he teaches companies how to foster equality at work and avoid litigation. He believes a convergence of political, legal and social factors may put civil rights on an upwardly mobile path:
* Politics: Unlike his recent predecessors, President Clinton genuinely supports civil rights law; that is clear from his statements and Justice Department appointments.
* Society: Americans are becoming more aware, thanks to Anita Hill and Rodney King, of race and gender.
* Legislation: New laws, like the Family and Medical Leave Act and the Americans With Disabilities Act, are now in force and have heightened awareness of civil rights.
* Economics: Many other areas of law are becoming less lucrative. For example, it is getting harder to win big verdicts in liability law.
These changes are turning "what used to be an unprofitable area into another tort," Mr. Paskoff said. "Good lawyers are jumping in."
Welcome to Dan Quayle's nightmare.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Stepping Stones Toward Equal Opportunity in America"

1963: The Equal Pay Act outlaws discrimination in wages on basis of gender.
 
1964: Civil Rights Act outlaws discrimination on basis of race, color, religion or national origin. Title VII of the act applies to the workplace and creates the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
 
1967: The Age Discrimination in Employment Act outlaws workplace discrimination on basis of age.
 
1972: Title VII is amended to outlaw gender discrimination.
 
1978: The Pregnancy Discrimination Act, another amendment to Title VII, makes it illegal to refuse to hire or fire a pregnant woman or compel her to take maternity leave.
 
1986: The U.S. Supreme Court rules sexual harassment is discrimination.
 
1990: Older Workers Benefit Protection Act, an amendment to the 1967 age discrimmination act, outlaws discrimination in employment benefit programs on the basis of employees' age for employees 40 and older.
 
The Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990 outlaws discrimination against people with physical and mental disabilities.
 
1991: The "reasonable woman" standard emerges in harassment rulings.
 
1993: The Family and Medical Leave Act grants employees in companies with 50 or more employees the right to take up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave for a pregnancy or an illness of a close family member.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Middle Years, Middle Road

SERIES: Second of three articles on investing by generation. Next: the 60's and older.

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
PEOPLE in their 40's and 50's are often called the "sandwich generation," squeezed by competing needs to finance their retirement, pay for their children's education and maybe support their elderly parents.
For emergencies, they should keep three months of living expenses on hand, and more if they lack disability insurance and secure employment, said Harold R. Evensky, a financial planner in Coral Gables, Fla. An umbrella policy that extends their auto and homeowner's insurance also can help protect their growing net worth. 
 On the savings front, "Most people tend not to integrate their planning" for short- and long-term needs, Mr. Evensky said.
Money needed in the near future for tuition payments or a child's wedding should be put in investments with little volatility, like short-term bond funds. Mr. Evensky likes the Vanguard Short-Term Bond Fund and Federated Short-Intermediate Government Fund because of their low expenses. For people in high tax brackets, he recommends the Vanguard Limited Term Municipal Bond Fund.
Because the 40's and 50's are peak earning years, investing for retirement is paramount, and finding a tax-free vehicle to do so really pays off. "Pump as much as you can into qualified retirement plans," like 401(k) plans, Mr. Evensky said. Avoid overloading on your company's stock, because by reducing diversity, that increases risk. Up to 25 percent of earnings from a sideline business can be contributed to a Keogh retirement plan.
Once money is stashed away in retirement plans, don't borrow from them.
Portfolio growth remains an important goal because inflation erodes wealth over time. For example, the equivalent of an $18,000 car today will be a $64,000 car in the year 2030, assuming a 3.5 percent annual inflation rate, said Carol C. Pankros, a financial planner in Palantine, Ill.
A 45-year-old who wants to have $1 million by age 62 must save $2,088.04 a month if the investments return 9 percent a year, Ms. Pankros estimated.
Someone who has delayed investing and is ready to make a first mutual fund purchase should buy a solid "blend" fund, mixing growth and value stock-picking styles, said Katharine A. McGee, a St. Louis financial planner. She recommends two funds that buy large companies at lower-than-market prices -- the Nicholas Fund and the Yacktman Fund.
Diversification is the key for people who have built a core investment portfolio. "Spread your portfolio out and build it up," said Ross Levin, president of Accredited Investors Inc., a Minneapolis financial planning firm. "Introduce funds that work with each other without overlapping."
Mr. Levin likes Schaefer Value, a large-capitalization value fund that uses a contrarian strategy; Janus Fund, which moves between stocks and cash, and Selected American Shares, a large-capitalization growth fund. He also recommends the Brandywine Fund, a growth fund, for people who can meet its $25,000 minimum investment.
Ms. McGee noted that "as people get older, it gets more important not to lose money in down markets." To reduce risk but maintain capital growth, she would split domestic equity holdings between large- and small-capitalization stock funds that focus on growth or value. In the growth category, she likes the Janus Fund and Neuberger & Berman Manhattan. On the value side, she recommends the Lindner Fund and FAM Value, which invest in smaller companies.
Ms. Pankros, whose core portfolio recommendation is the Vanguard Index Trust 500, advises bringing overseas stock fund holdings up to 5 to 10 percent of the portfolio by buying shares in Harbor International, T. Rowe Price International Stock Fund and Vanguard Commingled International Stock Fund. On the domestic side, she would add Neuberger & Berman Partners or Guardian Fund, medium- to large-cap stock funds, and Vanguard Wellington, a balanced fund.
The international funds from Harbor and Price also appeal to Mr. Evensky. For further diversity, he likes two value funds, SEI Value and Windsor II, and three growth funds, SEI Capital Appreciation, Gabelli Growth and Twentieth Century Growth. Small-stock funds he favors are Meridian, SEI Small Cap Growth Portfolio and DFA U.S. Small Cap Value.
As people grow older, they should decrease equity exposure to 60 or 65 percent, most advisers say. However, "If you don't have too much money set aside already, you might have to stretch it a little," up to 70 percent, said Eileen M. Sharkey, a planner in Denver.
For the nonequity portion, Ms. Sharkey recommends the T. Rowe Price Short-Term Bond Fund and the Fidelity Intermediate Bond Fund. Among long-term offerings, she likes the PIMCO Total Return and PIMCO Low Duration funds.
Once a portfolio grows to, say, $350,000, "add an inflation hedge," Ms. McGee advised. She likes the Vanguard Specialized Energy Fund, which she said "should do well if the market falls and inflation creeps up."

HEADLINE: Viewpoints;
The Energy Tax: Its Time Will Come

BYLINE: By DAVID MORRIS and MICHAEL LEWIS; David Morris and Michael Lewis work at the Institute for Local Self-Reliance, a nonprofit environmental group in Washington, D.C., and Minneapolis. They are co-authors of "Beating the B.T.U. Tax: The 6 Percent Solution."

 BODY:
NOW that the budget battle is over, the nation can pick up the pieces of the broad energy tax. After long debate, Congress wound up with a narrow transportation fuel tax instead of President Clinton's across-the-board B.T.U. plan.
The funny thing, though, is that during the long national budget discussion, the proposed energy tax was portrayed solely as a deficit-reduction tool. It surely was that, but it was also much more. It took an important new approach to taxation. 
 Unlike most other taxes, a levy on energy is a tax on "bads" instead of "goods." A broad energy tax -- especially one that exempted renewable fuels as President Clinton's would have done -- is a tax on pollution. Isn't it better to tax pollution, something we want less of, than to tax income or jobs, two outputs we would like more of?
Looked at slightly differently, a broad energy tax penalizes inefficiency. An efficient business that uses less energy will pay less tax than an inefficient one that uses more. From this perspective, too, an energy tax seems like a good idea -- over and above its ability to raise revenue.
The specifics of the abandoned B.T.U. tax show how this works. The tax would have raised the price of energy, on average, by 6 percent. This means that consumers who improved energy efficiency by 6 percent would offset its impact.
Such improvements in efficiency are easily and economically achieved with current technology. For example, because processing scrap requires less energy than processing virgin materials, manufacturers can boost efficiency simply by using more recycled matter. The average glass mill uses 30 percent scrap glass, but some glass mills use as much as 78 percent. If we raised the industry average from 30 percent to 55 percent, the industry as a whole would reduce energy use enough to fully offset the B.T.U. tax.
Similarly, the typical aluminum smelter uses 31 percent scrap, while a state-of-the-art mill uses 70 percent. Raise the average smelter's use of scrap from 31 percent to 40 percent and the industry's savings would cancel the cost of the B.T.U. levy.
What about factory and office lighting? A 20 percent improvement in lighting efficiency would offset the B.T.U. tax, and would also be easily achieved. According to the Environmental Protection Agency, many buildings have reduced lighting energy by 35 percent to 83 percent through investments that repay themselves within three years.
And the farm lobby -- which loudly opposed the B.T.U. tax -- had only to look to its own fields to see how to neutralize it. More and more farmers are adopting a cultivation technique that minimizes plowing. While they use this "no tillage" practice to meet Federal soil-erosion goals, they've learned that it also lessens diesel fuel consumption by three to five gallons an acre.
Wherever one looks, in fact, similar savings are possible. But because Congress rejected a broad energy tax in favor of a narrow one, far fewer people will adopt these antipollution strategies.
Nevertheless, someday soon the nation will use tax policy to cut pollution. After all, the general idea is hardly revolutionary; "sin" taxes on liquor and cigarettes have long been widely accepted. And some states already use taxes to stem specific pollutants. Minnesota taxes some toxic emissions at 8 cents a pound, for instance.
But a broad-based energy tax -- especially one that exempts renewable fuels -- would dramatically extend this concept. And it may do so soon. The battle of the budget may be over, but the idea of using a tax as both a revenue raiser and a pollution deterrent may have just begun.

HEADLINE: COINS;
Rare Slave Badges To Be Sold at Auction

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:
COMING to auction on Sept. 9 is a collection of very rare slave-hiring badges from Charleston, S.C. Slave-hiring badges were issued to the owners of slaves who wished to rent them out for day work. In more rural places such an arrangement would have been a purely private affair, but in Charleston the practice became regulated in the early 18th century, and by 1751, hired-out slaves were required to wear badges.
Only 100 or so badges are now extant, and Stack's, which is handling the sale for the John J. Ford Jr. Collection, estimates that the 14 being offered will bring anywhere from $200 to $4,000. While thousands of badges are thought to have been issued by Mobile, Ala.; Savannah, Ga., and New Orleans, only badges from Charleston are known to exist. What happened to all the others is a mystery. 
 While the badges seem deeply repugnant today -- similar badges were also issued for dogs -- they are illustrative of the culture of slavery. Slaves hired for day work were paid less than whites, and because employers wanted to save money, whites were soon losing business. So Charleston instituted not only the badge system but also a quota system to protect white jobs: fewer badges were issued for occupations in which whites might lose jobs to slaves and more badges were issued for occupations in which nonwhites predominated.
By 1793 in Charleston, slaves who sold fish or vegetables at stands in the city were also required to wear badges. But eventually slave owners started to balk at the fees charged for the badges -- $2 to $7 a year, depending on occupation -- and lobbied to get the badge laws repealed in 1790.
After 10 years, Charleston reinstituted the badges at the insistence of white artisans. After the Civil War, badge laws were ignored and finally forgotten.
Each thin copper badge, an inch and a halfsquare, showed the name of the city, the year of issue, a badge number and a trade. Those trades are indicative of the economy of time: about 60 percent of the badges that still remain are for house servants, while nearly 20 percent are for porters. The rarest occupations are those of mechanic, carpenter, fruiterer and fisherman.
It is impossible to tell exactly how widespread the badge system was in Charleston. In the 1840's, Charleston had about 15,000 slaves, and it's estimated that 12 percent to 30 percent were ever hired out. Some early Charleston badges are struck on the reverse with the name of the city marshal (also a silversmith) who was responsible for enforcing the badge laws and setting wage scales.
The 14 slave-hiring badges, along with a superb collection of United States and Colonial coins that will also be sold, can be viewed at Stack's,123 West 57th Street, beginning Aug. 30, from from 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through Friday. Stack's will be closed on Labor Day, Sept. 6. The sale is scheduled for Sept. 8 and 9 at the Park Central Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 56th Street. More information is available from Stack's at (212) 582-2580.

GRAPHIC: Photo: One of the 14 slave-hiring badges, this one from 1847, for a porter. (Stack's)

HEADLINE: When Banks Make Currency Go Up and Down

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Central Banks Make It Easy to Bet Big on a Sure Thing" (Business Day, Aug. 3), you note that European central banks have given away "hundreds of millions, if not billions, of dollars" in failed attempts to defend certain currencies, particularly buying French francs, which were collapsing in value. This, you write, "again raised the question of why European governments, which end up paying the losses of their central banks, have been so willing to put up with a system that makes such losses a periodic inevitability." 
 While you implicitly recognize that Germany's Bundesbank could have averted such huge losses had it cut its discount rate by even a token amount, you fail to identify the primary political condition that allows the Bundesbank to choose its present high interest rate policy. The Bundesbank, like our own Federal Reserve Board, is independent of any elected government and free to pursue policies that harm the public while benefiting its natural constituency of powerful speculators and commercial bankers.
Presidents, none other than Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson, warned that vesting public powers in a privately directed central bank would result in such monumental favoritism. For instance, you report in "Europe Tumult Is U.S. Banks' Gain" (Business Day, Aug. 4) that the five largest United States banks have taken advantage of the latest instability in currencies and earned more than 40 percent of their profits on currency trading, reporting combined revenues of $2.2 billion from such activities in the second quarter alone, a record.
Why, then, would elected governments put up with such a system in which their central banks continue to subsidize private speculators and commercial bankers? It could be that those governments are now less accountable to electorates than to the private interests that finance their expensive political campaigns.
Certainly, the 1992 Presidential election campaign failed to offer any choices to American voters on such fundamental issues as the structure of the nation's central bank and the formulation of monetary policy.
All of us, including elected officials, journalists and the television news media, have too easily accepted the basic premise that central banking policy is best left to the so-called experts and that ordinary citizens, as well as Congress, should look the other way.
 
TIMOTHY A. CANOVA
New York, Aug. 6, 1993
 
The writer has taught international finance at the college level.

HEADLINE: Counsel Praises Bankruptcy Creditors

 BODY:
"Anatomy of L.I.'s Major Bankruptcy" fails to provide the overall context that would allow the reader to understand how and why any real estate bankruptcy takes place on Long Island during the recession of 1993.
The Racanelli corporate bankruptcy was not some sudden implosion but a calculated response by the firm to a combination of factors far beyond their control. These elements include the redrafting of Federal tax laws lowering the value of real estate investments, the ongoing commercial credit crunch, the region's lingering recession and a property tax structure that is crippling commercial and residential property owners alike. 
 In an internal report to members of the Association for a Better Long Island, which represents some $15 billion worth of Long Island commercial, retail, industrial and residential property, economist Thomas Conoscenti reported that, in contrast to past recessions, the economy of Long Island was affected by the downturn earlier and more severely than many other regions in the U.S.
He noted that, given the severeity of the regional downturn, coupled with the deep defense cutbacks, it will take some time for the local economy to fully recover. He reminds that the recession hit the regional manufacturing sector very hard. Since its peak in 1985, over 50,000 manufacturing jobs, mainly defense-related, have been lost. Employment in the construction and trade sectors has likewise declined in response to the weakness in the housing market and consumer spending. All of these elements have an impact on the commercial real estate market.
Those who view the economic troubles of the Racanelli company as some distant event with little impact on their personal lives, have no conception of how pivotal a role real estate plays in the Long Island economy. When a bankruptcy is suffered by a leader in an industry that comprises nearly a third of the bicounty's economy, every facet of the economy is touched -- from charitable donations to furniture sales to school tax generation.
While the Racanelli company, through their law firm, Meltzer, Lippe & Goldstein, is using the protection of the bankruptcy law to pay back their creditors, the best protection for all of us is a tax credit and economic structure that strengthens our real estate industry rather than one that invites them to hemorrhage. Until Congress understand that simple but profound fact of business, we all will stand with the Rancanellis.
 
STEPHEN HESS
Hauppauge
 
The writer is president of the Association for a Better Long Island.

HEADLINE: AUG. 8-14: On to Congress;
A Hurdle Is Cleared For Free-Trade Accord, And Its Foes Hiss

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration linked American trade policy to labor and environmental issues as never before last week when it struck three deals with Mexico and Canada, its prospective partners in the still-unratified North American Free Trade Agreement. The deals are aimed at protecting workers, businesses and the environment from possible side effects of the accord.
For decades, the United States has resisted tying trade to other issues, contending that free trade helps economies most when each country is free to use any competitive advantage it perceives as in its overriding interest, including low-wage labor or a willingness to pollute. Last week's deals will set up commissions in Ottawa and Washington to assure that all three countries at least enforce their domestic labor and environmental laws. 
 The three nations also agreed to meet at least annually to review any trade surges that threaten to overwhelm an industry in one country. If approved by Congress this fall, the free-trade pact would take effect on Jan. 1, 1994, and gradually eliminate tariffs, quotas and other investment barriers over the next 15 years.
But the side agreements persuaded few if any politicians or interest groups to change their views, and the agreement's prospects on Capitol Hill are cloudy. Ross Perot, the Texas businessman and Presidential aspirant, said the side agreements did not satisfy him. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, came off the fence when the deals were announced -- on the side of the free-trade pact's opponents.

HEADLINE: It's August; How Much Policy Can a Nation Take?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SAY of them what you will, Ronald Reagan and George Bush knew the value of a good rest from the public eye. Every August, Mr. Reagan flew to Santa Barbara and disappeared for a month, visible only rarely and only by telephoto lens, riding horses and clearing pesky brush. Mr. Bush went to Maine and rode boats and played golf. Momentous and terrifying world events sprang up with lunar regularity in August but dynamite could not have extracted these Presidents from their leisures.
January's Man from Hope, Ark., by contrast, threatens daily to become August's Man from Boring, Md. President Clinton has spent more time on television in the last seven months than Willard Scott. He has been host to domestic roundtables, proposed Russian economic rescue plans, contorted himself over policies on gay soldiers and illegal nannies. He has peddled budgets and stimulus packages and motor-voter schemes and campaign-finance reform, and heaven help us all, it is blazing hot outside and he is only now getting to the really mind-numbing stuff. 
 Much of America is in station wagons headed for the Great Smokies or at hardware stores getting the mower blades sharpened and new webbing for the lawn chairs. The President, however, is happily warming to the task of telling the citizenry about free-trade agreements and health-care reform. Even his own endless trek to a vacation spot is a series of earnest photo-ops with the Pope, flood victims and jobless defense workers.
He may be -- indeed, probably is -- terrifically conscientious about policy. It also may be rotten timing. At some uncalibrated dew point in the public psyche, the preachings of even the best-informed and most diligent leader cease to be informative. People start tuning out.
Managing the capital of the Presidency -- as Mr. Reagan proved until Iran-contra and Mr. Bush until the economy soured -- is a lot like managing the diamond cartels. Put too little on the market and they become too precious for the common man; too much and they become zircon. Pacing is all. At the moment, with fingers in Bosnia, the North American Free Trade Agreement, health-care reform and a new round of budget cuts, Mr. Clinton seems to be holding a fire sale.
Monitoring of public opinion provides some hints of that, though nothing conclusive. According to Nielsen Media Research, the television ratings people, the new President was absolutely boffo in February. His State of the Union address then grabbed a 54.8 rating, higher than any such speech since Ronald Reagan drew a 60 in his first such address in 1981. George Bush's best State of the Union, in 1992, got a 47.2. (Forget the actual numbers; each speech was seen on well over half the television sets that were turned on. A hit television show does well to get a 20 rating and a 30 share of sets in use.)
In succeeding months, Mr. Clinton's viewership has more or less steadily tailed off, as might be expected of anyone who has lost his novelty. By June, the introduction of his Supreme Court nominee, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, was drawing a 15.6 rating.
 
Competition From Old B-Movies
 The ratings for Mr. Clinton's Aug. 3 budget speech are not in. But a CNN-USA Today opinion poll after the address suggested it was tuned in by about half of adults, but that only about 21 percent persevered to the end. That would seem to place the President perilously close to Bill Cosby's B-movie "Ghost Dad," which attracted 16 percent of viewers in a network outing some months ago.
Mr. Clinton's advisers complain, with some justification, that the President is catching flak for incessantly directing national attention to the very problems -- the deficit, the trade balance, health care -- that people elected him to attack. "I think people said three months ago that we weren't adequately focused," a senior Administration official said last week. "Now we're adequately focused, and now they're saying, 'Hey, gee, we're too focused.' Give me a break."
All right. To be fair, Mr. Clinton is in part a victim of changing habits and tastes. Citizens cleaved to Franklin Roosevelt and his radio fireside chats in part because he was a voice of hope amid depression, and in part because there was no Nintendo, "Hard Copy" or Chicago Bulls to divert them. Mr. Reagan offered some of the same hope and singleness of purpose amid economic travail and Cold War tension.
The current President has none of those unifying advantages. Fears of war have faded, replaced by a faceless anxiety about jobs and life styles that the Government seems wholly incapable of salving. There is no national cause, like defeating the Soviet Union or rebuilding the cities, because there is no enemy and there is no money. Nor is there any reliable way to judge what is important, because the 1980's explosion of news and pseudo-news -- from cable TV, national newspapers and television "magazines" -- has created calamity out of a simpler, if more threatening world.
That is all the more true if political leaders are not modulating their voices, distinguishing the essential from what is merely extremely important. For the Presidency these days is less a bully pulpit than a telephone solicitor, interrupting the dinner hour or "Roseanne" for a pitch that the folks at home either deeply mistrust or simply don't want to hear. Make it quick; we just got home and it's only two hours till bed. And no, you can't have our credit-card number.
"Some period ago, maybe in the 60's and 70's, people felt that government and politics were either interesting to them or were acutely important, because they had a direct relationship to their daily lives," one of Mr. Reagan's advisers, the opinion analyst Robert M. Teeter, said last week.
The changes of the 1980's, he said, broke that link. Presidents and governments just don't command rapt and continuous attention any more. To get attention at all -- to seem vital again, to set the national agenda -- they have to learn when to shout and when to whisper. And when to say nothing at all.
Especially when it's hot.
It's very hot now. No offense, but we're a busy nation, this is our only week off, and we have to go make deviled eggs for the block party.
