SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1241 words

HEADLINE: A Little Gun Control, a Lot of Guns

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
IT was 1981 when a young man with a handgun shot President Reagan and his press secretary, James S. Brady, prompting what would become a new wave of gun-control activism led by the permanently maimed Mr. Brady and his tirelessly campaigning wife, Sarah. In the dozen years since that day, Americans have bought nearly 50 million new guns, including more than 20 million handguns. Altogether, Federal officials estimate, Americans may own 200 million firearms.
Last week, as promised, President Clinton declared his support for the measure that gun-control advocates have sought most avidly: the Brady bill, which would require background checks on handgun purchasers in every state, in most cases with a waiting period of five business days. Such checks aim to detect felons, people who have been committed for mental illness, out-of-state residents and others who are legally prohibited from buying a gun. 
 It remains uncertain whether the bill will become part of a broader, more controversial crime bill, as it did -- fatally -- in 1991. But with the public behind it by nearly nine to one in several different polls, a majority of Congress in support and a sympathetic President, there seems a real chance that this most modest of limits on the hallowed American right to wield firearms will soon become law.
How much practical difference it would make is less clear. The National Rifle Association may be stretching things when it says that legal restrictions affect only the law-abiding.
But most gun-control advocates admit that many criminals will still find ways to buy or steal weapons. And half the states already have some sort of background checks or waiting periods, some more stringent than the requirements in the Brady bill.
Backers see the bill as only the first of many measures to tighten regulation of gun sales. They also argue that the Brady bill's nationwide reach will hamper gun-runners who now buy in the states where purchases are easiest for resale in blighted cities. This could ultimately raise black-market prices and make it harder for a 16-year-old boy in New York or Washington to find a weapon to settle a petty dispute.
Proponents say that checks and waits could also deter people who are not normally part of the criminal world from obtaining a gun for murder or suicide in the heat of anger or depth of depression. Since half the country's households already keep a gun, though, this effect too may be limited.
"I don't think anybody sees it as making a major dent in the violent crime problem," said Philip J. Cook, an economist and expert on gun violence at Duke University who is sympathetic to gun controls. "It's not going to reduce the murder rate by 20 percent.
"But it's not very costly either, and it's not going to be a major imposition on gun buyers. It's a common-sense type of regulation, and it's going to help on the margin."
Figures from California, which has the kind of law that many Brady bill promoters would write for the whole nation if they could, are instructive but not conclusive. There, a 15-day waiting period covers purchases of all guns -- rifles and shotguns as well as handguns. It also covers private sales of used guns, not just retail sales. (The Brady bill covers only handguns and retail sales, leaving significant gaps.)
In 1992, the state received 559,608 applications to buy a gun. After checking out the would-be purchasers, it turned down 5,763 of them, in nearly all cases because they had criminal records. What no one knows is how many of the rejected applicants then had friends stand in as buyers or found weapons on the black market.
Nor can anyone possibly calculate how many crimes were prevented. Through recent years, as its gun-purchase laws were tightened, California's murder rate still hovered at 25 percent above the national average. Yet, as Sarah Brady said in an interview, "You have to stop and ask: 'Would you rather have those 6,000 people able to go into a store and buy a gun?' "
Though she declines to speculate on numbers, Ms. Brady, who is chairwoman of Handgun Control Inc., says she is sure that background checks and waiting periods will prevent many killings, assaults and robberies. But even more, she sees the Brady bill as "the cornerstone of a serious gun-control policy in America" that will eventually include more restrictions.
That, of course, is the reason the gun lobby opposes the bill despite its moderate scope, and even despite the support it receives in surveys from more than four out of five gun-owners.
 
In the Chamber: Assault Rifle Ban
 High on the advocates' list of next steps are a national ban on semiautomatic assault-style weapons, which hold large numbers of cartridges; limits on multiple purchases (like the new anti-gun-runner law in Virginia that restricts buyers to one handgun a month); background checks for private gun sales, and far tighter control over who gets Federal licenses to sell guns.
"Without the first step of the Brady bill, we're never going to get anywhere," Ms. Brady said. "We can't waste any more time." She pointed out that the Virginia limit on multiple purchases, for example, would be unenforceable without some sort of waiting period, backed up by a computerized system that would catch those who tried to buy from several stores.
Other future measures she and her colleagues are discussing, she said, include more thorough background checks including fingerprinting of purchasers, required safety training for gun buyers and a system of "needs-based licensing," with different requirements for hunters, target shooters and security guards. Her organization, unlike some others, does not call for an outright ban on handgun sales. This would arguably do far more to curb crime, but the proposal raises the hackles of many recreational gun owners who may support more modest measures.
Ms. Brady predicts, optimistically in light of history, that passage of the Brady bill will soften up Congress for more. "Once we get this," she said, "I think it will become easier and easier to get the laws we need passed."
In any case, many experts caution, gun laws -- short perhaps of politically unreal steps to bar most sales or even confiscate many weapons -- cannot transform patterns of violence that are deeply rooted in economic, cultural and social trends. Gary Kleck, a criminologist at Florida State University who is a skeptic about the effects of gun control, agreed that background checks are worthwhile. But he cautioned against expecting too much from even stringent rules.
He argues that the criminal justice system does not -- either through jails or gun controls -- have a large impact on crime. "Social control doesn't come from the legal system, but from a national social order," he said. "So the N.R.A. is flat wrong in suggesting that the alternative to gun control is stopping that revolving-door justice system they are always yammering about. And Handgun Control is wrong in suggesting that its measures will have much of an impact either."
Dr. Cook puts a different gloss on the same sobering truth: "In these areas of social control there is only so much you can do. You would have to accept a 10 percent reduction in violent crime as a great victory.
"If we stop thinking in percentages and think instead that maybe we'll save a few hundred lives every year," he said, "then it sounds like a worthwhile thing to do."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
For Japan, the Old Slurs Are the New Party Line

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
CHANGE in Japan often seems glacial, a process of half-steps that usually add up to little. Then there are periods like the last 10 days.
In a complex about-face, Japan has broken through a half-century of denials, speaking frankly about the terrible mistakes of World War II and about the dynamics of its economy. But while the Japanese now express shame over what their military leaders did during World War II, they feel just fine, thank you, about what their economic leaders have done ever since. 
 Five years ago, some Western critics were derided by the Japanese establishment as wrong -- and probably racist -- for declaring that Japanese policy was set by bureaucrats, not politicians, and that Japanese politics was often corrupt. The Japanese denied that their country's economy was controlled by an "iron triangle" of bureaucrats, businessmen and politicians and bristled at the notion that Japan's form of state-supported capitalism was different from Western capitalism.
That was then. Now, there is a dramatic change in the language -- if not the reality -- of political and economic discourse here. Suddenly, expressions and criticisms previously regarded as blasphemous when uttered by foreign "revisionists" and "Japan bashers" are spoken with a surprising matter-of-factness.
"This is giving me a funny feeling," said Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., a former United States trade negotiator and one of the experts who has been reviled as a "revisionist." "Five years ago they were condemning me to the outermost reaches of hell for saying some of this stuff. We were called racist."
Morihiro Hosokawa, the new Prime Minister and the first one drawn from outside the Liberal Democratic Party in 38 years, not only declared the war an act of aggression, but also vowed to break open the iron triangle that has run Japan for decades and kept its markets effectively closed to foreign competition.
Mr. Hosokawa referred to the corrupt old order as "disgusting" and promised, "We will eliminate this collusive structure."
The new Minister of International Trade and Industry, Hiroshi Kumagai, dropped a bombshell when he said that Japan's economy is basically closed and riddled with anti-competitive practices. "Big business's cartel-like character is tremendous," Mr. Kumagai insisted.
The country's business leaders, worried about the mounting international anger over Japan's trade surpluses -- the imbalance is expected to come to more than $150 billion this year -- now admit that tougher measures may be required to crack open Japan's markets. Some suggest that targets for imports may be necessary if the surplus is to be reduced. That is just what the Clinton Administration has demanded.
"It is a fact that Japan has a trade surplus with the United States, and that Japan's market openings are not sufficient," said Masaru Hayami, chairman of the Nissho Iwai Corporation, one of Japan's largest trading houses. "I understand the American side's feeling of wanting to use target figures for a range of three to four years."
Of course, skeptics argue that this cathartic outpouring is a means of deflecting calls for real change. There are already plenty of signs that the new Government will be slower to enact reform than to talk about it. In his first press conference last week, Mr. Hosokawa said he was eager to reduce Japan's yawning trade surpluses, but he rejected most of the Clinton Administration's proposal for doing so.
 
Japan: Emulate Us

 
 The surprising candor has another aspect. If the Japanese once responded to Western economic critics by saying, "Not so," they are now saying, essentially, "So what?" There is a new, vocal insistence that some elements of the Japanese way of doing things have worked brilliantly and should be emulated.
The problem is that these longstanding methods fly in the face of classical Western economic theory, since they give government an active role in shaping industrial and financial development, inhibiting the free play of markets.
Japanese officials may be openly declaring some aspects of their power structure corrupt, but they are increasingly selling abroad those features about which they feel confident, particularly the idea that a well-drawn and judiciously applied industrial policy is superior to free markets. In effect, the latest Japanese export is not a product, but an economic theory, and in the marketplace of ideas it could well prove as competitive as Japanese autos and VCR's.
One of the main ideas espoused by the so-called revisionists -- people like Mr. Prestowitz, Chalmers Johnson, author of a pioneering study of Japanese industrial policy, and Karl Van Wolfern, who has written on the political structure -- is that Japan is different in fundamental ways from the West, principally because of the role of the bureaucracy in guiding the markets. Classical Western economists argue that any such interference will, by definition, weaken the economy. Japanese experts say the results speak for themselves.
In the current period of Japanese glasnost, the differences in its economic organization are claimed as a virtue, particularly since other successful East Asian nations, including South Korea, Taiwan, China and Singapore, have followed a similar path.
In a speech last year, Yasushi Mieno, the governor of the Bank of Japan, exhorted the boards of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to recognize that the Japanese model was superior to the free-market approach.
"Experience in Asia has shown that, although development strategies require a healthy respect for market mechanisms, the role of the government cannot be forgotten," Mr. Mieno said. He added that Japan hoped the West would examine its approach and "that the fruit of such a study will be applied extensively to development strategies."
 
No Change Seen

 
 "It's hard to question success," said Vinod Thomas, chief economist of the East Asian region at the World Bank. "The only area of the world that has grown with such dramatic success in recent years is East Asia."
Japan has sent economic missions to the Central Asian republics of the former Soviet Union and, more recently, to Moscow. Those economic missionaries have not been shy about explaining why they feel the West's insistence that Russia throw its markets open is misguided.
And that is why, even with the new mood in Tokyo, some things are bound to change, and some will not. The new Government and its Prime Minister want to remove points of friction between Japan and the West and to restore the Government's credibility by attacking corruption. But the Government still wants to cultivate a strong economy, following its own proven methods.
Confidence in those methods is evident. Recently, the Government directed trading companies to import less beef, because this was causing prices to decline and hurting domestic producers. Eijiro Hata, the Agriculture Minister, defended the intervention in the market, arguing that low prices ultimately would hurt the Japanese consumer.

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
Weary Clinton Takes Break From His Own Frenetic Style

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 14

 BODY:
After a whirlwind first stretch that has lasted seven long months, President Clinton has finally gone on vacation today. He has left Washington weary; even worse, much of his support is exhausted.
Not for two generations has a new President sought to do so much, so fast and so directly. And not since modern polling began has popular approval of a new occupant of the White House declined so precipitously and failed to rebound. 
 Mr. Clinton, to be sure, is a plurality President, having won office with just 43 percent of the popular vote. That left his standing fragile from Inauguration Day, guaranteeing that each fight would require a balancing act as he sought to reconstitute a vague mandate for change.
But more than that has been at work to give Mr. Clinton's initial months in office their frenetic cast. The triumphs and wreckage scattered across his calendar reflect what he himself brought to the Presidency. More by nature than circumstance, perhaps, Mr. Clinton governs by careering from one tight spot to another.
That pattern reflects Mr. Clinton's inclination first to overreach, offering schemes too ambitious for political reality, and then to pull back, leaving confusion about which tack is authentic. From homosexuals in the military to the battle over the budget, he has relied for extrication on words in torrents, energy without sleep and, in the end, compromise.
 
Emotional Issues
 Against early advice to maintain his promised focus on the economy, Mr. Clinton has swept through a dizzying series of emotional issues, planting him in the middle of dust-ups on nannies and Social Security, civil rights, accusations of misconduct in the White House and the propriety of a haircut at the Los Angeles airport.
Such stormy weather could hardly have been more different from the breezes or steady trade winds that prevailed under his two Republican predecessors. But then Mr. Clinton, who turns 47 on Thursday, is the first of the Vietnam War generation to reach the White House, and the squalls of his tenure may reflect something of his youth.
After taking a real vacation in four years, Mr. Clinton not surprisingly responded, "Definitely," the other night when asked whether he was looking forward to this one. (Even so, he will do a day's work on Monday in delivering a health care address to the National Governor's Association in Tulsa, Okla.)
But it seemed somehow telling that Mr. Clinton and his family, who own no home of their own, began their holiday with a visit to this Rocky Mountain resort and its paterfamilias, former President Gerald R. Ford.
Among the misgivings of those who clamored for change, one may be that from George Washington to George Bush, Americans have generally regarded Presidents as fathers. In appearance and manner, Mr. Clinton has played more the role of a brother or even a son.
That should not detract from the very real achievements of his first seven months in office, and at news conferences, on talk radio shows and in public forums, Mr. Clinton has grown accomplished at reminding his audiences of just how much he has accomplished.
 
What Has Been Done
 There was the quick Congressional agreement on the broad outlines of his budget, he says. There was the Vancouver summit meeting and the pledge by the West to help shore up the economy of the former Soviet Union. There was the deal to allow logging in the Northwest while protecting spotted owls. There was the passage of his national service plan, which provides college grants in return for a commitment to community work.
And most important of all was the approval of his plan for spending cuts and tax increases to shave $496 billion from the projected budget deficit over the next five years. As the President asserted today in a radio address he taped before beginning his holiday, "It puts our house in order with the largest deficit reduction measure in our history."
But Mr. Clinton's very need to call attention to his victories suggests the degree to which Americans have not seen them as such -- or the degree to which the gains have been obscured by what else went wrong.
 
Turbulent Weeks
 As landmarks in a young Presidency, the failed choices of Zoe Baird and Judge Kimba M. Wood as Attorneys General; the flaps over the Presidential haircut; the abrupt dismissal of the staff of the White House travel office, and the suicide of Vincent W. Foster Jr., the deputy White House counsel, have in some ways stood out even more than the triumphs.
Part of the reason, as Mr. Clinton's aides acknowledge, is that he is not adept at making his victories look easy. Rather than choosing a modest goal at the outset, Mr. Clinton's inclination has been to reach for the stars, and only then to walk his sights back to earth.
That pattern reflects two contradictory impulses that Mr. Clinton shares with many members of his generation: idealism and a preference for consensus. But in the political world, they leave him in the position of always appearing to retreat, with each accommodation raising questions in the minds of many voters about what he truly believes in.
That was the case with Mr. Clinton's budget proposal, whose early promises of a middle-class tax cut were quickly withdrawn, with other ambitious elements later cast aside to satisfy lawmakers' objections. The endless haggling took its toll: public support for the package dropped even after it was approved by Congress.
 
Different Yardsticks
 To those who ask why he seems so willing to compromise, Mr. Clinton has insisted that toughness should be measured in the task. He says he would rather do hard things than merely talk tough about them.
But compromise, even to achieve a goal, stands at odds with the kind of public swagger Americans usually admire in politicians. If that translates to weakness, as it appears to have done, it raises the danger of self-perpetuation, with each concession inviting another.
After an election that was more a referendum on his opponent than on himself, Mr. Clinton and his advisers had recognized that these first months would be a forum for public judgment. Even in January, Mr. Clinton's pollster, Stanley Greenberg, was issuing reminders about the fickleness of public opinion.
As others marveled over how high Mr. Clinton's approval rating had soared, Mr. Greenberg noted that George Bush had embarked on his Presidency from similar heights.
 
Change of Generations
 What perhaps no one could measure seven months ago was how Mr. Clinton's youth, and that of his cadre of aides, would affect perceptions of his Presidency. By defeating a man 22 years older, Mr. Clinton won the single greatest generational contest for the White House in more than a century.
If his youth served then as a symbol of all that would be different, it has also carried with it the risk that affairs of state would seem to be in less than full control. When Mr. Clinton owns up to mistakes, or his staff apologizes for error, the impression left sometimes is less that of contrition than of inexperience.
As the leader of the free world at last month's Group of Seven meeting in Tokyo, Mr. Clinton carried out his role with aplomb. But there remain occasional reminders of just how young this new President can seem.
At the Denver airport this week, Mr. Clinton even became his own soundman when he encountered a malfunctioning microphone as he tried to introduce John Paul II. "Can you hear me?" the President of the United States shouted repeatedly. "Can you hear me now?"
Each time, Mr. Clinton glumly answered his own question, "No," but the Pope looked on beatifically.

HEADLINE: Brazil Seeks to Return Ancestral Lands to Descendants of Runaway Slaves

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DAS RAS, Brazil

 BODY:
Backed by lawyers and land titles, a rancher recently drove black peasants from their traditional lands here, bulldozing their houses, shooting their horses, burning their fences and running cattle through their crops.
But drawing on a centuries-old spirit of resistance, the farmers stubbornly refuse to surrender lands that their ancestors first settled as fugitive slaves. 
 "We prefer to walk on our own two feet than to be led around like goats on halters," said Mario Nunes de Souza, a leader of the Rio das Ras, or Frog Creek, community in the state of Bahia in northeastern Brazil. "We don't have the slightest doubt that the land will be returned to us."
Using this remote land fight as a test case, Brazil's Attorney General's office hopes to set a legal precedent that could eventually protect hundreds of black villages in rural Brazil. In September, prosecutors will ask a federal judge to return ancestral lands to black farmers here on the ground that they are descendants of a "quilombo," a community of runaway slaves.
Seeking to extend to traditional black communities the same legal protection offered Indian tribes, Brazil's 1988 Constitution provides that the state should recognize land use by "descendants of quilombo communities" and should "issue them the respective titles."
The clause was supported by black groups, the Roman Catholic Church, the leftist Workers' Party and groups advocating distribution of land to landless peasants.
 
500,000 Could Win Land Titles

Brazil imported about 18 million enslaved West Africans, more than any other colony or country in the Americas. Instituted shortly after the Portuguese claimed Brazil in 1500, slavery lasted here until 1888, longer than anywhere else in the Americas.
Today, anthropologists estimate that the quilombo clause in the Constitution could give land titles to about 500,000 descendants of free black communities established before slavery was abolished. In contrast, most of Brazil's 250,000 Indians already live on legally protected reservations.
The urgency of land titling grows as paved roads and hydroelectric dam projects suddenly bring the modern world to the doorsteps of remote black communities.
In Brazil, which has the world's largest black population after Nigeria, interest in quilombos is growing with the approach of the 300th anniversary of the execution in 1695 of Zumbi dos Palmares, the most prominent black resistance leader. About half of Brazil's 155 million people trace all or part of their ancestry to West Africa.
Originally called Little Angola, the Palmares quilombo grew to house 20,000 people in 10 villages scattered over a forested, hilly area overlooking sugar cane plantations on the coast of what is now Alagoas State. ("Kilombu" variously means "encampment" or "forest dweller" in the languages of West Africa's coast, the homeland of most Africans forced into slavery in Brazil.)
Enduring from 1605 to 1694, the Palamares quilombo provided a challenge to the slave-based economy of colonial Brazil. Registered recently as a National Historic Landmark, Palamares is being excavated by a Brazilian-American archeological team led by Charles E. Orser, an assistant professor of anthropology at Illinois State University.
Brazilian black activists hope to observe the 300th anniversary of Zumbi's death by distributing land titles to descendants of quilombos. Last year, the Palmares Foundation, a Government agency, started a nationwide survey of eligible black communities.
 
Dams Are Planned Where Slaves Fled
 Isolation is a modern legacy of 18th- and 19th-century Portuguese colonial policy. The authorities relentlessly pursued escaped slaves with special military units and private bounty hunters. In the Amazon, slaves escaping the cocoa plantations of Santarem started to flee up the Trombetas River in the early 1800's. After each armed incursion in pursuit, they retreated deeper into the forest, portaging their possessions around river rapids.
Today, these same rapids attract the attention of companies that want to build two hydroelectric dams in the area, and descendants of these Amazon quilombos are fighting for titles to lands used by 7,000 people in 25 villages.
"Community representatives are now walking and marking the limits of their traditional lands," said Leinad Ayer de Oliveira Santos, an anthropologist.
In Brazil's central savanna, slaves fled the gold mines of Goias in the 18th century for rugged hill country above Bezerra Falls on the Parana River. Today, about 4,000 descendants live in 41 villages scattered over 780 square miles.
"When I first went there in 1982, there were no roads," said Mari Baiocchi, an anthropologist. "The only way in was by donkey."
Later, as Brazil's agricultural frontier stretched west, dirt roads reached into the territory and plans were made to block Bezerra Falls with a hydroelectric dam. Although Goias State registered the lands as historic patrimony in 1991, about 60 mining, ranching and farming companies moved into the blacks' ancestral lands.
"There are serious land conflicts in the region, characterized by the systematic invasion of lands and the expansion of existing ranches," read a recent report by Furnas, the power company.
Historically, political support for the land rights of Brazil's rural blacks has been weak or nonexistent. But in one exception, about 1,000 descendants of a quilombo in Maranhao State won legal protection of their area in 1990. At the time, a Maranhao native, Jose Sarney, was Brazil's President.
"In Maranhao there are 10,000 families living in 400 black communities," said Alfredo Wagner, an anthropologist who in 1989 conducted a survey financed by the Ford Foundation. "But five years after the Constitution went into effect, no quilombo has won official recognition. Today, Maranhao is a champion of agrarian conflicts."
 
Music Groups Give Blacks Influence
 But Brazil's rural blacks are winning new allies -- the Roman Catholic Church, the Workers' Party and an urban black rights movement, bolstered by popular Afro-Brazilian music groups like the internationally famous drum corps Ile Aiye and Olodum.
"I had been to Brasilia 15 times, but I never got a reception like the one I got last May," Mr. de Souza said as fellow workers gathered under the shade of a mango tree here to hear him tell the story once again. "Those boys from Ile Aiye really opened doors."
Indeed, the turning point for the decade-old struggle of the 198 families here may have come in May, after a black newspaper reporter made the 13-hour bus ride here from Salvador, the coastal capital of Bahia State and the home of Ile Aiye and Olodum. His dispatches caught their attention.
On May 18, a mixed group of rural and urban black activists arrived in Brasilia, the capital. As the pounding of tall drums echoed off Government buildings, protesters chanted: "Quilombo, here we are; my only debt is to the quilombo; my only debt is to Zumbi."
In a turnaround, the delegation was received by Brazil's Minister of Justice, Mauricio Correa. The minister, a close friend of President Itamar Franco, promised to speed legal recognition of the quilombo descendants.
In the 18th and 19th centuries, Brazilian landowners demanded zealous enforcement of laws banning quilombos, which were defined as "two or more blacks living in the wild." Today, Brazilian landowners demand stringent, scholarly proof of a quilombo's existence.
Warning that the quilombo movement is "a Trojan Horse for agrarian reform," some landowners say they will ask Brazil's Congress to remove the clause when Congress starts a constitutional review in October. Black groups are pushing to set a legal precedent before the review starts.
"There is no evidence that there ever was a quilombo on my land," maintained Carlos Newton Vasconcelos Bonfim, the rancher who moved here in 1984. "If my land was a quilombo, then all of Bahia is a quilombo, because there are blacks all over the state."
Asserting that his land titles are part of an unbroken chain stretching to the 1600's, Mr. Bonfim ignored several orders by a local judge to return 58 square miles, about one third of his land, to black families. To enforce a 1988 accord with the peasants, Mr. Bonfim's ranch hands bulldozed houses, shot livestock and destroyed crops, farmers here said.
Last October, the rancher won national notoriety when gunmen under his control blocked a Roman Catholic bishop and 300 people from celebrating an outdoor Mass at a black community here.
 
Lack of Paper Trail Complicates Search
 A federal judicial decision in the dispute will hinge on a report by a team of anthropologists who came here in June. Their scientific detective game will undoubtedly be replayed again and again in the 1990's as more and more black communities seek recognition.
Illiterates, former slaves left no paper records. Fugitives, they rarely registered their births with local Catholic churches. Contributing to a lack of paper documents, Brazil's military Government ordered the nationwide destruction of all slave records in 1890. The Government feared indemnity lawsuits by former slaveholders.
In one breakthrough, researchers uncovered a 1667 royal order to establish authority around Rio das Ras, "where bandits and blacks live in quilombos." Always a frontier area, this region was tied by the Sao Francisco River to regions where slaves worked in colonial cotton plantations and salt mines.
Moving camps frequently, fugitive Afro-Brazilians stayed ahead of 19th-century bounty hunters, but left little material evidence behind for 20th-century historians.
"We have to rely largely on oral history and reconstructing genealogies," said Siglia Zambrotti Doria, an anthropologist who worked here.
Local family trees go back as far as the 1870's, well before abolition. According to family histories, in the 1890's farmers here shifted cultivation from the dry, inhospitable outback to the fertile river bank. This would coincide with the end of river-borne slave-raiding parties.
With no trace of a plantation house in the area, older community members led researchers to the ruins of a hilltop corral. According to local lore, a bounty hunter detained captured Indians and runaway slaves in the corral.
"Our ancestors came here to get away from the whip, from the hard labor regime," Mr. de Souza said to explain why the community resists an offer by Mr. Bonfim to live on 10 percent of his ranch. "We aren't livestock to be kept in a corral."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
Candidates Fight for NOW's Support

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

 BODY:
No sooner had Christine Todd Whitman picked up a political plum in her Republican campaign for New Jersey governor by winning the support of the state chapter of the National Organization for Women than Gov. Jim Florio tried to persuade one and all that it was more like sour grapes. Then Mr. Florio spent the rest of last week trying to steal the plum from Mrs. Whitman's plate, or at least to force her to share it.
NOW's state political action committee announced its qualified support of Mrs. Whitman on Monday, but by the end of the week, Mr. Florio and his Democratic political allies were buoyed by a wave of defections among local NOW chapters. 
 Beth B. Hess, a charter member of NOW's state organization and a founder of the Morris County area chapter, led the defectors, resigning from the state chapter after criticizing the group's support of Mrs. Whitman as "irresponsible" and "utterly stupid." Ms. Hess also proclaimed Mr. Florio a "better feminist" than Mrs. Whitman.
Expressing reservations about both candidates and their stances on feminist issues, NOW stopped short of a full endorsement of Mrs. Whitman and instead issued a "recommendation" that its members vote for her.
Still, the decision was important for several reasons.
NOW has traditionally supported Democratic candidates in statewide and national races. Mr. Florio, who failed to win NOW's endorsement four years ago, had hoped the organization would support him in his uphill fight for re-election. Then there is the factor that Mrs. Whitman's Republican primary opponents dreaded and that must also concern Mr. Florio.
Mrs. Whitman is the first woman to run for governor in New Jersey as a major party candidate. While polls show no gap between the sexes and Mr. Florio running slightly ahead of Mrs. Whitman among men and women, both sides have been diligent in courting women's votes.
NOW praised both Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Florio for their support of abortion rights without restrictions, the Equal Rights Amendment and civil rights for homosexuals.
But the group split with Mr. Florio over his vigorous support of the state's controversial welfare plan, which among other things denies increased benefits to women on welfare who continue having children. Mrs. Whitman also supports the legislation, although Mr. Florio accused her of waffling on the issue to attract NOW's support.
"We are deeply disappointed that we have one candidate who is championing the New Jersey version of welfare reform nationwide and another candidate who is thus far supportive of the New Jersey welfare reform," NOW said. "However, Governor Florio is proselytizing across the nation to spread the concept. Whitman is willing to look at alternatives."
 
Reviving the 'Green Agenda'
 A former hot-button issue that has been missing from the New Jersey political debate this year stirred another special-interest group into action last week in Trenton.
A coalition of six environmental and public interest groups -- the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, the Sierra Club, the Association of New Jersey Environmental Commissioners, the American Lung Association, the Clean Air Network and the New Jersey Environmental Lobby -- launched a campaign to pressure the gubernatorial and legislative candidates into addressing environmental issues.
"We have been waiting in vain for either gubernatorial candidate to take a strong leadership role on environmental issues facing the state," said Tim Dillingham, executive director of the Sierra Club.
Four years ago polls showed that New Jersey residents placed the environment at the top of their list of concerns. But polls this year show it near the bottom of the list, with the economy and jobs at the top.
Nevertheless, the groups said they would press ahead with their "green agenda," urging strict state compliance with the Federal Clean Air Act, restoration of millions of dollars to the Office of State Planning's budget and quick passage of pending legislation that would impose tough penalties to protect the state's Pinelands wilderness area.
 
New Voice in Abortion Case
 Mother Teresa has weighed in on a legal case in New Jersey involving abortion.
She has added her voice to those of John Cardinal O'Connor, the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey and the New Jersey Right to Life Committee in asking the New Jersey Supreme Court to hear the case of Alexander V. Loce.
Mr. Loce, a college student, was arrested in 1990 when he tried unsuccessfully to block access to an operating room at a clinic to prevent his fiancee, who was eight weeks pregnant, from getting an abortion.
What began as a trespassing case has grown over the last two years into a legal debate not only about when life begins, but whether a fetus deserves constitutional protection. Mr. Loce has argued that if the fetus was constitutionally protected he may not be prosecuted "for acting reasonably in its defense."

HEADLINE: Bushwick's Hope Is a Public Project

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
In their darkest days, the blocks around St. Barbara's Roman Catholic Church in the Bushwick neighborhood of Brooklyn absorbed misfortunes of nearly biblical dimensions.
In the mid- to late 1970's, fires coursed through the streets with such regularity that to enable fast evacuation, mothers often dressed their children for bed in street clothes. In the name of urban renewal, the city tore down blocks and blocks of homes, but never built the promised replacements. Packs of wild dogs were often the only signs of life on these streets, the pounding of scavengers pulling copper wire and aluminum fixtures from burned-out buildings the only sound. 
 The Sunday after the power blackout of July 1977, when Bushwick was devastated by more looting and arson than any other neighborhood in the city, a visiting Ecuadorean priest named Gabriel Santacruz mounted St. Barbara's carved wood pulpit, with its fanciful representations of peacocks, squirrels and other animals, and bleakly told his dwindling congregation, "We are without God now."
 
Unconventional, Little Heralded, Very Successful
 Today Father Santacruz would hardly recognize the place. Though Bushwick remains intensely poor, the neighborhood around St. Barbara's Church is one of the least heralded and most successful urban reclamation projects in New York City. At its heart is the largest public housing project built in America since the Reagan Administration took office in 1981 -- a development, unconventional for New York, consisting mostly of three-story buildings, which sprawl out over once-filthy lots for a half mile or more. Its residents have named it Hope Gardens.
At the center of Hope Gardens is a 14-story residential tower for the elderly and three seven-story apartment buildings, completed 11 years ago, that form a wall along Menahan Street. But these are not what distinguish the development. Rather it is the more than 50 red- or tan-brick, suburban style three-story buildings, built over a five-year period in the 1980's, that spread for more than 30 acres in all directions from St. Barbara's, still interspersed with blocks of old wood-frame row houses, lots strewn with garbage and even crack dens.
These buildings are known as the town houses by their black residents and casitas by Hispanic residents, and they represent the Housing Authority's most sweeping move away from the signature red-brick high-rises that critics have long argued stigmatize residents and neighborhoods and add to their danger and lack of community.
Other developments intended to revive troubled neighborhoods around the city also include new low-rise buildings, but those projects focus on home ownership and are aimed at working-class and moderate-income residents. Hope Gardens, on the other hand, is overwhelmingly filled with low-income tenants, more than a third of them on welfare.
Yet its success is evident in small details. There are murals in public hallways in some of the buildings, painted by their tenants. There are tidy white draperies in some of the public hallway windows.
Antonia Vazquez, who has lived in Bushwick for more than 20 years, is not unusual when she opens the unguarded window of her light yellow, 2-bedroom ground-floor apartment and lets the sun and the laughter of children from the public school playground across Central Avenue flood into her living room.
"I've never had a problem here," she said, shaking her head toward the turmoil from the drug dens of Troutman Street 15 blocks away that people associate with Bushwick at large. "This neighborhood is safe. Everything people hear about happens over there."
 
'Gem' of Low Scale And Low Density
 Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Housing Authority's chairwoman, calls Hope Gardens "a gem -- low scale, low density, that gives a sense of control and a feeling of private ownership."
Msgr. John Powis, the pastor at St. Barbara's, said: "I think if the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development is ever going to visit a housing project in New York City, this is the one he should see. It's the best public housing in the city." Such a project could almost certainly not be built today, however, because of huge cuts in Federal spending for such construction.
Life around Hope Gardens can still be a daunting experience, with crack and heroin dealing often half a block away and gunfire often punctuating the night. While crime in several categories is down from the dark years epitomized by the power blackout, the murder and robbery rates are up considerably in Bushwick.
In Hope Gardens itself, public housing seems to have performed against the conventional stereotypes. Its crime rate is half the citywide average for housing projects. Supermarkets, dry cleaners and hairdressers have returned to the once bombed-out streets around it. And largely because of Hope Gardens, with 3,586 residents, Bushwick's population has risen by nearly 12 percent in a decade, according to Census figures.
Dozens of two-family homes sponsored by the New York City Housing Partnership, the first built in the neighborhood in more than half a century, are rising around the project with the help of city and state subsidies, and every one is now owner-occupied.
 
Unlikeliest Heroes: The Bureaucrats
 "It's not to say we don't have dark clouds here," said Vincent L. Hall Jr., a postal worker who has lived in Bushwick for 31 years and watched the neighborhood burn from his private home at Evergreen and Greene Avenues, "but to me it seems as if the sun is finally starting to shine."
Public housing isn't the only factor in the area's comeback that seems to defy conventional wisdom. In this neighborhood more than almost anywhere else, those most maligned of individuals, city government bureaucrats, were the central catalyst for the change.
To this day, Bushwick residents fondly remember the names of many of them -- like David F. Feingold, Elliott Yablon and Jon T. Collins -- and say they managed to transcend racial and ethnic differences by putting in long hours and fighting for a vision of neighborhood renewal that came out of what they learned on the street. Mr. Collins is still the liaison to the neighborhood for the City Planning Commission.
"In most of the neighborhoods that have experienced dramatic comebacks, there is an unusually strong nonprofit organization, a charismatic local leader or unusual and attractive development opportunities," said Kathy Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership. "In this case, there was nothing to distinguish this neighborhood architecturally or otherwise. It's sort of the land the glacier forgot.
"The city organized the neighborhood and put it together and turned what had typically been a negative for neighborhood redevelopment -- a public housing project -- into a positive. It really re-created a neighborhood where one had been wiped out."
 
From Breweries To Blockbusters
 As a community, Bushwick dates back more than 350 years, but its modern character was shaped by German immigrants in the 19th century, who filled the wood-frame railroad flats that methodically lined its streets and who found work in its factories, knitting mills and breweries, like those that produced Rheingold, Piels and Schaefer beers.
But in the late 1960's, the neighborhood's cloistered stability began to give way to an urban free fall: factories and breweries closed by the scores and the real-estate operators known as blockbusters intimidated longtime white homeowners into selling for a pittance through intimidating, racist tactics.
But most ominous were the fires. In the 70's, the blazes -- many intentionally set, others accidental fires that raced through the attached wood-frame buildings -- struck at the rate of 500 a year.
When the city tried to save the heart of the neighborhood by replacing a full block of old frame buildings across Menahan Street from St. Barbara's -- a block that included 33 active businesses and 277 homes -- it resulted in perhaps the worst debacle of all. After wiping the block clean, the city found that for reasons varying from a moratorium on Federal housing construction to New York's near-bankruptcy in 1975, it could not build the replacement housing. Belatedly, it recognized that it had torn down the core of the neighborhood.
 
Drugs, White Flight And Unemployment
 By this time one of every 12 buildings was vacant. Attendance at Sunday Mass at St. Barbara's dropped from 1,500 to 600 in five years and the church was forced to close its school and exhaust its reserve fund. Drugs, huge unemployment and white flight swept through the neighborhood.
It was Bushwick and neighborhoods like it that Marshall Berman of City College, the social critic, was contemplating when he observed, "From ancient times to our own times, the experience of seeing one's city in ruins has been one of the traumatic primal scenes."
Mr. Yablon, the son of a trucker from East New York, was searching for some direction in his life when he went to work for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development nearly 30 years ago. Mr. Feingold had a master's degree in social work from Columbia and an interest in community organizing when he joined the agency.
The two became part of a much-heralded effort by Mayor John V. Lindsay in 1972 to establish neighborhood city halls in Bushwick and a handful of other communities around the city. Soon the pair, among a crew of other civil servants from police captains to sanitation crews, began prowling its streets, listening to complaints and trying to respond to them quickly.
Mr. Yablon, who is now an assistant commissioner in the department, and Mr. Feingold, who died of a heart attack suddenly at 47 two years ago, proved to be among the most popular of the workers. They turned up at community meetings at all hours and circled the neighborhood, slapping violations on landlords, ordering tree plantings by the thousands and simply listening to people.
 
'Like Part Of the Family'
 "They were not from the particular ethnic groups they were serving," recalled Chineda Carter, who was the head of Bushwick's community board through much of the 1970's. "But I never felt Elliott and Dave were outsiders. They were always there, like part of the family."
What they heard strongly was heated opposition to a plan for a project of five 14- and 15-story buildings on the cleared urban renewal site across Menahan Street from St. Barbara's.
Arlene Young, a community organizer who led the opposition, recalled: "We said, 'No, we will not have them that high.' We didn't want them to become an institutionalized thing where people feel like there is a fence around them. We wanted people to feel just as good as the people living in two- and three-family houses around here."
Mr. Yablon and Mr. Feingold argued her case before Housing Authority officials who had begun to question high-rise development themselves. As bureaucratic delays stalled the project time and again, Mr. Feingold sketched out possible alternatives.
"We sat out there for years," Mr. Yablon, 53, recalled recently. "Then after the blackout people came to us. We just whipped out all the plans. People were interested."
 
Taking a Stand Against High-Rises
 Instead of the five towers on the block across from St. Barbara's, there would be the single 14-story high-rise for the elderly and the three seven- story buildings, the Authority agreed. And, recalled Mr. Yablon, "they committed that in the future they would do no high-rise housing in Bushwick."
Ground was broken for the first 330 apartments in 1979. Eight thousand people applied to live in them. An effort was made to choose residents who had lived in Bushwick for many years and to have a preponderance of working families.
Keeping a campaign promise, Mayor Edward I. Koch pressed for money to build close to 900 other units. These are the low-rise "town houses" or "casitas" that define Hope Gardens. The entrances to the town houses open to 12 apartments at the most and as few as six, the lowest number in the city's 324 developments. No doubt in good part because tenants clearly have a sense of who doesn't belong in their buildings or backyards, there were no murders reported in Hope Gardens the first half of this year and there was but one last year.
 
Government Help Also Raises Fears
 The project cost more than $80 million. Its tenants pay an average of $202 a month in rent, and the Federal Government subsidizes its operation with about $4 million more a year.
Still, there are problems. Around the neighborhood, the very sort of government involvement that has been helpful is also seen as potentially ruinous. On the block of Harman Street between Wilson and Central Avenues, the Casuso family, which has lived in Bushwick for five generations, is fearful that a plan to build 42 apartments, mostly for homeless families, will tip the balance on a once-anarchic block.
Kathleen Casuso, the family matriarch, said that life there had improved because of the housing project, even though there was a shootout outside her door two weeks ago, but she said that the homeless housing plan had left her bitter and might cause the family to leave.
But on the streets around St. Barbara's Church these days, the complaints can seem surprisingly middle class. For Belgica Gonzalez, who works at La Primavera florist across Central Avenue from St. Barbara's, it is not stickup men that are her concern, but street peddlers selling flowers and men who occasionally play their car radios loudly on the corner.
For Geneva Curry, a hairdresser who bought a Partnership home around the corner from Hope Gardens with her husband, Michael, "It's a struggle trying to keep the block clean."
Just inside the Hope Gardens town house where Mamie Perryman lives on Palmetto Street, a sign reads: "Neighbors -- We have a nice clean building. Let's keep it that way. Put your cigarette butts in the garbage. Let's be neighborly. Thank you."

HEADLINE: Church Mirrors Neighborhood's Hope

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
When Bushwick came into its own a century ago as a brawny Brooklyn neighborhood of factories, breweries and blue-collar bustle, the construction of St. Barbara's Church served as a metaphor for its ascendance.
And when Bushwick was virtually consumed in the worst urban deterioration of the 70's, St. Barbara's once more stood as a metaphor, with its school closing, attendance at Mass falling by half, $800,000 in reserves exhausted, and, for the first time in its history, its doors locked at night to protect against theft and vandalism. 
 Today, the resurgence of the neighborhood around it is once more symbolized best by St. Barbara's, where scaffolding encases the church's landmark 175-foot high cream-colored spires.
Msgr. John Powis, who has worked in poor parishes around Brooklyn for more than three decades, said that aside from fixing structural problems in the church -- one of Brooklyn's most ornate and beautiful -- the restoration project was important because "people needed a sign of hope."
"This has been a great sign for them of their own power" he said.
The congregation, one of the poorest in Brooklyn, has raised more than $150,000 of the more than $600,000 that will be needed to complete the job. They are counting on regular monthly donations from 300 parishioners along with hope or faith to get them the rest of the way.
With the active encouragement of St. Barbara's, its parishioners have become involved in establishing a new public high school in the neighborhood, a day-care center and several other social service programs, and in pressuring the Housing Authority to provide more groundskeepers for Hope Gardens.
St. Barbara's is celebrating its centennial as a parish this year. Ground was broken for the church building in 1907 and construction was virtually completed in 1910.
Its elaborate exterior provides the often bleak streets of Bushwick with a Mediterranean, welcoming presence. In the words of the Guide to New York published by the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects, its towers are "wedding-cake icing: edible."
The interior is filled with statuary, carvings, frescoes, bas-reliefs and more than 25 stained glass renderings -- the product of an outpouring of German craftsmanship from the turn of the century which in varying ways told or evoked the story of the Scriptures.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
A First For Jones, A Best For Bogar

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14

 BODY:
The baseball cracked off the top of the wall in deepest left-center, and it was as if a starter's gun had gone off in Tim Bogar's head.
"Got in gear," said Bogar. 
 There is, of course, a lot for the Mets to run from in 1993 -- investigations of all sorts and defeats of all variety. And so Bogar, deprived of oxygen but not motivation, sprinted all-out around second as the baseball rolled around the outfield at Veterans Stadium. He looked at his third-base coach, saw a blur of an arm being waved, and Bogar never looked back.
To not look back, if even for a moment, it's an experience all the Mets would savor.
An instant later, Bogar's raucous ninth-inning route of 360 feet complete, the infielder for the Mets arrived at the plate in an exhausted heap. Safe, but perhaps not quite sound.
"The dive?" said Bogar. "On a scale of 1 to 10, it was a 3. A face plant."
However, it completed Bogar's one-man body slam of the Phillies. The inside-the-park home run was Bogar's second home run of the night, his first clearing the wall and thus not taxing him aerobically. It also was his fourth hit and fourth run produced. It left his total bases for the night at 12, one shy of the club record for a game.
It also made the Mets 9-5 victors over the Phillies and meant Bobby Jones, the 23-year-old right-hander, had won his major-league debut.
"I think I will go home and sleep quite well," said Bogar.
Jones might stare at the hotel ceiling for a while, replaying the details of what was a performance of great poise and purpose, if not scintillating statistics. Jones, the soft-thrower with cerebral strength, pitched six innings. He endured four errors by his defense and allowed only one earned run. He walked one, struck out three and faced the intimidating Phillies with an economy of energy and no fear.
"Good pitches have a good chance of getting good hitters out," Jones said simply.
"He held his composure, pitched us through," said Manager Dallas Green. "He gave us what he had."
What he had at the start was a major case of nerves.
"The first inning was the worst," said Jones.
Still, the damage was only a hard but harmless double by Mariano Duncan. Jones put his first zero on the scoreboard, and the night's momentum had been initiated.
Bogar, who had gone 10-for-70 since the All-Star break, doubled and scored against Danny Jackson in the third to put the Mets ahead, 2-0. Charlie O'Brien's subsequent two-run double in that inning then doubled the score.
In the fifth, Jones took the mound with a 5-1 lead and a nice two-hitter in the works. But Kim Batiste was safe starting the fifth when Bobby Bonilla butchered a grounder at third.
Jones didn't even wince, and after yielding a following single, the right-hander did his finest pitching. He froze Rickey Jordan with a fastball for strike three. He then reduced Lenny Dykstra to a contorted oarsman with a third-strike fastball that dove away from the National League's top leadoff man.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Giants Find Two Potential 20-Game Winners Better Than One

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Talk about cautious conservatism.
Dick Pole, the San Francisco Giants' pitching coach, supervises the two most successful pitchers in the National League, but he won't acknowledge, publicly at least, that they are on the verge of gaining a distinction rare in the National League in recent years. 
 John Burkett and Bill Swift can become only the second pair of teammates in nearly a quarter century to become 20-game winners. Burkett has an 18-4 record, Swift a 17-5 mark. No one else in the league has more than 13 victories.
But old spoilsport Pole said: "They haven't done it yet. I had an experience in 1988 with a kid who was 15-1 at the All-Star break, and he wound up 18-7 or something like that."
Greg Maddux actually had a 15-3 record at the All-Star break that season and finished 18-8, but Pole made his point. Nothing is guaranteed, especially with something as fragile as pitching arms. Short of suffering disabling injuries, though, Burkett and Swift seem certain to gain the victories they need for 20.
They would then be the first 20-game winning teammates in the National League since Joaquin Andujar and John Tudor of St. Louis in 1985 and only the second since 1969. The last time the Giants had two 20-game winners was in 1966, when Juan Marichal and Gaylord Perry reached that plateau.
"They complement each other," Pole said of his prized pupils. "We have a good defense. These guys throw strikes; they make guys put the ball in play. The defense knows the ball can be hit in their direction at any time. And with our offense, if they keep the game close, we can win at any time."
The Giants have won 38 of the 49 times Burkett and Swift have started. The Giants -- and the pitchers -- have compiled a 14-2 record since Swift last lost, to the Mets of all people, July 3. Swift has won seven times in seven starts since then. Burkett has won his last five starts.
"They make adjustments, they're open to suggestions, they follow signs, they're coachable, they're bright, they're what you want in pitchers," Pole said. "Both have a good feel for pitching. It's something you can bring out in a guy, but you can't pound into a guy. They have good arms, know how to change speeds and don't panic when they get into a predicament."
Swift found himself in a predicament last season. Strictly a relief pitcher the year before with Seattle, Swift became a starter -- indeed, he was the opening-day starter -- for the Giants. But the pitching load might have been too much too soon, and he developed problems in his right shoulder, twice going on the disabled list and finishing the season in relief.
He also finished the season with a league-low 2.08 earned run average.
Swift, the club decided, would start, but Manager Dusty Baker and Pole would closely watch the number of pitches he threw and innings he worked.
 
Swift Was Monitored
 "We wanted to monitor him early in the season, try to keep him below 100 pitches," Pole said. "He's very conservative with his pitches. He was getting through seven or eight innings with 90 pitches."
Swift hasn't pitched a complete game in his 24 starts.
"If you have opportunities to take him out of the game when he doesn't have to complete it, you take him out," Pole said. "We don't have many complete games, only three. These guys could each have five or six complete games, but we thought it was better to let someone else complete the game. We've got six guys in our bullpen, and it's a very capable bullpen."
Swift, 31 years old, is a complete game, or nine innings, away from matching his busiest season -- 174 2/3 innings.
Burkett, who in winning a total of 39 times the previous three seasons indicated he was blossoming into a top-flight pitcher, was buoyed by the Giants' signing of Barry Bonds during the offseason.
"When we acquired Bonds, he really started to bear down and accelerated his off-season program," Quinn said. "It was time to step it up a notch."
As potent as the Bonds-bombarding offense has been, Burkett and Swift have not won just because of the runs scored for them. Besides a career-high victory total, the 28-year-old Burkett has a 3.09 earned run average, nearly a full run below his career 3.92 mark. Swift is even more stingy at 2.61.
Before the season, no one mentioned the Giants' pitching staff in the same conversation that included the Atlanta Braves' contingent, but the Giants now are a close second to the Braves.
 
The Tiger Barrage
 In scoring 47 runs in three successive games against Baltimore last week, the Detroit Tigers surpassed their 45-run assault against Minnesota in April. Only one other American League team has scored as many as 30 runs in three consecutive games against the same team. The Yankees amassed 32 runs against Oakland last month. The National League high is 39, Philadelphia battering Colorado.
The Tigers have scored 10 or more runs 15 times, erupting for 20 twice in April four days apart. The most bizarre aspect of their scoring splurges: In the seven games in which they have scored 15 or more runs, Cecil Fielder, who is in position to lead the major leagues in runs batted in for an unprecedented fourth straight season, drove in only four runs of the 120 scored. He hit no home runs in those seven games. He drove in only one run in each of the three-game explosions against the Twins and the Orioles.
 
The Mysterious Rockies
 Someday maybe someone will be able to explain why these things happen. Colorado loses 13 games in a row, then reels off six consecutive victories. Sunk by a pitching staff that allows nearly six earned runs a game, the team gets such sizzling performances from their starters that they allow only 11 earned runs in 45 innings for a 2.20 e.r.a. In the six games, the Rockies give up 12 runs.
In each of the first five victories, the starter pitch at least seven innings.
"So I didn't have to go to the bullpen," Manager Don Baylor said. "Normally, our downfall is the starter gets knocked out in the second or third and I have to use everybody. I've told those guys if you give me seven, we'll win the game."
Baylor, who this season will be watched by more fans than any manager in baseball history, also tells his pitchers to speed up their work habits.
"When you take all day to pitch, the defense is on their heels," he said. "We went through a bad streak where they couldn't catch the ball. When you go to three balls on every hitter, everybody is sitting back. If you're decisive about what you want to do on the mound, it keeps everybody in the game. I told Kent Bottenfield if I'm going to watch 'Sports Center,' you better pick it up. It helped him the next game."
That game was a seven-hitter in one of the Rockies' four victories over the stunned Los Angeles Dodgers.
 
'93 Season, '94 Guarantee
 Pitchers sometimes have contracts in which the following season's salary becomes guaranteed if they reach a certain number of games or innings pitched. But Jeff Russell has a unique economic agreement with the Boston Red Sox under which his 1994 salary became guaranteed with his appearance against Toronto Friday night.
The option in the reliever's contract became vested when he earned enough bonuses to push this season's pay to his magic number of $1.7 million. Added so far to his base salary of $500,000 have been bonuses worth $400,000 for games pitched, $375,000 for games finished and $500,000 for number of days on the Red Sox roster. His pay stands at $1,775,000 and, without much difficulty but with good health, could go to $2,775,000.
His 1994 salary will be $2 million or whatever he earns this year.
 
Owners' Woes
 The second day of the owners' economic summit meeting in Kohler, Wis., began with owners of five wealthy clubs, including George Steinbrenner of the Yankees and Peter O'Malley of the Dodgers, walking through a side door of the building where the meeting was being held. A minute later, the owners walked sheepishly back through the door to the street. That entrance did not lead to the meeting room.
The day ended, about 15 hours later, with all of the owners escaping from Kohler under dark of night in half a dozen vans. The owners had not made their reservations at the American Club through Thursday night, and they had to go elsewhere to sleep or get their private planes.
Town residents, attracted by the television lights, stood on Highland Drive and Orchard Road watching the spectacle. The owners and their aides did not look happy.
Earlier in the day, Richard Ravitch, the engineer of the revenue-sharing effort, was talking with reporters. He looked tired as he began to tell a joke, then paused.
"I have to think about it before I start," he said. "I'd look foolish if I started it and couldn't finish it."
That also was the problem he was trying desperately to avoid with his revenue-sharing effort.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Stadium Drama: Parking vs. Charm

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
In the battle for the affections of George M. Steinbrenner 3d, New York City is trying to be a good landlord at Yankee Stadium, but city and state officials know New Jersey will woo the club with assurances that three million fans per season would attend a state-of-the-art ball park -- more than has ever filed through the team's Bronx turnstiles.
"They're courting him with charm," said Ellen Baer, the chief of staff for New York City's First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel. "We're courting him with parking spaces." 
 Robert Mulcahy, the president of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority told the MSG Network last week: "We're trying to put forth what we have to offer in New Jersey, and we think that's a lot. There's no question in my mind that this would be a three million attendance deal."
The current spasm of news and speculation since June about which option Steinbrenner will choose -- stay in the Bronx, go south to Manhattan's West Side Long Island Rail Road storage yards, or decamp for one of several New Jersey sites -- will probably be the overture to the real ball park opera a few years from now as the expiration of the Yankee Stadium lease in 2002 draws nigh.
"Everyone will forget in three years the things being said now and this will happen again," said Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer.
Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, has been relatively silent on the issue, uncharacteristically for him. His spokesman, Howard Rubenstein, said the owner had made no decision and, for now, only wants the city to live up to the current 30-year Yankee Stadium lease by providing, among other things, the promised 6,900 parking spots.
To that end, staff members of the Yankees and Barry Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for economic development, spent four hours one recent day counting parking spots, space-by-space, in the garages and lots that surround the stadium. It is one of several similar counts that differ slightly depending on whether it is a game day or not. The most recent tally came up a little short, said Rubenstein.
Baer said the actual count is irrelevant. "You know, 6,900 spots is not enough," she said. "They're entitled to 6,900 and it's not enough."
Steinbrenner has squawked about being short several hundred spots in the past, but utilization of the spaces has only recently become an issue with the Yankees' renaissance in the American League East standing. "Before this year, nobody cared," said Betsy Gotbaum, the city's Parks Commissioner. "Nobody was in those spots anyway."
 
Tending to Short-Term Demands
 The city is tending to the short-term because Steinbrenner won't discuss the long-term until he trusts his immediate concerns are addressed. Steinbrenner is testing the city's fidelity to the lease, much as he proclaimed a recent homestand "test week," to gauge fans' desire to visit Yankee Stadium. "Steinbrenner wants his contract fulfilled permanently," Rubenstein said.
In its emerging role as a good landlord, the city arranged temporary parking on the ball field at Macombs Dam Park during the recent Blue Jays series, which drew 192,000 fans, shifted long-term parking tenants out of spaces designated for fans and into a supermarket lot, tried to improve traffic flow off the Major Deegan Expressway, cleaned up the garbage-strewn Deegan and increased police patrols of the parking areas.
 
Traffic Snarls From the Air
 No time frame has been set on Steinbrenner's test of the city's faith. But, as if to show the city can still do more, Steinbrenner hired a helicopter during the recent series against the Blue Jays to demonstrate the game-time traffic snarl along the Deegan. Passengers along for the aerial view included a camera crew from WABC-TV and a photographer from The New York Post.
"It took two to three hours to get to the ballpark," said Rubenstein.
Ferrer thinks all the talk about parking, crime and traffic obscures Steinbrenner's true agenda. Ferrer has been a frequent critic of Steinbrenner, but he has been no fan of the city either, suing the city earlier this month to force it to repair rutted Bronx roadways.
"If you negotiate, rise above the nonsense and get to the point," Ferrer said, "the ultimate issue here is dollars. "
Ferrer incurred the wrath of Yankees officials recently when, after attending a Yankees-Blue Jays game, he said the team had "fudged" figures downward when announcing attendance of 48,000. "I was there," he said. "Nobody can tell me there were 9,000 empty seats. I don't make dangerous charges." The Stadium seating capacity is 57,545.
Although Rubenstein said, "Steinbrenner was miffed by Ferrer's eyeball count and said, 'We'd never do anything like that,' " Steinbrenner has nontheless hired the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand to audit the figures.
 
Pitching Not Parking
 Ferrer said there is a practical cure for substandard attendance.
"It's not parking," he said. "It's pitching."
An ongoing audit by the City Controller's office continues to slow a possible settlement of financial issues between the city and the Yankees. The city is poring over invoices submitted by the Yankees for maintenance it paid in 1990, 1991 and 1992, which total $8.7 million. During that time, the Yankees have withheld payment of their stadium rent, computed at $6.1 million.
The Yankees have subsequently withheld electricity and parking payments since 1991 because of the city's laxness in repaying the maintenance money, which is long overdue. "They're not doing anything illegal," said Joanne Imohiosen, assistant commissioner of revenue for the Parks Department. "There's no doubt that we owe them money."
The city wants to wrap this issue into a settlement of the controller's 1991 audit that said the Yankees owed the city $709,483 in 1989 cable TV payments, and $220,000 more from luxury box income. The Yankees argue the figure should be $103,318. "This doesn't relate to a new lease," Imohoisen said.
 
Politics Keeps Noise Down

But in a larger sense, everything is being done to sign Steinbrenner to a future lease, wherever that might be. Outright contentiousness with the city has been submerged during the mayoral election year, as Sullivan, a publicity-shy former banker, has become Mayor David N. Dinkins's quiet agent to the Yankees.
Quiet, too, is talk about the West Side rail yard option for the Yankees. Community Board 4, which has jurisdiction in the area, has urged New York Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to abandon the idea. Cuomo had raised the possibility in early July of shifting the Yankees to a $500 million ball park as a counter to what New Jersey would offer and if the state and city cannot satisfy Steinbrenner in the Bronx. "There have been no recent talks," said Rubenstein.
More vocal recently have been New Jersey officials. The authority's Mulcahy says he won't negotiate in the press, and that he has made no offers to Steinbrenner. Mulcahy and Jon Hanson, an authority board member, are known to be friends of the Yankees owner, who races horses at the Meadowlands Racetrack.
 
New Jersey Raises Voice

New Jersey Gov. Jim Florio said last week: "No one's going to be talking seriously about specifics until there is an understanding that someone is serious about coming here." His press secretary, John Shure, added, "There have been talks involving the state and the Yankees."
A report last week in The Record of Hackensack said the authority was preparing a $250 million stadium plan for October presentation to Steinbrenner. John Samerjan, a spokesman for the authority, said, "I won't get into that."
Meanwhile, Neil Brown, a spokesman for the Public Service Electric & Gas Company, said the authority recently asked about the availability of a 155-acre tract the utility owns west of the Hudson Generating Station in Jersey City.
"We said we would work with them if it came to pass," he said.
Bob Hughey, Gov. Florio's outgoing chief of economic recovery, said the state has looked at "three to five sites," including one in the Meadowlands area, where Giants Stadium, Brendan Byrne Arena and the Meadowlands Racetrack are located. If Steinbrenner does not re-enlist in the Bronx, Hughey said: "We'd put our concept into play. If it's not the Bronx, then we make as much sense as the Manhattan Yankees."
As for any October deadline for presenting a plan to Steinbrenner, Hughey said: "I don't think the situation is moving that quickly."

HEADLINE: What's Wrong With Buying Black

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I don't know how blacks will react to the suggestion that they "buy black," even to the point of seeking out black physicians. But I know how I would reply if anyone told me to "buy female." I intend to keep spending my hard-earned money where I can get the best product or service for the best price, regardless of the race or sex of the provider. And I can't help wondering whether if the author were facing surgery, he would look for anything other than the best surgeon he could find (who, of course, might or might not be black).
 
FELICIA ACKERMAN
Providence, R.I., Aug. 1

HEADLINE: Air Fares: Poor Case, Good Verdict

 BODY:
Predatory pricing. That's what Continental and Northwest accused American Airlines of doing last summer when it cut air fares. American, it was alleged, set prices below costs in an attempt to drive competitors out of business; then, having monopolized the market, American planned to raise prices to, well, sky-high levels.
The accusation was feeble. And the jury needed only a couple of hours to say so. The jurors figured out that American wasn't stupid enough, first, to intentionally rack up huge losses to eliminate current rivals and then lose much more to keep future rivals from competing after it tried to recoup its losses by raising its fares. 
 Poor case. Sound verdict. But what's noteworthy, and disturbing, is that American had to spend $20 million defending itself; Continental and Northwest also spent millions. There's something seriously awry when financially ailing companies throw away millions battling over dubious charges.
To put the charges brought against American in perspective, guess how many examples of such predatory pricing economists have documented over the past 30 or 40 years? Thousands? Hundreds? The answer, according to Prof. Frederic Scherer of Harvard, is, perhaps, two. There might have been a case in the rocket fuel industry. And there probably was a failed attempt in the computer equipment industry. American Airlines, in other words, spent $20 million defending itself against charges involving a virtually nonexistent practice.
What American tried to do last summer was to put an end to the industry's irrational, and bankrupting, fare structure. Travelers were being offered a blizzard of discounts that made comparative shopping nearly impossible. American proposed cutting unrestricted fares, but also eliminating almost all of the discounts. It hoped its competition would go along with the simplified fare structure; the competitors didn't.
Searching for explanations for the suit is frustrating. The antitrust laws aren't the problem, because the Supreme Court has set down strict conditions for convicting a firm of predation. Somehow Continental and Northwest didn't seem to notice. The bankruptcy laws might have given a financially weak carrier like Continental a go-for-broke attitude: spending money it didn't have in a desperate leap for a billion-dollar jackpot. All it needed was this: Its high-priced lawyers had to sell a fantasy to lay jurors.
The proceedings in Galveston, Tex., weren't just wasteful; they were chilling. Suppose the verdict had gone the other way. Then U.S. carriers would have been told: Don't compete, don't cut prices because competition has now been declared illegal. That would have turned a wasteful exercise into an economic fiasco.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: When Banks Make Currency Go Up and Down;
No Boon to U.S.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Money Woes in Europe May Aid U.S." (Business Day, Aug. 5): Some North American economists interpret the European currency crisis as having a positive effect for the United States. They argue that other European states have finally followed Britain's decision of 1992 and distanced themselves from the problems of a dominant, ailing Germany. 
 Now, so the thinking goes, these countries can lower their interest rates to stimulate their economies. It will only be a matter of time until they will regain their old economic strength. Then they can help their neighbors and trading partners left behind (including the United States).
This interpretation is only partly true. It is important first to understand that the driving force behind currency realignment was the desire of European countries to lower their interest rates independent of Germany. Lower interest rates mean a de facto currency devaluation against the mark and the dollar.
Weaker European currencies hurt American exports because potential European purchasers of American-made products will have to pay more than before devaluation. As a result, they will tend to purchase a cheaper domestic product, as opposed to more expensive imported goods. Sales of American cars in Europe serve as an example. Since America runs a trade surplus with Europe, any advantages for cheaper purchases of American products overseas are negligible. It will certainly not help the United States out of the recession.
I believe large currency fluctuations are not a good idea. Despite all modern hedging techniques, most midsize enterprises see strong fluctuation as an undesirable risk. It makes trading with overseas partners very unpredictable. As a consequence, most of these companies will concentrate on the domestic market and ignore opportunities in foreign markets. Ultimately, this behavior leads to fewer investments and, slowly, to decreased competitiveness by those corporations in world markets.
In addition, currency fluctuations are further being fueled by speculators in it for the quick buck. Think, for example, of George Soros, the successful and respected fund manager who reportedly made about $1 billion betting on the British pound in 1992. This money, of course, will be taken out of the economy affected.
Last, but not least, today's realignment of prices will not be the last. Others are likely to follow. Again, the result will be more instability in Europe. Overall, it will result in a less predictable relationship between Europe and its American trading partner. And this is not in North America's interest.
 
PETER SCHOLLA
Senior Vice President
Credit Suisse Asset Management
Miami, Aug. 6, 1993
